It Its probable origin. appears that an arraignment of the aged Sophocles, by his son Iophon, before a court of his clansmen (phratores), had furnished a scene to a contemporary comedyThe passage which shows this is in the anonymous Î’á½·Î¿Ï‚; â€” Ï†á½³ÏÎµÏ„Î±Î¹ Î´á½² ÎºÎ±á½¶ Ï€Î±Ïá½° Ï€Î¿Î»Î»Î¿á¿–Ï‚ á¼¡ Ï€Ïá½¸Ï‚ Ï„á½¸Î½ Ï…á¼±á½¸Î½ á¼¸Î¿Ï†á¿¶Î½Ï„Î± Î³ÎµÎ½Î¿Î¼á½³Î½Î· Î±á½Ï„á¿· Î´á½·ÎºÎ· Ï€Î¿Ï„á½³. á¼”Ï‡Ï‰Î½ Î³á½°Ï á¼Îº Î¼á½²Î½ ÎÎ¹ÎºÎ¿ÏƒÏ„Ïá½±Ï„Î·Ï‚ á¼¸Î¿Ï†á¿¶Î½Ï„Î±, á¼Îº Î´á½² Î˜Îµá½½ÏÎ¹Î´Î¿Ï‚ Î£Î¹ÎºÏ…Ï‰Î½á½·Î±Ï‚ á¼ˆÏá½·ÏƒÏ„Ï‰Î½Î±, Ï„á½¸Î½ á¼Îº Ï„Î¿á½»Ï„Î¿Ï… Î³ÎµÎ½á½¹Î¼ÎµÎ½Î¿Î½ Ï€Î±á¿–Î´Î± Î£Î¿Ï†Î¿ÎºÎ»á½³Î± Ï€Î»á½³Î¿Î½ á¼”ÏƒÏ„ÎµÏÎ³ÎµÎ½. ÎºÎ±á½· Ï€Î¿Ï„Îµ á¼Î½ Î´Ïá½±Î¼Î±Ï„Î¹ Îµá¼°Ïƒá½µÎ³Î±Î³Îµ Ï„á½¸Î½ á¼¸Î¿Ï†á¿¶Î½Ï„Î± Î±á½Ï„á¿· Ï†Î¸Î¿Î½Î¿á¿¦Î½Ï„Î± ÎºÎ±á½¶ Ï€Ïá½¸Ï‚ Ï„Î¿á½ºÏ‚ Ï†Ïá½±Ï„Î¿ÏÎ±Ï‚ á¼Î³ÎºÎ±Î»Î¿á¿¦Î½Ï„Î± Ï„á¿· Ï€Î±Ï„Ïá½¶ á½¡Ï‚ á½‘Ï€á½¸ Î³á½µÏÏ‰Ï‚ Ï€Î±ÏÎ±Ï†ÏÎ¿Î½Î¿á¿¦Î½Ï„Î¹Â· Î¿á¼± Î´á½² Ï„á¿· á¼¸Î¿Ï†á¿¶Î½Ï„Î¹ á¼Ï€ÎµÏ„á½·Î¼Î·ÏƒÎ±Î½. Î£á½±Ï„Ï…ÏÎ¿Ï‚ Î´á½³ Ï†Î·ÏƒÎ¹Î½ Î±á½Ï„á½¸Î½ Îµá¼°Ï€Îµá¿–Î½Â· Îµá¼° Î¼á½³Î½ Îµá¼°Î¼Î¹ Î£Î¿Ï†Î¿ÎºÎ»á¿†Ï‚, Î¿á½ Ï€Î±ÏÎ±Ï†ÏÎ¿Î½á¿¶Â· Îµá¼° Î´á½² Ï€Î±ÏÎ±Ï†ÏÎ¿Î½á¿¶, Î¿á½Îº Îµá¼°Î¼á½¶ Î£Î¿Ï†Î¿ÎºÎ»á¿†Ï‚Â· ÎºÎ±á½¶ Ï„á½¹Ï„Îµ Ï„á½¸Î½ ÎŸá¼°Î´á½·Ï€Î¿Î´Î± á¼€Î½Î±Î³Î½á¿¶Î½Î±Î¹. In the sentence, ÎºÎ±á½· Ï€Î¿Ï„Îµ...Îµá¼°Ïƒá½µÎ³Î±Î³Îµ, the name of a comic poet, who was the subject to Îµá¼°Ïƒá½µÎ³Î±Î³Îµ, has evidently been lost. Some would supply Î›Îµá½»ÎºÏ‰Î½, one of whose plays was entitled *fra/tores. Hermann conjectured, ÎºÎ±á½· Ï€Î¿Ï„Îµ á¼ˆÏÎ¹ÏƒÏ„Î¿Ï†á½±Î½Î·Ï‚ á¼Î½ Î”Ïá½±Î¼Î±ÏƒÎ¹Î½,â€”Aristophanes having written a play called *dra/mata, or rather two, unless the *dra/mata h)\ *ke/ntauros and *dra/mata h)\ *ni/obos were only different editions of the same. Whoever the comic poet was, his purpose towards Sophocles was benevolent, as the phratores censured Iophon. This tone, at least, is quite consistent with the conjecture that the poet was Aristophanes (cp. Ran. 79). Just after the death of Sophocles, Phrynichus wrote of him as one whose happiness had been unclouded to the very endâ€”ÎºÎ±Î»á¿¶Ï‚ Î´â€™ á¼Ï„ÎµÎ»Îµá½»Ï„Î·Ï‚), Î¿á½Î´á½²Î½ á½‘Ï€Î¿Î¼Îµá½·Î½Î±Ï‚ ÎºÎ±Îºá½¹Î½. There is some force in Schneidewin's remark that this would be strange if the poet's last days had been troubled by such a scandal as the supposed trial.; and it is highly probable that the comic poet's inventionâ€”founded possibly on gossip about differences between Sophocles and his sons â€”was the origin of the story. This inference is slightly confirmed by the words which, according to one account, Sophocles used in the law-court: Îµá¼° Î¼á½³Î½ Îµá¼°Î¼Î¹ Î£Î¿Ï†Î¿ÎºÎ»á¿†Ï‚, Î¿á½ Ï€Î±ÏÎ±Ï†ÏÎ¿Î½á¿¶Â· Îµá¼° Î´á½² Ï€Î±ÏÎ±Ï†ÏÎ¿Î½á¿¶, Î¿á½Îº Îµá¼°Î¼á½¶ Î£Î¿Ï†Î¿ÎºÎ»á¿†Ï‚. That has the ring of the Old ComedyI need scarcely point out how easily the words could be made into a pair of comic trimeters, e.g. Îµá¼° Î¼á½²Î½ Î£Î¿Ï†Î¿ÎºÎ»á½³Î·Ï‚ Îµá¼°Î¼á½·, Ï€Î±ÏÎ±Ï†ÏÎ¿Î½Î¿á¿–Î¼â€™ á¼‚Î½ Î¿á½”Â· Îµá¼° Î´â€™ Î±á½– Ï€Î±ÏÎ±Ï†ÏÎ¿Î½á¿¶, Î£Î¿Ï†Î¿ÎºÎ»á½³Î·Ï‚ Î¿á½Îº Îµá¼´Î¼â€™ á¼Î³á½½. This would fit into a burlesque forensic speech, in the style of the new rhetoric, which the comedy may have put into the mouth of Sophocles. As though, in a modern comedy, the pedagogue should say,â€”"If I am Doctor X., I am not fallible; if I am fallible, I am not Doctor X.". The words are quoted in the anonymous Life of Sophocles as being recorded by Satyrus, a Peripatetic who lived about 200 B.C., and left a collection of biographies. His work appears to have been of a superficial character, and uncriticalThe literary vestiges of this Satyrus will be found in MÃ¼ller, Fragm. Hist. III. 159 ff.. The incident of the trial, as he found it in a comedy of the time of Sophocles, would doubtless have found easy acceptance at his hands. From Satyrus, directly or indirectly, the story was probably derived by Cicero and later writers.

Î¿á½— Îºá¿¶Î»Î± Îºá½±Î¼ÏˆÎ¿Î½ Ï„Î¿á¿¦Î´â€™ á¼Ï€â€™ á¼€Î¾á½³ÏƒÏ„Î¿Ï… Ï€á½³Ï„ÏÎ¿Ï…Â· ğŸ—©
Line 19

Internal evidence â€”supposed political bearings.

It must now be asked how far the internal evidence of the play supports the belief that it belongs to the poet's latest years. Lachmann, maintaining the singular view that the Oedipus Coloneus was "political through and through" ("durch und durch politisch"), held that it was composed just before the beginning of the Peloponnesian war, with the purpose of kindling Athenian patriotism. Another conjecture is that the play was prepared for the Great Dionysia of 411 B.C., just after the Government of Four Hundred had been established by the assembly held at Colonus; that Colonus Hippius may have been "in some special sense the Knights' Quarter"; that hence the play would commend itself to a class of men among whom the new oligarchy had found most of its adherents; and that, after the fall of the Four Hundred, political considerations prevented a reproduction of the play, until, after the poet's death, it was revived in 402 B.C.Prof. L. Campbell, Sophocles, vol. I. 276 ff. This is an ingenious view, but not (to my apprehension) a probable one. That the play would have been especially popular with the Athenian Knights need not be doubted; but it is another thing to suppose that the composition of the play had regard to their political sympathies in 411 B.C. In a time of public excitement any drama bearing on the past of one's country is pretty sure to furnish some words that will seem fraught with a present meaning. We may grant that such a meaning would sometimes, perhaps, have been found by an Athenian spectator of this play, and also that the poet's mind, when he wrote it, was not insensible to the influence of contemporary events. But it seems not the less true to affirm that, from the first verse to the last, in great things and in small, the play is purely a work of ideal art.

20 Î¼Î±ÎºÏá½°Î½ Î³á½°Ï á½¡Ï‚ Î³á½³ÏÎ¿Î½Ï„Î¹ Ï€ÏÎ¿á½ÏƒÏ„á½±Î»Î·Ï‚ á½Î´á½¹Î½. ğŸ—©
Line 20

Character of the composition.

Another species of internal evidence has been sought in the character of the dramatic composition. It has been held that the Oedipus Coloneus shares certain traits with the Philoctetes, the other play which tradition assigns to the latest years of Sophocles. One such trait is the larger scope given to scenic effects which appeal to the eye and the ear,â€”such as the pitiable garb of Oedipus, the personal violence of Creon, the scenery of Colonus, the thunder-storm. Another is the change from a severer type of tragedy, which concentrates the interest on a single issueâ€”as in the Tyrannusâ€”to a type which admits the relief of secondary interests,â€”such as the cult at Colonus, the rescue of the maidens, the glory of Athens, the fortunes of Thebes. A third trait of similar significance has been recognised in the contemplative tendency of the play, which leaves the spectator at leisure to meditate on questions other than those which are solved by a stroke of dramatic action,â€”such as the religious and the moral aspects of the hero's acts, or the probable effect of his pleas on the Athenian mindSee Campbell, I. 259 ff.. Akin to this tendency is the choice of subjects like those of the Coloneus and the Philoctetes, which end with a reconciliation, not with a disaster. And here there is an analogy with some of the latest of Shakspeare's plays,â€”the Winter's Tale, Tempest, and Cymbeline, â€”which end, as Prof. Dowden says, with "a resolution of the dissonance, a reconciliation."Shakspereâ€”His Mind and Art, p. 406.

It may at once be conceded that the traits above mentioned are present in the Coloneus, and that they are among those which distinguish it from the Tyrannus. The Coloneus is indeed more picturesque, more tolerant of a distributed interest, more meditative; and its end is peace. But it is less easy to decide how far these traits are due to the subject itself, and how far they can safely be regarded as distinctive of the poet's latest period. Let us suppose for a moment that external evidence had assigned the Coloneus to the earlier years of Sophocles. It would not then, perhaps, seem less reasonable to suggest that these same traits are characteristic of youth. Here, it might be said, we find the openness of a youthful imagination to impressions of the senses; its preference of variety to intensity, in the absence of that matured and virile sternness of dramatic purpose which can concentrate the thoughts on a single issue; its affinity to such themes as temper the darker view of human destiny with some gladness and some hope. In saying this, I do not mean to suggest that the latter view of the traits in question is actually more correct than the former, but merely to illustrate the facility with which considerations of this nature can be turned to the support of opposite hypotheses.

Rhetoric.Another feature of the play which has been supposed to indicate the close of the fifth century B.C. is the prominence of the rhetorical element in certain places, especially in the scenes with Creon and Polyneices. We should recollect, however, that the Ajax is generally allowed to be one of the earlier plays, and that the scenes there between Teucer and the Atreidae show the taste for rhetorical discussion quite as strongly as any part of the Coloneus. Rhetoric should be distinguished from rhetorical dialectic. Subtleties of the kind which appear in some plays of Euripides are really marks of date, as showing new tendencies of thought. But the natural rhetoric of debate, such as we find it in the Ajax and the Coloneus, was as congenial to Greeks in the days of Homer as in the days of Protagoras.

ÎŸá¼°. Îºá½±Î¸Î¹Î¶á½³ Î½á½»Î½ Î¼Îµ ÎºÎ±á½¶ Ï†á½»Î»Î±ÏƒÏƒÎµ Ï„á½¸Î½ Ï„Ï…Ï†Î»á½¹Î½. ğŸ—©
Line 21

Conclusion.

Our conclusion may be as follows. There is no reason to question the external evidence which refers the Oedipus Coloneus to the latest years of Sophocles. But no corroboration of it can be derived from the internal evidence, except in one general aspect and one detail,â€”viz. the choice of an Attic subject, and the employment of a fourth actor. The Attic plays of Euripides, mentioned above, belong to the latter part of the Peloponnesian war, which naturally tended to a concentration of home sympathies. An Attic theme was the most interesting that a dramatist could choose; and he was doing a good work, if, by recalling the past glories of Athens, he could inspire new courage in her sons. If Attica was to furnish a subject, the author of the Oedipus Tyrannus had no need to look beyond his native Colonus; and it is conceivable that this general influence of the time should have decided the choice. In three scenes of the play, four actors are on the stage together. This innovation may be allowed as indicating the latest period of SophoclesA discussion of this point will be found below, in the note on the Dramatis Personae, p. 7..

á¼Î¾Î¿Î¹Îºá½µÏƒÎ¹Î¼Î¿Ï‚, capable of being made into a dwelling-place, "habitable," here implying "inhabited." Adjectives with the suffix ÏƒÎ¹Î¼Î¿ properly denote adaptability. They were primarily formed from substantives in â€ÏƒÎ¹â€Ï‚, as Ï‡Ïá½µÏƒÎ¹â€Î¼Î¿â€Ï‚, fitted for use, from Ï‡Ïá¿†ÏƒÎ¹Ï‚. The noun á¼Î¾Î¿á½·ÎºÎ·ÏƒÎ¹Ï‚ is found only in the sense of "emigration," Plat. Legg. 704C, 850 B. But as from á¼±Ï€Ï€á½±Î¶Î¿Î¼Î±Î¹ was formed á¼±Ï€Ï€á½±â€ÏƒÎ¹Î¼Î¿Ï‚, though no á¼µÏ€Ï€Î±ÏƒÎ¹Ï‚ occurs, so á¼Î¾Î¿Î¹Îºá½µÏƒÎ¹Î¼Î¿Ï‚ here is taken directly from á¼Î¾Î¿Î¹ÎºÎµá¿–Î½ as="to make into a dwellingplace" (Thuc. 2.17 á¼Î¾á¿³Îºá½µÎ¸Î·). Î¿á¼°Îºá½µÏƒÎ¹Î¼Î¿Ï‚ as="habitable" occurs in later Greek. Just as á¼Î¾Î¿Î¹Îºá½µÏƒÎ¹Î¼Î¿Ï‚ is practically equivalent to Î¿á¼°ÎºÎ·Ï„á½¹Ï‚ here, so Silius speaks of the Capitoline as "superis habitabile saxum," alluding to the actual shrines on it (1. 541). Cp. á¼Î»á½½ÏƒÎ¹Î¼Î¿Ï‚ Î²á½±Î¾Î¹Ï‚ (Aesch. Ag. 10), tidings of an actual, not merely possible, capture. This poet. use is the converse of that by which á¼„ÏÏÎ·Ï„Î¿Ï‚ could mean "unspeakable," or invictus, "unconquerable."

ÎŸá¼°. 30 á¼¦ Î´Îµá¿¦ÏÎ¿ Ï€ÏÎ¿ÏƒÏƒÏ„Îµá½·Ï‡Î¿Î½Ï„Î± Îºá¼€Î¾Î¿ÏÎ¼á½½Î¼ÎµÎ½Î¿Î½; ğŸ—©
Line 30

Impatient for more light, Oed. asks, "Is he coming forth towards us,â€” so that it is really needless for thee to move?" Î´Îµá¿¦ÏÎ¿ denotes the goal, Ï€ÏÎ¿Ï‚â€ the direction, and á¼Î¾â€ the starting-point. Î´Îµá¿¦ÏÎ¿ goes with both participles, which form a single expression,="coming towards us from the abodes" implied by Î¿á¼°ÎºÎ·Ï„á½¹Ï‚ (28). Cp. Ai. 762 á¼€Ï€â€™ Î¿á¼´ÎºÏ‰Î½... á¼Î¾Î¿ÏÎ¼á½½Î¼ÎµÎ½Î¿Ï‚. Other explanations are:â€” (1) "approaching" (Î´Îµá¿¦ÏÎ¿ being taken with Ï€ÏÎ¿ÏƒÏƒÏ„. only) "and setting out," as a "prothysteron" for "setting out and approaching." This is impossible. (2) "Moving, and hastening, hither": but this obliterates á¼Î¾â€, and strains á½ÏÎ¼á½½Î¼ÎµÎ½Î¿Î½.

Ï„á½·Î½Ï‰Î½ â€¦ ÎºÎ»á½»Ï‰Î½; of whom hearing the august name might I make a prayer? i.e. "who may they be, whose name I am to hear, and to invoke?" Î¼á½²Î½ seems right. á½¡Ï‚ is clearly right. The á½¥ÏƒÏ„) of the MSS. would mean, "and so" (i.e. since they are the Eumenides). Line 46

Ï„á½· Î´â€™ á¼ÏƒÏ„á½¶ Ï„Î¿á¿¦Ï„Î¿; "What means this?" (cp. Ï„á½· Î´â€™ á¼”ÏƒÏ„Î¹; "what now?" O. T. 319 n.). "What has this sudden resolve to do with the mention of the Eumenides?"

Î¾Ï…Î¼Ï†Î¿Ïá¾¶Ï‚ Î¾á½»Î½Î¸Î·Î¼â€™ á¼Î¼á¿†Ï‚. Ïƒá½»Î½Î¸Î·Î¼Î±=something agreed upon (ÏƒÏ…Î½Ï„á½·Î¸ÎµÎ¼Î±Î¹), as e.g. a military watchword (Her. 9.98). Apollo had told Oedipus that, when he reached a shrine of the Î£ÎµÎ¼Î½Î±á½·, then he should find rest (90). This was the Ïƒá½»Î½Î¸Î·Î¼Î±, the sign preconcerted between them, which Oedipus has now recognised at Colonus (cp. á¼”Î³Î½Ï‰ÎºÎ±, 96). He calls his own prayer (44 f.) the Ïƒá½»Î½Î¸Î·Î¼Î± of his fate, because it embodies the two points of the Ïƒá½»Î½Î¸Î·Î¼Î±, â€” "Here are the Eumenides, â€” here I stay." Campbell renders, "the word that sums my destiny," and seems to regard the notion of "sign" as blended with that of "summary." But the two notions are distinct. Ïƒá½»Î½Î¸Î·Î¼Î± is always parallel in sense with ÏƒÏ…Î½Ï„á½·Î¸ÎµÎ¼Î±Î¹ as="to concert" (Î²Î¿Ï…Î»á½µÎ½, etc.), never with ÏƒÏ…Î½Ï„á½·Î¸Î·Î¼Î¹ as="to put briefly together."

á¼Î¼Î¿á½· is indispensable, while Î¿á½Î´á½² Î¼á½³Î½Ï„Î¿Î¹ would be weak.

Î´á½·Ï‡), like á¼„Î½ÎµÏ… or Ï‡Ï‰Ïá½·Ï‚, "without the sanction of": Ai. 768 ÎºÎ±á½¶ Î´á½·Ï‡Î± ÎºÎµá½·Î½Ï‰Î½, "e'en without the gods' help." Îºá¼€Î³á½½. We say: â€” "What I know, you also shall know" (á½…Ïƒâ€™ Î¿á¼¶Î´â€™ á¼Î³á½½, ÎºÎ±á½¶ Ïƒá½º á¼Ï€Î¹ÏƒÏ„á½µÏƒÎµÎ¹). This altar of Poseidon (á¼Ï€Î¹ÏƒÏ„á½±Ï„Î·Ï‚ ÎšÎ¿Î»Ï‰Î½Î¿á¿¦ 889) lies beyond the stage-scene (888).

á¼Î½ Î´â€™ (adv.), sc. á¼ÏƒÏ„á½·Î½: Prometheus did not belong to Colonus itself (as Poseidon did), but to the neighbouring Academy (see on 56): he is named as one of several divine presences in the vicinity. So á¼Î½ Î´â€™ adds a new member to a group, O. T. 27 (where the same words á¼Î½ Î´â€™ á½ Ï€. Î¸Îµá½¹Ï‚ refer to the plague), Ai. 675. If, instead of á¼Î½ Î´â€™ we read á¼ Î´â€™ (which Soph. sometimes used in dialogue, fr. 345 and 493), this would rather link the two deities as holding Colonus.

Line 56

Î ÏÎ¿Î¼Î·Î¸Îµá½»Ï‚ is a "Titan" as son of the Titan Iapetus (Hes. Theog. 510). Welcker (Griech. GÃ¶tterl. 2. 254) thinks that "Titan," instead of "Titanid," is used here only because, like the Titans, Prometheus rebelled against Zeus: but this seems strained. Cp. Cic. Tusc. 2. 10.23 (from the *prom. *luo/menos of Aesch., Prometheus speaking) Titanum suboles, socia nostri sanguinis, Generata caelo. Line 57

á½€Î´á½¹Ï‚. Somewhere near the grove of the Eumenides, but not within the stagescene, was a spot called "the threshold" of Hades,â€”a steeply-descending rift or cavern in the rock, at the mouth of which some brazen steps had been made (see on 1590 f.),â€”in accordance with the epic notion that Hades had a Ï‡á½±Î»ÎºÎµÎ¿Ï‚ Î¿á½Î´á½¹Ï‚ (Il. 8.15). From this spot, the immediately adjacent region (including the grove) was known as "the brazen threshold," â€” Ï‡Î±Î»Îºá½¹Ï€Î¿Ï…Ï‚, borrowed from the literal Ï‡Î±Î»Îºá¾¶ Î²á½±Î¸ÏÎ± (1591), taking the general sense of "adamantine." As "rooted on the nether rock" (Î³á¿†Î¸ÎµÎ½ á¼ÏÏÎ¹Î¶Ï‰Î¼á½³Î½Î¿Î½ 1591), and also as linked by mystic sanctities with the Powers of the Under-world, this region of the "brazen threshold" is called á¼”ÏÎµÎ¹ÏƒÎ¼â€™ á¼ˆÎ¸Î·Î½á¿¶Î½, the stay of Athens: a phrase in which the idea of physical basis is joined to that of religious safeguard.

Ï‡Î±Î»Îºá½¹Ï€Î¿Ï…Ï‚, with feet of brass (El. 491 Ï‡. á¼˜ÏÎ¹Î½á½»Ï‚, untiring), i.e. furnished with brazen steps: not, putting brass under the foot, as some have taken it: so á¼€ÏÎ³Ï…Ïá½¹Ï€Î¿Ï…Ï‚, Ï‡ÏÏ…Ïƒá½¹Ï€Î¿Ï…Ï‚ etc.

á¼”ÏÎµÎ¹ÏƒÎ¼â€™ á¼ˆÎ¸Î·Î½á¿¶Î½Â· Î¿á¼± Î´á½² Ï€Î»Î·Ïƒá½·Î¿Î¹ Î³á½»Î±Î¹
Ï„á½¹Î½Î´â€™ á¼±Ï€Ï€á½¹Ï„Î·Î½ ÎšÎ¿Î»Ï‰Î½á½¸Î½ Îµá½”Ï‡Î¿Î½Ï„Î±Î¹ ÏƒÏ†á½·ÏƒÎ¹Î½ ğŸ—©
Line 59

The name â€” though ÎºÎ¿Î»Ï‰Î½á½¹Ï‚ was so familiar a word â€” is traced in the usual Greek fashion to a hero Colonus, the á¼Ï€á½½Î½Ï…Î¼Î¿Ï‚ of the deme; and, to justify the epithet of the place, á¼µÏ€Ï€Î¹Î¿Ï‚, he is called á¼±Ï€Ï€á½¹Ï„Î·Ï‚, horseman, or knight. In the roads about Colonus (Ï„Î±á¿–ÏƒÎ´Îµ...á¼€Î³Ï…Î¹Î±á¿–Ï‚ 715) men first learned to use Poseidon's gift of the horse. With Ï„á½¹Î½Î´â€™ cp. 65 Ï„Î¿á¿¦Î´Îµ Ï„Î¿á¿¦ Î¸ÎµÎ¿á¿¦. In the case of the tribes, at least, statues of eponymi were familiar to Athenians (cp. Aristoph. Pax 1183 Ï„á½¸Î½ á¼€Î½Î´ÏÎ¹á½±Î½Ï„Î± Ï„á½¸Î½ Î Î±Î½Î´á½·Î¿Î½Î¿Ï‚). A statue of the hero Colonus on the stage would be an effective device for giving greater vividness to the local legend. The speaker could point to it with dramatic fitness, since Antigone is with her blind father.

Elmsley reads á¼„ÏÏ‡ÎµÎ¹ Ï„á½·Ï‚ Î±á½Ï„á¿¶Î½; "Who is their king?" But Oed. rather asks, "Have they a monarchy or a democracy?" It would be a prosaic objection that the question is hardly suited to the heroic age of Ï€Î±Ï„ÏÎ¹ÎºÎ±á½¶ Î²Î±ÏƒÎ¹Î»Îµá¿–Î±Î¹ (Thuc. I. 13).

Line 69

Sophocles conceives the union of the Attic communes (commemorated by the annual festival of the ÏƒÏ…Î½Î¿á½·ÎºÎ¹Î± in August) as already accomplished by Theseus. Athens is the capital, all the people of Attica being reckoned as its citizens (á¼Ï€á½±Î½Ï„Ï‰Î½ á¼¤Î´Î· Î¾Ï…Î½Ï„ÎµÎ»Î¿á½»Î½Ï„Ï‰Î½ á¼Ï‚ Î±á½Ï„á½µÎ½, Thuc. 2.15). Isocr. or. 10 Â§ 18 speaks of Theseus as á½ Î»ÎµÎ³á½¹Î¼ÎµÎ½Î¿Ï‚ Î¼á½²Î½ Î‘á¼°Î³á½³Ï‰Ï‚, Î³ÎµÎ½á½¹Î¼ÎµÎ½Î¿Ï‚ Î´â€™ á¼Îº Î Î¿ÏƒÎµÎ¹Î´á¿¶Î½Î¿Ï‚. Aegeus, too, was said to have been king of Athens: see on 297; and was the eponymus of one of the ten Attic tribes (Î‘á¼°Î³Î·á½¶Ï‚ Ï†Ï…Î»á½µ, Andoc. or. 1 Â§ 62). He gave the title to a lost play of Sophocles.

Line 70

Îá½³. á½¡Ï‚ Ï€Ïá½¸Ï‚ Ï„á½· Î»á½³Î¾Ï‰Î½ á¼¢ ÎºÎ±Ï„Î±ÏÏ„á½»ÏƒÏ‰Î½ Î¼Î¿Î»Îµá¿–Î½; ğŸ—©
Line 71

á½¡Ï‚ Ï€Ïá½¸Ï‚ Ï„á½· goes with both participles, Î¼Î¿Î»Îµá¿–Î½ with the second only. The Chorus are uncertain whether Oedipus has merely some message for Theseus, or wishes to bring him in person to the spot (as Ï€Î¿Î¼Ï€á½¹Ï‚ might imply). Our pointing is better than á½¡Ï‚ Ï€Ïá½¸Ï‚ Ï„á½·; Î». á¼¢ Îº. Î¼Î¿Î»Îµá¿–Î½; The query turns more on the motive of the appeal than on a sharp contrast between its possible forms. Î»á½³Î¾Ï‰Î½ should not be joined with Î¼Î¿Î»Îµá¿–Î½ ("bid him come," Blaydes).

The reading and explanation of the verse hinge on the question whether á½¡Ï‚ (1) belongs to Ï€Ïá½¸Ï‚ Ï„á½·, = "with what view?" or (2) is final, = "in order that." Now (1) is strongly supported by two other places of Soph., in each of which this formula stands, as here, at the beginning of a question: O. T. 1174 ÎŸÎ™. á½¡Ï‚ Ï€Ïá½¸Ï‚ Ï„á½· Ï‡ÏÎµá½·Î±Ï‚; Tr. 1182 Î¥Î‘. á½¡Ï‚ Ï€Ïá½¸Ï‚ Ï„á½· Ï€á½·ÏƒÏ„Î¹Î½ Ï„á½µÎ½Î´â€™ á¼„Î³Î±Î½ á¼Ï€Î¹ÏƒÏ„Ïá½³Ï†ÎµÎ¹Ï‚; The simple Ï€Ïá½¸Ï‚ Ï„á½·; (also freq. in Soph.) = merely "with reference to what?" while á½¡Ï‚ Ï€Ïá½¸Ï‚ Ï„á½·= "with reference to what, in your conception or intention (á½¡Ï‚)?": hence the latter is appropriate when the questioner cannot imagine the agent's motive.

ÎºÎ±Ï„Î±ÏÏ„á½»ÏƒÏ‰Î½ Î¼Î¿Î»Îµá¿–Î½, to prepare things (to work upon his mind, directly or indirectly), so that he shall come: for the inf. cp. 1286: Plat. Rep. 562C Ï„á½´Î½ Ï€Î¿Î»Î¹Ï„Îµá½·Î±Î½... Ï€Î±ÏÎ±ÏƒÎºÎµÏ…á½±Î¶ÎµÎ¹ Ï„Ï…ÏÎ±Î½Î½á½·Î´Î¿Ï‚ Î´ÎµÎ·Î¸á¿†Î½Î±Î¹: and for ÎºÎ±Ï„Î±ÏÏ„á½»Ï‰ of mental or moral influence, Plut. Mor. 38 D á¼‚Î½...Î¼á½´ Î»á½¹Î³Î¿Î¹Ï‚ Ï‡ÏÎ·ÏƒÏ„Î¿á¿–Ï‚ á¼€Ï†Î±Î¹Ïá¿¶Î½ á¼¢ Ï€Î±ÏÎ±Ï„Ïá½³Ï€Ï‰Î½ ÎºÎ±Ï„Î±ÏÏ„á½»á¿ƒ Ï„á½´Î½ Ï†á½»ÏƒÎ¹Î½.

With L's Î¼á½¹Î»Î¿Î¹ (á½¡Ï‚ being then final), we must render: "That Theseus might come with what view (Ï€Ïá½¸Ï‚ Ï„á½·), â€”to say or to arrange (what)?" The opt. can stand (in spite of ÎºÎµÏÎ´á½±Î½á¿ƒ 72), since á¼†Ïâ€™ á¼‚Î½ Î¼á½¹Î»Î¿Î¹; (70) puts the case hypothetically: see on 11. But: (a) the double Î¼á½¹Î»Î¿Î¹, at the end of two successive verses, is intolerable. Dindorf, therefore, conjecturally reads Ï€Î±Ïá¿‡, which Wecklein and others adopt. (b) The antithesis between Î»á½³Î¾Ï‰Î½ and ÎºÎ±Ï„Î±ÏÏ„á½»ÏƒÏ‰Î½ is hardly clear. Wecklein explains, Ï€Ïá½¸Ï‚ Ï€Î¿á¿–Î¿Î½ Î»á½¹Î³Î¿Î½ á¼¢ á¼”ÏÎ³Î¿Î½; Certainly Ï„á½· Î»á½³Î¾Ï‰Î½ á¼¢ Î´Ïá½±ÏƒÏ‰Î½ could mean, "for what conceivable purpose?" (cp. Line 84

Ï€á½¹Ï„Î½Î¹Î±Î¹, fitting in his mouth, as being esp. their name at Thebes (43).

Î´ÎµÎ¹Î½á¿¶Ï€ÎµÏ‚: as looking sternly on sin (42). The face of the Avengers is still terrible to his inner eye. Sophocles nowhere portrays the lineaments of the Furies, as Aesch. does (Eum. 46-54), but he leaves on the mind an impression not less awful.

Îµá½–Ï„Îµ: Î½á¿¦Î½ á¼”ÎºÎ±Î¼ÏˆÎ± á¼Ï€á½¶ á¼•Î´ÏÎ±Ï‚ (gen. sing.) á½‘Î¼á¿¶Î½ Ï€Ïá½½Ï„Ï‰Î½ (possess. gen.) Ï„á¿†ÏƒÎ´Îµ Î³á¿†Ï‚ (partitive gen.). á¼Ï€á½· can be so placed since á½‘Î¼á¿¶Î½ is possessive gen. (=á½‘Î¼ÎµÏ„á½³ÏÎ±Ï‚): cp. 126, O. T. 177 á¼€ÎºÏ„á½°Î½ Ï€Ïá½¸Ï‚ á¼‘ÏƒÏ€á½³ÏÎ¿Ï… Î¸ÎµÎ¿á¿¦.

Ï„Î±á½»Ï„Î·Î½ á¼”Î»ÎµÎ¾Îµ Ï€Î±á¿¦Î»Î±Î½: spoke of this as a rest. The pronominal object of the verb, instead of being Ï„Î¿á¿¦Ï„Î¿, is assimilated to the gender of the predicate Ï€Î±á¿¦Î»Î±Î½: cp. Îµá¼¶Î½Î±Î¹ Ï„Î±á½»Ï„Î·Î½ á½€ÏÎ¸á½¹Ï„Î·Ï„Î± á½€Î½á½¹Î¼Î±Ï„Î¿Ï‚, Î¾Ï…Î½Î¸á½µÎºÎ·Î½, he says that in this consists the correctness of a word,â€”convention: Lysias or. 12 Â§ 37 Ï„Î±á½»Ï„Î·Î½ Î³á½°Ï á¼ÏƒÏ‡á½±Ï„Î·Î½ Î´á½·ÎºÎ·Î½ Î´Ï…Î½á½±Î¼ÎµÎ¸Î± Ï€Î±Ïâ€™ Î±á½Ï„á¿¶Î½ Î»Î±Î²Îµá¿–Î½, this (death) is the extreme penalty which we can exact from them.

á¼Î½ Ï‡Ïá½¹Î½á¿³ Î¼Î±ÎºÏá¿·: so El. 330: Ant. 422, Ph. 235, etc.: but 1648 Ï‡Ïá½¹Î½á¿³ Î²ÏÎ±Ï‡Îµá¿– (without á¼Î½). The general Attic rule was to use á¼Î½ in such phrases as á¼Î½ Ï€Î¿Î»Î»á¿·, Î¼Î±ÎºÏá¿·, á½€Î»á½·Î³á¿³, Î²ÏÎ±Ï‡Îµá¿– Ï‡Ïá½¹Î½á¿³, á¼Î½ á½€Î»á½·Î³Î±Î¹Ï‚ á¼¡Î¼á½³ÏÎ±Î¹Ï‚, á¼Î½ Ï€Î¿Î»Î»Î¿á¿–Ï‚ á¼”Ï„ÎµÏƒÎ¹Î½. The instances in which á¼Î½ is omitted are comparatively rare in poetry, and very rare (usu. doubtful) in prose, with the exception of the phrase á½‘ÏƒÏ„á½³Ïá¿³ Ï‡Ïá½¹Î½á¿³ which in prose usu. lacks á¼Î½: it takes it, however, below at 614 and Tr. 18.

á¼Î»Î¸á½¹Î½Ï„Î¹ Ï‡á½½ÏÎ±Î½ Ï„ÎµÏÎ¼á½·Î±Î½, á½…Ï€Î¿Ï… Î¸Îµá¿¶Î½ ğŸ—©
Line 89

á¼Î»Î¸á½¹Î½Ï„Î¹ â€¦ Î²á½·Î¿Î½. Apollo said: Î±á½•Ï„Î· Ï€Î±á¿¦Î»á½± ÏƒÎ¿Î¹ á¼”ÏƒÏ„Î±Î¹, á¼Î»Î¸á½¹Î½Ï„Î¹ Ï‡á½½ÏÎ±Î½ Ï„ÎµÏÎ¼á½·Î±Î½, á½…Ï€Î¿Ï… á¼‚Î½ Î»á½±Î²á¿ƒÏ‚ Î¸. In the orat. obliqua, if the tense of the principal verb were primary (as Î»á½³Î³ÎµÎ¹), á½…Ï€Î¿Ï… á¼‚Î½ Î»á½±Î²á¿ƒÏ‚ would become á½…Ï€Î¿Ï… á¼‚Î½ Î»á½±Î²Ï‰: since it is secondary (á¼”Î»ÎµÎ¾Îµ), we have á½…Ï€Î¿Ï… Î»á½±Î²Î¿Î¹Î¼Î¹. Ï„ÎµÏÎ¼á½·Î±Î½ is proleptic: in whatever land he should find the Semnae, that land was to be for him Ï„ÎµÏÎ¼á½·Î±, i.e. was to contain the goal of his wanderings. Ï€Î±ÏÎ·Î³Î³á½»Î± cannot mean "pledged,""promised" (á¼ Î³Î³Ï…á¾¶Ï„Î¿), but only "passed the watchword to me," i.e. "told me, as a sign." Xen. Cyr. 3.3.58 Ï€Î±ÏÎ·Î³Î³á½»Î± á½ Îšá¿¦ÏÎ¿Ï‚ Ïƒá½»Î½Î¸Î·Î¼Î±, Î–Îµá½ºÏ‚ Ïƒá½»Î¼Î¼Î±Ï‡Î¿Ï‚ ÎºÎ±á½¶ á¼¡Î³ÎµÎ¼á½½Î½, "C. proceeded to pass the watchword, 'Zeus'", etc. Ï€Î±ÏÎµÎ³Î³Ï…á½±Ï‰ regularly has this sense (which sometimes passes into that of "exhorting," "encouraging" one another); or else that of "putting something into another's hand," "entrusting" it to him. The omission of the temporal augment in L and other MSS. is not a sufficient ground for adopting Herwerden's Ï†ÎµÏá½³Î³Î³Ï…Î± ("trusty").

Î¿á½Îº á¼”ÏƒÎ¸â€™ á½…Ï€Ï‰Ï‚ Î¿á½, which in grammatical order immediately follows á½¡Ï‚, can be thus placed because felt as one adverbial expression="assuredly": so often á¼”ÏƒÏ„Î¹Î½ á½…Ï„Îµ (="sometimes"), Î¿á½Îº á¼”ÏƒÏ„Î¹Î½ á¾— ("in no wise"), Î¿á½Î´Îµá½¶Ï‚ á½…ÏƒÏ„Î¹Ï‚ Î¿á½ ("everybody"), etc.

Ï€Ï„ÎµÏá½¸Î½: no outward sign had been given. The "omen" was in the leading of his will. Cp. the feeling in the Odyssey (more spiritual here than the Iliad) that the gods sometimes act directly on the human mind by inspiring a thought at a crisis. á½€Î¼Ï†á½°Ï‚: see on 550.

Ï€á½³ÏÎ±ÏƒÎ¹Î½ á¼¤Î´Î· ÎºÎ±á½¶ ÎºÎ±Ï„Î±ÏƒÏ„ÏÎ¿Ï†á½µÎ½ Ï„Î¹Î½Î±,
Îµá¼° Î¼á½´ Î´Î¿Îºá¿¶ Ï„Î¹ Î¼ÎµÎ¹á½¹Î½Ï‰Ï‚ á¼”Ï‡ÎµÎ¹Î½, á¼€Îµá½¶ ğŸ—©
Line 104

Î¼ÎµÎ¹á½¹Î½Ï‰Ï‚ á¼”Ï‡ÎµÎ¹Î½=Î¼Îµá½·Ï‰Î½ Îµá¼¶Î½Î±Î¹. This euphemistic mode of expression with the comparative adverb is often found where censure or disparagement is to be conveyed less bluntly. Plat. Phaedo 75A á½€Ïá½³Î³ÎµÏ„Î±Î¹ Î¼á½²Î½ Ï€á½±Î½Ï„Î± Ï„Î±á¿¦Ï„Î± Îµá¼¶Î½Î±Î¹ Î¿á¼·Î¿Î½ Ï„á½¸ á¼´ÏƒÎ¿Î½, á¼”Ï‡ÎµÎ¹ Î´á½² á¼Î½Î´ÎµÎµÏƒÏ„á½³ÏÏ‰Ï‚ (repeated just afterwards thus, Î±á½Ï„Î¿á¿¦ á¼Î½Î´Îµá½³ÏƒÏ„ÎµÏá½± á¼ÏƒÏ„Î¹Î½): Apol. 34 C Ï„á½±Ï‡â€™ á¼‚Î½ Î¿á½–Î½ Ï„Î¹Ï‚ Ï„Î±á¿¦Ï„Î± á¼Î½Î½Î¿á½µÏƒÎ±Ï‚ Î±á½Î¸Î±Î´á½³ÏƒÏ„ÎµÏÎ¿Î½ á¼‚Î½ Ï€Ïá½¹Ï‚ Î¼Îµ ÏƒÏ‡Î¿á½·Î·, = Î±á½Î¸Î±Î´á½³ÏƒÏ„ÎµÏÎ¿Ï‚ á¼‚Î½ Îµá¼´Î·: Legg. 932 A á¼á½±Î½ Ï„Î¹Ï‚ á¼Î½ Ï„á¿‡Î´Îµ Ï„á¿‡ Ï€á½¹Î»ÎµÎ¹ Î³Î¿Î½á½³Ï‰Î½ á¼€Î¼ÎµÎ»á½³ÏƒÏ„ÎµÏÎ¿Î½ á¼”Ï‡á¿ƒ Ï„Î¿á¿¦ Î´á½³Î¿Î½Ï„Î¿Ï‚ = á¼€Î¼ÎµÎ»á½³ÏƒÏ„ÎµÏÎ¿Ï‚ á¾–. Oedipus says to the Furies: "Grant me rest, unless haply (Ï„Î¹, adv., as O. T. 969, here with bitter irony) I seem to be beneath such grace,â€”I, who have suffered so much and so long." Î¼ÎµÎ¹á½¹Î½Ï‰Ï‚ á¼”Ï‡ÎµÎ¹Î½ means here to be Î¼Îµá½·Ï‰Î½ in the sense of "too insignificant," "of too little account," in respect of suffering: i.e., one who has not yet suffered enough. Thus we arrive at the same sense which the scholiast extorts by a method which seems impossible. He explains Î¼ÎµÎ¹á½¹Î½Ï‰Ï‚ á¼”Ï‡ÎµÎ¹Î½ as = á¼Î»Î±Ï„Ï„á½¹Î½Ï‰Ï‚ á¼”Ï‡ÎµÎ¹Î½ Ï„á½° ÎºÎ±Îºá½±, "to have ills in too small a degree." But (1) as Herm. said, this would be Î¼Îµá¿–Î¿Î½ or Î¼Îµá½·Ï‰ á¼”Ï‡ÎµÎ¹Î½, and (2) it is impossible to understand Ï„á½° ÎºÎ±Îºá½±. Campbell thinks that Î¼ÎµÎ¹á½¹Î½Ï‰Ï‚ á¼”Ï‡ÎµÎ¹Î½ Î»Î±Ï„ÏÎµá½»Ï‰Î½ = Î¼ÎµÎ¹á½¹Î½Ï‰Ï‚ á¼”Ï‡ÎµÎ¹Î½ Î»Î±Ï„ÏÎµÏ…Î¼á½±Ï„Ï‰Î½: which is open to objection (1), and also to this, that the partic. Î»Î±Ï„ÏÎµá½»Ï‰Î½ could not do duty for a partitive gen. after á¼”Ï‡ÎµÎ¹Î½. Wecklein (who follows the schol.) suggests Î¼ÎµÎ¹á½¹Î½Ï‰Ï‚ á¼”Ï‡ÎµÎ¹Î½ ÎºÎ±Îºá¿¶Î½, and á¼€Îµá½· for Î²ÏÎ¿Ï„á¿¶Î½ in 105.

This verse is corrupt in the MSS., but two things seem clear: (1) there is no reason to suspect Ï€ÏÎ¿ÏƒÎ´á½³ÏÎºÎ¿Ï…: (2) the singular Î»Îµá¿¦ÏƒÏƒÎµ must be restored, and placed after Ï€ÏÎ¿ÏƒÎ´á½³ÏÎºÎ¿Ï…. Line 122

Ï€ÏÎ¿ÏƒÏ€Îµá½»Î¸Î¿Ï… (only here) ought to mean "ask, or learn, further" (the reg. sense of Ï€ÏÎ¿ÏƒÏ€Ï…Î½Î¸á½±Î½ÎµÏƒÎ¸Î±Î¹, Ï€ÏÎ¿ÏƒÎµÏÏ‰Ï„á¾¶Î½), but this is weak: here, it seems rather to mean, "press the inquiry," inquire assiduously: cp. Ï€ÏÎ¿ÏƒÎ±Î¹Ï„Îµá¿–Î½, Ï€ÏÎ¿ÏƒÎ»Î¹Ï€Î±ÏÎµá¿–Î½. Ï€ÏÎ¿ÏƒÏ†Î¸á½³Î³Î³Î¿Ï… ("speak to him"), a v.l. for Ï€ÏÎ¿ÏƒÏ€Îµá½»Î¸Î¿Ï…, is plainly unsuitable. The conjectures Î»Îµá¿¦ÏƒÏƒâ€™ Î±á½Ï„á½¹Î½, Ï€ÏÎ¿ÏƒÎ´ÏÎ±ÎºÎ¿á¿¦, Ï€ÏÎ¿ÏƒÏ€Îµá½»Î¸Î¿Ï… (or Ï€ÏÎ¿ÏƒÏ€Ï…Î¸Î¿á¿¦, Ï€ÏÎ¿ÏƒÎ´á½³ÏÎºÎ¿Ï…) are open not only to the objection from the sense of Î»Îµá½»ÏƒÏƒÎµÎ¹Î½ (121), but also to this, that the aor. is less fitting here. Ï„á¾¶Î½Î´â€™ á¼€Î¼Î±Î¹Î¼Î±ÎºÎµÏ„á¾¶Î½ ÎºÎ¿Ïá¾¶Î½, ğŸ—©
Line 127

á¼€Î¼Î±Î¹Î¼Î±ÎºÎµÏ„á¾¶Î½: used by the poets of any violent force, divine or elemental, with which men cannot cope (as the Chimaera, Il. 6.179; Artemis in her wrath, Pind. Pyth. 3.33; the sea, ib. 1.14; fire, O. T. 177), and probably associated with á¼„Î¼Î±Ï‡Î¿Ï‚. But the reduplication recalls Î¼Î±Î¹â€Î¼á½±â€Ï‰ (cp. Ï€Î¿Ïâ€Ï†á½»Ïâ€Ï‰, Ï€Î¿Î¹â€Ï€Î½á½»â€Ï‰), â€”the á¼€ being intensive: and if we suppose a secondary development of âˆšMA as Î¼Î±Îº (Fennell on Pind. P. 1. 14), the proper sense of á¼€Î¼Î±Î¹Î¼á½±ÎºÎµÏ„Î¿Ï‚ would be "very furious." The word being of epic coinage, it is conceivable that associations with Î¼á½±Ï‡Î¿Î¼Î±Î¹ may have influenced the formation as well as the usage.

á¼ƒÏ‚ Ï„Ïá½³Î¼Î¿Î¼ÎµÎ½ Î»á½³Î³ÎµÎ¹Î½
130 ÎºÎ±á½¶ Ï€Î±ÏÎ±Î¼ÎµÎ¹Î²á½¹Î¼ÎµÏƒÎ¸â€™ á¼€Î´á½³ÏÎºÏ„Ï‰Ï‚, ğŸ—©
Line 130

ÎºÎ±á½¶ Ï€Î±ÏÎ±Î¼ÎµÎ¹Î²á½¹Î¼ÎµÏƒÎ¸â€™ Îº.Ï„.Î». In approaching or passing a shrine, it was usual to salute (Ï€ÏÎ¿ÏƒÎºÏ…Î½Îµá¿–Î½), and to invoke the deity audibly. But in passing the grove of the Eumenides the people of Colonus avoid looking towards it. No sound, no articulate word, escapes them. Their lips only move in sign of the prayer which the mind conceives. Cp. on 489.

Ï„á½¸ Ï„á¾¶Ï‚ á¼Ï†á½±Î¼Î¿Ï… ÏƒÏ„á½¹Î¼Î± Ï†ÏÎ¿Î½Ï„á½·Î´Î¿Ï‚ á¼±á½³Î½Ï„ÎµÏ‚ = "moving the lips of (in) reverently-mute thought"; á¼±á½³Î½Î±Î¹ (instead of Î¿á¼´Î³ÎµÎ¹Î½, Î»á½»ÎµÎ¹Î½, Î´Î¹Î±á½·ÏÎµÎ¹Î½) ÏƒÏ„á½¹Î¼Î± has been suggested by the phrases Ï†Ï‰Î½á½´Î½ (or Î³Î»á¿¶ÏƒÏƒÎ±Î½) á¼±á½³Î½Î±Î¹: cp. fr. 844. 3 Ï€Î¿Î»Î»á½´Î½ Î³Î»á¿¶ÏƒÏƒÎ±Î½ á¼ÎºÏ‡á½³Î±Ï‚ Î¼á½±Ï„Î·Î½. This is better than to make ÏƒÏ„á½¹Î¼Î± purely figurative (like "the still, small voice"), when the sense would be, "giving a (still) voice to our reverent thought," Îµá½Ï†á½±Î¼Î¿Ï… (=silent) qualifying the metaphor as when discord is called Ï€á¿¦Ï á¼€Î½á½µÏ†Î±Î¹ÏƒÏ„Î¿Î½, Eur. Or. 621.

á¼€Ï†á½½Î½Ï‰Ï‚, á¼€Î»á½¹Î³Ï‰Ï‚ Ï„á½¸ Ï„á¾¶Ï‚. ğŸ—©
Line 131

á¼€Ï†á½½Î½Ï‰Ï‚. The ancient custom was to pray aloud, partly from a feeling that one ought not to make any prayer which might not be heard by all mortals. Pythagoras in Clemens Alex. á¼ÎºÎµá¿–Î½Î¿Ï‚, of whom ye were speaking: Ant. 384: Aristoph. Ach. 41 Ï„Î¿á¿¦Ï„â€™ á¼ÎºÎµá¿–Î½â€™ Î¿á½‘Î³á½¼ )Î»ÎµÎ³Î¿Î½: Nub. 1167 á½…Î´â€™ á¼ÎºÎµá¿–Î½Î¿Ï‚ á¼€Î½á½µÏ: El. 665.

Ï†Ï‰Î½á¿‡ Î³á½°Ï á½Ïá¿³: (I appear to you), for in sound is my sight (i.e. I know your presence by your voices). To this announcement of his blindness a certain gentle pathos is added by Ï„á½¸ Ï†Î±Ï„Î¹Î¶á½¹Î¼. [Dem.] or. 25 Â§ 89 á½¥ÏƒÏ€ÎµÏ Ï„á½¸ Ï„á¿†Ï‚ Ï€Î±ÏÎ¿Î¹Î¼á½·Î±Ï‚, á½Ïá¿¶Î½Ï„Î±Ï‚ Î¼á½´ á½Ïá¾¶Î½ ÎºÎ±á½¶ á¼€ÎºÎ¿á½»Î¿Î½Ï„Î±Ï‚ Î¼á½´ á¼€ÎºÎ¿á½»ÎµÎ¹Î½. Î¿á½ Ï€á½±Î½Ï… Î¼Î¿á½·ÏÎ±Ï‚ Ï€Ïá½½Ï„Î·Ï‚ not wholly of the best fortune, Îµá½Î´Î±Î¹Î¼Î¿Î½á½·ÏƒÎ±Î¹ (epexeg. inf., Îµá¼°Ï‚ Ï„á½¸ Îµá½Î´Î±Î¹Î¼Î¿Î½á½·ÏƒÎ±Î¹ schol.) so that men should call him happy. Line 149

á¼á½µ. L has á¼’ á¼’Â· which should metrically answer to á½…ÏÎ± (117). It is possible that in an exclamation, followed by a momentary pause, the second á¼” should stand here: but it is more prob. that, as in Aesch. Theb. 966 etc., we should write á¼á½µ.

á¼€Î»Î±á¿¶Î½ á½€Î¼Î¼á½±Ï„Ï‰Î½. Oedipus has spoken of his own ill fortune as if it consisted primarily in his blindness. The Chorus then ask: â€” "Ah! and wast thou blind from thy birth? Thy life has been long, as well as unhappy, one may judge." The gen. could depend on á¼á½µ, as oft. on Ï†Îµá¿¦, á½¦, Î¿á¼´Î¼Î¿Î¹, etc., but is better taken with Ï†Ï…Ï„á½±Î»Î¼Î¹Î¿Ï‚, of which the sense (with Î±á½Ï„á¿¶Î½ understood) would else be obscure.

150 á¼†ÏÎ± ÎºÎ±á½¶ á¼¦ÏƒÎ¸Î± Ï†Ï…Ï„á½±Î»Î¼Î¹Î¿Ï‚; Î´Ï…ÏƒÎ±á½·Ï‰Î½ ğŸ—©
Line 150

Ï†Ï…Ï„á½±Î»Î¼Î¹Î¿Ï‚="generator": i.e. didst thou bring them with thee into life? á¼”Ï†Ï…ÏƒÎ±Ï‚ Ï„Ï…Ï†Î»á½° á½„Î¼Î¼Î±Ï„Î±;=á¼¦ÏƒÎ¸Î± Ï„Ï…Ï†Î»á½¸Ï‚ á¼Îº Î³ÎµÎ½ÎµÏ„á¿†Ï‚; Ai. 1077 Îºá¼‚Î½ Ïƒá¿¶Î¼Î± Î³ÎµÎ½Î½á½µÏƒá¿ƒ Î¼á½³Î³Î± though one grow a great body (=though his frame wax mighty).

Î¼Î±ÎºÏÎ±á½·Ï‰Î½ Î³â€™, á½…Ïƒâ€™ á¼Ï€ÎµÎ¹Îºá½±ÏƒÎ±Î¹.
á¼€Î»Î»â€™ Î¿á½ Î¼á½°Î½ á¼”Î½ Î³â€™ á¼Î¼Î¿á½¶ ğŸ—©
Line 152

=120 á½ Ï€á½±Î½Ï„Ï‰Î½ á¼€ÎºÎ¿Ïá½³ÏƒÏ„Î±Ï„Î¿Ï‚. Ï€ÏÎ¿ÏƒÎ¸á½µÏƒÎµÎ¹ Ï„á½±ÏƒÎ´â€™ á¼€Ïá½±Ï‚. ğŸ—©
Line 153

("Thou hast already suffered;) but verily, within my power (á¼”Î½ Î³â€™ á¼Î¼Î¿á½·, =if I can help it), thou shalt not add these curses (to thy woes)."

á¼”Î»Î¸á¿ƒ, delib. subjunct., in third pers., as Dem. De Cor. Â§ 124 Ï€á½¹Ï„ÎµÏá½¹Î½ Ïƒá½³ Ï„Î¹Ï‚, Î‘á¼°ÏƒÏ‡á½·Î½Î·, Ï„á¿†Ï‚ Ï€á½¹Î»ÎµÏ‰Ï‚ á¼Ï‡Î¸Ïá½¸Î½ á¼¢ á¼Î¼á½¸Î½ Îµá¼¶Î½Î±Î¹ Ï†á¿‡; L has á¼”Î»Î¸Î¿Î¹, which might be defended as = "whither can one possibly turn?" â€” a more despairing form of á¼”Î»Î¸á¿ƒ. Mr. A. Sidgwick has pointed out (Aesch. Cho. The principle is (I think) true. But here, at least, the genuinely "deliberative" á¼”Î»Î¸á¿ƒ seems best. See Appendix.

Since Îºá¼€ÎºÎ¿á½»Î¿Î½Ï„Î±Ï‚ suits both metre and sense, it seems more likely that this was the reading from which, by a scribe's mistake, ÎºÎ¿á½Îº á¼€ÎºÎ¿á½»Î¿Î½Ï„Î±Ï‚ arose, than that á¼€ÎºÎ¿á½»Î¿Î½Ï„Î±Ï‚ conceals some other participle (such as ÎºÎ±Ï„Î¿ÎºÎ½Î¿á¿¦Î½Ï„Î±Ï‚ or á¼€Ï€Î¹Î¸Î¿á¿¦Î½Ï„Î±Ï‚). ÏƒÎ¿á½¶ (the coryphaeus) after á½¦ Î¾Îµá¿–Î½Î¿Î¹ (the Chorus): cp. 208 á½¦ Î¾á½³Î½Î¿Î¹,...Î¼á½µ Î¼â€™ á¼€Î½á½³Ïá¿ƒ: 242 ff. á½¦ Î¾á½³Î½Î¿Î¹, Î¿á¼°ÎºÏ„Îµá½·ÏÎ±Ï„â€™, followed by á½„Î¼Î¼Î± Ïƒá½¹Î½. Cp. ÎºÎ±á½¶ was omitted by Herm., to make a paroemiac (when the sound and rhythm become extremely unpleasing); ÏƒÎ¿á½¶ was omitted, with the same object, by Brunck and Elmsley. Both words are genuine. A paroemiac is neither needful nor desirable here, when another follows so closely (177).

Î§Î¿. Î¿á½” Ï„Î¿Î¹ Î¼á½µÏ€Î¿Ï„á½³ Ïƒâ€™ á¼Îº Ï„á¿¶Î½Î´â€™ á¼‘Î´Ïá½±Î½Ï‰Î½, ğŸ—©

Ï„á¿¶Î½Î´â€™ á¼‘Î´Ïá½±Î½Ï‰Î½, "these seats," the resting-place, generally, in front of the grove, rather than the particular rocky seat pointed out at 192 f.: cp. 233 f. (Hardly "abodes," i.e. Colonus, as Aesch. Pers. 4.)

á½¦ Î³á½³ÏÎ¿Î½, á¼„ÎºÎ¿Î½Ï„á½± Ï„Î¹Ï‚ á¼„Î¾ÎµÎ¹. ğŸ—©
Line 177

á¼„Î¾ÎµÎ¹ was altered to á¼„Ïá¿ƒ by Elmsley on the ground that Î¿á½ Î¼á½µ with the fut. indic. forbids; with the subjunctive, denies. But, besides the passages in which Î¿á½ Î¼á½µ stands with the 2nd pers. fut. ind., and forbids (as Aristoph. Ran. 462 Î¿á½ Î¼á½´ Î´Î¹Î±Ï„Ïá½·ÏˆÎµÎ¹Ï‚, "don't dawdle"), there are others in which it stands with the 1st or 3rd pers. fut. ind., and denies. In some of these our MSS. are doubtless corrupt; but there are others in which the correction, if any, must be bold. Thus: (1) with 1st pers.: Soph. L's á¼”Ï„â€™ Î¿á½–Î½ á¼”Ï„Î¹ Ï€ÏÎ¿Î²á¿¶; metrically answers to Î¿á½•Ï„Ï‰Ï‚ in 194. á¼„Î½ with the optat. verbs, not with á¼µÎ½Î±: "(to a place) where I may speak on the one hand, and hear on the other": Ï„á½¸ Î¼á½²Î½ â€¦ Ï„á½¸ Î´á½³ are adverbial: cp. Xen. Anab. 4.1.14 Ï„á½° Î¼á½³Î½ Ï„Î¹ Î¼Î±Ï‡á½¹Î¼ÎµÎ½Î¿Î¹, Ï„á½° Î´á½² ÎºÎ±á½¶ á¼€Î½Î±Ï€Î±Ï…á½¹Î¼ÎµÎ½Î¿Î¹.

á¼„Î½ with the optat. in the relative clause just as in apodosis; so Theocr. 25. 61 á¼Î³á½¼ Î´á½³ Ï„Î¿Î¹ á¼¡Î³ÎµÎ¼Î¿Î½Îµá½»ÏƒÏ‰ â€¦ á¼µÎ½Î± ÎºÎµÎ½ Ï„á½³Ï„Î¼Î¿Î¹Î¼ÎµÎ½ á¼„Î½Î±ÎºÏ„Î± (to a place where we are likely to find him): Xen. Î§Î¿. Î±á½Ï„Î¿á¿¦Â· Î¼Î·Îºá½³Ï„Î¹ Ï„Î¿á¿¦Î´â€™ Î±á½Ï„Î¿Ï€á½³Ï„ÏÎ¿Ï… ğŸ—©
Line 192

Î±á½Ï„Î¿á¿¦. Oed. has now advanced to the verge of the grove. Here a low ledge of natural rock forms a sort of threshold, on which his feet are now set.

Î±á½Ï„Î¿Ï€á½³Ï„ÏÎ¿Ï… Î²á½µÎ¼Î±Ï„Î¿Ï‚, a "step," i.e. ledge, of natural rock, not shaped by man (as was the ordinary Î²á¿†Î¼Î± or raised place for speakers, etc.), distinct, of course, from the á¼„Î¾ÎµÏƒÏ„Î¿Ï‚ Ï€á½³Ï„ÏÎ¿Ï‚ of 19, which was within the grove. So Î±á½Ï„á½¹Î¾Ï…Î»Î¿Ï‚ (of rough wood, Ph. 35), Î±á½Ï„Î¿Ï€á½¹ÏÏ†Ï…ÏÎ¿Ï‚ (of natural purple), Î±á½Ï„á½¹Ï€Î¿ÎºÎ¿Ï‚ (of simple wool), Î±á½Ï„á½¹Ï€Ï…â€”ÏÎ¿Ï‚ (of unbolted wheaten flour), Î±á½Ï„á½¹ÎºÎ¿Î¼Î¿Ï‚ (with natural hair, Aristoph. Ran. 822), Î±á½Ï„á½¹ÏÎ¿Ï†Î¿Î¹ Ï€á½³Ï„ÏÎ±Î¹ (rocks forming a natural roof, Oppian Halieut. 1. 22). The á¼€Î½Ï„Î¹Ï€á½³Ï„ÏÎ¿Ï… of the MSS. could mean:â€”(1) "A ledge like rock"; cp. á¼€Î½Ï„á½·Ï€Î±Î¹Ï‚ (Aesch. Eum. 38)= "weak as a child": and so the schol. in L, á¼°ÏƒÎ¿Ï€á½³Ï„ÏÎ¿Ï…, Ï‡Î±Î»ÎºÎ¿á¿¦,â€”i.e. "a ledge of material firm as rock," "of brass," meaning the Ï‡Î±Î»Îºá½¹Ï€Î¿Ï…Ï‚ á½€Î´á½¹Ï‚ understood literally: see, however, on 57. (2) "A ledge serving as a rock": cp. (á½€Î½Îµá½·Î´Î·) á¼€Î½Ï„á½·ÎºÎµÎ½Ï„ÏÎ± (Aesch. Eum. 136), Î»á½·Î¸Î¿Ï‚ á¼€Î½Ï„Î¹Î¸á½»ÏÎµÏ„ÏÎ¿Ï‚ (Nonnus 11. 140), á¼€Î½Ï„á½·Ï€Ï…ÏÎ³Î¿Ï‚ Ï€á½³Ï„ÏÎ± (Eur. Bacch. 1097). (3) "A seat of rock fronting thee": cp. á¼€Î½Ï„á½·Ï€Ïá¿³ÏÎ¿Ï‚, with Ï€Ïá¿´ÏÎ± facing one. This does not fit the data. (4) Bellermann: "a (stone) seat over against a rock," i.e. "behind which the stone wall rises" (?).â€”Campb. renders first by "rocky," then by "rock-like," and refers it to "some peculiarity in the basement of the low seats."

Î²á½µÎ¼Î±Ï„Î¿Ï‚ á¼”Î¾Ï‰ Ï€á½¹Î´Î± ÎºÎ»á½·Î½á¿ƒÏ‚. ğŸ—©
Line 193

Ï€á½¹Î´Î± ÎºÎ»á½·Î½á¿ƒÏ‚ (aor.) like Ï€á½¹Î´Î± Ï„Ïá½³Ï€ÎµÎ¹Î½ (Eur. Suppl. 718), since, the seat being now at his side, he turns away from it if he moves forward. Wecklein explains it as =Î³á½¹Î½Ï… Îºá½±Î¼Ïˆá¿ƒÏ‚ ("sit down"), but (1) Ï€á½¹Î´Î± could not here stand for Î³á½¹Î½Ï…, and (2) the question is now of halting, not yet of sitting down (see 195).

ÎŸá¼°. Î¿á½•Ï„Ï‰Ï‚;
Î§Î¿. á¼…Î»Î¹Ï‚, á½¡Ï‚ á¼€ÎºÎ¿á½»ÎµÎ¹Ï‚. ğŸ—©
Line 195

á¼¦ á¼‘ÏƒÎ¸á¿¶; "am I to sit down?" deliberative aor. subj. of á¼•Î¶Î¿Î¼Î±Î¹. This aor. of the simple verb occurs nowhere else: but á¼ÎºÎ±Î¸á½³ÏƒÎ¸Î·Î½ is used in later Greek (as ÎºÎ±Î¸ÎµÏƒÎ¸á½³Î½Ï„Î± Paus. 3.22.1). Since á¼‘ is the radical vowel, it seems better to suppose a synizesis (á¼¦ á¼‘ÏƒÎ¸á¿¶;) than an aphaeresis (á¼¦ )ÏƒÎ¸á¿¶;): the á¼¦, though not necessary, is prob. genuine. I have left this questionable á¼‘ÏƒÎ¸á¿¶ in the text, on the strength of á¼ÎºÎ±Î¸á½³ÏƒÎ¸Î·Î½: but the v.l. á¼¦ ÏƒÏ„á¿¶ ("am I to halt?"), preferred by the schol. in L, seems more defensible than it has been thought by recent edd. The answer of the Chorus, no doubt, refers to sitting down. So, however, it could do after á¼¦ ÏƒÏ„á¿¶; He has already been told to go no further (191 f.): but, in his anxiety to avoid further offence, it is conceivable that he should repeat his question in the clearest form. (Cp. Eur. Hec. 1079 Ï€á¾¶ Î²á¿¶, Ï€á¾¶ ÏƒÏ„á¿¶, Ï€á¾¶ Îºá½±Î¼ÏˆÏ‰...;)

Î»á½³Ï‡ÏÎ¹á½¹Ï‚ Î³â€™ â€¦ á½€ÎºÎ»á½±ÏƒÎ±Ï‚, "yes, moving sideways," â€” the rocky seat being near his side â€” "(sit down), crouching low on the top of the rock." á½€â€ÎºÎ»á½±Î¶Ï‰ (cp. á½€â€Î´á½±Î¾, from âˆšÎ´Î±Îº), from ÎºÎ»á½±â€Ï‰, to bend the hams in crouching down; Xen. Anab. 6.1.10 Ï„á½¸ Î ÎµÏÏƒÎ¹Îºá½¸Î½ á½ ÏÏ‡Îµá¿–Ï„Î¿,...ÎºÎ±á½¶ á½¤ÎºÎ»Î±Î¶Îµ ÎºÎ±á½¶ á¼Î¾Î±Î½á½·ÏƒÏ„Î±Ï„Î¿, "he danced the Persian dance, sinking down and rising again by turns" (there was a dance called á½„ÎºÎ»Î±ÏƒÎ¼Î±): so á½€ÎºÎ»Î±Î´á½·Î±Ï‚=a folding campstool.

Î²ÏÎ±Ï‡á½ºÏ‚, "low," (as Î¼á½³Î³Î±Ï‚="tall,") because the seat is near the ground.

á¼„ÎºÏÎ¿Ï…, on the outer edge of the rocky platform (Î²á¿†Î¼Î± 192).

ÎŸá¼°. 195 á¼¦ á¼‘ÏƒÎ¸á¿¶; ğŸ—©
Line 195Line 195

á¼¦ á¼‘ÏƒÎ¸á¿¶; "am I to sit down?" deliberative aor. subj. of á¼•Î¶Î¿Î¼Î±Î¹. This aor. of the simple verb occurs nowhere else: but á¼ÎºÎ±Î¸á½³ÏƒÎ¸Î·Î½ is used in later Greek (as ÎºÎ±Î¸ÎµÏƒÎ¸á½³Î½Ï„Î± Paus. 3.22.1). Since á¼‘ is the radical vowel, it seems better to suppose a synizesis (á¼¦ á¼‘ÏƒÎ¸á¿¶;) than an aphaeresis (á¼¦ )ÏƒÎ¸á¿¶;): the á¼¦, though not necessary, is prob. genuine. I have left this questionable á¼‘ÏƒÎ¸á¿¶ in the text, on the strength of á¼ÎºÎ±Î¸á½³ÏƒÎ¸Î·Î½: but the v.l. á¼¦ ÏƒÏ„á¿¶ ("am I to halt?"), preferred by the schol. in L, seems more defensible than it has been thought by recent edd. The answer of the Chorus, no doubt, refers to sitting down. So, however, it could do after á¼¦ ÏƒÏ„á¿¶; He has already been told to go no further (191 f.): but, in his anxiety to avoid further offence, it is conceivable that he should repeat his question in the clearest form. (Cp. Eur. Hec. 1079 Ï€á¾¶ Î²á¿¶, Ï€á¾¶ ÏƒÏ„á¿¶, Ï€á¾¶ Îºá½±Î¼ÏˆÏ‰...;)

Î»á½³Ï‡ÏÎ¹á½¹Ï‚ Î³â€™ â€¦ á½€ÎºÎ»á½±ÏƒÎ±Ï‚, "yes, moving sideways," â€” the rocky seat being near his side â€” "(sit down), crouching low on the top of the rock." á½€â€ÎºÎ»á½±Î¶Ï‰ (cp. á½€â€Î´á½±Î¾, from âˆšÎ´Î±Îº), from ÎºÎ»á½±â€Ï‰, to bend the hams in crouching down; Xen. á¼Î¼á½¸Î½ Ï„á½¹Î´): i.e. the office of placing him in his seat (cp. 21Îºá½±Î¸Î¹Î¶á½³... Î¼Îµ). Hermann changes the á¼Î½ á¼¡ÏƒÏ…Ï‡á½·á¾³ of the MSS. to á¼Î½ á¼ÏƒÏ…Ï‡Î±á½·á¾³, joining it with Î²á½±ÏƒÎµÎ¹. The corresponding strophic verse is lost (see on 181): but the metre confirms the emendation (see Metrical Analysis). The words á¼Î½ á¼¡ÏƒÏ…Ï‡Î±á½·á¾³ â€¦ á¼Î¼á½±Î½ are said as she helps him to sit down. He has to make one step sideways (195) to the seat. Taking his arm, she says: "Lean on me, and join step to quiet step" (á¼…ÏÎ¼Î¿ÏƒÎ±Î¹ aor. imper. midd.): i.e. "advance one foot to the resting-place, bring the other up beside it, and then (supported by my arm) sit down." Cp. Eur. Or. 233 á¼¦ Îºá¼€Ï€á½¶ Î³Î±á½·Î±Ï‚ á¼ÏÎ¼á½¹ÏƒÎ±Î¹ Ï€á½¹Î´Î±Ï‚ Î¸á½³Î»ÎµÎ¹Ï‚; "wouldest thou set thy feet together (plant thy feet) on the ground?" Line 224

The MSS. give the one word Î´Ï…ÏƒÎ¼Î¿ÏÎ¿Ï‚ to Oed., as uttered by him between the exclamations of the Chorus. It thus marks his despair at their refusal to hear him. There is dramatic force in the sentence of expulsion (226) being the first articulate utterance of the Chorus after the disclosure which has appalled them.

Line 227

Ï€Î¿á¿– ÎºÎ±Ï„Î±Î¸á½µÏƒÎµÎ¹Ï‚; fig. from the payment of a debt in money. If you will not pay it here and now, to what place will you bring the payment for it? i.e. when, and in what form, can your promise of a safe refuge (176 f.) be redeemed, if I am driven from Colonus? Ï€Î¿á¿– with a verb pregnantly used, as 476 Ï„á½¸ Î´â€™ á¼”Î½Î¸ÎµÎ½ Ï€Î¿á¿– Ï„ÎµÎ»ÎµÏ…Ï„á¿†ÏƒÎ±á½· Î¼Îµ Ï‡Ïá½µ; to what end am I to bring it? Cp. 383. For ÎºÎ±Ï„Î±Î¸á½µÏƒÎµÎ¹Ï‚ cp. Dem. In Mid. Â§ 99 Î¿á½ Î³á½±Ï á¼ÏƒÏ„Î¹Î½ á½„Ï†Î»Î·Î¼Î± á½… Ï„Î¹ Ï‡Ïá½´ ÎºÎ±Ï„Î±Î¸á½³Î½Ï„Î± á¼Ï€á½·Ï„Î¹Î¼Î¿Î½ Î³ÎµÎ½á½³ÏƒÎ¸Î±Î¹ Ï„Î¿Ï…Ï„Î¿Î½á½·, there is no debt (to the Treasury), by paying which he can recover the franchise. Î¿á½Î´ÎµÎ½á½¶ Î¼Î¿Î¹ÏÎ¹Î´á½·Î± Ï„á½·ÏƒÎ¹Ï‚ á¼”ÏÏ‡ÎµÏ„Î±Î¹, to no one comes punishment from fate, á½§Î½ (=Ï„Î¿á½»Ï„Ï‰Î½ á¼ƒ) Ï€ÏÎ¿Ï€á½±Î¸á¿ƒ, for things (caus. gen.) which he has already suffered, Ï„á½¸ Ï„á½·Î½ÎµÎ¹Î½ (acc.), in respect of his requiting them. Dem. or. 37 Â§ 59 á¼‚Î½ á¼‘Î»á½½Î½ Ï„Î¹Ï‚ á¼€ÎºÎ¿Ï…Ïƒá½·Î¿Ï… Ï†á½¹Î½Î¿Ï…...Î¼ÎµÏ„á½° Ï„Î±á¿¦Ï„â€™ Î±á¼°Î´á½³ÏƒÎ·Ï„Î±Î¹ ÎºÎ±á½¶ á¼€Ï†á¿‡ (with ref. to the kinsman of a slain man pardoning the involuntary slayer).

á¼€Î»Î»â€™, "Nay," opening the appeal: cp. O. T. 14. The second á¼€Î»Î»â€™ in 241 = "at least."

This whole Î¼á½³Î»Î¿Ï‚ á¼€Ï€á½¸ ÏƒÎºÎ·Î½á¿†Ï‚ of Antigone (237 â€” 253), with the tetrastichon of the Chorus (254 â€” 257), was rejected by some of the ancient critics, acc. to the schol. on L: "for they say it is better that Oed. should forthwith address his justification to them." But, as the schol. rightly adds, it is natural and graceful that an appeal to pity (á¼Î»ÎµÎµÎ¹Î½Î¿Î»Î¿Î³á½·Î±),â€” which the daughter makes,â€”should precede the father's appeal to reason (Ï„á½¸ Î´Î¹ÎºÎ±Î¹Î¿Î»Î¿Î³Î¹Îºá½¹Î½). The schol. further remarks that Didymus (circ. 30 B.C.) had not obelized any part of the passage. This is important, as making it most improbable that the á¼€Î¸á½³Ï„Î·ÏƒÎ¹Ï‚ rested on the absence of these verses from the older Alexandrian copies. Though the text is doubtful in some points, the internal evidence cannot be said to afford any good ground for suspicion.

Line 243

Hermann's Ï„Î¿á½Î¼Î¿á¿¦ Î¼á½¹Î½Î¿Ï… (for the MS. Ï„Î¿á¿¦ Î¼á½¹Î½Î¿Ï…) is metrically right, but Î¼á½¹Î½Î¿Ï… can hardly be sound. It must mean (1) "for my father alone" (and not for my own sake): not (2) "lonely, as he is": nor (3) "for my own father" (Campbell's view, which I do not comprehend). Î¤ÎŸÎ¥ÎœÎŸÎÎŸÎ¥ may have come from Î¤ÎŸÎ¥Î”Î‘Î˜Î›Î™ÎŸÎ¥ (Mekler), but Ï„á½¸Î½ á¼„Î¸Î»Î¹Î¿Î½ in 246 is against this (see, however, on 554). Perhaps Ï„Î¿á¿¦Î´â€™ á¼€Î¼Î¼á½¹ÏÎ¿Ï….

245 á½„Î¼Î¼Î± Ïƒá½¸Î½ á½„Î¼Î¼Î±ÏƒÎ¹Î½, á½¥Ï‚ Ï„Î¹Ï‚ á¼€Ï†â€™ Î±á¼µÎ¼Î±Ï„Î¿Ï‚ ğŸ—©
Line 245

á½¥Ï‚ Ï„Î¹Ï‚ Îº.Ï„.Î».: as if I were a young kinswoman of your own, appealing to you, the eldest of my house, for protection. The words are hardly so strong as "like daughter to father"; and though Ïƒá½¸Î½ is addressed to the coryphaeus (cp. on 175), this sense would be less fitting. So Creon imagines his niece Antigone appealing to the sacred ties of kinship (Ant. 487 Î–Î·Î½á½¸Ï‚ á¼‘ÏÎºÎµá½·Î¿Ï…; 658 á¼Ï†Ï…Î¼Î½Îµá½·Ï„Ï‰ Î”á½·Î± | Î¾á½»Î½Î±Î¹Î¼Î¿Î½).

Line 247

á¼Î½ á½”Î¼Î¼Î¹ ÎºÎµá½·Î¼ÎµÎ¸Î±, "we are situated" (not, "prostrate") "in your power": á¼Î½ á½”Î¼Î¼Î¹, penes vos, cp. 392, 422, 1443, O. T. 314 (n.), Dem. De Cor. Â§ 193 á¼Î½ Î³á½°Ï Ï„á¿· Î¸Îµá¿· Ï„Î¿á¿¦Ï„Î¿ Ï„á½¸ Ï„á½³Î»Î¿Ï‚ á¼¦Î½, Î¿á½Îº á¼Î½ á¼Î¼Î¿á½·. Line 254254-667: First episode

First á¼Ï€ÎµÎ¹Ïƒá½¹Î´Î¹Î¿Î½. Oedipus appeals to the Chorus, who resolve that Theseus shall decide (295). Ismene arrives from Thebes (324), with news of the war between her two brothers, and presently goes to perform the prescribed rites in the grove of the Eumenides (509). After a ÎºÎ¿Î¼Î¼á½¹Ï‚ (510â€”548) between Oedipus and the Chorus, Theseus enters, and assures Oedipus of protection.

Î¸ÎµÎ¿ÏƒÎµÎ²ÎµÏƒÏ„á½±Ï„Î±Ï‚. Athens is pre-eminently (1) religious, (2) compassionate towards the oppressed. Paus. 1.17.1 á¼ˆÎ¸Î·Î½Î±á½·Î¿Î¹Ï‚ Î´á½² á¼Î½ Ï„á¿‡ á¼€Î³Î¿Ïá¾· ÎºÎ±á½¶ á¼„Î»Î»Î± á¼ÏƒÏ„á½¶Î½ Î¿á½Îº á¼Ï‚ á½±Ï€Î±Î½Ï„Î±Ï‚ á¼Ï€á½·ÏƒÎ·Î¼Î± ÎºÎ±á½¶ á¼˜Î»á½³Î¿Ï… Î²Ï‰Î¼á½¹Ï‚, á¾§ Î¼á½±Î»Î¹ÏƒÏ„Î± Î¸Îµá¿¶Î½ á¼Ï‚ á¼€Î½Î¸Ïá½½Ï€Î¹Î½Î¿Î½ Î²á½·Î¿Î½ ÎºÎ±á½¶ Î¼ÎµÏ„Î±Î²Î¿Î»á½°Ï‚ Ï€ÏÎ±Î³Î¼á½±Ï„Ï‰Î½ á½…Ï„Î¹ á½ Ï†á½³Î»Î¹Î¼Î¿Ï‚, Î¼á½¹Î½Î¿Î¹ Ï„Î¹Î¼á½°Ï‚ á¼™Î»Î»á½µÎ½Ï‰Î½ Î½á½³Î¼Î¿Ï…ÏƒÎ¹Î½ á¼ˆÎ¸Î·Î½Î±á¿–Î¿Î¹. Ï„Î¿á½»Ï„Î¿Î¹Ï‚ Î´á½² Î¿á½ Ï„á½° á¼Ï‚ Ï†Î¹Î»Î±Î½Î¸ÏÏ‰Ï€á½·Î±Î½ Î¼á½¹Î½Î¿Î½ ÎºÎ±Î¸á½³ÏƒÏ„Î·ÎºÎµÎ½, á¼€Î»Î»á½° ÎºÎ±á½¶ á¼Ï‚ Î¸ÎµÎ¿á½ºÏ‚ Îµá½ÏƒÎµÎ²Î¿á¿¦ÏƒÎ¹Î½ á¼„Î»Î»Ï‰Î½ Ï€Î»á½³Î¿Î½Â· ÎºÎ±á½¶ Î‘á¼°Î´Î¿á¿¦Ï‚ ÏƒÏ†á½·ÏƒÎ¹ Î²Ï‰Î¼á½¹Ï‚ á¼ÏƒÏ„Î¹ ÎºÎ±á½¶ Î¦á½µÎ¼Î·Ï‚ ÎºÎ±á½¶ á½‰ÏÎ¼á¿†Ï‚.

Îµá¼¶Î½Î±Î¹, Î¼á½¹Î½Î±Ï‚ Î´á½² Ï„á½¸Î½ ÎºÎ±ÎºÎ¿á½»Î¼ÎµÎ½Î¿Î½ Î¾á½³Î½Î¿Î½ ğŸ—©
Line 261

Î¼á½¹Î½Î±Ï‚, not strictly "alone," but "more than all others": cp. O. T. 299 n.

Ï„á½¸Î½ ÎºÎ±ÎºÎ¿á½»Î¼ÎµÎ½Î¿Î½ Î¾á½³Î½Î¿Î½. The two standard instances were subsequent, in mythical date, to the time of Oedipus. (1) Theseus, at the prayer of Adrastus king of Argos, compels Creon and his Thebans to permit the burial of the Argive warriors who had fallen in the war of Eteocles and Polynices. This is the subject of the Supplices of Eur., which continues the story of the Antigone and the Phoenissae. (2) Demophon, the son of Theseus, protects the children of Hercules against the Argive Eurystheus. This is the subject of the Heracleidae of Eur.

These two examples are cited in Her. 9.27; in the spurious á¼Ï€Î¹Ï„á½±Ï†Î¹Î¿Ï‚ ascribed to Lysias (or. 2 Â§Â§ 4-16); and in that ascribed to Demosthenes (or. 60 Â§Â§ 7, 8). Isocrates quotes them in the Panegyricus, as showing how the Athenians Î´Î¹ÎµÏ„á½³Î»ÎµÏƒÎ±Î½ Ï„á½´Î½ Ï€á½¹Î»Î¹Î½ ÎºÎ¿Î¹Î½á½´Î½ Ï€Î±Ïá½³Ï‡Î¿Î½Ï„ÎµÏ‚ ÎºÎ±á½¶ Ï„Î¿á¿–Ï‚ á¼€Î´Î¹ÎºÎ¿Ï…Î¼á½³Î½Î¿Î¹Ï‚ á¼€Îµá½¶ Ï„á¿¶Î½ á¼™Î»Î»á½µÎ½Ï‰Î½ á¼Ï€Î±Î¼á½»Î½Î¿Ï…ÏƒÎ±Î½ ï¼ˆÂ§ 52); also in his Encomium Helenae Â§ 31; and again in his Panathenaicus, where he remarks that Tragedy has made them familiar to all (Â§ 168 Ï„á½·Ï‚ Î¿á½Îº á¼€Îºá½µÎºÎ¿Îµ Ï„á¿¶Î½ Ï„ÏÎ±Î³á¿³Î´Î¿Î´Î¹Î´Î±ÏƒÎºá½±Î»Ï‰Î½ Î”Î¹Î¿Î½Ï…Ïƒá½·Î¿Î¹Ï‚;). They figure, too, in the Platonic Menexenus, with the comment that Athens might justly be accused of too great compassion, and too much zeal for "the weaker cause": á½¡Ï‚ á¼€Îµá½¶ Î»á½·Î±Î½ Ï†Î¹Î»Î¿Î¹ÎºÏ„á½·ÏÎ¼Ï‰Î½ á¼ÏƒÏ„á½¶ ÎºÎ±á½¶ Ï„Î¿á¿¦ á¼¥Ï„Ï„Î¿Î½Î¿Ï‚ Î¸ÎµÏÎ±Ï€á½·Ï‚, 244 E. Line 262

Ïƒá¿´Î¶ÎµÎ¹Î½, to give him a safe refuge: á¼€ÏÎºÎµá¿–Î½, to come to his rescue (El. 322 á¼ÏƒÎ¸Î»á½¹Ï‚, á½¥ÏƒÏ„â€™ á¼€ÏÎºÎµá¿–Î½ Ï†á½·Î»Î¿Î¹Ï‚), if anyone seeks to take him thence by force.

Îºá¼„Î¼Î¿Î¹Î³Îµ Ï€Î¿á¿¦ Ï„Î¿á¿¦Ï„â€™ á¼ÏƒÏ„á½·Î½, Î¿á¼µÏ„Î¹Î½ÎµÏ‚ Î²á½±Î¸ÏÏ‰Î½ ğŸ—©

Îºá¼„Î¼Î¿Î¹Î³Îµ Ï€Î¿á¿¦. ÎºÎ±á½·, prefixed to interrogative words (as Ï€Î¿á¿¦, Ï€á¿¶Ï‚, Ï€Î¿á¿–Î¿Ï‚, Ï„á½·Ï‚), makes the query an indignant comment on a preceding statement: El. 236: Dem. De Fals. Legat. Â§ 232 ÎºÎ±á½¶ Ï„á½·Ï‚, á½¦ á¼„Î½Î´ÏÎµÏ‚ á¼ˆÎ¸Î·Î½Î±á¿–Î¿Î¹, Ï„Î¿á¿¦Ï„â€™ á¼°Î´á½¼Î½ Ï„á½¸ Ï€Î±Ïá½±Î´ÎµÎ¹Î³Î¼Î± Î´á½·ÎºÎ±Î¹Î¿Î½ Î±á½‘Ï„á½¸Î½ Ï€Î±ÏÎ±ÏƒÏ‡Îµá¿–Î½ á¼Î¸ÎµÎ»á½µÏƒÎµÎ¹;

Î¿á¼µÏ„Î¹Î½ÎµÏ‚, causal, as if Ï€Î±Ïâ€™ á½‘Î¼á¿–Î½ had preceded: hence=á¼Ï€Îµá½¶ á½‘Î¼Îµá¿–Ï‚. Cp. 427, 866. Thuc. 4.26 á¼€Î¸Ï…Î¼á½·Î±Î½ Ï„Îµ Ï€Î»Îµá½·ÏƒÏ„Î·Î½ á½ Ï‡Ïá½¹Î½Î¿Ï‚ Ï€Î±ÏÎµá¿–Ï‡Îµ Ï€Î±Ïá½° Î»á½¹Î³Î¿Î½ á¼Ï€Î¹Î³Î¹Î³Î½á½¹Î¼ÎµÎ½Î¿Ï‚, Î¿á½“Ï‚ ï¼ˆ á½…Ï„Î¹ Î±á½Ï„Î¿á½ºÏ‚ ï¼‰ á¾¤Î¿Î½Ï„Î¿ á¼¡Î¼ÎµÏá¿¶Î½ á½€Î»á½·Î³Ï‰Î½ á¼ÎºÏ€Î¿Î»Î¹Î¿ÏÎºá½µÏƒÎµÎ¹Î½, since they had thought to reduce them in a few days. 1. 68 Î½á¿¦Î½ Î´á½² Ï„á½· Î´Îµá¿– Î¼Î±ÎºÏÎ·Î³Î¿ÏÎµá¿–Î½, á½§Î½ ï¼ˆ = á¼Ï€Îµá½¶ á¼¡Î¼á¿¶Î½ ï¼‰ Ï„Î¿á½ºÏ‚ Î¼á½²Î½ Î´ÎµÎ´Î¿Ï…Î»Ï‰Î¼á½³Î½Î¿Ï…Ï‚ á½Ïá¾¶Ï„Îµ...; 6. 68 Ï€Î¿Î»Î»á¿‡ Î¼á½²Î½ Ï€Î±ÏÎ±Î¹Î½á½³ÏƒÎµÎ¹...Ï„á½· Î´Îµá¿– Ï‡Ïá¿†ÏƒÎ¸Î±Î¹, Î¿á¼³ Ï€á½±ÏÎµÏƒÎ¼ÎµÎ½ á¼Ï€á½¶ Ï„á½¸Î½ Î±á½Ï„á½¸Î½ á¼€Î³á¿¶Î½Î±; 8. 76 Â§ 6 (Î¿á¼µ Î³Îµ). Ai. 457 Ï„á½· Ï‡Ïá½´ Î´Ïá¾¶Î½; á½…ÏƒÏ„Î¹Ï‚ á¼Î¼Ï†Î±Î½á¿¶Ï‚ Î¸ÎµÎ¿á¿–Ï‚ | á¼Ï‡Î¸Î±á½·ÏÎ¿Î¼Î±Î¹. Cp. O. T. 1228 n.: Ph. 1364.

á¼Îº Ï„á¿¶Î½Î´á½³ Î¼â€™ á¼Î¾á½±ÏÎ±Î½Ï„ÎµÏ‚ Îµá¼¶Ï„â€™ á¼Î»Î±á½»Î½ÎµÏ„Îµ, ğŸ—©
Line 264

As 276 shows, á¼Î¾á½±ÏÎ±Î½Ï„ÎµÏ‚ refers to his first seat, in the grove. They had induced him to leave that seat (174 ff.), on a pledge that no one should remove him from the resting-place outside of the grove. Yet now they command him to quit Attica (á¼Î»Î±á½»Î½ÎµÏ„Îµ: 226 á¼”Î¾Ï‰...Î²Î±á½·Î½ÎµÏ„Îµ Ï‡á½½ÏÎ±Ï‚).

Ï„á½±Î´Îµ Î²á½±Î¸ÏÎ± denote, generally, the seats afforded by the natural rock in or near the grove: here he is thinking specially of the Î²á½±Î¸ÏÎ¿Î½ á¼€ÏƒÎºá½³Ï€Î±ÏÎ½Î¿Î½ (101) within its precincts.

265 á½„Î½Î¿Î¼Î± Î¼á½¹Î½Î¿Î½ Î´Îµá½·ÏƒÎ±Î½Ï„ÎµÏ‚; Î¿á½ Î³á½°Ï Î´á½´ Ï„á½¹ Î³Îµ ğŸ—©
Line 265

Line 266

á¼Ï€Îµá½¶ â€¦ á¼”Î¾Î¿Î¹Î´Î±. I am "a man more sinned against than sinning" ï¼ˆLear 3. 2. 60),â€”as would appear, could I unfold to you my relations with my parents (Ï„á½° Î¼Î·Ï„Ïá½¸Ï‚ ÎºÎ±á½¶ Ï€Î±Ï„Ïá½¹Ï‚), on account of which relations (the parricide and the incestâ€” á½§Î½ neuter) ye dread me. Of that I am sure. (For those relations began with their casting out their new-born son to perish. That first wrong led to the rest: hence it was that I knew not the face of my assailant in the pass, or of my bride at Thebes.)

Ï€ÎµÏ€Î¿Î½Î¸á½¹Ï„â€™ á¼ÏƒÏ„á½¶ Î¼á¾¶Î»Î»Î¿Î½ á¼¢ Î´ÎµÎ´ÏÎ±Îºá½¹Ï„Î±, ğŸ—©
Line 267

Ï€ÎµÏ€Î¿Î½Î¸á½¹Ï„â€™ â€¦ Î´ÎµÎ´ÏÎ±Îºá½¹Ï„Î±. The agent's activities (Ï„á½° á¼”ÏÎ³Î± Î¼Î¿Ï…) here stand for the agent himself; and so, instead of Ï„Î¿á¿–Ï‚ á¼”ÏÎ³Î¿Î¹Ï‚ Ï€ÎµÏ€Î¿Î½Î¸á½½Ï‚ Îµá¼°Î¼Î¹ (cp. 873), we have Ï„á½° á¼”ÏÎ³Î± Î¼Î¿Ï… Ï€ÎµÏ€Î¿Î½Î¸á½¹Ï„â€™ á¼ÏƒÏ„á½·. (Cp. 74, 1604.) O. T. 1214 Î³á½±Î¼Î¿Ï‚Â· Ï„ÎµÎºÎ½á¿¶Î½ ÎºÎ±á½¶ Ï„ÎµÎºÎ½Î¿á½»Î¼ÎµÎ½Î¿Ï‚ = one in which the son has become the spouse. So a particular activity of a person's mind is sometimes expressed by the active participle (neut.) of a verb to which the person himself would properly be subject: Ï„á½¸ Î²Î¿Ï…Î»á½¹Î¼ÎµÎ½Î¿Î½, Ï„á½¸ á½€ÏÎ³Î¹Î¶á½¹Î¼ÎµÎ½Î¿Î½ Ï„á¿†Ï‚ Î³Î½á½½Î¼Î·Ï‚ (Thuc. 1.90, 2. 59): Ï„á½¸ Î´ÎµÎ´Î¹á½¹Ï‚, Ï„á½¸ Î¸Î±ÏÏƒÎ¿á¿¦Î½ Î±á½Ï„Î¿á¿¦ (1. 36).

Îµá¼´ ÏƒÎ¿Î¹ Ï„á½° Î¼Î·Ï„Ïá½¸Ï‚ ÎºÎ±á½¶ Ï€Î±Ï„Ïá½¸Ï‚ Ï‡ÏÎµá½·Î· Î»á½³Î³ÎµÎ¹Î½,

270 á¼”Î¾Î¿Î¹Î´Î±. ÎºÎ±á½·Ï„Î¿Î¹ Ï€á¿¶Ï‚ á¼Î³á½¼ ÎºÎ±Îºá½¸Ï‚ Ï†á½»ÏƒÎ¹Î½, ğŸ—©
Line 270

"Ye shrink from me as from a guilty man. And yet (ÎºÎ±á½·Ï„Î¿Î¹),â€” evil as were my acts (in themselves),â€” how have I shown an evil disposition (Ï†á½»ÏƒÎ¹Î½), or incurred moral guilt? Before I struck my father, he had struck me (Ï€Î±Î¸á½¼Î½ á¼€Î½Ï„á½³Î´ÏÏ‰Î½: see O. T. 809). Even if I had been aware (Ï†ÏÎ¿Î½á¿¶Î½) who he was, I might plead this in my defence: but, in fact, I did not know. Nor did I recognise my mother. They, on the other hand, had deliberately tried to kill their babe." â€” Note that the clause á½¥ÏƒÏ„â€™ Îµá¼° Ï†ÏÎ¿Î½á¿¶Î½ â€¦ ÎºÎ±Îºá½¹Ï‚, which could not apply to the incest, limits the reference of á¼€Î½Ï„á½³Î´ÏÏ‰Î½ to the parricide; while á¼±Îºá½¹Î¼Î·Î½ (273) refers to both stains.

á½…ÏƒÏ„Î¹Ï‚ Ï€Î±Î¸á½¼Î½ Î¼á½²Î½ á¼€Î½Ï„á½³Î´ÏÏ‰Î½, á½¥ÏƒÏ„â€™ Îµá¼° Ï†ÏÎ¿Î½á¿¶Î½ ğŸ—©
Line 271

He has two distinct pleas, (1) provocation, and (2) ignorance. These could have been expressed by á¼€Î½Ï„á½³Î´ÏÏ‰Î½ (1) Ï€Î±Î¸á½¼Î½ Î¼á½³Î½, (2) Îµá¼°Î´á½¼Ï‚ Î´â€™ Î¿á½Î´á½³Î½. But (2) is forestalled by the thought that, if he had known, (1) would have excused him. This hypothesis is then contrasted with the fact (273); and the fact on his side is next contrasted with the fact on the other (274). Hence Ï€Î±Î¸á½¼Î½ Î¼á½³Î½ has no clause really answering to it; for Î½á¿¦Î½ Î´) answers to Îµá¼° Ï†ÏÎ¿Î½á¿¶Î½, and á½‘Ï†â€™ á½§Î½ Î´) to Î¿á½Î´á½²Î½ Îµá¼°Î´á½½Ï‚. The impf. (á¼€Î½Ï„á½³Î´ÏÏ‰Î½) expresses the situation ("I was retaliating"): the aor. (273), an act accomplished at a definite moment.

Î¼Î¿á½·ÏÎ±Ï‚ Ï€Î¿Î¹Îµá¿–ÏƒÎ¸Îµ Î¼Î·Î´Î±Î¼á¿¶Ï‚Â· á¼¡Î³Îµá¿–ÏƒÎ¸Îµ Î´á½² ğŸ—©
Line 278

Î¼Î¿á½·ÏÎ±Î¹Ï‚ Ï€Î¿Îµá¿–ÏƒÎ¸Îµ could not stand for á¼Î½ Î¼Î¿á½·ÏÎ±Î¹Ï‚ Ï€Î¿Î¹Îµá¿–ÏƒÎ¸Îµ. The prep. á¼Î½ is indispensable. See the discussion of this passage in the Appendix. The gentlest remedy would be Î¼Î¿á½·ÏÎ±Ï‚ (as gen. sing.), which two MSS. have. As á¼Î½ Î¿á½Î´ÎµÎ½á½¶ Î»á½¹Î³á¿³ Ï€Î¿Î¹Îµá¿–ÏƒÎ¸Î±Î¹ (Her. 3.50) and á¼Î½ Î¿á½Î´ÎµÎ¼Î¹á¾· Î¼Î¿á½·Ïá¾³ á¼„Î³ÎµÎ¹Î½ (2. 172) are parallel phrases, so Î¿á½Î´ÎµÎ½á½¸Ï‚ Î»á½¹Î³Î¿Ï… Ï€Î¿Î¹Îµá¿–ÏƒÎ¸Î±Î¹ (1. 33) might suggest Î¿á½Î´ÎµÎ¼Î¹á¾¶Ï‚ Î¼Î¿á½·ÏÎ±Ï‚ Ï€Î¿Î¹Îµá¿–ÏƒÎ¸Î±Î¹. For the two negatives cp. El. 336 ÎºÎ±á½¶ Î¼á½´ Î´Î¿ÎºÎµá¿–Î½ Î¼á½²Î½ Î´Ïá¾¶Î½ Ï„Î¹ Ï€Î·Î¼Î±á½·Î½ÎµÎ¹Î½ Î´á½² Î¼á½µ, "and not to seem active yet do no harm." It is hollow, Oed. says, to insist so strictly on the sanctity of a grove (Î¸ÎµÎ¿á½ºÏ‚ Ï„Î¹Î¼á¿¶Î½Ï„ÎµÏ‚), and then to refuse the gods their Î¼Î¿á¿–ÏÎ±, their due tribute of practical piety. You treat the gods as if they were not, when at their shrines you do á¼€Î½á½¹ÏƒÎ¹Î± á¼”ÏÎ³Î± (283) by violating your pledge to a suppliant.

Ï€Î¿Îµá¿–ÏƒÎ¸Îµ. Numerous Attic inscriptions of the 5th and 4th cent. B.C. show that in this verb Î¹ was regularly omitted before ÎµÎ¹ or Î· (Ï€Î¿Îµá¿–, Ï€Î¿á½µÏƒÎµÎ¹), though never before Î¿Ï…, Î¿Î¹, or Ï‰ (á¼Ï€Î¿á½·Î¿Ï…Î½, Ï€Î¿Î¹Î¿á½·Î·, Ï€Î¿Î¹á¿¶Î½: Meisterhans, p. 27). L generally, but not always, omits the Î¹ before ÎµÎ¹ or Î· if the syll. is short. Forms from Ï€Î¿Î¹á¿¶, with the 1st syll. short, occur below in 459, 584, 652, 1018, 1033, 1037, 1144. In 584 and 652, as here, L keeps the Î¹: in the other five places it omits it. In 1517, where the quantity is different, L has Ï€Î¿Îµá¿–Î½.

Ï†Ï‰Ï„á½¸Ï‚ â€¦ Î²ÏÎ¿Ï„á¿¶Î½, no wight among mortals, no one in the world. In Ai. 1358 Ï„Î¿Î¹Î¿á½·Î´Îµ Î¼á½³Î½Ï„Î¿Î¹ Ï†á¿¶Ï„ÎµÏ‚ á¼”Î¼Ï€Î»Î·ÎºÏ„Î¿Î¹ Î²ÏÎ¿Ï„á¿¶Î½, though Î²ÏÎ¿Ï„Î¿á¿–Ï‚ is a specious variant, Î²ÏÎ¿Ï„á¿¶Î½ has the better authority: cp. Î¾á½ºÎ½ Î¿á¼·Ï‚ Ïƒá½º Î¼á½´ Îºá½±Î»Ï…Ï€Ï„Îµ Ï„á½°Ï‚ Îµá½Î´Î±á½·Î¼Î¿Î½Î±Ï‚ ğŸ—©

Î¾á½ºÎ½ Î¿á¼·Ï‚, Ïƒá½ºÎ½ Ï„Î¿á¿–Ï‚ Î¸ÎµÎ¿á¿–Ï‚ (schol.), "with whose help," since the gods strengthen men to refrain from evil, as well as to do good.

Î¼á½´ Îºá½±Î»Ï…Ï€Ï„Îµ, as with a veil (Îºá½±Î»Ï…Î¼Î¼Î±) of dishonour cast over her bright fame: cp. Il. 17.591 Ï„á½¸Î½ Î´â€™ á¼…Ï‡ÎµÎ¿Ï‚ Î½ÎµÏ†á½³Î»Î· á¼Îºá½±Î»Ï…ÏˆÎµ Î¼á½³Î»Î±Î¹Î½Î±. Ï„á½°Ï‚ Îµá½Î´Î±á½·Î¼Î¿Î½Î±Ï‚: Her. 8.111 Î»á½³Î³Î¿Î½Ï„ÎµÏ‚ á½¡Ï‚ ÎºÎ±Ï„á½° Î»á½¹Î³Î¿Î½ á¼¦ÏƒÎ±Î½ á¼„ÏÎ± Î±á¼± á¼ˆÎ¸á¿†Î½Î±Î¹ Î¼ÎµÎ³á½±Î»Î±Î¹ Ï„Îµ ÎºÎ±á½¶ Îµá½Î´Î±á½·Î¼Î¿Î½ÎµÏ‚.

á¼”ÏÎ³Î¿Î¹Ï‚ á¼ˆÎ¸á½µÎ½Î±Ï‚ á¼€Î½Î¿Ïƒá½·Î¿Î¹Ï‚ á½‘Ï€Î·ÏÎµÏ„á¿¶Î½,

Line 284

á¼”Î»Î±Î²ÎµÏ‚, since Oed. put himself into their hands when he left sanctuary (174 f.).

Ï„á½¸Î½ á¼±Îºá½³Ï„Î·Î½, cp. 44, 487.

á¼Ï‡á½³Î³Î³Ï…Î¿Î½, having received your á¼Î³Î³á½»Î·, pledge, that I should not be wronged (176). Î§Î¿. Ï€Î±Ï„Ïá¿·Î¿Î½ á¼„ÏƒÏ„Ï… Î³á¿†Ï‚ á¼”Ï‡ÎµÎ¹Â· ÏƒÎºÎ¿Ï€á½¸Ï‚ Î´á½³ Î½Î¹Î½, ğŸ—©
Line 297

Ï€Î±Ï„Ïá¿·Î¿Î½ á¼„ÏƒÏ„Ï… Î³á¿†Ï‚, not for Ï€Î±Ï„Ïá¿´Î±Ï‚ Î³á¿†Ï‚ á¼„ÏƒÏ„Ï…, but simply "his father's city in the land" (the gen. Î³á¿†Ï‚ as 45), i.e. the city from which Aegeus (69) had swayed Attica. The poets can use Ï€Î±Ï„Ïá¿·Î¿Ï‚ as=Ï€á½±Ï„ÏÎ¹Î¿Ï‚; but in the mouth of Oed. (O. T. 1450) Ï€Î±Ï„Ïá¿·Î¿Î½ á¼„ÏƒÏ„Ï… means the city of LaÃ¯us, and in that of Ant. (Ant. 937) the city of Oedipus: on the other hand, Ï„á½° Ï€á½±Ï„ÏÎ¹Î±...Î´á½½Î¼Î±Ï„Î± (O. T. 1394), his "ancestral" home.

á¼”Ï‡ÎµÎ¹ = "is in," cp. 37. Isocrates conceives the line of hereditary Attic kings as having been unbroken from Erichthonius down to Theseus (Panath. Â§ 126). The greatness of Athens as the centre of government was reputed to date from Theseus; but the royal seat of his predecessors was supposed to have been a lesser Athens (the acropolis and the part south of it. Thuc. 2.15), from which they swayed Attica while its communes were still independent (ÏƒÏ€Î¿Ïá½±Î´Î·Î½ ÎºÎ±á½¶ ÎºÎ±Ï„á½° Îºá½½Î¼Î±Ï‚ Î¿á¼°ÎºÎ¿á¿¦ÏƒÎ±Î½, Isocr. Encom. Helen. Â§ 35).

ÏƒÎºÎ¿Ï€á½¸Ï‚ refers to the quality in which the man of Colonus had presented himself to Oed. (35), and so helps him at once to know who is meant. The word can mean "messenger" only in the sense of "one sent to obtain news"; but we need not change it, as Wecklein does, to Ï€Î¿Î¼Ï€á½¹Ï‚.

á½ƒÏ‚ Îºá¼€Î¼á½² Î´Îµá¿¦Ïâ€™ á¼”Ï€ÎµÎ¼ÏˆÎµÎ½, Î¿á¼´Ï‡ÎµÏ„Î±Î¹ ÏƒÏ„ÎµÎ»á¿¶Î½. ğŸ—©
Line 298

Îºá¼€Î¼á½²: see on 53.

á¼”Ï€ÎµÎ¼ÏˆÎµÎ½ is better here than á¼”Ï€ÎµÎ¼Ï€ÎµÎ½, which could only mean, "was our summoner."

ÏƒÏ„ÎµÎ»á¿¶Î½, to make him set forth, to fetch him: O. T. 860 Ï€á½³Î¼ÏˆÎ¿Î½ Ï„Î¹Î½á½° ÏƒÏ„ÎµÎ»Î¿á¿¦Î½Ï„Î±.

ÎŸá¼°. á¼¦ ÎºÎ±á½¶ Î´Î¿ÎºÎµá¿–Ï„Îµ Ï„Î¿á¿¦ Ï„Ï…Ï†Î»Î¿á¿¦ Ï„Î¹Î½â€™ á¼Î½Ï„ÏÎ¿Ï€á½´Î½ ğŸ—©
Line 299299-307

Wecklein brackets these nine verses, thinking that they arose from a misunderstanding of 551-554. Theseus divined the name of Oedipus from the description of his person; but these vv. were inserted by one who thought it necessary to explain how Theseus knew the name. I hold the verses to be genuine. The Î¾á½³Î½Î¿Ï‚ must have been sent to Athens by the Chorus before they came to the grove (117), and could not, therefore, know the name of Oedipus (first disclosed at 222). He could only tell Theseus that there was a blind stranger at Colonus, who hinted at his own power to confer benefits (72), and who looked noble (76). Theseus, on entering (551), at once greets Oedipus by name, though he had never seen him before (68). He had divined the identity through a knowledge of the history (553) â€” i.e. he started from Athens on the strength of what the Î¾á½³Î½Î¿Ï‚ could tell. And on the way to Colonus (adds Theseus) he has been made certain of the fact (554) â€” i.e. he had heard the name. Now, it was precisely for such certainty that the dramatist meant this passage to provide. He felt that otherwise there might have been too great improbability in the instant confidence of the recognition by Theseus.

300 á¼¢ Ï†ÏÎ¿Î½Ï„á½·Î´â€™, á¼•Î¾ÎµÎ¹Î½, Î±á½Ï„á½¸Î½ á½¥ÏƒÏ„â€™ á¼Î»Î¸Îµá¿–Î½ Ï€á½³Î»Î±Ï‚; ğŸ—©
Line 300

Join Î±á½Ï„á½¸Î½ with á¼Î»Î¸Îµá¿–Î½, not with á¼•Î¾ÎµÎ¹Î½: cp. O. T. 6 á¼Î³á½¼ Î´Î¹ÎºÎ±Î¹á¿¶Î½ Î¼á½´ Ï€Î±Ïâ€™ á¼€Î³Î³á½³Î»Ï‰Î½, Ï„á½³ÎºÎ½Î±, á¼„Î»Î»Ï‰Î½ á¼€ÎºÎ¿á½»ÎµÎ¹Î½ Î±á½Ï„á½¸Ï‚ á½§Î´â€™ á¼Î»á½µÎ»Ï…Î¸Î±.

ÎŸá¼°. Ï„á½·Ï‚ Î´â€™ á¼”ÏƒÎ¸â€™ á½ ÎºÎµá½·Î½á¿³ Ï„Î¿á¿¦Ï„Î¿ Ï„Î¿á½”Ï€Î¿Ï‚ á¼€Î³Î³ÎµÎ»á¿¶Î½;
Î§Î¿. Î¼Î±ÎºÏá½° Îºá½³Î»ÎµÏ…Î¸Î¿Ï‚Â· Ï€Î¿Î»Î»á½° Î´â€™ á¼Î¼Ï€á½¹ÏÏ‰Î½ á¼”Ï€Î· ğŸ—©
Line 303

Îºá½³Î»ÎµÏ…Î¸Î¿Ï‚: cp. 164. Some wayfarers, passing by Colonus towards Athens, may have heard the prolonged tumult of horror which greeted the name of Oedipus (222). As the distance to the city is more than a mile, there will be many chances for the news to be caught up from their lips, and carried to Theseus.

ÎºÎµá¼° Î²ÏÎ±Î´á½ºÏ‚ Îµá½•Î´ÎµÎ¹, even if he is reposing (from affairs), and is unwilling to move.

Î²ÏÎ±Î´á½»Ï‚ here=indisposed to exertion (as Î²ÏÎ±Î´á½»Ï‚ is joined with Î¼Î±Î»Î±Îºá½¹Ï‚ in Plat. Polit. 307A, and Î²ÏÎ±Î´á½»Ï„Î·Ï‚ with á¼¡ÏƒÏ…Ï‡Î¹á½¹Ï„Î·Ï‚ in Charm. 160 B).

ÎºÎ»á½»Ï‰Î½ ÏƒÎ¿á¿¦ (gen. of connection), hearing about thee, El. 317 Ï„Î¿á¿¦ ÎºÎ±ÏƒÎ¹Î³Î½á½µÏ„Î¿Ï… Ï„á½· Ï†á½µÏ‚; Ph. 439 á¼€Î½Î±Î¾á½·Î¿Ï… Î¼á½²Î½ Ï†Ï‰Ï„á½¸Ï‚ á¼Î¾ÎµÏá½µÏƒÎ¿Î¼Î±Î¹: Od. 11.174 Îµá¼°Ï€á½² Î´á½³ Î¼Î¿Î¹ Ï€Î±Ï„Ïá½¹Ï‚ Ï„Îµ ÎºÎ±á½¶ vá¼±á½³Î¿Ï‚. Cp. 355.

ÎŸá¼°. á¼€Î»Î»â€™ Îµá½Ï„Ï…Ï‡á½´Ï‚ á¼µÎºÎ¿Î¹Ï„Î¿ Ï„á¿‡ Î¸â€™ Î±á½‘Ï„Î¿á¿¦ Ï€á½¹Î»ÎµÎ¹
á¼Î¼Î¿á½· Ï„ÎµÂ· Ï„á½·Ï‚ Î³á½°Ï á¼ÏƒÎ¸Î»á½¸Ï‚ Î¿á½Ï‡ Î±á½‘Ï„á¿· Ï†á½·Î»Î¿Ï‚; ğŸ—©
Line 309

Ï„á½·Ï‚ Î³á½°Ï á¼ÏƒÎ¸Î»á½¹Ï‚. Oedipus has hinted to the Chorus that he brings á½„Î½Î·ÏƒÎ¹Î½ á¼€ÏƒÏ„Î¿á¿–Ï‚ Ï„Î¿á¿–ÏƒÎ´Îµ, but has reserved all explanation of his meaning until Theseus shall arrive (288ï¼‰. His exclamation here again touches on his secret; but, instead of interpreting Îµá½Ï„Ï…Ï‡á½µÏ‚, he turns it off, for the present, by a quickly-added commonplace. "Does not experience, indeed, teach us that the benefactor of others is often his own?" The generous man, though he acts from no calculation of self-interest, actually serves himself by making zealous friends. Like thoughts are found in many popular shapes elsewhere: Il. 13.734 (Î¿Ï† Ï„Î·Îµ Î¼Î±Î½ Ï‰Î¹Ï„Î· Î½á½¹Î¿Ï‚ á¼ÏƒÎ¸Î»á½¹Ï‚ï¼‰ ÎºÎ±á½· Ï„Îµ Ï€Î¿Î»á½³Î±Ï‚ á¼Ïƒá½±Ï‰ÏƒÎµ, Î¼á½±Î»Î¹ÏƒÏ„á½± Ï„á½³ Îºâ€™ Î±á½Ï„á½¸Ï‚ á¼€Î½á½³Î³Î½Ï‰, "he saveth many, yea, and he himself best recognises (the worth of wisdom)": Menander Sentent. 141 á¼ÏƒÎ¸Î»á¿· Î³á½°Ï á¼€Î½Î´Ïá½· [ Î³â€™ ] á¼ÏƒÎ¸Î»á½° ÎºÎ±á½¶ Î´Î¹Î´Î¿á¿– Î¸Îµá½¹Ï‚: ib. 391 Î¾á½³Î½Î¿Î¹Ï‚ á¼Ï€Î±ÏÎºá¿¶Î½ Ï„á¿¶Î½ á¼´ÏƒÏ‰Î½ Ï„Îµá½»Î¾á¿ƒ Ï€Î¿Ï„á½³: Hortat. 23 á½ Ï‡ÏÎ·ÏƒÏ„á½¹Ï‚, á½¡Ï‚ á¼”Î¿Î¹ÎºÎµ, ÎºÎ±á½¶ Ï‡ÏÎ·ÏƒÏ„Î¿á½ºÏ‚ Ï€Î¿Î¹Îµá¿–: pseudo - Philem. ap. Boissonad. Anecd. 1. 147 Î¼ÎµÏ„á½³ÏÏ‡ÎµÏ„Î±Î¹ Ï„á½¸ Î´á½·ÎºÎ±Î¹Î¿Î½ Îµá¼°Ï‚ Ï€Î»ÎµÎ¿Î½ÎµÎ¾á½·Î±Î½. Conversely, Î¿á¼· Î±á½Ï„á¿· ÎºÎ±Îºá½° Ï„Îµá½»Ï‡ÎµÎ¹ á¼€Î½á½´Ï á¼„Î»Î»á¿³ ÎºÎ±Îºá½° Ï„Îµá½»Ï‡Ï‰Î½ (Hes. Opp. 265), Î»á½·Î±Î½ Ï†Î¹Î»á¿¶Î½ ÏƒÎµÎ±Ï…Ï„á½¸Î½ Î¿á½Î´â€™ á¼•Î¾ÎµÎ¹Ï‚ Ï†á½·Î»Î¿Î½ (Men. Sent. 310). We should not suppose a suppressed clause: ("I do not say, to himself,") "for what good man is not a friend to himself?" The interest of the king is identified with that of his realm. To distinguish them so sharply is unfitting here. Cp. 1124, 1496, 1553. The conjecture á¼”ÏƒÎ¸â€™ á½ƒÏ‚ (for á¼ÏƒÎ¸Î»á½¸Ï‚) makes Oed. apologise for the selfishness of á¼Î¼Î¿á½· Ï„Îµ: "for who is not his own friend?" (!)

á¼ˆÎ½. 310 á½¦ Î–Îµá¿¦, Ï„á½· Î»á½³Î¾Ï‰; Ï€Î¿á¿– Ï†ÏÎµÎ½á¿¶Î½ á¼”Î»Î¸Ï‰, Ï€á½±Ï„ÎµÏ; ğŸ—©
Line 310

Line 311

Line 312

Î‘á¼°Ï„Î½Î±á½·Î±Ï‚ â€¦ Ï€á½½Î»Î¿Ï…, not seen, of course, by the spectators: Ismene leaves it with her servant (334), and enters on foot (320). Sicily having a reputation both for its horses (Oppian Cyneg. 1. 170) and for its mules (Photius 366. 12), some understand a mule here, as that animal (with an easy saddle, á¼€ÏƒÏ„Ïá½±Î²Î·) was much used for such journeys. But though Ï€á¿¶Î»Î¿Ï‚, with a defining word (as Ï„á¿¶Î½ ÎºÎ±Î¼á½µÎ»Ï‰Î½ Arist. Hist. An. 1.1.47, Îºá½»Î½ÎµÎ¿Î¹ Anthol. 12. 238) could denote the young of animals other than the horse, Ï€á¿¶Î»Î¿Ï‚ alone would always mean a young horse.

Î‘á¼°Ï„Î½Î±á½·Î±Ï‚ implies some choice breed, as in Theophr. Char. XXI (=VII in my 1st ed.) the Î¼Î¹ÎºÏÎ¿Ï†Î¹Î»á½¹Ï„Î¹Î¼Î¿Ï‚ buys Î›Î±ÎºÏ‰Î½Î¹Îºá½°Ï‚ Îºá½»Î½Î±Ï‚, Î£Î¹ÎºÎµÎ»Î¹Îºá½°Ï‚ Ï€ÎµÏÎ¹ÏƒÏ„ÎµÏá½±Ï‚, etc. In Aristoph. Pax 73 the Î‘á¼°Ï„Î½Î±á¿–Î¿Ï‚ Î¼á½³Î³Î¹ÏƒÏ„Î¿Ï‚ Îºá½±Î½Î¸Î±ÏÎ¿Ï‚ is not a mere joke on the Etna breed of horses, but alludes to a species of beetle actually found there (cp. Aesch. fr. 229, Plato Com. e(ort. fr. 13, quoted by schol. ad loc.).

Line 313

ÎºÏÎ±Ï„á½¶: locative dat., "on her head," rather than dat. of interest with á¼¡Î»Î¹Î¿ÏƒÏ„ÎµÏá½´Ï‚, "for her head." The á¼¡Î»Î¹Î¿ÏƒÏ„ÎµÏá½µÏ‚ of the MSS. is a very strange word. It ought to mean "deprived of the sun": cp. Î²Î¹Î¿ÏƒÏ„ÎµÏá½µÏ‚ 747, á½€Î¼Î¼Î±Ï„Î¿ÏƒÏ„ÎµÏá½µÏ‚ 1260. Even with an active sense, "depriving of the sun," it is awkward. It could not mean "sun-averting." In Aesch. Suppl. 1063 Î–Îµá½ºÏ‚...á¼€Ï€Î¿ÏƒÏ„ÎµÏÎ¿á½·Î· Î³á½±Î¼Î¿Î½ is not, "may he avert from us," but "may he take away (from our foes)": Hartung would read á¼€Ï€Î¿ÏƒÏ„Ïá½³Ï†Î¿Î¹ Î¼Î¿Î¹. The latter seems most applicable to rain: cp. Pind. P. 4. 81 á¼€Î¼Ï†á½¶ Î´á½² Ï€Î±ÏÎ´Î±Î»á½³á¾³ ÏƒÏ„á½³Î³ÎµÏ„Î¿ Ï†Ïá½·ÏƒÏƒÎ¿Î½Ï„Î±Ï‚ á½„Î¼Î²ÏÎ¿Ï…Ï‚, Anthol. Line 321

The Î´á¿†Î»Î¿Î½ of the MSS. can mean only "manifest to me" (a very weak sense): for it could not bear the emphatic sense, "in living presence" (as opp. to "in my fancy"). Nor, again, can it well be taken as a parenthetic adv., "'tis clear" (like Ai. 906 Î±á½Ï„á½¸Ï‚ Ï€Ïá½¸Ï‚ Î±á½‘Ï„Î¿á¿¦Â· Î´á¿†Î»Î¿Î½Â·). The conjecture á¼€Î´ÎµÎ»Ï†á½¸Î½ (cp. Ant. 1 á½¦ ÎºÎ¿Î¹Î½á½¸Î½ Î±á½Ï„á½±Î´ÎµÎ»Ï†Î¿Î½ á¼¸ÏƒÎ¼á½µÎ½Î·Ï‚ Îºá½±ÏÎ±) may be right.

ÎŸá¼°. Ï€á¿¶Ï‚ Îµá¼¶Ï€Î±Ï‚, á½¦ Ï€Î±á¿–;
á¼ˆÎ½. Ï€Î±á¿–Î´Î± Ïƒá½µÎ½, á¼Î¼á½´Î½ Î´â€™ á½Ïá¾¶Î½
á½…Î¼Î±Î¹Î¼Î¿Î½Â· Î±á½Î´á¿‡ Î´â€™ Î±á½Ï„á½·Îºâ€™ á¼”Î¾ÎµÏƒÏ„Î¹Î½ Î¼Î±Î¸Îµá¿–Î½. ğŸ—©
Line 324

Ismene has come from Thebes, where she has hitherto continued to live, in order to bring her father important tidings. The Thebans will shortly make an attempt to fix his home, not within, but near their borders. A war has already broken out between his sons.

There is no contrast in this play, as in the early part of the Antigone, between the spirit of the sisters. But the contrast between their circumstances indirectly exalts Antigone. She is wandering barefooted, enduring heat and cold (349 f.), â€” Creon is struck by the suffering shown in her aspect (748), â€” while Ismene has at least the ordinary comforts of life.

á½¦ Î´Î¹ÏƒÏƒá½° Ï€Î±Ï„Ïá½¸Ï‚ ÎºÎ±á½¶ ÎºÎ±ÏƒÎ¹Î³Î½. Îº.Ï„.Î». = á½¦ Ï€á½±Ï„ÎµÏ ÎºÎ±á½¶ ÎºÎ±ÏƒÎ¹Î³Î½á½µÏ„Î·, Î´Î¹ÏƒÏƒá½° á¼Î¼Î¿á½¶ á¼¥Î´Î¹ÏƒÏ„Î± Ï€ÏÎ¿ÏƒÏ†Ï‰Î½á½µÎ¼Î±Ï„Î±, two names most sweet for me to use: cp. Or. 1049 á½¦ ÏƒÏ„á½³ÏÎ½â€™ á¼€Î´ÎµÎ»Ï†á¿†Ï‚ â€¦ Ï„á½±Î´â€™ á¼€Î½Ï„á½¶ Ï€Î±á½·Î´Ï‰Î½ ÎºÎ±á½¶ Î³Î±Î¼Î·Î»á½·Î¿Ï… Î»á½³Ï‡Î¿Ï…Ï‚ Ï€ÏÎ¿ÏƒÏ†Î¸á½³Î³Î¼Î±Ï„â€™ á¼€Î¼Ï†á½¶ Ï„Î¿á¿–Ï‚ Ï„Î±Î»Î±Î¹Ï€á½½ÏÎ¿Î¹Ï‚ Ï€á½±ÏÎ±. Suppl. 802 á½¦ Ï€Î±á¿–Î´ÎµÏ‚, á½¦ Ï€Î¹ÎºÏá½¸Î½ Ï†á½·Î»Ï‰Î½ Ï€ÏÎ¿ÏƒÎ·Î³á½¹ÏÎ·Î¼Î± Î¼Î±Ï„á½³ÏÏ‰Î½ ("sons," a name bitter for your mothers to utter).

á¼¸Ïƒ. á½¦ Ï€á½±Ï„ÎµÏ Î´á½»ÏƒÎ¼Î¿Î¹Ïâ€™ á½Ïá¾¶Î½. ğŸ—©
Line 328

In the MSS. the verse á¼¦ Ï„á¿†ÏƒÎ´Îµ Îºá¼€Î¼Î¿á¿¦; etc. stands immediately after the verse Ï€Ïá½¹ÏƒÏˆÎ±Ï…ÏƒÎ¿Î½, á½¦ Ï€Î±á¿–, etc. Musgrave has been followed by nearly all subsequent editors, in separating these two verses by the insertion between them of the verse á½¦ ÏƒÏ€á½³ÏÎ¼â€™ á½…Î¼Î±Î¹Î¼Î¿Î½ etc. This transposition is plainly necessary: else Ismene will say that she touches not only her father and sister, but herself. Campbell defends Î¸Î¹Î³Î³á½±Î½Ï‰ â€¦ Î´Ï…ÏƒÎ¼á½¹ÏÎ¿Ï… â€¦ á¼Î¼Î¿á¿¦ Ï„Ïá½·Ï„Î·Ï‚ as meaning, "I too am linked in this unhappy circle": adding that "the construction of a reply, in this sort of dialogue, is not to be pressed too closely." The source of the confusion in the MSS. was obviously that the gen. á¼¦ Ï„á¿†ÏƒÎ´Îµ Îºá¼€Î¼Î¿á¿¦ etc. could depend, in grammar, either on Î¸Î¹Î³Î³á½±Î½Ï‰ or on Ï„ÏÎ¿Ï†Î±á½·, though the sense leaves no choice. Nauck further places v. 327 (á½¦ Ï„á½³ÎºÎ½Î¿Î½, á¼¥ÎºÎµÎ¹Ï‚) after v. 329 (Ï€Ïá½¹ÏƒÏˆÎ±Ï…ÏƒÎ¿Î½). Wecklein places v. 328 (Ï„á½³ÎºÎ½Î¿Î½, Ï€á½³Ï†Î·Î½Î±Ï‚) after v. 329. Neither of these changes is hurtful; but neither appears necessary.

ÎŸá¼°. Ï„á½³ÎºÎ½Î¿Î½, Ï€á½³Ï†Î·Î½Î±Ï‚;
á¼¸Ïƒ. Î¿á½Îº á¼„Î½ÎµÏ… Î¼á½¹Ï‡Î¸Î¿Ï… Î³á½³ Î¼Î¿Î¹. ğŸ—©
Line 330

á½¦ Î´Ï…Ïƒá½±Î¸Î»Î¹Î±Î¹ Ï„ÏÎ¿Ï†Î±á½·, wretched mode of life (338), â€” referring to the outward signs of suffering and destitution on which Creon dwells, 745 ff.: cp. 1250 ff. By his reply, á¼¦ Ï„á¿†ÏƒÎ´Îµ Îºá¼€Î¼Î¿á¿¦; Oed. seems to hint that she separates herself from those whom she pities. Ismene with quick sensibility rejoins, Î´Ï…ÏƒÎ¼á½¹ÏÎ¿Ï… Ï„â€™ á¼Î¼Î¿á¿¦ Ï„Ïá½·Ï„Î·Ï‚, the life is to be mine, too, in your company (for Ï„Ïá½·Ï„Î·Ï‚ cp. 8). Dindorf's conjecture, á½¦ Î´á½” á¼€Î¸Î»á½·Ï‰ Ï„ÏÎ¿Ï†á½±, makes the subsequent question of Oedipus appear needless.

á½…Î¼Î±Î¹Î¼Î¿Î½ expresses the sisters' relation to each other only ("my children and my sisters" would be Î´á½»ÏƒÏ†Î·Î¼Î¿Î½ here). In Soph. á½…Î¼Î±Î¹Î¼Î¿Ï‚, á½Î¼Î±á½·Î¼Ï‰Î½ always refer to brother or sister: 323, 979, 1275, 1405, 1772: Ant. 486, 512 f.: El. 12, 325, 531: O. T. 639.

Line 335

Ï€Î¿Î½Îµá¿–Î½, epexeg. infin. with Ï€Î¿á¿¦ (Îµá¼°ÏƒÎ¹): so as to do their part. The infin. was thus used in affirmative clauses (esp. after á½…Î´Îµ), as Il. 9.688 Îµá¼°Ïƒá½¶ ÎºÎ±á½¶ Î¿á¼µÎ´Îµ Ï„á½±Î´â€™ Îµá¼°Ï€á½³Î¼ÎµÎ½, Î¿á¼µ Î¼Î¿Î¹ á¼•Ï€Î¿Î½Ï„Î¿, here are these also to tell the tale, who went with me: Eur. Hipp. 294 Î³Ï…Î½Î±á¿–ÎºÎµÏ‚ Î±á¼´Î´Îµ ÏƒÏ…Î³ÎºÎ±Î¸Î¹ÏƒÏ„á½±Î½Î±Î¹ Î½á½¹ÏƒÎ¿Î½, here are women to help in soothing thy trouble. So on the affirmative Î¿á¼µÎ´Îµ Îµá¼°Ïƒá½¶ Ï€Î¿Î½Îµá¿–Î½ ("here they are to serve") is modelled the interrogative Ï€Î¿á¿¦ Îµá¼°Ïƒá½¶ Ï€Î¿Î½Îµá¿–Î½; "where are they, that they may serve (as they are bound to do)?" So Eur. Or. 1473 Ï€Î¿á¿¦ Î´á¿†Ï„â€™ á¼€Î¼á½»Î½ÎµÎ¹Î½ Î¿á¼± ÎºÎ±Ï„á½° ÏƒÏ„á½³Î³Î±Ï‚ Î¦Ïá½»Î³ÎµÏ‚;

Ï€Î¿á¿¦ (the scholiast's reading) is right. Ï€Î¿á¿– supposes a very harsh ellipse of á¼¥ÎºÎ¿Ï…ÏƒÎ¹Î½ or the like, and agrees less well with the reply.

ÎŸá¼°. Ï€á½¹Ï„ÎµÏÎ± Ï€á½¹Î¸Î¿Î¹ÏƒÎ¹; ğŸ—©
Line 336

Î¿á½—Ï€á½³Ï Îµá¼°ÏƒÎ¹: on 273. Schaerer's Ï„á¼€Î½ is better than the MS. Î´â€™ á¼Î½ because the hint is made more impressive by the abruptness.

Line 337

Î‘á¼°Î³á½»Ï€Ï„á¿³. Her. 2.35 Ï„á½° Ï€Î¿Î»Î»á½° Ï€á½±Î½Ï„Î± á¼”Î¼Ï€Î±Î»Î¹Î½ Ï„Î¿á¿–ÏƒÎ¹ á¼„Î»Î»Î¿Î¹ÏƒÎ¹ á¼€Î½Î¸Ïá½½Ï€Î¿Î¹ÏƒÎ¹ á¼ÏƒÏ„á½µÏƒÎ±Î½Ï„Î¿ á¼¤Î¸Îµá½± Ï„Îµ ÎºÎ±á½¶ Î½á½¹Î¼Î¿Ï…Ï‚Â· á¼Î½ Ï„Î¿á¿–ÏƒÎ¹ Î±á¼± Î¼á½²Î½ Î³Ï…Î½Î±á¿–ÎºÎµÏ‚ á¼€Î³Î¿Ïá½±Î¶Î¿Ï…ÏƒÎ¹ ÎºÎ±á½¶ ÎºÎ±Ï€Î·Î»Îµá½»Î¿Ï…ÏƒÎ¹, Î¿á¼± Î´á½² á¼„Î½Î´ÏÎµÏ‚ ÎºÎ±Ï„ Î¿á¼´ÎºÎ¿Ï…Ï‚ á¼á½¹Î½Ï„ÎµÏ‚ á½‘Ï†á¼€á½·Î½Î¿Ï…ÏƒÎ¹. Soph. certainly seems to have had this passage of his friend's work in view: else it would be strange that v. 341 should correspond so exactly with the special tasks ascribed to the women by Her. So the reference in El. 62 to the (supposed) dead returning recalls the Thracian Salmoxis in Her. 4.95, and the disputed passage Ant. 905 ff. recalls the wife of Intaphernes in Her. 3.119. Nymphodorus of Syracuse (275 B.C.?), in the 3rd book (read Î³â€™ for Î¹Î³â€™ in the schol. here, MÃ¼ller fr. Hist. 2. 380) of his Îá½¹Î¼Î¹Î¼Î± Î’Î±ÏÎ²Î±ÏÎ¹Îºá½±, repeated the statement of Her., adding (prob. of himself) that Sesostris had thus sought to tame the men of Egypt to his sway. Anaxandrides, of the Middle Comedy (circ. 340 B.C.), in his *po/leis, represented the Athenians as rejecting an Egyptian alliance on the ground of the opposition between the manners of Greece and Egypt: â€” Î¿á½”Î¸â€™ Î¿á¼± Ï„Ïá½¹Ï€Î¿Î¹ Î³á½°Ï á½Î¼Î¿Î½Î¿Î¿á¿¦Ï‚), Î¿á½”Î¸â€™ Î¿á¼± Î½á½¹Î¼Î¿Î¹ | á¼¡Î¼á¿¶Î½ ï¼ˆFragm. Line 342

ÏƒÏ†á¿·Î½ Î´), dat. of interest, "for you two" (Ant. and Ism.), in your case. Some take it as partitive gen.: then it would mean, "of you two pairs," â€” the pair of brothers being one unit, and the pair of sisters another. But I know no parallel for such an use of a dual pronoun. It is different when á¼„Î¼Ï†Ï‰ is said of two "sides" or armies, considered as units (Il. 2.123 Îµá¼´Ï€ÎµÏ Î³á½±Ï Îºâ€™ á¼Î¸á½³Î»Î¿Î¹Î¼ÎµÎ½ á¼ˆÏ‡Î±Î¹Î¿á½· Ï„Îµ Î¤Ïá¿¶á½³Ï‚ Ï„Îµ | â€¦ á¼€ÏÎ¹Î¸Î¼Î·Î¸á½µÎ¼ÎµÎ½Î±Î¹ á¼„Î¼Ï†Ï‰): or when a dual verb has a twofold dual subject, Il. 8.185 Îá½±Î½Î¸Îµ Ï„Îµ ÎºÎ±á½¶ Ïƒá½», Î á½¹Î´Î±ÏÎ³Îµ, ÎºÎ±á½¶ Î‘á¼´Î¸Ï‰Î½ Î›á½±Î¼Ï€Îµ Ï„Îµ Î´á¿–Îµ Î½á¿¦Î½ Î¼Î¿Î¹ Ï„á½´Î½ ÎºÎ¿Î¼Î¹Î´á½´Î½ á¼€Ï€Î¿Ï„á½·Î½ÎµÏ„Î¿Î½.

Line 343

Not noticing Ismene's hint (336), Oedipus imagines his sons in repose at Thebes. He is soon to learn that one of them, an exile, is levying war against the other (374).

Î¿á¼°ÎºÎ¿Ï…ÏÎ¿á¿¦ÏƒÎ¹Î½, not Î¿á¼°ÎºÎ¿Ï…ÏÎµá¿–Ï„Î¿Î½, though a dual follows (345): O. T. 1511f. Îµá¼°Ï‡á½³Ï„Î·Î½...Îµá½”Ï‡ÎµÏƒÎ¸Îµ: Xen. Cyr. 6.1.47 á½¡Ï‚ Îµá¼°Î´á½³Ï„Î·Î½...á¼ ÏƒÏ€á½±ÏƒÎ±Î½Ï„Î¿ á¼€Î»Î»á½µÎ»Î¿Ï…Ï‚: Plat. Prot. 330C Îµá¼´Ï€ÎµÏ„Î¿Î½ Î´á½µ Î¼Î¿Î¹...á½ƒ á½ Î½Î¿Î¼á½±ÏƒÎ±Ï„Îµ á¼„ÏÏ„Î¹.

Ï„á¼€Î¼á½° â€¦ ÎºÎ±Îºá½°: cognate acc. to á½‘Ï€ÎµÏÏ€Î¿Î½Îµá¿–Ï„Î¿Î½ (like Ï€Î¿Î½Îµá¿–Î½ Ï€á½¹Î½Î¿Ï…Ï‚), "ye bear the woes of me hapless for me" (Î´Ï…ÏƒÏ„á½µÎ½Î¿Ï…, placed between art. and noun, must not be taken with á½‘Ï€ÎµÏÏ€Ï€Î¿Î½Îµá¿–Ï„Î¿Î½). Î½á½³Î±Ï‚ Ï„ÏÎ¿Ï†á¿†Ï‚ á¼”Î»Î·Î¾Îµ, ceased to need the tender care which is given to children. Î½Î·Î»á½·Ï€Î¿Ï…Ï‚: schol. Î±Â·Î½Ï…Ï€á½¹Î´Î·Ï„Î¿Ï‚. Apoll. 350 Ï€Î¿Î»Î»Î¿á¿–ÏƒÎ¹ Î´â€™ á½„Î¼Î²ÏÎ¿Î¹Ï‚ á¼¡Î»á½·Î¿Ï… Ï„Îµ ÎºÎ±á½»Î¼Î±ÏƒÎ¹Î½

Line 351

á¼¡Î³Îµá¿–Ï„Î±Î¹. The sentence Î³ÎµÏÎ¿Î½Ï„Î±Î³Ï‰Î³Îµá¿–, Ï€Î¿Î»Î»á½° Î¼á½²Î½ ... á¼€Î»Ï‰Î¼á½³Î½Î·, Ï€Î¿Î»Î»Î¿á¿–ÏƒÎ¹ Î´â€™ á½„Î¼Î²Ï. Î¼Î¿Ï‡Î¸Î¿á¿¦ÏƒÎ±, is so far regular and complete: then we should have expected á¼¡Î³Î¿Ï…Î¼á½³Î½Î·, introducing a comment on the whole sentence. Instead, we have á¼¡Î³Îµá¿–Ï„Î±Î¹, which draws Î¼Î¿Ï‡Î¸Î¿á¿¦ÏƒÎ± to itself, and thus breaks the symmetry of the antithesis. The substitution of a finite verb for a second participial clause is freq. in Greek; but is usu. managed as if here we had Ï€Î¿Î»Î»á½° Î¼á½²Î½...á¼€Î»Ï‰Î¼á½³Î½Î·, Ï€Î¿Î»Î»Î¿á¿–Ï‚ Î´â€™ á½„Î¼Î²Ï. Î¼Î¿Ï‡Î¸Îµá¿–, á¼¡Î³Î¿Ï…Î¼á½³Î½Î· etc. Cp. El. 190 Î¿á¼°ÎºÎ¿Î½Î¿Î¼á¿¶ Î¸Î±Î»á½±Î¼Î¿Ï…Ï‚ Ï€Î±Ï„Ïá½¹Ï‚, á½¦Î´Îµ Î¼á½²Î½ á¼€ÎµÎ¹ÎºÎµá¿– Ïƒá½ºÎ½ ÏƒÏ„Î¿Î»á¾·, ÎºÎµÎ½Î±á¿–Ï‚ Î´â€™ á¼€Î¼Ï†á½·ÏƒÏ„Î±Î¼Î±Î¹ Ï„ÏÎ±Ï€á½³Î¶Î±Î¹Ï‚ (instead of á¼€Î¼Ï†Î¹ÏƒÏ„Î±Î¼á½³Î½Î·): Ph. 213 ff. Î¿á½ Î¼Î¿Î»Ï€á½°Î½...á¼”Ï‡Ï‰Î½,â€”...á¼€Î»Î»á½°...Î²Î¿á¾· (instead of Î²Î¿á¿¶Î½): Lys. or. 12 Â§ 15 á¼Î´á½¹ÎºÎµÎ¹ Î¼Î¿Î¹ Ï„Î±á½»Ï„á¿ƒ Ï€ÎµÎ¹Ïá¾¶ÏƒÎ¸Î±Î¹ ÏƒÏ‰Î¸á¿†\Î½Î±Î¹, á¼Î½Î¸Ï…Î¼Î¿Ï…Î¼á½³Î½á¿³ á½…Ï„Î¹, á¼á½°Î½ Î¼á½²Î½ Î»á½±Î¸Ï‰, ÏƒÏ‰Î¸á½µÏƒÎ¿Î¼Î±Î¹Â·, á¼á½°Î½ Î´á½² Î»Î·Ï†Î¸á¿¶, á¼¡Î³Î¿á½»Î¼Î·Î½ etc.: and O. Ï„á½° Ï„á¿†Ï‚. There are only three other instances in Soph. of the art. so placed: Ph. 263 Î¦Î¹Î»Î¿ÎºÏ„á½µÏ„Î·Ï‚ á½ƒÎ½ Î¿á¼± | Î´Î¹ÏƒÏƒÎ¿á½¶ ÏƒÏ„ÏÎ±Ï„Î·Î³Î¿á½·: Ant. 409 Îºá½¹Î½Î¹Î½ Ïƒá½µÏÎ±Î½Ï„ÎµÏ‚ á¼¢ ÎºÎ±Ï„Îµá¿–Ï‡Îµ Ï„á½¸Î½ | Î½á½³ÎºÏ…Î½: El. 879 Îºá¼€Ï€á½¶ Ï„Î¿á¿–Ï‚ | ÏƒÎ±Ï…Ï„á¿†Ï‚ ÎºÎ±ÎºÎ¿á¿–ÏƒÎ¹. Close cohesion in thought and utterance is the excuse for this, as for the elision of Î´â€™, Ï„â€™, Ï„Î±á¿¦Ï„â€™ at the end of a v. (O. T. 29 n.).

Î¿á¼´ÎºÎ¿Î¹ Î´Î¹Î±á½·Ï„Î·Ï‚, Îµá¼° Ï€Î±Ï„á½´Ï Ï„ÏÎ¿Ï†á½´Î½ á¼”Ï‡Î¿Î¹. ğŸ—©
Line 352

Îµá¼° â€¦ á¼”Ï‡Î¿Î¹ is an abstract statement of the condition: â€” "Supposing him to have tendance, she is content." For optat. in protasis, with pres. ind. in apodosis, cp. Antiphanes fr. incert. 51 (Bothe p. 412) Îµá¼° Î³á½°Ï á¼€Ï†á½³Î»Î¿Î¹ Ï„Î¹Ï‚ Ï„Î¿á¿¦ Î²á½·Î¿Ï… Ï„á½°Ï‚ á¼¡Î´Î¿Î½á½±Ï‚, ÎºÎ±Ï„Î±Î»Îµá½·Ï€ÎµÏ„â€™ Î¿á½Î´á½²Î½ á¼•Ï„ÎµÏÎ¿Î½ á¼¢ Ï„ÎµÎ¸Î½Î·Îºá½³Î½Î±Î¹, "supposing one takes away...then nothing is left."

Ï„ÏÎ¿Ï†á½´Î½, "tendance": see on 345: cp. 1614.

Ïƒá½º Î´â€™, á½¦ Ï„á½³ÎºÎ½Î¿Î½, Ï€Ïá½¹ÏƒÎ¸ÎµÎ½ Î¼á½²Î½ á¼Î¾á½·ÎºÎ¿Ï… Ï€Î±Ï„Ïá½¶
Î¼Î±Î½Ï„Îµá¿–â€™ á¼„Î³Î¿Ï…ÏƒÎ± Ï€á½±Î½Ï„Î±, ÎšÎ±Î´Î¼Îµá½·Ï‰Î½ Î»á½±Î¸Ïá¾³, ğŸ—©
Line 354

Î¼Î±Î½Ï„Îµá¿–Î± Ï€á½±Î½Ï„Î± implies several oracles, given to the Thebans about Oedipus after he had left Thebes. There is no clue to their purport, and we need not ask: they are invented merely to create a pious office for Ismene. It would not have seemed well that she should have stayed at Thebes all these years without showing any active interest in his fate: on the other hand, the poetic legend required that Antigone should be the sole guide of his wanderings. The oracle about final rest had been given to Oed. in his youth (see on 87); the oracle about his grave has only just been received at Thebes (389). Between these two, the only oracle suggested by the Sophoclean version of the story is a response to the question which Creon had proposed to ask at Delphi (O. T. 1438), as to whether Oed. should remain at Thebes. But the story of the expulsion (768 ff.) implies that no such response had then been obtained.

355 á¼ƒ Ï„Î¿á¿¦Î´â€™ á¼Ï‡Ïá½µÏƒÎ¸Î· Ïƒá½½Î¼Î±Ï„Î¿Ï‚, Ï†á½»Î»Î±Î¾ Ï„á½³ Î¼Î¿Ï… ğŸ—©
Line 355

Ï„Î¿á¿¦Î´Îµ Ïƒá½½Î¼Î±Ï„Î¿Ï‚ (without Ï€ÎµÏá½·), gen. of connection; see on 307.

Ï†á½»Î»Î±Î¾ Î´á½³ Î¼Î¿Î¹ Îº.Ï„.Î»., a general description of her part, subjoined to the special instance just given: "and you constituted yourself a trusty watcher (at Thebes) in my interest, when I was being driven from the land," i.e. from the moment when the decision to expel me had been taken, and the act was in contemplation.

Î¼Î¿Î¹ for Î¼Î¿Ï… seems necessary: and I suspect that Î¼Î¿Ï… first arose from inattention to the exact sense. A gen. after Ï†á½»Î»Î±Î¾ always denotes the object guarded: thus Ï†á½»Î»Î±Î¾ Î¼Î¿Ï… ought to mean (not, "a watcher in my interest," but) "a guardian of my person"; this, however, was Antigone's part (21): Ismene had never roamed with him. So in Eur. Bacch. 612 Ï„á½·Ï‚ Î¼Î¿Î¹ Ï†á½»Î»Î±Î¾ á¼¦Î½; (say the Bacchants to Dionysus), "what overseer, master (of our rites, like á¼Ï€á½·ÏƒÎºÎ¿Ï€Î¿Ï‚ of Dionysus, Ant. 1148) had we?" â€” not, "what guardian of our persons was there?" Yet there L2 (cod. Laur. 32. 2) has Î¼Î¿Ï….

Ï€Î¹ÏƒÏ„á½´ ÎºÎ±Ï„á½³ÏƒÏ„Î·Ï‚, Î³á¿†Ï‚ á½…Ï„â€™ á¼Î¾Î·Î»Î±Ï…Î½á½¹Î¼Î·Î½Â·

á¼¥ÎºÎµÎ¹Ï‚ Î³á½°Ï Î¿á½ ÎºÎµÎ½á½µ Î³Îµ, Ï„Î¿á¿¦Ï„â€™ á¼Î³á½¼ ÏƒÎ±Ï†á¿¶Ï‚
360 á¼”Î¾Î¿Î¹Î´Î±, Î¼á½´ Î¿á½Ï‡á½¶ Î´Îµá¿–Î¼â€™ á¼Î¼Î¿á½¶ Ï†á½³ÏÎ¿Ï…Ïƒá½± Ï„Î¹. ğŸ—©
Line 360

Î¼á½´ Î¿á½Ï‡á½¶ â€¦ Ï†á½³ÏÎ¿Ï…ÏƒÎ± explains the special sense of ÎºÎµÎ½á½µ. "You have not come empty-handedâ€”i.e. without bringing some terror for me." Î¼á½´ Î¿á½ properly stands with a partic. in a negative statement only when Î¼á½µ could stand with it in the corresponding affirmative statement: thus (a) affirmative: Î²ÏÎ±Î´á½ºÏ‚ á¼”ÏÏ‡ÎµÎ¹ Î¼á½´ Ï†á½³ÏÏ‰Î½, you (always) come slowly, if you are not bringing: (b) negative: Î¿á½ Î²ÏÎ±Î´á½ºÏ‚ á¼”ÏÏ‡ÎµÎ¹, Î¼á½´ Î¿á½ fe/rwn, you never come slowly, unless you are bringing. Here Î¼á½´ Î¿á½ is irregular, because the affirmative form would be á¼¥ÎºÎµÎ¹Ï‚ Î¿á½ (not Î¼á½´) Ï†á½³ÏÎ¿Ï…ÏƒÎ±, a simple statement of fact; and so the negative should be Î¿á½Ï‡ á¼¥ÎºÎµÎ¹Ï‚ Î¿á½ Ï†á½³ÏÎ¿Ï…ÏƒÎ±. But bringing bad news is felt here as a condition of her coming. Hence Î¼á½´ Î¿á½ is used as if the sentence were formally conditional: Î¿á½Îº á¼‚Î½ á¼¦Î»Î¸ÎµÏ‚ Î¼á½´ Î¿á½ Ï†á½³ÏÎ¿Ï…ÏƒÎ±.

á¼¸Ïƒ. á¼Î³á½¼ Ï„á½° Î¼á½²Î½ Ï€Î±Î¸á½µÎ¼Î±Î¸â€™ á¼…Ï€Î±Î¸Î¿Î½, Ï€á½±Ï„ÎµÏ, ğŸ—©
Line 361

From Thebes to Athens is a short day's journey; but Ismene has sought her father far and wide. This could not well have been if, as Campbell supposes (on 355), the oracles which she herself had formerly brought to him had directed his course towards Attica.

Î¶Î·Ï„Î¿á¿¦ÏƒÎ± Ï„á½´Î½ Ïƒá½´Î½ Ï€Î¿á¿¦ ÎºÎ±Ï„Î¿Î¹ÎºÎ¿á½·Î·Ï‚ Ï„ÏÎ¿Ï†á½µÎ½, ğŸ—©

365 á¼ƒ Î´â€™ á¼€Î¼Ï†á½¶ Ï„Î¿á¿–Î½ ÏƒÎ¿á¿–Î½ Î´Ï…ÏƒÎ¼á½¹ÏÎ¿Î¹Î½ Ï€Î±á½·Î´Î¿Î¹Î½ ÎºÎ±Îºá½° ğŸ—©
