Î½á¿¦Î½ á¼ÏƒÏ„Î¹, Ï„Î±á¿¦Ï„Î± ÏƒÎ·Î¼Î±Î½Î¿á¿¦Ïƒâ€™ á¼Î»á½µÎ»Ï…Î¸Î±.
Ï€Ïá½¶Î½ Î¼á½²Î½ Î³á½°Ï Î±á½Ï„Î¿á¿–Ï‚ á¼¦Î½ á¼”ÏÏ‰Ï‚ ÎšÏá½³Î¿Î½Ï„á½· Ï„Îµ ğŸ—©
Line 367

Eteocles and Polyneices were young boys at the fall of Oedipus (see on 1), and their uncle Creon (brother of Iocasta) became regent (O. T. 1418). As the two brothers grew up, they agreed, at first, in wishing to resign the throne, of which they were joint heirs, to Creon, lest Thebes should be tainted by their own rule; but afterwards they fell to striving with each other for the sole power.

á¼”ÏÏ‰Ï‚, desire (436), is a necessary and a certain correction. The MS. á¼”ÏÎ¹Ï‚ would have to mean "emulous desire," either (a) between the two brothers, if Ï„Îµ â€¦ Î¼Î·Î´á½³ = "both" â€¦ "and not": or (b) between the brothers and (Ï„Îµ) Creon. Now, there is no objection to using á¼Ïá½·Î¶Ï‰, á¼”ÏÎ¹Ï‚ of noble rivalry. The fatal objection is that the idea of rivalry at all is here completely,â€”almost ludicrously,â€”out of place. The notion that Soph. was thinking of the á¼€Î³Î±Î¸á½´ á¼”ÏÎ¹Ï‚, which rouses men to effort, as opp. to the ÎºÎ±Îºá½´ á¼”ÏÎ¹Ï‚ (Hes. Opp. 11 ff.), is surely very frigid. It is possible, however, that it was this notion which first brought á¼”ÏÎ¹Ï‚ into 367.

ÎšÏá½³Î¿Î½Ï„á½· Ï„Îµ. The Ï„Îµ = "both," answering to Î¼Î·Î´á½³ "and not." So Ï„Îµ is answered by Î¿á½Î´á½³ (instead of Î¿á½”Ï„Îµ) Eur. I. T. 697, or by Î´á½³ Soph. Ph. 1312. So, too, Î¿á½”Ï„Îµ by Î´á½³, Eur. Suppl. 223, etc. Such irregularity is natural when the second thought is opposed to the first. The objection to reading Î¼á½µÏ„Îµ in 368 is that, while Î¿á½”Ï„Îµ (or Î¼á½µÏ„Îµ)... Ï„Îµ is common enough, there is no example of Ï„Îµ...Î¿á½”Ï„Îµ (or Î¼á½µÏ„Îµ).

Paley's ÎšÏá½³Î¿Î½Ï„Î¹ Î´á½´ is, however, highly probable. It would mean, "to Creon in the next resort." So Î´á½´ is used of succession in Ant. 173, where Creon says á¼Î³á½¼ ÎºÏá½±Ï„Î· Î´á½´ Ï€á½±Î½Ï„Î± ÎºÎ±á½¶ Î¸Ïá½¹Î½Î¿Ï…Ï‚ á¼”Ï‡Ï‰, I next (the sons of Oed. being dead); and Aesch. Eum. 3 á¼£ Î´á½´ Ï„á½¸ Î¼Î·Ï„Ïá½¸Ï‚ Î´ÎµÏ…Ï„á½³ÏÎ± Ï„á½¹Î´â€™ á¼•Î¶ÎµÏ„Î¿ | Î¼Î±Î½Ï„Îµá¿–Î¿Î½.

Ï„á½´Î½ Ï€á½±Î»Î±Î¹ â€¦ Ï†Î¸Î¿Ïá½±Î½, beginning with the curse called down on LaÃ¯us by Pelops, for robbing him of his son Chrysippus. Cp. Îºá¼€Î»Î¹Ï„Î·Ïá½·Î¿Ï…. The MS. reading, Îºá¼€Î¾ á¼€Î»Ä­Ï„Î·ÏÎ¿á¿¦, is against metre, and gives a form of the adj. which occurs nowhere else; though, had it existed, it would have been most convenient for epic verse. á¼€Î»Î¹Ï„á½µÏÎ¹Î¿Ï‚, and the poet. á¼€Î»Ä­Ï„Ïá½¹Ï‚, alone are found. Îµá¼°Ïƒá¿†Î»Î¸Îµ Ï„Î¿á¿–Î½ Ï„Ïá½¶Ï‚ á¼€Î¸Î»á½·Î¿Î¹Î½ á¼”ÏÎ¹Ï‚ ÎºÎ±Îºá½µ, ğŸ—©

The dat. after Îµá¼°Ïƒá¿†Î»Î¸Îµ is strictly a dat. of the person interested, but was perh. influenced by the analogy of the dat. in Ï€Î±Ïá½³ÏƒÏ„Î· Î¼Î¿Î¹, "it occurred to me," and the like; cp. Tr. 298 á¼Î¼Î¿á½¶ Î³á½°Ï Î¿á¼¶ÎºÏ„Î¿Ï‚... Îµá¼°Ïƒá½³Î²Î·: Her. 1.86 ï¼‰ Î»á½³Î³ÎµÏ„Î±Î¹ ï¼ˆ Ï„á¿· ÎšÏÎ¿á½·Ïƒá¿³ â€¦ á¼ÏƒÎµÎ»Î¸Îµá¿–Î½...Ï„á½¸ Ï„Î¿á¿¦ Î£á½¹Î»Ï‰Î½Î¿Ï‚: but 6. 125 Ï„á½¸Î½ ÎšÏÎ¿á¿–ÏƒÎ¿Î½ Î³á½³Î»Ï‰Ï‚ á¼Ïƒá¿†Î»Î¸Îµ: and so Eur. Ï„Ïá½¶Ï‚ á¼€Î¸Î»á½·Î¿Î¹Î½ for Ï„ÏÎ¹ÏƒÎ±Î¸Î»á½·Î¿Î¹Î½ was first given by Porson, since otherwise there would be no caesura either in the 3rd or in the 4th foot. He compares Od. 5.306 Ï„Ïá½¶Ï‚ Î¼á½±ÎºÎ±ÏÎµÏ‚ Î”Î±Î½Î±Î¿á½¶ ÎºÎ±á½¶ Ï„ÎµÏ„Ïá½±ÎºÎ¹Ï‚: Ar. Plut. 851 ÎºÎ±á½¶ Ï„Ïá½¶Ï‚ ÎºÎ±ÎºÎ¿Î´Î±á½·Î¼Ï‰Î½ ÎºÎ±á½¶ Ï„ÎµÏ„Ïá½±ÎºÎ¹Ï‚, Îº.Ï„.Î». To Hermann's argument, that in any case Ï„Ïá½¶Ï‚ and á¼€Î¸Î»á½·Î¿Î¹Î½ cohere, the answer is that, for the metre, the degree of coherence makes all the difference. Blaydes, keeping Ï„ÏÎ¹ÏƒÎ±Î¸Î»á½·Î¿Î¹Î½, quotes five such cases as "free from suspicion." They are the same five which Porson had discussed and proposed to amend in connection with this passage (praef. p. xxviii): viz. Aesch. Pers. 501 (transpose ÎºÏÏ…ÏƒÏ„Î±Î»Î»Î¿Ï€á¿†Î³Î±), Eur. I. A. 1586 (transpose á½ÏÏ‰Î¼á½³Î½Î¿Ï…), Soph. Ai. 969 (not strictly similar,â€”á¼Ï€ÎµÎ³Î³ÎµÎ»á¿·ÎµÎ½), Aesch. Ag. 1261 (=1252 Dind. Ï€Î±ÏÎµÏƒÎºá½¹Ï€ÎµÎ¹Ï‚, doubtful), Suppl. 252 (=244 D. á¼Ï€ÎµÎ¹Îºá½±ÏƒÎ±Î¹, doubtful). Of these, Ï€Î±ÏÎµÏƒÎºá½¹Ï€ÎµÎ¹Ï‚ is the only exact parallel to Ï„ÏÎ¹ÏƒÎ±Î¸Î»á½·Î¿Î¹Î½, as being a single word coincident with the dipodia, and not preceded by elision.

á¼€ÏÏ‡á¿†Ï‚ Î»Î±Î²á½³ÏƒÎ¸Î±Î¹ ÎºÎ±á½¶ ÎºÏá½±Ï„Î¿Ï…Ï‚ Ï„Ï…ÏÎ±Î½Î½Î¹ÎºÎ¿á¿¦.
Ï‡á½  Î¼á½²Î½ Î½Îµá½±Î¶Ï‰Î½ ÎºÎ±á½¶ Ï‡Ïá½¹Î½á¿³ Î¼Îµá½·Ï‰Î½ Î³ÎµÎ³á½¼Ï‚ ğŸ—©
Line 374

If Î½Îµá½±Î¶Ï‰Î½ merely=Î½Îµá½½Ï„ÎµÏÎ¿Ï‚ á½¤Î½, the pleonasm would be too weak: perh., then, it is tinged with the notion of Î½ÎµÎ±Î½Î¹ÎµÏ…á½¹Î¼ÎµÎ½Î¿Ï‚ (as in Eur. Ag. 763 Ï†Î¹Î»Îµá¿– Î´á½² Ï„á½·ÎºÏ„ÎµÎ¹Î½ á½•Î²ÏÎ¹Ï‚ Î¼á½²Î½ Ï€Î±Î»Î±Î¹á½° Î½Îµá½±â€ Î¶Î¿Ï…ÏƒÎ±Î½ á½•Î²ÏÎ¹Î½.

375 Ï„á½¸Î½ Ï€Ïá½¹ÏƒÎ¸Îµ Î³ÎµÎ½Î½Î·Î¸á½³Î½Ï„Î± Î Î¿Î»Ï…Î½Îµá½·ÎºÎ· Î¸Ïá½¹Î½Ï‰Î½ ğŸ—©
Line 375

Ï„á½¸Î½ Ï€Ïá½¹ÏƒÎ¸Îµ: Polyneices alludes to his right as the firstborn, 1294, 1422: Eur. (Phoen. 71) followed the common account in making Eteocles the elder. The change adopted by Soph. is here a twofold dramatic gain; for (a) Polyneices, who is to come on the scene, can be treated as the foremost ofiender; (b) Eteocles has now a special fault, and so the curse on both sons is further justified (421).

á¼€Ï€Î¿ÏƒÏ„ÎµÏá½·ÏƒÎºÎµÎ¹, Îºá¼€Î¾ÎµÎ»á½µÎ»Î±ÎºÎµÎ½ Ï€á½±Ï„ÏÎ±Ï‚. ğŸ—©
Line 376

á¼€Ï€Î¿ÏƒÏ„ÎµÏá½·ÏƒÎºÎµÎ¹, historic pres., "deprives of" (rather than a true pres., "is excluding from"). The simple ÏƒÏ„ÎµÏá½·ÏƒÎºÏ‰ (Thuc., Plat., Eur., etc.) was commoner in Attic than this compound.

á¼ŒÏÎ³Î¿Ï‚, the territory, not only the city; called ÎºÎ¿á¿–Î»Î¿Î½ because the Argive plain is bounded on W., N. and E. by hills, as on S. by the sea. If the MS. á½…Ï€Î¿Î¹ (Vat. á½…Ï€Î·) is right, the phrase is harsh beyond example. Ï€Î¿á¿–, á½…Ï€Î¿Î¹, instead of Ï€Î¿á¿¦, á½…Ï€Î¿Ï…, are often boldly used, when the verb implies either (a) motion, as 227 ÎºÎ±Ï„Î±Î¸á½µÏƒÎµÎ¹Ï‚, 476 Ï„ÎµÎ»ÎµÏ…Ï„á¿†ÏƒÎ±Î¹, Eur. Lys. 526 Ï€Î¿á¿– Î³á½°Ï ÎºÎ±á½¶ Ï‡Ïá¿†Î½ á¼€Î½Î±Î¼Îµá¿–Î½Î±Î¹; But it is hard to see how á½…Ï€Î¿Î¹ ÎºÎ±Ï„Î¿Î¹ÎºÏ„Î¹Î¿á¿¦ÏƒÎ¹Î½ could mean "how far they will prolong (thy woes) before they pity them." To supply Ï€ÏÎ¿ÎµÎ»Î¸á½¹Î½Ï„Î±Ï‚ or Ï€ÏÎ¿Î±Î³Î±Î³á½¹Î½Ï„ÎµÏ‚ is to cut the knot. If the phrase meant anything, it ought rather to mean, "up to what point they will pity them." As in 335 Ï€Î¿á¿– is a MS. error for Ï€Î¿á¿¦, so here á½…Ï€Î¿Î¹ for á½…Ï€Î¿Ï… (Wecklein prefers á½…Ï€á¿ƒ, "in what way"). Note that, in this context, Ï€á½¹Î½Î¿Ï…Ï‚ = the woes of Oed. generally (mental and physical), not merely his toils in wandering: this is against the emend. ÎºÎ±Ï„Î¿Î¹ÎºÎ¹Î¿á¿¦ÏƒÎ¹Î½.

á½¡Ï‚ â€¦ Î¸ÎµÎ¿á½ºÏ‚ á¼•Î¾ÎµÎ¹Î½ may be sound. Line 389

The purport of this new oracle seems to have been: â€” "The welfare of Thebes depends on Oed., alive or dead." Ismene paraphrases it: â€” "It shows that you will be in request with the Thebans some day (Ï€Î¿Ï„á½³, i.e. some day soon, 397), â€” not merely after your death, but while you live." She knows that Creon is coming in the hope of carrying Oed. back â€” not to Thebes, but to some place just beyond the Theban border, where his person, and afterwards his grave, should be under Theban control. Cp. on 1331.

Î³á½·Î³Î½ÎµÏƒÎ¸Î±Î¹ is never merely Îµá¼¶Î½Î±Î¹. á¼Î½ ÏƒÎ¿á½¶ Î³á½·Î³Î½ÎµÏ„Î±Î¹ Ï„á½° ÎºÎµá½·Î½Ï‰Î½ ÎºÏá½±Ï„Î·=their power comes to be in thy hand: i.e. the new oracle so appoints.

ÎŸá¼°. á¼¡ Î´â€™ á½ Ï†á½³Î»Î·ÏƒÎ¹Ï‚ Ï„á½·Ï‚ Î¸á½»ÏÎ±ÏƒÎ¹ ÎºÎµÎ¹Î¼á½³Î½Î¿Ï…; ğŸ—©
Line 401401-408

The tenor of this fine passage should be observed.

Oedipus took á¼Î½ ÏƒÎ¿á½· (392) to mean that the welfare of Thebes depended on his presence there. He is thinking of a restoration to his Theban home (395). He asks, therefore, â€”"Of what use can I be to them if I am left at their doors, and not received within their land?" "They will suffer," she replies, "if your tomb is neglected." Oedipus does not see the force of this answer: he still infers (from Î¸Î±Î½á½¹Î½Ï„Î± in 390) that, whatever may be his doom in life, he is at least to be buried at Thebes. "Why, of course they will," he replies (403). "So" â€” pursues the daughter (404) â€” "they mean to keep you within their grasp." A new suspicion flashes on him. "They will bury me at Thebes?" "It cannot be." That is enough. He will never give himself into their hands. â€” Remark that he was supposing Apollo's former decree (91) to have been cancelled by this later one (389). He now sees that the new oracle does not cancel the former, but merely confirms it in one aspect, viz. in the promise of á¼„Ï„Î·Î½ Ï„Î¿á¿–Ï‚ Ï€á½³Î¼ÏˆÎ±ÏƒÎ¹Î½ (93).

Î¸á½»ÏÎ±ÏƒÎ¹, foris, as Eur. El. 2074 Î¿á½Î´á½²Î½ Î³á½°Ï Î±á½Ï„á½´Î½ Î´Îµá¿– Î¸á½»ÏÎ±ÏƒÎ¹Î½ Îµá½Ï€ÏÎµÏ€á½²Ï‚ | Ï†Î±á½·Î½ÎµÎ¹Î½ Ï€Ïá½¹ÏƒÏ‰Ï€Î¿Î½ (she ought not to show her beauty abroad), where, as here, Elms. restored it from the MS. Î¸á½»ÏÎ±Î¹ÏƒÎ¹. Campbell retains the latter. But, while in Î¸á½»ÏÎ±ÏƒÎ¹, Î¸á½»ÏÎ±Î¶Îµ, Î¸á½»ÏÎ±Î¸ÎµÎ½, Î¸Ï…ÏÎ±á¿–Î¿Ï‚ the notion of "external" is uppermost, the figurative uses of the plural Î¸á½»ÏÎ±Î¹ always speak of approaching the house: as á¼Ï€á½¶ Ï„á½°Ï‚ Î¸á½»ÏÎ±Ï‚ Ï†Î¿Î¹Ï„á¾¶Î½, á¼Ï€á½¶ Ï„Î±á¿–Ï‚ Î¸á½»ÏÎ±Î¹Ï‚ Î´Î¹Î±Ï„Ïá½·Î²ÎµÎ¹Î½, á¼Ï€á½¶ Ï„Î±á¿–Ï‚ Î¸á½»ÏÎ±Î¹Ï‚ Ï„á¿†Ï‚ á¼™Î»Î»á½±Î´Î¿Ï‚ á¼ÏƒÎ¼á½³Î½ (Xen. Anab. 6.5.23). So here Î¸á½»ÏÎ±Î¹ÏƒÎ¹ would mean, not, "outside of their doors," but "at their very doors."

But they desired the throne for themselves. Here, as in regard to his expulsion, they neglected an opportunity which natural piety should have seized (441).

á¼¸Ïƒ. 420 á¼€Î»Î³á¿¶ ÎºÎ»á½»Î¿Ï…ÏƒÎ± Ï„Î±á¿¦Ï„â€™ á¼Î³á½½, Ï†á½³ÏÏ‰ Î´â€™ á½…Î¼Ï‰Ï‚. ğŸ—©
Line 420

Ï†á½³ÏÏ‰ Î´â€™ á½…Î¼Ï‰Ï‚ is usually taken, "but such are my tidings" (cp. 360). This would be fitting if, with Wecklein, we might read Ï†á½³ÏÎ¿Ï…ÏƒÎ± for ÎºÎ»á½»Î¿Ï…ÏƒÎ±: but the latter is in all MSS., and naturally refers to the words just heard by Ismene from Oed., not to a report heard by her at Thebes. The indignant question of Oed. invited a defence. She replies, "I am pained to hear my brothers charged with such conduct, but I must bear it" â€” i.e. I cannot deny the charge. The contrast between á¼€Î»Î³á¿¶ and Ï†á½³ÏÏ‰ has thus more point.

ÎŸá¼°. á¼€Î»Î»â€™ Î¿á¼± Î¸ÎµÎ¿á½· ÏƒÏ†Î¹Î½ Î¼á½µÏ„Îµ Ï„á½´Î½ Ï€ÎµÏ€ÏÏ‰Î¼á½³Î½Î·Î½ ğŸ—©
Line 421

á¼€Î»Î»â€™. "Nay, then" â€” opening the imprecation, as Ph. 1040 á¼€Î»Î»â€™, á½¦ Ï€Î±Ï„Ïá¿´Î± Î³á¿† Î¸ÎµÎ¿á½· Ï„â€™ á¼Î³Ï‡á½½ÏÎ¹Î¿Î¹, Ï„Îµá½·ÏƒÎ±ÏƒÎ¸Îµ, Ï„Îµá½·ÏƒÎ±ÏƒÎ¸â€™.

ÏƒÏ†Î¹Î½, not ÏƒÏ†Î¹, was prob. always the form used by Attic tragedy. It is required by metre below, 444, 451, 1490: Ai. 570: El. 1070: Aesch. PV 252, 457: Pers. 759, 807: fr. 157 (ap. Plat. Rep. 391E). Eur. has the dat. in two places where, as here, ÏƒÏ†Î¹ is possible, but in both ÏƒÏ†Î¹Î½ has MS. authority, and should probably be read, Med. 398 (v.l. ÏƒÏ†Î¹), Suppl. 769. On the other hand there is no place in trag. where metre excludes ÏƒÏ†Î¹Î½.

Ï„á½´Î½ Ï€ÎµÏ€ÏÏ‰Î¼á½³Î½Î·Î½, by the curse in the house of LaÃ¯us (369).

á¼”ÏÎ¹Î½ ÎºÎ±Ï„Î±ÏƒÎ²á½³ÏƒÎµÎ¹Î±Î½, á¼”Î½ Ï„â€™ á¼Î¼Î¿á½¶ Ï„á½³Î»Î¿Ï‚ ğŸ—©
Line 422

á¼Î½ Î´â€™ after Î¼á½µÏ„Îµ is harsh, and Elmsley's á¼”Î½ Ï„â€™ may be right. There is, however, a good deal of MS. evidence for Ï„Îµ...Î´á½³ in trag.: see on 367. Cp. Ant. 1096 Ï„á½¹ Ï„â€™ Îµá¼°ÎºÎ±Î¸Îµá¿–Î½ Î³á½°Ï Î´ÎµÎ¹Î½á½¹Î½, á¼€Î½Ï„Î¹ÏƒÏ„á½±Î½Ï„Î± Î´á½² Îº.Ï„.Î»., n.

á¼Î½ á¼Î¼Î¿á½· (cp. 247), may the issue for them come to be (392) in my hands, i.e. may the gods allow me to be the final arbiter, and to doom them both by a father's curse.

Î±á½Ï„Î¿á¿–Î½ Î³á½³Î½Î¿Î¹Ï„Î¿ Ï„á¿†ÏƒÎ´Îµ Ï„á¿†Ï‚ Î¼á½±Ï‡Î·Ï‚ Ï€á½³ÏÎ¹,
á¼§Ï‚ Î½á¿¦Î½ á¼”Ï‡Î¿Î½Ï„Î±Î¹ Îºá¼€Ï€Î±Î½Î±á½·ÏÎ¿Î½Ï„Î±Î¹ Î´á½¹ÏÏ…Â· ğŸ—©
Line 424

Îºá¼€Ï€Î±Î½Î±á½·ÏÎ¿Î½Ï„Î±Î¹. The words ÎºÎ±á½¶ á¼Ï€Î±Î½Î±á½·ÏÎ¿Î½Ï„Î±Î¹ Î´á½¹ÏÏ… do not form a second relative clause,â€”as if, from the á¼§Ï‚ before á¼”Ï‡Î¿Î½Ï„Î±Î¹, we had to supply the relat. pron. in a different case (á¼Ï†â€™ á¾—, or Îµá¼°Ï‚ á¼¥Î½) with á¼Ï€Î±Î½Î±á½·ÏÎ¿Î½Ï„Î±Î¹. They form an independent sentence, which is co-ordinated with the relative clause, á¼§Ï‚ á¼”Ï‡Î¿Î½Ï„Î±Î¹. This is the normal Greek construction. See note in Appendix. Cp. 467, 731.

á¼Ï€Î±Î½Î±Î¹ÏÎ¿á¿¦Î½Ï„Î±Î¹ Î´á½¹ÏÏ…, the MS. reading, would mean, "are taking a spear upon them," the verb being used figuratively (like in se suscipere) of obligations or responsibilities (Ï†Î¹Î»á½·Î±Î½, Ï€á½¹Î»ÎµÎ¼Î¿Î½, Ï„á½³Ï‡Î½Î·Î½, Î»Î±Ï„ÏÎµá½·Î±Î½ etc.); but á¼Ï€Î±Î½Î±á½·ÏÎµÏƒÎ¸Î±Î¹, in its literal sense of "uplifting against," is more natural and more poetical with Î´á½¹ÏÏ…: cp. Î¿á½Îº á¼”ÏƒÏ‡Î¿Î½, did not stop me (from being expelled). We find such phrases as á¼”Ï‡Ï‰ Ï„Î¹Î½á½° Ï€Î¿Î¹Î¿á¿¦Î½Ï„á½± Ï„Î¹, to check one in the act of doing something (O. III. 77) á½‘Ï€Î¿Ï†Î¿Ïá½° Î´á½³ á¼ÏƒÏ„Î¹Î½ á½…Ï„Î±Î½ Î¼á½´ á¼‘Î¾á¿†Ï‚ Ï€ÏÎ¿Î²Î±á½·Î½á¿ƒ á½ Î»á½¹Î³Î¿Ï‚, á¼€Î»Î»â€™ á½‘Ï€Î¿Î¸Îµá½·Ï‚ Ï„Î¹ á¼¢ á½¡Ï‚ Ï€Î±Ïá½° Ï„Î¿á¿¦ á¼€Î½Ï„Î¹Î´á½·ÎºÎ¿Ï… á¼¢ á½¡Ï‚ á¼Îº Ï„Î¿á¿¦ Ï€Ïá½±Î³Î¼Î±Ï„Î¿Ï‚ á¼€Ï€Î¿ÎºÏá½·Î½Î·Ï„Î±Î¹ Ï€Ïá½¸Ï‚ Î±á½‘Ï„á½¹Î½, á½¥ÏƒÏ€ÎµÏ Î´á½»Î¿ á¼€Î½Ï„Î¹Î»ÎµÎ³á½¹Î¼ÎµÎ½Î± Ï€Ïá½¹ÏƒÏ‰Ï€Î± Î¼Î¹Î¼Î¿á½»Î¼ÎµÎ½Î¿Ï‚. Oed. here speaks chiefly to Ism., whose pain for her brothers (420) might suggest the excuse; though in 445, 457 he addresses the Chorus. Wecklein conceives Oed. as speaking directly to the spectators, who might recollect the close of the O. T. Need we charge the poet with this dramatic impropriety?

Î¸á½³Î»Î¿Î½Ï„Î¹, "desiring" (not merely "consenting"): cp. 767: O. T. 1356 Î¸á½³Î»Î¿Î½Ï„Î¹ Îºá¼€Î¼Î¿á½¶ Ï„Î¿á¿¦Ï„â€™ á¼‚Î½ á¼¦Î½. The desire of Oed. to be sent away from Thebes is passionately expressed in the O. T. (1410 ff., 1449 ff.). At the end of that play he repeats the request (1518), and Creon replies that it must be referred to Delphi.

á¼”ÏÏ‰Ï„â€™ á¼Ï‚ Ï„á½¹Î½Î´), the conjecture of Papageorgius (see cr. n.), is, I think, almost certain. Ï‡Ïá½¹Î½á¿³ Î´â€™, á½…Ï„â€™ á¼¤Î´Î· Ï€á¾¶Ï‚ á½ Î¼á½¹Ï‡Î¸Î¿Ï‚ á¼¦Î½ Ï€á½³Ï€Ï‰Î½, ğŸ—©
Line 437

Ï€á½³Ï€Ï‰Î½. The metaphor is not directly from the mellowing of fruit, but from the medical use of the word in ref. to the subsiding of inflammation (as in angry tumours, etc.). Cp. the fig. sense of á½ Î¼á½¹Ï‚. So Ï€ÎµÏ€Î±á½·Î½ÎµÏƒÎ¸Î±Î¹ Hippocr. 1170 B: Arist. Meteor. 4.3 á¼¡ Ï†Ï…Î¼á½±Ï„Ï‰Î½ (Ï„Ï…Î¼Î¿Ï…ÏÏ‚) ÎºÎ±á½¶ Ï†Î»á½³Î³Î¼Î±Ï„Î¿Ï‚...Ï€á½³Ï€Î±Î½ÏƒÎ¹Ï‚: Anthol. Îºá¼€Î¼á½±Î½Î¸Î±Î½Î¿Î½ Ï„á½¸Î½ Î¸Ï…Î¼á½¸Î½ á¼ÎºÎ´ÏÎ±Î¼á½¹Î½Ï„Î± Î¼Î¿Î¹ ğŸ—©

á¼ÎºÎ´ÏÎ±Î¼á½¹Î½Ï„Î±, had rushed out, run to excess (not, run á¼”Î¾Ï‰ Î´Ïá½¹Î¼Î¿Ï…, out of the course): 08: cp. Ant. 752 á¼¦ Îºá¼€Ï€Î±Ï€ÎµÎ¹Î»á¿¶Î½ á½§Î´â€™ á¼Ï€ÎµÎ¾á½³ÏÏ‡ÎµÎ¹ Î¸ÏÎ±Ïƒá½»Ï‚; dost thou e'en go to the length of threatening so boldly?

Î¼Îµá½·Î¶Ï‰ ÎºÎ¿Î»Î±ÏƒÏ„á½´Î½ Ï„á¿¶Î½ Ï€Ïá½¶Î½ á¼¡Î¼Î±ÏÏ„Î·Î¼á½³Î½Ï‰Î½, ğŸ—©
Line 439

The gen. might be taken with Î¼Îµá½·Î¶Ï‰, "a chastiser greater than the sins," i.e. "severer than they merited" (á¼¢ ÎºÎ±Ï„á½° Ï„á½° á¼¡Î¼Î±ÏÏ„.); but it is simpler to take it with ÎºÎ¿Î»Î±ÏƒÏ„á½µÎ½, "too great a chastiser of the sins." As Î¼á½³Î³Î±Ï‚ Î¸Ï…Î¼á½¹Ï‚ is "violent anger," so Î¸Ï…Î¼á½¹Ï‚ which is over-violent can be called Î¼Îµá½·Î¶Ï‰Î½ ÎºÎ¿Î»Î±ÏƒÏ„á½µÏ‚. The rhythm of the verse will not permit us to disjoin Î¼Îµá½·Î¶Ï‰ (as by a comma) from ÎºÎ¿Î»Î±ÏƒÏ„á½µÎ½.

440 Ï„á½¸ Ï„Î·Î½á½·Îºâ€™ á¼¤Î´Î· Ï„Î¿á¿¦Ï„Î¿ Î¼á½²Î½ Ï€á½¹Î»Î¹Ï‚ Î²á½·á¾³ ğŸ—©
Line 440

Ï„á½¸ Ï„Î·Î½á½·Îºâ€™ á¼¤Î´Î·, just when that time had come (the art. as in Ï„á½¸ Î±á½Ï„á½·ÎºÎ±, "Î±Ï„ Ï„Î·Îµ Î¼Î¿Î¼ÎµÎ½Ï„," Thuc. 2.41). While Ï„Î·Î½Î¹Îºá½±Î´Îµ ("at this time of day") was common, the simple Ï„Î·Î½á½·ÎºÎ± occurs nowhere else in elass. Attic; it is found, however, in the Alexandrian poets, and in later Greek.

Ï„Î¿á¿¦Ï„Î¿ Î¼á½³Î½ is answered by Î´á½³ (441) instead of Ï„Î¿á¿¦Ï„Î¿ Î´á½³, as by á¼”Ï€ÎµÎ¹Ï„Î± Î´á½³ ï¼ˆAnt. 63), Ï„Î¿á¿¦Ï„â€™ Î±á½–Î¸Î¹Ï‚ ï¼ˆib. 165), Îµá¼¶Ï„Î± ï¼ˆPh. 1345), Ï„Î¿á¿¦Ï„â€™ á¼„Î»Î»Î¿ ï¼ˆO. T. 605).

á¼¤Î»Î±Ï…Î½á½³ Î¼â€™ á¼Îº Î³á¿†Ï‚ Ï‡Ïá½¹Î½Î¹Î¿Î½, Î¿á¼± Î´â€™ á¼Ï€Ï‰Ï†ÎµÎ»Îµá¿–Î½, ğŸ—©
Line 441

Ï‡Ïá½¹Î½Î¹Î¿Î½, "after all that time,"â€” repeating the thought with which he had begun (Ï‡Ïá½¹Î½á¿³ 437). á¼Ï€Ï‰Ï†ÎµÎ»Îµá¿–Î½ with dat. (like á¼Ï€Î±ÏÎºÎµá¿–Î½) as Eur. Andr. 677, elsewhere usu. with acc. (Ph. 905, etc.): cp. the poet. dat. with the simple verb, Ant. 560 Ï„Î¿á¿–Ï‚ Î¸Î±Î½Î¿á¿¦ÏƒÎ¹Î½ á½ Ï†ÎµÎ»Îµá¿–Î½.

Î¿á¼± Ï„Î¿á¿¦ Ï€Î±Ï„Ïá½¹Ï‚, Ï„á¿· Ï€Î±Ï„Ïá½¶ Î´Ï…Î½á½±Î¼ÎµÎ½Î¿Î¹, Ï„á½¸ Î´Ïá¾¶Î½ ğŸ—©
Line 442

Î¿á¼± Ï„Î¿á¿¦ Ï€Î±Ï„Ïá½¸Ï‚ Ï„á¿· Ï€Î±Ï„Ïá½· blends two forms of antithesis,â€”(1) Î¿á¼± Ï€Î±á¿–Î´ÎµÏ‚ Ï„á¿· Ï€Î±Ï„Ïá½·, and (2) Î¿á¼± Ï„Î¿á¿¦ ÎŸá¼°Î´á½·Ï€Î¿Î´Î¿Ï‚ Ï„á¿· ÎŸá¼°Î´á½·Ï€Î¿Î´Î¹. The gen. of "origin," Ï„Î¿á¿¦ Ï€Î±Ï„Ïá½¹Ï‚, really a possessive gen., comes in with peculiar force here, as suggesting that the sons belong to the sire. For Ï€Î±^Ï„Ïá½¸Ï‚...Ï€Î±â€”Ï„Ïá½· cp. 883, Ph. 296 á¼€Î»Î»â€™ á¼Î½ Ï€á½³Ï„ÏÎ¿Î¹ÏƒÎ¹ Ï€á½³Ï„ÏÎ¿Î½, Ant. 1310 n.

Ï„á½¸ Î´Ïá¾¶Î½, on 47.

Î¿á½Îº á¼ Î¸á½³Î»Î·ÏƒÎ±Î½, á¼€Î»Î»â€™ á¼”Ï€Î¿Ï…Ï‚ ÏƒÎ¼Î¹ÎºÏÎ¿á¿¦ Ï‡á½±ÏÎ¹Î½ ğŸ—©
Line 443

á¼”Ï€Î¿Ï…Ï‚ ÏƒÎ¼Î¹ÎºÏÎ¿á¿¦ Ï‡á½±ÏÎ¹Î½, for lack of a few words in his defence (á¼€Î½Ï„Î¹Î»Î¿Î³á½·Î±Ï‚ Î²ÏÎ±Ï‡Îµá½·Î±Ï‚, schol.). As if one said, "They incurred all this loss for the sake of a petty sum" (i.e. to save it). This is a slight deviation from the ordinary use of á¼•Î½ÎµÎºÎ±, Î¿á½•Î½ÎµÎºÎ± (22), á¼•ÎºÎ±Ï„Î¹, Ï‡á½±ÏÎ¹Î½, in such phrases. Cp. fr. 510. 6 Îºá¼€Î¼Î¿á½¶ Î³á½°Ï á¼‚Î½ Ï€Î±Ï„á½µÏ Î³Îµ Î´Î±ÎºÏá½»Ï‰Î½ Ï‡á½±ÏÎ¹Î½ á¼€Î½á¿†ÎºÏ„â€™ á¼‚Î½ Îµá¼°Ï‚ Ï†á¿¶Ï‚, would have been brought up, if tears could bring him: Aesch. Ï†Ï…Î³á½±Ï‚ ÏƒÏ†Î¹Î½ á¼”Î¾Ï‰ Ï€Ï„Ï‰Ï‡á½¸Ï‚ á¼ Î»á½½Î¼Î·Î½ á¼€Îµá½·. ğŸ—©
Line 444

ÏƒÏ†Î¹Î½, i.e. they looked on and did nothing: see on Î±á½Ï„Î¿á¿–Î½ 430. The question between á¼€Îµá½· (L) and á¼Î³á½½ (A) turns on these points. With á¼€Îµá½·, á¼ Î»á½½Î¼Î·Î½ = "continued to wander." He can scarcely mean that, after his expulsion, they might at any time have recalled him, since he regards the new oracle as having given them an opportunity which did not exist before (418). But he may mean that their silence at the moment of his expulsion was the cause of the whole sequel. With á¼Î³á½½, á¼ Î»á½½Î¼Î·Î½ might mean, "proceeded to wander forth," referring to the moment of expulsion (cp. á¼Î¾Î·Î»Î±Ï…Î½á½¹Î¼Î·Î½ 356). But (a) the tense is somewhat awkward here, and (b) á¼Î³á½½ is weak unless taken as= "Iâ€”their father."

The constr. is, Îµá¼±Î»á½³ÏƒÎ¸Î·Î½ Î¸Ïá½¹Î½Î¿Ï…Ï‚, ÎºÎ±á½¶ ÎºÏÎ±á½·Î½ÎµÎ¹Î½ ÏƒÎºá¿†Ï€Ï„ÏÎ±, etc.

ÎºÏÎ±á½·Î½ÎµÎ¹Î½=(1) to bring a thing to pass, (2) to exercise power, to reign, sometimes with a gen. of the persons ruled (296, 862, etc.).

ÏƒÎºá¿†Ï€Ï„ÏÎ± goes with ÎºÏÎ±á½·Î½ÎµÎ¹Î½ as an almost adverbial cognate accus., "to rule with sceptre": as Ph. 140 ÏƒÎºá¿†Ï€Ï„ÏÎ¿Î½ á¼€Î½á½±ÏƒÏƒÎµÏ„Î±Î¹ (pass.) implies a similar ÏƒÎºá¿†Ï€Ï„ÏÎ¿Î½ á¼€Î½á½±ÏƒÏƒÏ‰. Line 453

The oracle newly brought by Ismene is distinguished from the oracle given to Oedipus himself at Delphi in former years (see on 87). He calls the former her oracle, because she brings it. Both oracles alike concern him. We must not, then, change Ï„á¼€Î¾ to Ï„á¼€Ï€â€™ ("concerning me").

Ï„á½° á¼Î¾ á¼Î¼Î¿á¿¦ Ï€Î±Î»Î±á½·Ï†Î±Ï„Î±=the earlier predictions which I, on my side, can produce: those which the resources of my knowledge furnish forth.

á¼Î¾ is appropriate, since they have been so long treasured in his inmost soul. Cp. on 293.

Line 454

á½Î¼Î¿á¿¦ | Ï€ÏÎ¿ÏƒÏ„á½±Ï„Î¹ÏƒÎ¹ (predicative), along with them as your protectors or champions against Theban violence. Oed. is already under the guard of the Eumenides as their á¼±Îºá½³Ï„Î·Ï‚ (284): if the Coloniates are loyal to the Eumenides, Attica and he will alike be saved.

Ï„á½¸ Ï€Ïá¿¶Ï„Î¿Î½ á¼µÎºÎ¿Ï… ÎºÎ±á½¶ ÎºÎ±Ï„á½³ÏƒÏ„ÎµÎ¹ÏˆÎ±Ï‚ Ï€á½³Î´Î¿Î½. ğŸ—©
Line 467

The libation is due (1) as a greeting to the Î¸ÎµÎ¿á½¶ á¼Î³Ï‡á½½ÏÎ¹Î¿Î¹ of Attica, (2) as an atonement for trespass on the grove. The words ÎºÎ±á½¶ ÎºÎ±Ï„á½³ÏƒÏ„ÎµÎ¹ÏˆÎ±Ï‚ Ï€á½³Î´Î¿Î½ form an independent sentence, and not a second relative clause (as if á½§Î½ were supplied from á¼Ï†â€™ á¼…Ï‚): see on 424.

ÎºÎ±Ï„á½³ÏƒÏ„ÎµÎ¹ÏˆÎ±Ï‚: Sappho fr. 95 Î¿á¼µÎ±Î½ Ï„á½°Î½ á½‘á½±ÎºÎ¹Î½Î¸Î¿Î½ á¼Î½ Î¿á½”ÏÎµÏƒÎ¹ Ï€Î¿Î¹Î¼á½³Î½ÎµÏ‚ á¼„Î½Î´ÏÎµÏ‚ Ï€Î¿ÏƒÏƒá½¶ ÎºÎ±Ï„Î±ÏƒÏ„Îµá½·Î²Î¿Î¹ÏƒÎ¹, "trample on": here the word suggests the rash violation of the Ï‡á¿¶ÏÎ¿Î½ Î¿á½Ï‡ á¼Î³Î½á½¸Î½ Ï€Î±Ï„Îµá¿–Î½ (37). The v.l. ÎºÎ±Ï„á½³ÏƒÏ„ÎµÏˆÎ±Ï‚ was explained figuratively: "came to the ground as a suppliant," who lays his branch (á¼±ÎºÎµÏ„Î·Ïá½·Î±), twined with festoons of wool (ÏƒÏ„á½³Ï†Î·), on an altar: see n. on O. T. 3. Schol.: ÎºÎ±Î¸Î¹Îºá½³Ï„ÎµÏ…ÏƒÎ±Ï‚, Î¼ÎµÏ„á½° á¼±ÎºÎµÏ„Î·Ïá½·Ï‰Î½ á¼€Ï†á½·ÎºÎ¿Ï…: justly adding that the other reading is Ï€Î¹Î¸Î±Î½á½½Ï„ÎµÏÎ¿Î½. ÎºÎ±Ï„á½±ÏƒÏ„ÎµÏˆÎ¿Î½ (marg. of L) was a grammarian's attempt to improve on ÎºÎ±Ï„á½³ÏƒÏ„ÎµÏˆÎ±Ï‚: it would refer to the twigs (483); but a secondary detail of the rite should not be thus forestalled and emphasised.

ÎŸá¼°. Ï„Ïá½¹Ï€Î¿Î¹ÏƒÎ¹ Ï€Î¿á½·Î¿Î¹Ï‚; á½¦ Î¾á½³Î½Î¿Î¹, Î´Î¹Î´á½±ÏƒÎºÎµÏ„Îµ.
Î§Î¿. Ï€Ïá¿¶Ï„Î¿Î½ Î¼á½²Î½ á¼±ÎµÏá½°Ï‚ á¼Î¾ á¼€ÎµÎ¹Ïá½»Ï„Î¿Ï… Ï‡Î¿á½°Ï‚ ğŸ—©
Line 469

á¼€ÎµÎ¹Ïá½»Ï„Î¿Ï…. The rule is that Ï is doubled when, by inflection or composition, a simple vowel precedes it, but remains single when a diphthong precedes it: hence Î½Îµá½¹ÏÏÏ…Ï„Î¿Ï‚, but á¼€Îµá½·ÏÏ…Ï„Î¿Ï‚. Through overlooking this distinction, Blaydes follows our MSS. in writing á¼€ÎµÎ¹ÏÏá½»Ï„Î¿Ï…. Metre often led the poets to use Ï instead of ÏÏ, as á¼€Î¼Ï†Î¹^Ïá½»Ï„Î¿Ï… (Ai. 134), Ï‡ÏÏ…ÏƒÎ¿Ïá½»Ï„Î¿Ï…Ï‚ (Ant. 950), Î±á½Ï„á½¹ÏÎ¹Î¶Î¿Ï‚ (Babrius fab. 69); and Ï€ÏÎ¿Ïá½³Ï‰, not Ï€ÏÎ¿ÏÏá½³Ï‰, was the regular form, as euphony plainly required. But there is no classical instance of the opposite anomaly.

470 ÎºÏá½µÎ½Î·Ï‚ á¼Î½ÎµÎ³ÎºÎ¿á¿¦, Î´á¿‘ á½Ïƒá½·Ï‰Î½ Ï‡ÎµÎ¹Ïá¿¶Î½ Î¸Î¹Î³á½½Î½. ğŸ—©
Line 470

Î´á¿‘ á½Ïƒá½·Ï‰Î½ Ï‡ÎµÎ¹Ïá¿¶Î½, i.e. after duly washing the hands before entering the sacred precinct. Blood-guilt is not thought of here: if that was in question, ÎºÎ±Î¸Î±ÏÎ¼Î¿á½¶ Ï‡Î¿Î¹ÏÎ¿ÎºÏ„á½¹Î½Î¿Î¹ (Aesch. Eum. 283) would first be needed for Oed. himself: but the Chorus assume that, as he said, he is now Îµá½ÏƒÎµÎ²á½µÏ‚ (287). Washings, or sprinklings, were required before approaching shrines, and for this purpose Ï€ÎµÏÎ¹ÏÏÎ±Î½Ï„á½µÏÎ¹Î± were set at the entrances of sacred places. Cp. Hippocr. Morb. á¼€Îºá½µÏÎ±Ï„Î¿Î½: Chrysippus ap. Plut. Stoic. repugn. 22 commends Hesiod for enjoining on men that they should respect the purity of rivers and springs, since thence the gods were served (Hes. Opp. 755).

Î§Î¿. ÎºÏÎ±Ï„á¿†Ïá½³Ï‚ Îµá¼°ÏƒÎ¹Î½, á¼€Î½Î´Ïá½¸Ï‚ Îµá½”Ï‡ÎµÎ¹ÏÎ¿Ï‚ Ï„á½³Ï‡Î½Î·, ğŸ—©
Line 472

ÎºÏÎ±Ï„á¿†Ïá½³Ï‚ Îµá¼°ÏƒÎ¹Î½: i.e. the priest in charge of the shrine keeps them ready for the use of the worshippers, near the spring in the inner part of the grove (505), from which they were to be filled. The libations to the Eumenides were wineless (100), but they are associated with the mixing-bowl which was regularly used in libations (of wine) to other deities. The crater had various forms, some of them local (thus Her. 4.61 speaks of a Î›á½³ÏƒÎ²Î¹Î¿Ï‚ ÎºÏÎ·Ï„á½µÏ, and 4. 152 of an á¼ˆÏÎ³Î¿Î»Î¹Îºá½¹Ï‚): but the general type was that of a large bowl, supported by a foot with a broad base, and having a handle at each side (cp. Guhl and Koner, p. 150).

ÎºÏá¾¶Ï„), acc. sing., the "top," i.e. rim, of each ÎºÏÎ±Ï„á½µÏ. In Il. 19.93 ÎºÏá½±Î±Ï„Î± is acc. plur., and Pindar is quoted by Eustath. Î»Î±Î²á½°Ï‚ á¼€Î¼Ï†Î¹ÏƒÏ„á½¹Î¼Î¿Ï…Ï‚, handles on each side of the ÏƒÏ„á½¹Î¼Î±, or mouth. The festoon of wool, which was to be wreathed round the rim of the bowl, could be secured to these. Wecklein understands handles which also served as spouts.

Ï‡Î¿á½°Ï‚ Ï‡á½³Î±ÏƒÎ¸Î±Î¹. Ï‡Î¿Î±á½· were offered to the gods of the under-world (cp. 1599), or to the dead (Ant. 431), as ÏƒÏ€Î¿Î½Î´Î±á½· to the gods above. Ï€Ïá½¸Ï‚ Ï€Ïá½½Ï„Î·Î½ á¼•Ï‰, not meaning, of course, that the time must be dawn. On the contrary it was an ancient custom that sacrifices to the Ï‡Î¸á½¹Î½Î¹Î¿Î¹ and to the dead should not be offered till after midday: Etym. M. 468 á¼€Ï€á½¸ Î´á½² Î¼ÎµÏƒÎ·Î¼Î²Ïá½·Î±Ï‚ á¼”Î¸Ï…Î¿Î½ Ï„Î¿á¿–Ï‚ ÎºÎ±Ï„Î±Ï‡Î¸Î¿Î½á½·Î¿Î¹Ï‚, and in Aesch. Eum. 109 Clytaemnestra speaks of sacrificing to the Eum. by night, á½¥ÏÎ±Î½ Î¿á½Î´ÎµÎ½á½¸Ï‚ ÎºÎ¿Î¹Î½á½´Î½ Î¸Îµá¿¶Î½.

The schol. here says that persons performing expiatory rites (á¼ÎºÎ¸á½»ÏƒÎµÎ¹Ï‚) or purifications (ÎºÎ±Î¸Î±ÏÎ¼Î¿á½·) faced the East (as the region of light and purity), quoting El. 424 f., where Electra á¼¡Î»á½·á¿³ | Î´Îµá½·ÎºÎ½Ï…ÏƒÎ¹ Ï„Î¿á½”Î½Î±Ï, and Cratinus á¼Î½ Î§Îµá½·ÏÏ‰Î½Î¹ (the title of the comedy was Î§Îµá½·ÏÏ‰Î½ÎµÏ‚, Bothe, Frag. Com. p. 47): á¼„Î³Îµ Î´á½´ Ï€Ïá½¸Ï‚ á¼•Ï‰ Ï€Ïá¿¶Ï„Î¿Î½ á¼Ï€á½±Î½Ï„Ï‰Î½ á¼µÏƒÏ„Ï‰ ÎºÎ±á½¶ Î»á½±Î¼Î²Î±Î½Îµ Ï‡ÎµÏÏƒá½¶ | ÏƒÏ‡á¿–Î½Î¿Î½ Î¼ÎµÎ³á½±Î»Î·Î½,â€”the squill being used in purifications.

Statues of gods were oft. set to face the East (Paus. 5.23.1, etc.): also, victims about to be sacrificed (Sen. Oed. 338). Cp. the precept of Zoroaster "to face some luminous object while worshipping god" (Max MÃ¼ller, Chips 1. 175). Conversely, in pronouncing solemn curses the priests faced the West,â€”waving red banners: [Lys.] In Andoc. Â§ 51 ÏƒÏ„á½±Î½Ï„ÎµÏ‚ ÎºÎ±Ï„Î·Ïá½±ÏƒÎ±Î½Ï„Î¿ Ï€Ïá½¸Ï‚ á¼‘ÏƒÏ€á½³ÏÎ±Î½ ÎºÎ±á½¶ Ï†Î¿Î¹Î½Î¹Îºá½·Î´Î±Ï‚ á¼€Î½á½³ÏƒÎµÎ¹ÏƒÎ±Î½.

ÎŸá¼°. á¼¦ Ï„Î¿á¿–ÏƒÎ´Îµ ÎºÏÏ‰ÏƒÏƒÎ¿á¿–Ï‚ Î¿á¼·Ï‚ Î»á½³Î³ÎµÎ¹Ï‚ Ï‡á½³Ï‰ Ï„á½±Î´Îµ; ğŸ—©
Line 478

ÎºÏÏ‰ÏƒÏƒÎ¿á¿–Ï‚ here=ÎºÏÎ±Ï„á¿†ÏÏƒÎ¹Î½. The word is fitting, since the ÎºÏÏ‰ÏƒÏƒá½¹Ï‚ was more esp. used for water (Eur. Ion 1173, Cycl. 89), though also sometimes for wine (Aesch. fr. 91 ÎºÏÏ‰ÏƒÏƒÎ¿á½ºÏ‚ | Î¼á½µÏ„â€™ Î¿á¼°Î½Î·ÏÎ¿á½ºÏ‚ Î¼á½µÏ„â€™ á½‘Î´Î±Ï„Î·ÏÎ¿á½»Ï‚), also for oil,â€”or as a cinerary urn. Guhl and Koner (p. 149) think that the krossos resembled the á½‘Î´Ïá½·Î±, which, like the Îºá½±Î»Ï€Î¹Ï‚, was a bulky, shortnecked vessel, oft. seen in the vase-paintings as borne by maidens on their heads when fetching water.

Î¿á¼·Ï‚ by attract. for Î¿á½•Ï‚.

Ï‡á½³Ï‰ delib. aor. (rather than pres.) subjunct.

Î§Î¿. Ï„ÏÎ¹ÏƒÏƒá½±Ï‚ Î³Îµ Ï€Î·Î³á½±Ï‚Â· Ï„á½¸Î½ Ï„ÎµÎ»ÎµÏ…Ï„Î±á¿–Î¿Î½ Î´â€™ á½…Î»Î¿Î½. ğŸ—©
Line 479

Ï€Î·Î³á½±Ï‚: here, strictly the gushing of the water from the bowl. From each of the three bowls he is to pour a Ï‡Î¿á½µ. The first and second bowls are to be filled with the spring water only; and from each of these he is to make a libation without emptying the bowl. The third bowl is to contain water sweetened with honey; and, in making the libation from this, he is to empty it.

Ï„ÏÎ¹ÏƒÏƒá½±Ï‚ might be distributive, "three from each bowl" (as the number nine recurs in 483); but in the Ï‡Î¿á½µ to the dead in Od. 10.519, at least, there are only three pourings, viz. of (1) hydromel, (2) wine, (3) water.

Ï„á½¸Î½ Ï„ÎµÎ»ÎµÏ…Ï„. (ÎºÏÏ‰ÏƒÏƒá½¹Î½) as if á¼”ÎºÏ‡ÎµÎ¿Î½, not Ï‡á½³Î¿Î½, were understood: cp. Menander fr. 461 Ï„á½¸Î½ Ï‡Î¿á¾¶ | á¼ÎºÎºá½³Ï‡Ï…ÎºÎ±Ï‚, you have emptied the pitcher.

ÎŸá¼°. 480 Ï„Î¿á¿¦ Ï„á½¹Î½Î´Îµ Ï€Î»á½µÏƒÎ±Ï‚ Î¸á¿¶; Î´á½·Î´Î±ÏƒÎºÎµ ÎºÎ±á½¶ Ï„á½¹Î´Îµ. ğŸ—©
Line 480

Î¸á¿¶ has raised needless doubts. The operator is to fetch water from the spring in the grove (469), fill the bowls which he will find ready, and place them in a convenient position for the rite. From the distinction just drawn between the first two bowls and the third, Oed. surmises that the contents of the latter are not to be of precisely the same nature as those of the others. He asks, then,â€” "With what shall I fill it, before placing it beside the other two,â€”preparatory to beginning the rite?"

Î§Î¿. á½•Î´Î±Ï„Î¿Ï‚, Î¼ÎµÎ»á½·ÏƒÏƒÎ·Ï‚Â· Î¼Î·Î´á½² Ï€ÏÎ¿ÏƒÏ†á½³ÏÎµÎ¹Î½ Î¼á½³Î¸Ï…. ğŸ—©

Î¼ÎµÎ»á½·ÏƒÏƒÎ·Ï‚=Î¼á½³Î»Î¹Ï„Î¿Ï‚: schol. á¼€Ï€á½¸ Î³á½°Ï Ï„Î¿á¿¦ Ï€Î¿Î¹Î¿á¿¦Î½Ï„Î¿Ï‚ Ï„á½¸ Ï€Î¿Î¹Î¿á½»Î¼ÎµÎ½Î¿Î½, quoting the Erastae (fr. 160) Î³Î»á½½ÏƒÏƒÎ·Ï‚ Î¼ÎµÎ»á½·ÏƒÏƒÎ·Ï‚ Ï„á¿· ÎºÎ±Ï„ÎµÏÏÏ…Î·Îºá½¹Ï„Î¹. á¼Î¾ á¼€Î¼Ï†Î¿á¿–Î½ Ï‡ÎµÏÎ¿á¿–Î½, perh. laying them with each hand alternately, beginning and ending with the right, or lucky, hand. The olive-branches symbolise the fruits of the earth and of the womb, for the increase of which the Eumenides were esp. prayed, since they could blight it: Aesch. ÏƒÏ‰Ï„á½µÏÎ¹Î¿Î½="with a view to ÏƒÏ‰Ï„Î·Ïá½·Î±",â€”leaving the hearer to think of that which Oed. gives, and also of that which he receives. Ïƒá½» Ï„), not Ïƒá½» Î³), is right. The constr. is Ïƒá½» Ï„Îµ Î±á½Ï„á½¸Ï‚ Î±á¼°Ï„Î¿á¿¦, ÎºÎ±á½¶ (Î±á¼°Ï„Îµá½·ÏƒÎ¸Ï‰) Îµá¼´ Ï„Î¹Ï‚ á¼„Î»Î»Î¿Ï‚ á¼€Î½Ï„á½¶ ÏƒÎ¿á¿¦ (Î±á¼°Ï„Îµá¿–Ï„Î±Î¹). á¼„Ï€Ï…ÏƒÏ„Î±: schol. á¼€Î½á½µÎºÎ¿Ï…ÏƒÏ„Î± (cp. on 130). Hence, he adds (quoting Polemon of Illium, circ. 180 B.C.), the hereditary priests of the Eumenides were called á¼©ÏƒÏ…Ï‡á½·Î´Î±Î¹. á¼€ÏÎºÎµá¿–Î½ â€¦ Ï€Î±Ïá¿‡. The thought is: "I have trespassed on the grove of the Eumenides, and it might be doubted whether such deities would accept the atonement from any hand but my own. Nay, I believe that they regard the intention rather than the outward details. If my deputy approaches the shrine in a loyal spirit, the offering will be acceptedâ€”yes, would be accepted, not on behalf of one man alone, but of many." Clemens Alex. Strom. 5. 258, after quoting Isaiah i. 16, "Wash you, make you clean," cites verses ascribed (though wrongly) to Menander, among which are, Î¸Îµá¿· Î´á½² Î¸á¿¦Îµ Î´Î¹á½° Ï„á½³Î»Î¿Ï…Ï‚ Î´á½·ÎºÎ±Î¹Î¿Ï‚ á½¤Î½, Î¼á½´ Î»Î±Î¼Ï€Ïá½¸Ï‚ á½¢Î½ Ï„Î±á¿–Ï‚ Ï‡Î»Î±Î¼á½»ÏƒÎ¹Î½ á½¡Ï‚ Ï„á¿‡ ÎºÎ±ÏÎ´á½·á¾³. Ï‡Ïá¿†ÏƒÏ„Î±Î¹ by crasis from Ï‡Ïá½´ á¼”ÏƒÏ„Î±Î¹, Ï‡Ïá½µ being a subst., "need." This is the view of H. L. Ahrens. I read á¼¤Î½ÎµÎ³Îºâ€™ Î¿á½–Î½ ÎºÎ±Îºá½¹Ï„Î±Ï„),... á¼¤Î½ÎµÎ³Îºâ€™ á¼€á½³ÎºÏ‰Î½. h)/negkon was, indeed, the ordinary form of the aor. in the older Attic, as inscriptions show, in which á¼¤Î½ÎµÎ³ÎºÎ± occurs first about 360 B.C. á¼¤Î½ÎµÎ³Îº) emphasises his ruling thought, his great pleaâ€” that he has been a sufferer, not a doer (267).

ÎºÎ±Îºá½¹Ï„Î±Ï„), the misery of his two involuntary crimes. á¼¤Î½ÎµÎ³ÎºÎ¿Î½ ... á¼¤Î½ÎµÎ³Îº) might possibly stand, but would be harsh. There is nothing to offend in á¼€á½³ÎºÏ‰Î½ Î¼á½²Î½... Ï„Î¿á½»Ï„Ï‰Î½ Î´á½³, meaningâ€”"The agent was not freeâ€”the acts were not voluntary."

In the MS. reading, á¼¤Î½ÎµÎ³ÎºÎ¿Î½â€”á¼¤Î½ÎµÎ³ÎºÎ¿Î½ á¼„ÎºÏ‰Î½ Î¼á½³Î½, á¼„ÎºÏ‰Î½ is wrong, since metre requires u- (cp. 510). With Bothe's á¼‘Îºá½¼Î½ the sense would be:â€”"I have endured misery through acts which were my own, indeed: but not one of them was done knowingly." The objections to this are insuperable. (1)

Î¸Îµá½¸Ï‚ á¼´ÏƒÏ„Ï‰ must clearly have been preceded by the mention of some point to which he could appeal in an extenuation of his deed,â€”not by an admission, such as á¼‘Îºá½½Î½ expresses. (2) á¼¤Î½ÎµÎ³ÎºÎ¿Î½ á¼‘Îºá½½Î½, in the supposed sense, is utterly at variance with the language and the whole tone of the play. Cp. 239 á¼”ÏÎ³Ï‰Î½ | á¼€Îºá½¹Î½Ï„Ï‰Î½: 964 á¼¤Î½ÎµÎ³ÎºÎ¿Î½ á¼„ÎºÏ‰Î½: 977 Ï€á¿¶Ï‚ á¼‚Î½ Ï„á½¹ Î³â€™ á¼†ÎºÎ¿Î½ Ï€Ïá¾¶Î³Î¼â€™ á¼‚Î½ Îµá¼°Îºá½¹Ï„Ï‰Ï‚ Ïˆá½³Î³Î¿Î¹Ï‚; he asks, speaking of his own deeds.

á¼Î¾ á¼Î¼Î¿á¿¦, sprung from me: no partic. need be supplied, since the verb á¼€Ï€á½³Î²Î». follows: cp. 250 á½… Ï„Î¹ ÏƒÎ¿Î¹ Ï†á½·Î»Î¿Î½ á¼Îº Ïƒá½³Î¸ÎµÎ½ (sc. á¼ÏƒÏ„á½·). ÎŸá¼°. Î¼Î±Ï„Ïá½¸Ï‚ ÎºÎ¿Î¹Î½á¾¶Ï‚ á¼€Ï€á½³Î²Î»Î±ÏƒÏ„Î¿Î½ á½ Î´á¿–Î½Î¿Ï‚. ğŸ—©
Line 533

Poetical Greek idiom would join ÎºÎ¿Î¹Î½á¾¶Ï‚ with á½ Î´á¿–Î½Î¿Ï‚ rather than with Î¼Î±Ï„Ïá½¹Ï‚. Cp. Aesch. Eum. 325 Î¼Î±Ï„Ïá¿·Î¿Î½ á¼…Î³Î½Î¹ÏƒÎ¼Î± Îºá½»ÏÎ¹Î¿Î½ Ï†á½¹Î½Î¿Ï…: Ant. 793 Î½Îµá¿–ÎºÎ¿Ï‚ á¼€Î½Î´Ïá¿¶Î½ Î¾á½»Î½Î±Î¹Î¼Î¿Î½.

ÎºÎ¿Î¹Î½á¾¶Ï‚ = which bore me also.

Î§Î¿. ÏƒÎ±á½· Ï„â€™ Îµá¼´Ïƒâ€™ á¼„Ïâ€™ á¼€Ï€á½¹Î³Î¿Î½Î¿á½· Ï„Îµ ÎºÎ±á½¶ ğŸ—©
Line 534

ÏƒÎ±á½· Ï„â€™ Îµá¼´Ïƒâ€™ á¼„á¿¤. The Chorus have known all along that Oed. had married Iocasta, and also that he was the father of the girls (cp. 170, 322); but they are supposed to learn now for the first time that Iocasta was their mother. In the earlier versions of the Oedipus-myth (as in the Odyssey) Iocasta bears no issue to Oed.; his children are borne by a second wife, Euryganeia. The Attic poets seem first to have changed this (see Introd. to O. T. p. xv). The Chorus would say: "Thine, then, they are by a double tie, at once as children and...as sisters?" but Oed. takes out of their mouths the second name which they shrink from uttering, and utters it himself with terrible emphasis.

ÎºÎ¿Î¹Î½Î±á½·, by the same mother: cp. O. T. 261 n.: so Ant. 1 ÎºÎ¿Î¹Î½á½¸Î½ Î±á½Ï„á½±Î´ÎµÎ»Ï†Î¿Î½ â€¦ Îºá½±ÏÎ±.

Ï€Î±Ï„Ïá½¸Ï‚ with á¼€Î´ÎµÎ»Ï†ÎµÎ±á½· only.

ÎŸá¼°. 535 ÎºÎ¿Î¹Î½Î±á½· Î³Îµ Ï€Î±Ï„Ïá½¸Ï‚ á¼€Î´ÎµÎ»Ï†ÎµÎ±á½·.
Î§Î¿. á¼°á½½. ğŸ—©
Line 536

á¼°á½½ â€” á¼°á½¼ Î´á¿†Ï„Î±: cp. El. 842 Î—Î›. Ï†Îµá¿¦. Î§ÎŸ. Ï†Îµá¿¦ Î´á¿†Ï„â€™.

Î³Îµ after Î¼Ï…Ïá½·Ï‰Î½ marks assent.

á¼Ï€Î¹ÏƒÏ„ÏÎ¿Ï†Î±á½· refers to the revival of the pangs in his soul by this questioning. His troubles are likened to foemen who, when they seem to have been repulsed and to be vanishing in the distance, suddenly wheel about and renew their onset. Î´á¿¶ÏÎ¿Î½. The Ï„Ï…ÏÎ±Î½Î½á½·Ï‚ was Î´Ï‰ÏÎ·Ï„á½¹Î½, Î¿á½Îº Î±á¼°Ï„Î·Ï„á½¹Î½ (O. T. 384),â€”the reward pressed on him by Thebes for worsting the Sphinx; and with the throne he received the hand of Iocasta.

Î¼Î·Î´â€™ á½‘Ï€á½¸ Î¤ÏÏ‰á¿“Î±Ï‚ Ï„Îµá½·Ï‡ÎµÏƒÎ¹ Ï†Î¸á½·Î¼ÎµÎ½Î¿Ï‚, Ï€á½±Ï„ÎµÏ, Î¼ÎµÏ„â€™ á¼„Î»Î»Ï‰Î½ Î´Î¿Ï…ÏÎ¹ÎºÎ¼á¿†Ï„Î¹ Î»Î±á¿· Ï€Î±Ïá½° Î£ÎºÎ±Î¼á½±Î½Î´ÏÎ¿Ï… Ï€á½¹ÏÎ¿Î½ Ï„ÎµÎ¸á½±Ï†Î¸Î±Î¹, Ï€á½±ÏÎ¿Ï‚ Î´â€™ Î¿á¼± ÎºÏ„Î±Î½á½¹Î½Ï„ÎµÏ‚ Î½Î¹Î½ Î¿á½•Ï„Ï‰Ï‚ Î´Î±Î¼á¿†Î½Î±Î¹. The MSS. give ÎºÎ±á½¶ Î³á½°Ï á¼„Î»Î»Î¿Ï…Ï‚ á¼Ï†á½¹Î½ÎµÏ…ÏƒÎ± Îº.Ï„.Î». Hermann's á¼Î»Î¿á½ºÏ‚ (for á¼„Î»Î»Î¿Ï…Ï‚) must mean either (1) "caught," as in a net, by fate, or (2) "caught" by LaÃ¯us and his men, in the sense of, "driven to fight for life." Neither sense is tolerable. Campbell suggests, "I murdered, and was convicted of the murder," saying that á¼Î»Î¿á½ºÏ‚ á¼Ï†á½¹Î½ÎµÏ…ÏƒÎ±=á¼‘á½±Î»Ï‰Î½ Ï†Î¿Î½Îµá½»ÏƒÎ±Ï‚. This is as if one said in English, "Having been hanged, he did the murder." To á¼€Î³Î½á½½Ï‚ the short Î±^ would be a grave objection: Soph. has the first Î± long thrice in á¼„Î³Î½Î¿Î¹Î±, twice in á¼€Î³Î½Î¿Îµá¿–Î½, once in á¼€Î³Î½á½½Ï‚ (O. T. 681), and short never: even in Î±á½Ï„á½¹Î³Î½Ï‰Ï„Î¿Ï‚ (Ant. 875) the Î¿ is long. Porson's á¼„Î½Î¿Ï…Ï‚ could hardly mean, "without understanding" merely in the sense of "unwittingly." The word means "silly," "foolish" (Ant. 281), and should here mean, "in folly," which is not an apt sense.

And all these corrections, confined to á¼„Î»Î»Î¿Ï…Ï‚, leave a blot. After á¼Ï†á½¹Î½ÎµÏ…ÏƒÎ±, ÎºÎ±á½¶ á½¤Î»ÎµÏƒÎ± is intolerably weak. Mekler's ÎºÎ±á½¶ Î³á½°Ï á¼„Î½, Î¿á½“Ï‚ á¼Ï†á½¹Î½ÎµÏ…Ï‚), á¼”Î¼â€™ á¼€Ï€á½½Î»ÎµÏƒÎ±Î½ brings out the point on which Oed. insists, and to which the words Î½á½¹Î¼á¿³ ÎºÎ±Î¸Î±Ïá½¹Ï‚ (548) refer,â€”viz. that, in slaying, he was defending his own life. Cp. 271. After he had returned the blow of LaÃ¯us, the attendants set on him (see on O. T. 804â€”812). The change of á¼Ï†á½¹Î½ÎµÏ…Ïƒâ€™ á¼”Î¼â€™ á¼€Ï€á½½Î»ÎµÏƒÎ±Î½ into á¼Ï†á½¹Î½ÎµÏ…ÏƒÎ± ÎºÎ±á½¶ á¼€Ï€á½½Î»ÎµÏƒÎ± (or Îºá¼€Ï€á½½Î»ÎµÏƒÎ±) would have been easy if á¼Ï†á½¹Î½ÎµÏ…Ïƒá½± Î¼â€™ á¼€Ï€á½½Î»ÎµÏƒÎ± had once been written. Î½á½¹Î¼á¿³ â€¦ ÎºÎ±Î¸Î±Ïá½¹Ï‚, because he had been first struck by LaÃ¯us, and was acting in self-defence. Plat. Line 549

ÎºÎ±á½¶ Î¼á½´Î½ introducing the new person: cp. 1249: so Ant. 526, 1180, 1257: Ai. 1168, 1223: El. 78, 1422.

ÎŸá¼°. á¼Î³á½¼ Ï†Ïá½±ÏƒÏ‰. ğŸ—©
Line 550

á½€Î¼Ï†á½µÎ½, his message. Usu. of a divine or oracular voice (102), but see 1351: Pind. fr. 53 á½€Î¼Ï†Î±á½¶ Î¼ÎµÎ»á½³Ï‰Î½ Ïƒá½ºÎ½ Î±á½Î»Î¿á¿–Ï‚: Eur. Med. 174 Î¼á½»Î¸Ï‰Î½ Ï„â€™ Î±á½Î´Î±Î¸á½³Î½Ï„Ï‰Î½ | â€¦ á½€Î¼Ï†á½±Î½ (the words of the Chorus).

ÎºÎ±á½¶ Î³á½°Ï á¼„Î½, Î¿á½“Ï‚ á¼Ï†á½¹Î½ÎµÏ…Ïƒâ€™, á¼”Î¼â€™ á¼€Ï€á½½Î»ÎµÏƒÎ±Î½Â· ğŸ—©
Line 551

The ÏƒÎºÎ¿Ï€á½¹Ï‚, who did not know the name of Oed., could describe the traces of wounds about the sightless eyes, and brought the mysterious message (72). Theseus then set out, surmising who it was. Meanwhile the name of Oed. had become known at Colonus (222), and wayfarers who met Theseus raised his surmise into certain knowledge. Cp. on 299 ff.

á¼”Î½ Ï„Îµ, answered by Ï„Î±Î½á¿¦Î½ Î¸â€™. The simplest statement would have been á¼”Î³Î½Ï‰Îºá½± ÏƒÎµ, á¼€ÎºÎ¿á½»Ï‰Î½ á¼”Î½ Ï„Îµ Ï„á¿· Ï€á½±ÏÎ¿Ï‚ Ï‡Ïá½¹Î½á¿³ Ï„Î±Î½á¿¦Î½ Ï„Îµ. Line 553

á¼”Î³Î½Ï‰Îºá½± Ï‚), "I have recognised thee"â€”explaining how he is able to greet him by name: not merely, "I recognise thee."

á¼”Î³Î½Ï‰ÎºÎ± is used (1) with a distinctly perfect sense: Lys. or. 17 Â§ 6 Ï„Î±á¿¦Ï„Î±...Ï€Ïá½¹Ï„ÎµÏÎ¿Î½ á¼Î³Î½á½½ÎºÎ±Ï„Îµ á¼¡Î¼á½³Ï„ÎµÏÎ± Îµá¼¶Î½Î±Î¹: Dem. or. 3 Â§ 10 á½…Ï„Î¹...Î´Îµá¿– Î²Î¿Î·Î¸Îµá¿–Î½...Ï€á½±Î½Ï„ÎµÏ‚ á¼Î³Î½á½½ÎºÎ±Î¼ÎµÎ½. ÏƒÎºÎµÏ…á½µ: cp. 1597 Îµá¼¶Ï„â€™ á¼”Î»Ï…ÏƒÎµ Î´Ï…ÏƒÏ€Î¹Î½Îµá¿–Ï‚ ÏƒÏ„Î¿Î»á½±Ï‚. The misery of his aspect impresses Creon (747), as it had impressed the Chorus (150). His garb, then, can hardly have announced a prince, though it may have indicated a Theban. Probably the reference is simply to the tale of long and destitute wanderings which his wretched apparel told (cp. 3 ff.).

á¼‚Î½ â€¦ Ï„á½»Ï‡Î¿Î¹Ï‚ â€¦ á¼Î¾Î±Ï†Î¹ÏƒÏ„Î±á½·Î¼Î·Î½: "strange would be the fortune which (=I cannot imagine what fortune) you could succeed in mentioning, from which I would hold aloof": another way of saying Î¿á½Îº á¼‚Î½ Ï„á½»Ï‡Î¿Î¹Ï‚ Î». Nub. 1250 Î¿á½Îº á¼‚Î½ á¼€Ï€Î¿Î´Î¿á½·Î·Î½ Î¿á½Î´â€™ á¼‚Î½ á½€Î²Î¿Î»á½¸Î½ Î¿á½Î´ÎµÎ½á½·, á½…ÏƒÏ„Î¹Ï‚ ÎºÎ±Î»á½³ÏƒÎµÎ¹Îµ Îºá½±ÏÎ´Î¿Ï€Î¿Î½ Ï„á½´Î½ ÎºÎ±ÏÎ´á½¹Ï€Î·Î½. Carefully distinguish the opt. á½ƒÎ½...Ïˆá½³Î¾Î±Î¹Î¼Î¹ at 1172, where see n.

Ï€Ïá¾¶Î¾Î¹Î½, "fortune," not "action." The sing. Ï€Ïá¾¶Î¾Î¹Ï‚ in Soph. usu. means "fortune," Ai. 790, Tr. 152, 294: while the sense of "action" usu. belongs to the plur. Ï€Ïá½±Î¾ÎµÎ¹Ï‚, as below, 958, O. T. 895, Ant. 435. There is only one Sophoclean exception each way: in Tr. 879 Ï€Ïá¾¶Î¾Î¹Ï‚ = "mode of doing," and in Ant. 1305 Ï€Ïá½±Î¾ÎµÎ¹Ï‚="fortunes." Cp. Aesch. PV 695 Ï€á½³Ï†ÏÎ¹Îºâ€™ á¼ÏƒÎ¹Î´Î¿á¿¦ÏƒÎ± Ï€Ïá¾¶Î¾Î¹Î½ á¼¸Î¿á¿¦Ï‚. Her. 3.65 á¼€Ï€á½³ÎºÎ»Î±Î¹Îµ Ï„á½´Î½ á¼‘Ï‰Ï…Ï„Î¿á¿¦ Ï€Ïá¿†Î¾Î¹Î½.

Î±á½Ï„á½¹Ï‚ Ï„Îµ Ï‡á¼  Ïƒá½´ Î´á½»ÏƒÎ¼Î¿ÏÎ¿Ï‚ Ï€Î±ÏÎ±ÏƒÏ„á½±Ï„Î¹Ï‚.
Î´á½·Î´Î±ÏƒÎºÎµÂ· Î´ÎµÎ¹Î½á½´Î½ Î³á½±Ï Ï„Î¹Î½â€™ á¼‚Î½ Ï€Ïá¾¶Î¾Î¹Î½ Ï„á½»Ï‡Î¿Î¹Ï‚ ğŸ—©
Line 562

Î¾á½³Î½Î¿Ï‚. Aethra, the mother of Theseus, was daughter of Pittheus, king of Troezen, where Theseus was brought up, in ignorance that his father was Aegeus, king of Athens. On arriving at manhood, he received from his mother the tokens of his birth (Ïƒá½»Î¼Î²Î¿Î»Î±, Î³Î½Ï‰Ïá½·ÏƒÎ¼Î±Ï„Î±) â€”the sword and sandals left at Troezen by Aegeusâ€”and set out for Attica. There he slew the sons of his uncle Pallas, who were plotting against his father, and was acknowledged by Aegeus as his heir (Plut. Thes. 4-13).

á¼Ï€á½¶ Î¾á½³Î½Î·Ï‚: 184

á½ƒÏ‚ Î¿á¼¶Î´Î± ÎºÎ±á½Ï„á½¸Ï‚ á½¡Ï‚ á¼Ï€Î±Î¹Î´Îµá½»Î¸Î·Î½ Î¾á½³Î½Î¿Ï‚, ğŸ—©
Line 564

ÎºÎ¹Î½Î´Ï…Î½Îµá½»Î¼Î±Ï„) (acc. of cognate notion), his encounters, on his way overland from Troezen to Attica, with various foes,â€”the robbers Periphetes, Sinis, Sciron, Procrustes,â€”the sow of Crommyon, â€”etc.; his slaying of the Minotaur in Crete;â€”his fighting on the side of the Lapithae against the Centaurs, etc. In all his Î±Î¸Î»Î¿Î¹ Theseus was depicted by the Attic legend as the champion of the oppressed,â€”á¼€Î´Î¹Îºá½µÏƒÏ‰Î½ Î¼á½²Î½ Î¿á½Î´á½³Î½Î±, Ï„Î¿á½ºÏ‚ Î´á½² á½‘Ï€á½±ÏÏ‡Î¿Î½Ï„Î±Ï‚ Î²á½·Î±Ï‚ á¼€Î¼Ï…Î½Î¿á½»Î¼ÎµÎ½Î¿Ï‚ (Plut. á¼Î½ Ï„á½ Î¼á¿· Îºá½±Ïá¾³, at the risk of my own life, á¼Î½ denoting the stake: Eur. Cycl. 654 á¼Î½ Ï„á¿· ÎšÎ±Ïá½¶ ÎºÎ¹Î½Î´Ï…Î½Îµá½»ÏƒÎ¿Î¼ÎµÎ½: Plat. Od. 2.237 Ï€Î±ÏÎ¸á½³Î¼ÎµÎ½Î¿Î¹ ÎºÎµÏ†Î±Î»á½±Ï‚, at the risk of their lives (as 3. 74 ÏˆÏ…Ï‡á½°Ï‚ Ï€Î±ÏÎ¸á½³Î¼ÎµÎ½Î¿Î¹): Il. 9.322 Î±á¼°á½²Î½ á¼Î¼á½´Î½ ÏˆÏ…Ï‡á½´Î½ Ï€Î±ÏÎ±Î²Î±Î»Î»á½¹Î¼ÎµÎ½Î¿Ï‚ Ï€Î¿Î»ÎµÎ¼á½·Î¶ÎµÎ¹Î½. Ï‡á½¡ Î»á½¹Î³Î¿Ï‚ Î´Î¹Î¿á½·Ï‡ÎµÏ„Î±Î¹, and the statement is at an end. á½ Î»á½¹Î³Î¿Ï‚ is the explanation due from Oedipus after sending for Theseus. Cp. Eur. Î´Î¹á½³ÏÏ‡ÎµÏ„Î±Î¹ (L) is certainly corrupt. It ought to mean, "the discussion is being carried through," rather than, "our conference draws to an end" (as Campbell, comparing Î´Î¹ÎµÎ¾ÎµÎ»á½µÎ»Ï…Î¸Î± Ï€á½±Î½Ï„Î±, Î´Î¹ÎµÎ¾á¿†Î»Î¸Î¿Î½ Î´Î¹á½° Î¼Î±ÎºÏÎ¿á¿¦ Î»á½¹Î³Î¿Ï…, which are not similar). Line 580

Ï€Î¿Ï…, i.e. so far as Oed. can conjecture the purpose of Apollo. He could not be sure that the close of his life would immediately follow on his arrival at the grove. The promised sign of the end had not yet been given (94).

Î˜Î·. Ï€Î¿á½·á¿³ Î³á½°Ï á¼¡ Ïƒá½´ Ï€ÏÎ¿ÏƒÏ†Î¿Ïá½° Î´Î·Î»á½½ÏƒÎµÏ„Î±Î¹; ğŸ—©
Line 581

Ï€Î¿á½·á¿³, sc. Ï‡Ïá½¹Î½á¿³, asks with surprise for some further definition of the vague Ï‡Ïá½¹Î½á¿³ Î¼á½±Î¸Î¿Î¹Ï‚ á¼„Î½. Theseus naturally assumes that the blessings are to come in the lifetime of Oedipus. And if not now, he asks, then in what contingency? The answer startles him.

Ï€ÏÎ¿ÏƒÏ†Î¿Ïá½°, offering, present. Theophrast. Char. XXX (=XXVI in my 1st ed.) it is like the Î±á¼°ÏƒÏ‡ÏÎ¿ÎºÎµÏÎ´á½µÏ‚, Î³Î±Î¼Î¿á¿¦Î½Ï„á½¹Ï‚ Ï„Î¹Î½Î¿Ï‚ Ï„á¿¶Î½ Ï†á½·Î»Ï‰Î½ ÎºÎ±á½¶ á¼ÎºÎ´Î¹Î´Î¿Î¼á½³Î½Î¿Ï… Î¸Ï…Î³Î±Ï„á½³ÏÎ± Ï€Ïá½¸ Ï‡Ïá½¹Î½Î¿Ï… Ï„Î¹Î½á½¸Ï‚ á¼€Ï€Î¿Î´Î·Î¼á¿†ÏƒÎ±Î¹, á¼µÎ½Î± Î¼á½´ Ï€á½³Î¼Ïˆá¿ƒ Ï€ÏÎ¿ÏƒÏ†Î¿Ïá½±Î½ (a wedding-present). Î´Î·Î»á½½ÏƒÎµÏ„Î±Î¹, pass.: see O. T. 672 n.

ÎŸá¼°. á½…Ï„Î±Î½ Î¸á½±Î½Ï‰ â€™Î³á½¼ ÎºÎ±á½¶ Ïƒá½» Î¼Î¿Ï… Ï„Î±Ï†Îµá½ºÏ‚ Î³á½³Î½á¿ƒ
Î˜Î·. Ï„á½° Î»Î¿á½·ÏƒÎ¸á¿‘ Î±á¼°Ï„Îµá¿– Ï„Î¿á¿¦ Î²á½·Î¿Ï…, Ï„á½° Î´â€™ á¼Î½ Î¼á½³Ïƒá¿³ ğŸ—©
Line 583

i.e. "You ask for the last offices which piety can render: you do not ask me for protection during your lifetime." Through the oracle (389), of which Theseus knows nothing, a grave in Attica had become the supreme concern of Oedipus.

Ï„á½° Î´â€™ á¼Î½ Î¼á½³Ïƒá¿³ is governed by Î»á¿†ÏƒÏ„Î¹Î½ á¼´ÏƒÏ‡ÎµÎ¹Ï‚ as=á¼Ï€Î¹Î»Î±Î½Î¸á½±Î½ÎµÎ¹ (see on 223), no less than by Ï€Î¿Îµá¿–. To make Ï„á½° Î´â€™ á¼Î½ Î¼. an accus. of respect would suit the first verb, but not the second.

Î´á¿‘ Î¿á½Î´ÎµÎ½á½¸Ï‚ Ï€Î¿Îµá¿–, a solitary instance of this phrase (instead of Î¿á½Î´ÎµÎ½á½¸Ï‚ or Ï€Î±Ïâ€™ Î¿á½Î´á½²Î½ Ï€Î¿Îµá¿–ÏƒÎ¸Î±Î¹), perh. suggested by the use of the prep. in such phrases as Î´Î¹á½° Ï†Ï…Î»Î±Îºá¿†Ï‚ á¼”Ï‡Ï‰ Ï„Î¹, etc.

á¼¢ Î»á¿†ÏƒÏ„Î¹Î½ á¼´ÏƒÏ‡ÎµÎ¹Ï‚ á¼¢ Î´á¿‘ Î¿á½Î´ÎµÎ½á½¸Ï‚ Ï€Î¿Îµá¿–.

Line 585

á¼Î½Ï„Î±á¿¦Î¸Î± Î³á½±Ï, "yes" for there,â€” in that boon (á¼Î½ Ï„á¿· Î¸á½±Ï€Ï„ÎµÏƒÎ¸Î±Î¹),â€”those other things (Ï„á½° á¼Î½ Î¼á½³Ïƒá¿³) are brought together for me: i.e. if you promise that I shall eventually be buried in Attica, you cannot meanwhile allow me to be forcibly removed to the Theban frontier. Line 586

á¼Î½ Î²ÏÎ±Ï‡Îµá¿– in sense=Î²ÏÎ±Ï‡Îµá¿–Î±Î½: "this grace which you ask of me lies in a small compass" (not, "you ask me this favour in brief speech"). Such phrases imply the omission of the partic. á½¤Î½: so 29 Ï€á½³Î»Î±Ï‚ Î³á½°Ï á¼„Î½Î´ÏÎ± Ï„á½¹Î½Î´â€™ á½Ïá¿¶: Ph. 26 Ï„Î¿á½”ÏÎ³Î¿Î½ Î¿á½ Î¼Î±ÎºÏá½°Î½ Î»á½³Î³ÎµÎ¹Ï‚ (the task which you set is not distant): El. 899 á½¡Ï‚ Î´â€™ á¼Î½ Î³Î±Î»á½µÎ½á¿ƒ Ï€á½±Î½Ï„â€™ á¼Î´ÎµÏÎºá½¹Î¼Î·Î½ Ï„á½¹Ï€Î¿Î½. Line 588

Ï€á½¹Ï„ÎµÏÎ±. Oed. has said, "If you pledge yourself to keep me in Attica, a serious issue will be raised." Theseus:â€” "Do you speak of the relations between your sons and me?" You mean that they will contest my right to retain you?

á¼Î³Î³ÎµÎ½á¿¶Î½ (Hartung) may be right; but the MS. á¼ÎºÎ³á½¹Î½Ï‰Î½ is not condemned by the evident fact that Theseus does not yet know of the quarrel between the father and the sons (599). It is enough if he knows the sons to exist: they would represent the claim of the á¼Î³Î³ÎµÎ½Îµá¿–Ï‚.

Îºá¼€Î¼Î¿á¿¦: the MS. á¼¢ )Î¼Î¿á¿¦ is certainly wrong. Theseus does not askâ€”"Will the issue be serious for your kinsmen, or for me?" but, "In what quarter will the issue arise?" ÎŸá¼°. ÎºÎµá¿–Î½Î¿Î¹ ÎºÎ¿Î¼á½·Î¶ÎµÎ¹Î½ ÎºÎµá¿–Ïƒâ€™ á¼„Î½Î±Î¾, Ï‡Ïá¿„Î¶Î¿Ï…Ïƒá½· Î¼Îµ. ğŸ—©
Line 589

Kayser's á¼„Î½Î±Î¾, Ï‡Ïá¿„Î¶Î¿Ï…ÏƒÎ¹ (for á¼€Î½Î±Î³Îºá½±Î¶Î¿Ï…ÏƒÎ¹) is exactly what the sense requires, and is fairly near to the MS. reading, while the latter is (I think) certainly corrupt. The verse must not be considered alone, but in close connection with 590, and with the whole context. It has been rendered:â€”(1) "They are for compelling (my protectors) to convey me to Thebes." But the ellipse of Ï„Î¹Î½á½± before ÎºÎ¿Î¼á½·Î¶ÎµÎ¹Î½ is intolerable. And the protectors could not be required to do more than surrender him. Therefore it is no cure to propose Îµá¼´ Ï‚) (for ÎºÎµá¿–Ï‚)) á¼€Î½Î±Î³Îºá½±ÏƒÎ¿Ï…Ïƒá½· Î¼Îµ. To read ÏƒÎµ for Î¼Îµ merely shifts the first difficulty, and leaves the second. (2) "They are for putting constraint on me, so as to carry (me) to Thebes." Such an epexegesis by the act. infin. is impossible here. Who could write á¼€Î½Î±Î³Îºá½±Î¶ÎµÎ¹ ÏƒÎµ á¼„Î³ÎµÎ¹Î½ á¼ÎºÎµá¿–ÏƒÎµ, meaning, "he is forcing thee, so as to take (thee) thither"? (3) ÎºÎ¿Î¼á½·Î¶ÎµÎ¹Î½ has been taken as="to return,"=ÎºÎ¿Î¼á½·Î¶ÎµÏƒÎ¸Î±Î¹. This needs no comment. We want either: (1) instead of ÎºÎ¿Î¼á½·Î¶ÎµÎ¹Î½, a word="to return"; but ÎºÎ±Ï„ÎµÎ»Î¸Îµá¿–Î½ is very unlikely, and no other substitute is obvious: or (2) instead of á¼€Î½Î±Î³Îºá½±Î¶Î¿Ï…ÏƒÎ¹, a word = "they wish, seek." That the fault lies in á¼€Î½Î±Î³Îºá½±Î¶Î¿Ï…ÏƒÎ¹ is very strongly suggested by 590, where L has á¼€Î»Î»â€™ Îµá¼° Î¸á½³Î»Î¿Î½Ï„â€™ á¼„Î½ Î³), evidently corrupted, by dittographia of Î³), from á¼€Î»Î»â€™ Îµá¼° Î¸á½³Î»Î¿Î½Ï„á½± Î³), which L2 has. This gives a clear and fitting sense, if in 589 we read á¼„Î½Î±Î¾, Ï‡Ïá¿„Î¶Î¿Ï…Ïƒá½· Î¼Îµ. All the trouble, for the MSS. and for the edd., has arisen from á¼€Î½Î±Î³Îºá½±Î¶Î¿Ï…ÏƒÎ¹. Hence (1) Goebel, á¼€Î»Î»â€™ Î¿á½ Î¸ÎµÎ»á½¹Î½Ï„Ï‰Î½, "but if they do not wish thee" (Ï†Îµá½»Î³ÎµÎ¹Î½): (2) Reisig, á¼€Î»Î»â€™ Îµá¼° Î¸á½³Î»Î¿Î½Ï„á½±Ï‚ Î³), "but what if it be not seemly for thee to shun them when willing (to receive thee)?" Both these are forced. Campbell supplies Îµá¼° Î²Î¿á½»Î»Î¿Î¹Î½Ï„Î¿ ÎºÎ¿Î¼á½·Î¶ÎµÎ¹Î½ to explain Î¸á½³Î»Î¿Î½Ï„Î±, keeping L's Î¸á½³Î»Î¿Î½Ï„â€™ á¼„Î½: but á¼„Î½ can stand with a partic. only when the latter is equiv. to an apodosis, as it is in 761. So far as the tense of á¼€Î½Î±Î³Îºá½±Î¶Î¿Ï…ÏƒÎ¹ is concerned, a change to the fut. is no gain: it is the pres. of tendency or intention. But the whole mention of compulsion or violence is premature in 589. Oed. leads very gently up to the disclosure of his sons' unnatural conduct (599).

Ï†Î¸á½·Î½ÎµÎ¹ Î¼á½²Î½ â€¦ Ï†Î¸á½·Î½ÎµÎ¹ Î´á½², epanaphora, as 5, O. T. 25 Ï†Î¸á½·Î½Î¿Ï…ÏƒÎ± Î¼á½²Î½ â€¦ | Ï†Î¸á½·Î½Î¿Ï…ÏƒÎ± Î´â€™, 259 á¼”Ï‡Ï‰Î½ Î¼á½²Î½...á¼”Ï‡Ï‰Î½ Î´á½³.

Î³á¿†Ï‚ has been needlessly suspected: here, as in the great speech of Ajax (Ai. 669â€”677), human destiny is viewed in relation to the whole order of nature. Cp. Tennyson, Tithonus 1 "The woods decay, the woods decay and fall, The vapours weep their burthen to the ground, Man comes and tills the field and lies beneath, And after many a summer dies the swan."

Î²á½³Î²Î·ÎºÎµÎ½, is set (cp. 1052). Ï„Î¿á¿–Ï‚ Î¼á½²Î½ Î³á½°Ï á¼¤Î´Î·, for some men at once (i.e., after but a brief friendship), for others, later.

á¼¤Î´Î· is here used as Î±á½Ï„á½·ÎºÎ± more often is: cp. Aesch. Cho. 1020 Î¼á½¹Ï‡Î¸Î¿Ï‚ Î´â€™ á½ Î¼á½²Î½ Î±á½Ï„á½·Ï‡), á½ Î´â€™ á¼¥Î¾ÎµÎ¹. No relationship between men or states is permanent, for the feelings with which they regard each other are liable to change,â€”from liking to dislike, yes, and back again to liking.

ÎºÎ±á½–Î¸Î¹Ï‚ Ï†á½·Î»Î±, by completing the circle, completes the picture of inconstancy. Nauck has quite needlessly suspected these two vv. á¼Ï†Î±á½·Î½ÎµÏ„Î¿ Ï„ÎµÎ»á¿¶Î½ (without á½¡Ï‚)= "was manifestly intending to perform": á¼Ï†Î±á½·Î½ÎµÏ„Î¿ á½¡Ï‚ Ï„ÎµÎ»á¿¶Î½="appeared as one intending to perform," á½¡Ï‚ marking the aspect in which he presented himself to their minds. Î´á¿†Ï„), "then," a comment on the speech of Oed. rather than on the words of the Chorus, as oft in questions (cp. 602).

á¼ÎºÎ²á½±Î»Î¿Î¹: properly, "cast out of doors," as a worthless thing: hence, "reject," "repudiate": Eur. fr. 362. 45 Ï€ÏÎ¿Î³á½¹Î½Ï‰Î½ Ï€Î±Î»Î±Î¹á½° Î¸á½³ÏƒÎ¼á¿‘ á½…ÏƒÏ„Î¹Ï‚ á¼ÎºÎ²Î±Î»Îµá¿–: Plat. Crito 46B Ï„Î¿á½ºÏ‚ Î´á½² Î»á½¹Î³Î¿Ï…Ï‚, Î¿á½“Ï‚ á¼Î½ Ï„á¿· á¼”Î¼Ï€ÏÎ¿ÏƒÎ¸ÎµÎ½ á¼”Î»ÎµÎ³Î¿Î½, Î¿á½ Î´á½»Î½Î±Î¼Î±Î¹ Î½á¿¦Î½ á¼ÎºÎ²Î±Î»Îµá¿–Î½. Others take it literally, "cast out of the land," so that á¼€Î½Î´Ïá½¸Ï‚ Îµá½Î¼á½³Î½ÎµÎ¹Î±Î½ Ï„Î¿Î¹Î¿á¿¦Î´Îµ=á¼„Î½Î´ÏÎ± Îµá½Î¼ÎµÎ½á¿† Ï„Î¿Î¹á½¹Î½Î´Îµ. But the notion of rashly scorning what is really precious gives more point both here and in 636.

Ï„Î¿Î¹Î¿á¿¦Î´â€™, á½…Ï„á¿³ Ï€Ïá¿¶Ï„Î¿Î½ Î¼á½²Î½ á¼¡ Î´Î¿Ïá½»Î¾ÎµÎ½Î¿Ï‚ ğŸ—©
Line 632

á½…Ï„á¿³, not á½…Ï„Î¿Ï…, is right. Con strue: á½…Ï„á¿³ á¼¡ Î´Î¿Ïá½»Î¾ÎµÎ½Î¿Ï‚ á¼‘ÏƒÏ„á½·Î± Î±á¼°á½²Î½ ÎºÎ¿Î¹Î½á½µ á¼ÏƒÏ„Î¹ Ï€Î±Ïâ€™ á¼¡Î¼á¿–Î½, lit., "to whom the hearth of an ally is always common among us":

ÎºÎ¿Î¹Î½á½µ, "common," = "giving reciprocal hospitality," which Theseus could claim at Thebes, as Oedipus at Athens.

Î±á¼°á½³Î½, i.e. "even if he had not this special claim." This seems better than to take ÎºÎ¿Î¹Î½á½µ as (1) "common to him with other Thebans," (2) "provided by our State," (3) "common to him with us," or (4) "accessible," as Andoc. or. 2 Â§ 147 Î¿á¼°Îºá½·Î± ÎºÎ¿Î¹Î½Î¿Ï„á½±Ï„Î· Ï„á¿· Î´ÎµÎ¿Î¼á½³Î½á¿³. With á½…Ï„Î¿Ï… the above version could not stand (since "belongs to him" could not replace "exists for him"), and so we should have to understand, á½…Ï„Î¿Ï… á¼¡ Î´Î¿Ïá½»Î¾ÎµÎ½Î¿Ï‚ á¼‘ÏƒÏ„á½·Î± Î±á¼°á½²Î½ ÎºÎ¿Î¹Î½á½µ á¼ÏƒÏ„Î¹ Ï€Î±Ïâ€™ á¼¡Î¼á¿–Î½, whose allied hearth (at Thebes) is always regarded among us as open to us ("as a common possession," Campb.): but this seems very forced.

Î´Î¿Ïá½»Î¾ÎµÎ½Î¿Ï‚, "spear-friend," is one with whom one has the tie of Î¾ÎµÎ½á½·Î± in respect of war: i.e., who will make common cause with one in war. It is applied by Aesch., Soph., and Eur. only to princes or chiefs, with an armed force at their command. Cp. Aesch. Cho. 562 Î¾á½³Î½Î¿Ï‚ Ï„Îµ ÎºÎ±á½¶ Î´Î¿Ïá½»Î¾ÎµÎ½Î¿Ï‚ Î´á½¹Î¼Ï‰Î½, said by Orestes when he presents himself Ï€Î±Î½Ï„ÎµÎ»á¿† ÏƒÎ±Î³á½´Î½ á¼”Ï‡Ï‰Î½: i.e. he comes not merely as the personal Î¾á½³Î½Î¿Ï‚ of the royal house, but as a chief in armed alliance with it. Plut. (Mor. 295 B, Quaest. Gr. 17) asks, Ï„á½·Ï‚ á½ Î´Î¿Ïá½»Î¾ÎµÎ½Î¿Ï‚; He conjectures that it meant, a ransomed prisoner of war, in his subsequent friendly relation to the ransomer (á¼Îº Î´Î¿ÏÎ¹Î±Î»á½½Ï„Î¿Ï… Î´Î¿Ïá½»Î¾ÎµÎ½Î¿Ï‚ Ï€ÏÎ¿ÏƒÎ±Î³Î¿ÏÎµÏ…á½¹Î¼ÎµÎ½Î¿Ï‚). This is against the usage of the poets, our only witnesses. And the source of the guess is clear. Plutarch was thinking of the verbal compounds, Î´Î¿ÏÎ¹á½±Î»Ï‰Ï„Î¿Ï‚, Î´Î¿Ïá½·ÎºÏ„Î·Ï„Î¿Ï‚, Î´Î¿Ïá½·Î»Î·Ï€Ï„Î¿Ï‚, etc. From these he inferred that Î´Î¿Ïá½»Î¾ÎµÎ½Î¿Ï‚ would mean primarily, "a friend gained through the spear."

Wecklein brackets the whole passage from 632 á½…Ï„á¿³ down to 637 Ï„á½´Î½ Ï„Î¿á¿¦Î´Îµ as "a later addition," because (1) there could be no Î¾ÎµÎ½á½·Î± when Oedipus did not even know the name of Theseus (68), and (2) ÏƒÎµÎ²Î¹ÏƒÎ¸Îµá½¶Ï‚ in 636 is suspicious. On this, see ad loc. As to (1), the Î¾ÎµÎ½á½·Î± to which Theseus refers is not a personal friendship, but a hereditary alliance between the royal houses, as in Eur. Suppl. 930 Polyneices (whom he had not seen before) is his Î¾á½³Î½Î¿Ï‚. Cp. on 619. After Wecklein's excision, we have Ï„á½·Ï‚ Î´á¿†Ï„â€™ á¼‚Î½ á¼€Î½Î´Ïá½¸Ï‚ Îµá½Î¼á½³Î½ÎµÎ¹Î±Î½ á¼ÎºÎ²á½±Î»Î¿Î¹ Ï„Î¿Î¹Î¿á¿¦Î´Îµ; Ï‡á½½Ïá¾³ Î´â€™ á¼”Î¼Ï€Î±Î»Î¹Î½ ÎºÎ±Ï„Î¿Î¹ÎºÎ¹á¿¶. This is incoherent.

ÎºÎ¿Î¹Î½á½µ Ï€Î±Ïâ€™ á¼¡Î¼á¿–Î½ Î±á¼°á½³Î½ á¼ÏƒÏ„Î¹Î½ á¼‘ÏƒÏ„á½·Î±;
á¼”Ï€ÎµÎ¹Ï„Î± Î´â€™ á¼±Îºá½³Ï„Î·Ï‚ Î´Î±Î¹Î¼á½¹Î½Ï‰Î½ á¼€Ï†Î¹Î³Î¼á½³Î½Î¿Ï‚ ğŸ—©
Line 634

á¼€Ï†Î¹Î³Î¼á½³Î½Î¿Ï‚, not, "because," but, "while," he has come. Besides his public claim (632), Oed. has two personal claims, (1) as the suppliant of the Eumenides, (2) as a visitor who can make a valuable return to Athens for protecting him.

Î´Î±ÏƒÎ¼á½¹Ï‚, usu. "tribute" (O. T. 36, and so in Xen.); here fig., "recompense."

Î¼á½³Î³â€™ á¼‚Î½ Î»á½³Î³Î¿Î¹Ï‚ Î´á½½ÏÎ·Î¼Î±,=Î¼á½³Î³Î± á¼‚Î½ Îµá¼´Î· Î´á½½ÏÎ·Î¼Î± á½ƒ Î»á½³Î³ÎµÎ¹Ï‚, it would be a great benefit of which you speak (sc. Îµá¼° ÎºÏÎ±Ï„Î¿á¿–Ï‚). Cp. Ant. 218.

Ï„á¿†Ï‚ ÏƒÏ…Î½Î¿Ï…Ïƒá½·Î±Ï‚, "from your abiding with the people here (at Colonus)": i.e. "You have suggested a strong reason for your staying here, rather than for going with me to Athens." Cp. Ï„á¿‡ Î¾Ï…Î½Î¿Ï…Ïƒá½·á¾³ in 63. It would be tame, at this stage, to take Î¾Ï…Î½Î¿Ï…Ïƒá½·Î± merely of his presence in Attica. The belief of Theseus in Theban amity (606) has now been shaken by his visitor (620).

Ï„á¿†Ï‚ Ï‚., gen. of source (ultimately possessive): O. T. 170 Ï†ÏÎ¿Î½Ï„á½·Î´Î¿Ï‚ á¼”Î³Ï‡Î¿Ï‚, a weapon furnished by thought.

Line 648

Îµá¼° ÏƒÎ¿á½· Î³â€™ | á¼…Ï€ÎµÏ Ï†á½´Ï‚ á¼Î¼Î¼ÎµÎ½Îµá¿–, "yes, if on your part (ethic dat.) the promise (of protection and burial) shall be observed, Ï„ÎµÎ»Î¿á¿¦Î½Ï„Î¹" by your performing it Î¼Î¿Î¹ for me (dat. of interest). á¼Î¼Î¼ÎµÎ½Îµá¿– alone might have meant merely, "if you abstain from withdrawing your promise": Ï„ÎµÎ»Î¿á¿¦Î½Ï„Î¹ supplements it, marking that good faith must be shown by deeds. Line 658

â€”660 Many emendations of 658 f. have been proposed, and Wecklein would reject the three verses altogether. To me they seem not only authentic but textually sound. They picture a tumult of passions in the soul, presently quelled by reason. The angry threats and the sobering reason are alike personified. The genuineness of the nominative Ï€Î¿Î»Î»Î±á½¶ Î´â€™ á¼€Ï€ÎµÎ¹Î»Î±á½¶ is confirmed by the imagery of the second clause, á¼€Î»Î»â€™ á½ Î½Î¿á¿¦Ï‚ á½…Ï„Î±Î½. For this animated personification of speech or passion, cp. Aesch. Cho. 845 á¼¢ Ï€Ïá½¸Ï‚ Î³Ï…Î½Î±Î¹Îºá¿¶Î½ Î´ÎµÎ¹Î¼Î±Ï„Î¿á½»Î¼ÎµÎ½Î¿Î¹ Î»á½¹Î³Î¿Î¹ Ï€ÎµÎ´á½±ÏÏƒÎ¹Î¿Î¹ Î¸Ïá½½ÏƒÎºÎ¿Ï…ÏƒÎ¹, Î¸Î½á¿„ÏƒÎºÎ¿Î½Ï„ÎµÏ‚ Î¼á½±Ï„Î·Î½: Eur. Hipp. 1416 Î¿á½Î´á½² Î³á¿†Ï‚ á½‘Ï€á½¸ Î¶á½¹Ï†á¿³ Î¸Îµá¾¶Ï‚ á¼„Ï„Î¹Î¼Î¿Î¹ Îšá½»Ï€ÏÎ¹Î´Î¿Ï‚ á¼Îº Ï€ÏÎ¿Î¸Ï…Î¼á½·Î±Ï‚ á½€ÏÎ³Î±á½¶ ÎºÎ±Ï„Î±ÏƒÎºá½µÏˆÎ¿Ï…ÏƒÎ¹Î½ á¼Ï‚ Ï„á½¸ Ïƒá½¸Î½ Î´á½³Î¼Î±Ï‚. The cognate verb ÎºÎ±Ï„Î·Ï€Îµá½·Î»Î·ÏƒÎ±Î½ (gnomic aorist), instead of the simple á¼”Î»ÎµÎ¾Î±Î½, gives an emphasis like that which the cogn. accus. would give in Ï€Î¿Î»Î»Î¿á½¶ á¼€Ï€ÎµÎ¹Î»á½°Ï‚ ÎºÎ±Ï„Î·Ï€Îµá½·Î»Î·ÏƒÎ±Î½.

Î¸Ï…Î¼á¿· modal dat., "in wrath-" (not locative, "in the soul"): cp. Plat. Legg. 866D ï¼ˆ á¼á½°Î½ ï¼‰ Î¸Ï…Î¼á¿· â€¦ á¾– Ï„á½¸ Ï€ÎµÏ€ÏÎ±Î³Î¼á½³Î½Î¿Î½ á¼ÎºÏ€ÏÎ±Ï‡Î¸á½³Î½: O. T. 405 á½€ÏÎ³á¿‡ Î»ÎµÎ»á½³Ï‡Î¸Î±Î¹.

ÎºÎµá½·Î½Î¿Î¹Ï‚ (referring to á¼„Î½Î´ÏÎµÏ‚ in 653) goes both with á¼Ï€ÎµÏÏ. and with Ï†Î±Î½á½µÏƒÎµÏ„Î±Î¹.

ÎºÎ±á½¶ Îµá¼° á¼Ï€ÎµÏÏá½½ÏƒÎ¸Î· (impersonal) even if courage has come to them Î´ÎµÎ¹Î½á½° Î»á½³Î³ÎµÎ¹Î½ to say dread things Ï„á¿†Ï‚ Ïƒá¿†Ï‚ á¼€Î³Ï‰Î³á¿†Ï‚ about your removal (for the gen. see on 355: for Ï„á¿†Ï‚ Ïƒá¿†Ï‚ as=an objective ÏƒÎ¿Ï…, on 332). Î»á½³Î³ÎµÎ¹Î½. Whitelaw: "though terrible things were emboldened to the utterance,"â€”comparing 658 á¼€Ï€ÎµÎ¹Î»Î±á½¶...ÎºÎ±Ï„Î·Ï€Îµá½·Î»Î·ÏƒÎ±Î½. We cannot read ÎºÎµá¿–Î½Î¿Ï‚, since the pl. is needed. The best solution would be ÎºÎµá½·Î½Î¿Î¹Ï‚ Î´á½³, ÎºÎµá¼´ Ï„Î¹Ï‚, from which á¼´ÏƒÏ‰Ï‚ ÎºÎµá¼° might have come through a transposition. But the sarcastic

á¼´ÏƒÏ‰Ï‚ is fitting: cp. Ai. 962 á¼´ÏƒÏ‰Ï‚ Ï„Î¿Î¹, ÎºÎµá¼° Î²Î»á½³Ï€Î¿Î½Ï„Î± Î¼á½´ )Ï€á½¹Î¸Î¿Ï…Î½ | Î¸Î±Î½á½¹Î½Ï„â€™ á¼‚Î½ Î¿á¼°Î¼á½½Î¾ÎµÎ¹Î±Î½.

ÎºÎµá¼° here where Îµá¼° ÎºÎ±á½¶ would be natural (as granting the fact); whereas in 306 the ÎºÎµá¼° is normal: see O. T. Append. Note 8, p. 296.

The first word Îµá½á½·Ï€Ï€Î¿Ï… strikes a note which connects Colonus á¼µÏ€Ï€Î¹Î¿Ï‚ with the fame of Attica. Take Î³á¾¶Ï‚ with ÎºÏá½±Ï„Î¹ÏƒÏ„Î±. Ï„á½¸Î½: the antistrophic syll. (Î½á½±ÏÎºâ€ 683), is long, but it is needless to write Ï„á½¹Î½Î´), since the anacrusis is common.

á¼€ÏÎ³á¿†Ï„Î±, "white," contrasting with Ï‡Î»Ï‰ÏÎ±á¿–Ï‚ (673). See Tozer, Geography of Greece p. 242: "The site of Colonus is distinguished by two bare knolls of lightcoloured earth, the á¼€ÏÎ³á¿†Ï„Î± ÎšÎ¿Î»Ï‰Î½á½¹Î½" of the poet,â€”not chalky, as the expositors of that passage often describe it to be. Schol. Ï„á½¸Î½ Î»ÎµÏ…Îºá½¹Î³ÎµÏ‰Î½. From âˆšARG, denoting "brightness," come (a) the group of words for "bright" or white, á¼€ÏÎ³á½¹Ï‚, á¼€ÏÎ³á½µÏ‚, á¼€ÏÎ³Î¹Î½á½¹ÎµÎ¹Ï‚, á¼€ÏÎ³ÎµÎ½Î½á½¹Ï‚, á¼„ÏÎ³Ï…Ï†Î¿Ï‚: (b) á¼„ÏÎ³Ï…ÏÎ¿Ï‚: (c) á¼„ÏÎ³Î¹Î»Î¿Ï‚, argilla, white clay. Thus the notion of a light-coloured soil was specially associated with this root. And this was certainly one reason why places were called "white,"â€”whether the soil was merely light-coloured, as at Colonus, or chalky. Pindar puts Cyrene á¼Î½ á¼€ÏÎ³Î¹Î½á½¹ÎµÎ½Ï„Î¹ Î¼Î±ÏƒÏ„á¿· (P. 4. 8), and it is known to have stood on a chalk cliff (F. B. Goddard in Amer. Journ. Philol. v. 31 ap. Gildersleeve ad loc.). Soil is suggested by á¼€ÏÎ³Îµá½·Î»Î¿Ï†Î¿Î½ Ï€á½°Ï Î–ÎµÏ†Ï…Ïá½·Ï‰Î½ ÎºÎ¿Î»á½½Î½Î±Î½ (the town Î›Î¿ÎºÏÎ¿á½¶ á¼˜Ï€Î¹Î¶ÎµÏ†á½»ÏÎ¹Î¿Î¹ on the S.E. coast of Italy, Pind. fr. 200); and soil or light-coloured rocks by á¼ˆÏÎ³Î¹Î½Î¿á¿¦ÏƒÎ±Î¹, the three islets off the coast of Aeolis (Strabo 617). Cp. "Albion." But a town on a hill might also owe the epithet to its buildings. The ivy and the vine (17) being sacred to Dionysus (Î¸ÎµÎ¿á¿¦), the foliage of the place generally is called his. Î¸ÎµÎ¿á¿¦ is certainly not the hero Colonus (65). We might desire Î¸Îµá¾¶Î½ (the Eumenides), but the Ï†Ï…Î»Î»á½±Ï‚ meant is not only that of the sacred grove; it includes the Academy.

Î¼Ï…ÏÎ¹á½¹ÎºÎ±ÏÏ€Î¿Î½ refers to the berries of the laurel (Ï€Î±Î³Îºá½±ÏÏ€Î¿Ï… Î´á½±Ï†Î½Î·Ï‚ O. T. 83), the fruit of the olive and of the vine. Cp. on 17.

á¼Î¼Î²Î±Ï„Îµá½»ÎµÎ¹, haunts the ground, Aesch. Pers. 449 Î á½°Î½ á¼Î¼Î²Î±Ï„Îµá½»ÎµÎ¹ Ï€Î¿Î½Ï„á½·Î±Ï‚ á¼€ÎºÏ„á¿†Ï‚ á¼”Ï€Î¹.

á¼€Î¼Ï†Î¹Ï€Î¿Î»á¿¶Î½, properly, "moving around," so, "attending on," "roaming in company with." The bold use seems to have been suggested by the noun á¼€Î¼Ï†á½·Ï€Î¿Î»Î¿Ï‚ as="follower" (Pind., etc.), á¼€Î¼Ï†Î¹Ï€Î¿Î»Îµá¿–Î½ being here to that noun as á½€Ï€Î±Î´Îµá¿–Î½ to á½€Ï€Î±Î´á½¹Ï‚.

Î§Î¿. Î¸á½±Î»Î»ÎµÎ¹ Î´â€™ Î¿á½ÏÎ±Î½á½·Î±Ï‚ á½‘Ï€â€™ á¼„Ï‡Î½Î±Ï‚ ğŸ—©
Line 681

Î¸á½±Î»Î»ÎµÎ¹ Î´). After the mention of Dionysus, the narcissus now serves to introduce a mention of Demeter and Persephone (Cora). Under the name of á¼¼Î±ÎºÏ‡Î¿Ï‚, represented as the son of Cora (or sometimes of Demeter), Dionysus was associated in the Eleusinian mysteries with the "two goddesses" (Ï„á½¼ Î¸Îµá½½): thus Ant. 1119 he reigns Ï€Î±Î³ÎºÎ¿á½·Î½Î¿Î¹Ï‚ á¼˜Î»ÎµÏ…ÏƒÎ¹Î½á½·Î±Ï‚ | Î”Î·Î¿á¿¦Ï‚ á¼Î½ Îºá½¹Î»Ï€Î¿Î¹Ï‚. A relief found at Eleusis in 1859, and referable to the period between Pheidias and Praxiteles, shows Persephone with her right hand on the head of the young Iacchos (a boy of some fifteen years), who is facing Demeter. It is reproduced in Baumeister's DenkmÃ¤ler des klass. Alterth., s.v. "Eleusinia," p. 471. There was a shrine of Demeter near Colonus, 1600.

á½ ÎºÎ±Î»Î»á½·Î²Î¿Ï„ÏÏ…Ï‚ ÎºÎ±Ï„â€™ á¼¦Î¼Î±Ï á¼€Îµá½¶
Î½á½±ÏÎºÎ¹ÏƒÏƒÎ¿Ï‚, Î¼ÎµÎ³á½±Î»Î±Î¹Î½ Î¸ÎµÎ±á¿–Î½ ğŸ—©
Line 683

Î½á½±ÏÎºÎ¹ÏƒÏƒÎ¿Ï‚. As the epithet shows, some thickly-flowering variety is meant: cp. Vergil's "comantem Narcissum," Geo. 4. 122. Wieseler (Narkissos, pp. 114 ff., GÃ¶tt. 1856) thinks that a lily is meant here. Bentham (British Flora, 4th ed., p. 473) says that the narcissus poeticus of the Mediterranean region "has usually a solitary flower of a pure white, except the crown, which is yellow, often edged with orange or crimson." This does not suit ÎºÎ±Î»Î»á½·Î²Î¿Ï„ÏÏ…Ï‚. There is a like doubt about the classical á½‘á½±ÎºÎ¹Î½Î¸Î¿Ï‚, variously taken as iris, gladiolus, or larkspurâ€”at any rate, not our hyacinth. But, whatever the true identification here may be, the symbolism of Î½á½±ÏÎºÎ¹ÏƒÏƒÎ¿Ï‚ in Greek mythology is clear. It is the flower of imminent death, being associated, through its narcotic fragrance, with Î½á½±ÏÎºÎ·,â€”the pale beauty of the flower helping the thought. It is the last flower for which Persephone is stretching forth her hand when Pluto seizes her,â€”Earth having put forth a wondrous narcissus, with a hundred flowers, on purpose to tempt her: Hom. Hymn. 5.15 á¼¡ Î´â€™ á¼„ÏÎ± Î¸Î±Î¼Î²á½µÏƒÎ±Ïƒâ€™ á½ Ïá½³Î¾Î±Ï„Î¿ Ï‡ÎµÏÏƒá½¶Î½ á¼…Î¼â€™ á¼„Î¼Ï†Ï‰ ÎºÎ±Î»á½¸Î½ á¼„Î¸Ï…ÏÎ¼Î± Î»Î±Î²Îµá¿–Î½Â· Ï‡á½±Î½Îµ Î´á½² Ï‡Î¸á½¼Î½ Îµá½ÏÏ…á½±Î³Ï…Î¹Î±. Paus. 9.31.9 (quoting an ancient hymn by the legendary poet Pamphos) says that Cora was seized Î¿á½Îº á¼´Î¿Î¹Ï‚ á¼€Ï€Î±Ï„Î·Î¸Îµá¿–ÏƒÎ±Î½ á¼€Î»Î»á½° Î½Î±ÏÎºá½·ÏƒÏƒÎ¿Î¹Ï‚. So Euphorion (220 B.C.) fr. 52 Î•á½Î¼ÎµÎ½á½·Î´ÎµÏ‚ Î½Î±ÏÎºá½·ÏƒÏƒÎ¿Ï… á¼Ï€Î¹ÏƒÏ„ÎµÏ†á½³ÎµÏ‚ Ï€Î»Î¿ÎºÎ±Î¼á¿–Î´Î±Ï‚. Artemidorus (160 A.D.), interpreting dreams of crowning the head, says, ÏƒÏ„á½³Ï†Î±Î½Î¿Î¹ Î½Î±ÏÎºá½·ÏƒÏƒÏ‰Î½ Ï€ÎµÏ€Î¿Î¹Î·Î¼á½³Î½Î¿Î¹ Ï€á¾¶ÏƒÎ¹ ÎºÎ±ÎºÎ¿á½· (Oneirocr. I. 77). Narcissus is the fair youth cold to love, whose face seen by himself in the water was the prelude of death (cp. Artemid. 2. 7).

Î¼ÎµÎ³á½±Î»Î±Î¹Î½ Î¸ÎµÎ±á¿–Î½: Paus. 8.31.1 (at Megalopolis) Î¸Îµá¿¶Î½ á¼±ÎµÏá½¸Î½ Ï„á¿¶Î½ Î¼ÎµÎ³á½±Î»Ï‰Î½Â· Î±á¼± Î´á½³ Îµá¼°ÏƒÎ¹Î½ Î±á¼± Î¼ÎµÎ³á½±Î»Î±Î¹ Î¸ÎµÎ±á½¶ Î”Î·Î¼á½µÏ„Î·Ï ÎºÎ±á½¶ Îšá½¹ÏÎ·. In Attic usu. Ï„á½¼ Î¸Îµá½½, and so Andoc. or. 1 Â§ 32 (of these goddesses) Ï€Ïá½¸Ï‚ Ï„Î¿á¿–Î½ Î¸ÎµÎ¿á¿–Î½ is now read (v.l. Ï„Î±á¿–Î½ Î¸ÎµÎ±á¿–Î½). Indeed Î¸Îµá½± is rare in Attic prose except in such phrases as Î¸ÎµÎ¿á½ºÏ‚ ÎºÎ±á½¶ Î¸Îµá½±Ï‚. But here, in a lyric passage, and with an epithet added, the poet may have preferred the less familiar Î¸ÎµÎ±á¿–Î½. The schol. was wrong in desiring Ï„á¾¶Î½ Î¼ÎµÎ³Î±Î»á¾¶Î½ Î¸Îµá¾¶Î½ (meaning the Eumenides).

á¼€ÏÏ‡Î±á¿–Î¿Î½ ÏƒÏ„ÎµÏ†á½±Î½Ï‰Î¼â€™, á½… Ï„Îµ ğŸ—©
Line 684

á¼€ÏÏ‡Î±á¿–Î¿Î½ ÏƒÏ„ÎµÏ†á½±Î½Ï‰Î¼). The narcissus does not figure specially as an attribute of the goddessesâ€”as the corn-ears and poppy of Demeter, the pomegranate of Cora, and the myrtle of Iacchos. But, as the flower which Cora was plucking when seized, it was associated with their cult from the first (á¼€ÏÏ‡Î±á¿–Î¿Î½), and was one of the flowers which would be most fitly woven into those floral wreaths which, on the wall-paintings, sometimes replace Demeter's more usual crown of corn-ears (see Baumeister, Denkm. p. 417). Hesych. says that in Crete the narcissus was called Î´Î±Î¼á½±Ï„ÏÎ¹Î¿Î½. In Rhodes Cora was crowned with asphodel (Bekker Anecd. I. 457. 9). At Hermione a flower like the á½‘á½±ÎºÎ¹Î½Î¸Î¿Ï‚, locally called ÎºÎ¿ÏƒÎ¼Î¿Ïƒá½±Î½Î´Î±Î»Î¿Î½, was worn by the worshippers of Demeter Chthonia (Paus. 2.35.5). Schneidewin's explanation, "original crown,"â€” before they changed it for others,â€”is against the myth itself, which makes the narcissus a new joy to Cora's eyes (Hom. Hymn. 5.15).

685 Ï‡ÏÏ…ÏƒÎ±Ï…Î³á½´Ï‚ ÎºÏá½¹ÎºÎ¿Ï‚Â· Î¿á½Î´â€™ á¼„Ï‹Ï€Î½Î¿Î¹ ğŸ—©
Line 685

Ï‡ÏÏ…ÏƒÎ±Ï…Î³á½´Ï‚ ÎºÏá½¹ÎºÎ¿Ï‚. Tozer, Geogr. of Greece p. 162: "when Sophocles... speaks of the crocus with its golden sheen," we would fain regard this as the same with the splendid flower that displays its golden blossoms close to the snow on Parnassus and the mountains of Arcadia. But, in reality, there can be little doubt that it was the cultivated crocus, from which the saffron was obtained, and which was introduced into Greece from the East, where it was prized as a dye for robes and slippers,â€” the ÎºÏÎ¿Îºá½¹Î²Î±Ï€Ï„Î¿Î½ Ï€Î¿Î´á½¸Ï‚ Îµá½”Î¼Î±ÏÎ¹Î½ of the Persae [660]â€”the sign of royalty and majesty. Cp. Hom. Hymn. 4.177 (Î¿Ï† Ï†Î±Î¹Ï Î¼Î±Î¹Î´ÎµÎ½Ï‚) á¼€Î¼Ï†á½¶ Î´á½² Ï‡Î±á¿–Ï„Î±Î¹ á½¤Î¼Î¿Î¹Ï‚ á¼€á¿“ÏƒÏƒÎ¿Î½Ï„Î¿ ÎºÏÎ¿ÎºÎ·á¿“á¿³ á¼„Î½Î¸ÎµÎ¹ á½Î¼Î¿á¿–Î±Î¹. Along with roses, violets, "hyacinth," "narcissus," and "agallis" (iris?), the "crocus" is gathered by Cora (ib. 6 ff.). Schol. Îºá¼€Î½ Ï„á¿‡ ÎÎ¹Î¿Î²á¿ƒ á½ Î£Î¿Ï†Î¿ÎºÎ»á¿†Ï‚ Ï„á½¸Î½ ÎºÏá½¹ÎºÎ¿Î½ á¼„Î½Ï„Î¹ÎºÏÏ…Ï‚ Ï„á¿‡ Î”á½µÎ¼Î·Ï„ÏÎ¹ á¼€Î½Î±Ï„á½·Î¸ÎµÏ„Î±Î¹. At the Thesmophoria (the festival of Demeter Î¸ÎµÏƒÎ¼Î¿Ï†á½¹ÏÎ¿Ï‚), when wreaths of flowers were not worn (schol.), the women appeared in ÎºÏÎ¿ÎºÏ‰Ï„Î¿á½·, saffroncoloured robes (Ar. Thesm. 138). The crocus was planted on graves (Juv. Sat. 7. 208).

ÎºÏá¿†Î½Î±Î¹ Î¼Î¹Î½á½»Î¸Î¿Ï…ÏƒÎ¹Î½ ğŸ—©
Line 686

ÎºÏá¿†Î½Î±Î¹, the "founts." "The most distant sources of the river are on the w. side of Mt. Pentelicus and the s. side of Mt. Parnes, and in the intermediate ridge which unites them" (Leake): in particular, a broad stream descends from the steepest part of Parnes. The Cephisus has a course of about 20 miles to the bay of Phalerum.

Î¼Î¹Î½á½»Î¸Î¿Ï…ÏƒÎ¹Î½. Soph. has seized a distinctive point. Even at this day, when the plain has much less shade than of old, the Cephisus "never fails," while in the long droughts of summer the bed of the Ilissus is absolutely dry. Cp. Modern Greece by H. M. Baird (1856) p. 294: "The little river Cephisus...scatters fertility and verdure around. Great was the contrast between its banks and the rest of the plain, which in the month of October is dry, parched, and dusty. The whole valley, in its width of six miles, had been stripped of nearly every vestige of vegetation; for not a drop of water had fallen during the previous four or five months."â€”Î¼Î¹Î½á½»Î¸Ï‰ is both trans. and intrans. in Homer; intrans. in the Ionic of Hippocr. (who has it of flesh "wasting"). Aesch. has it twice in lyrics (intrans.); Soph. only here.

ÎšÎ·Ï†Î¹ÏƒÎ¿á¿¦ Î½Î¿Î¼á½±Î´ÎµÏ‚ á¿¥Îµá½³Î¸ÏÏ‰Î½, ğŸ—©
Line 687

ÎšÎ·Ï†Î¹ÏƒÎ¿á¿¦. Chr. Wordsworth (Athens and Attica p. 137) observes that the Athenian poets never praise the Ilissus (perhaps because it was too much associated with the prose of daily life), though Plato, in the Phaedrus, makes some amends; they keep their praises for the Cephisus (so Eur. Med. 835). On the other hand the Ilissus, not the Cephisus, is the representative river of Attica for more distant singers, from Apollonius Rhodius (I. 215) to Milton (Par. Reg. 4. 249).

Î½Î¿Î¼á½±Î´ÎµÏ‚, wandering. The word alludes to irrigation by ducts or canals (a system still in use), but does so far more poetically than would be the case if (with E. Curtius) we made it active, with á¿¥Îµá½³Î¸ÏÏ‰Î½ for object. gen., "distributing the streams." There is no example of an adj. of this form (as ÏƒÏ€Î¿Ïá½±Ï‚, ÏƒÏ„ÏÎ¿Ï†á½±Ï‚, Ï†Î¿ÏÎ²á½±Ï‚) having an active sense. Cp. O. T. 1350 n.

Line 698

Ï†á½»Ï„ÎµÏ…Î¼). Ï†á½·Ï„ÎµÏ…Î¼), which Blaydes prefers, occurs only once in trag. (Aesch. Ag. 1281, of Orestes); it seems more appropriate to a "scion" (child) than to a plant.

á¼€Ï‡Îµá½·ÏÏ‰Ï„Î¿Î½ was read here by Pollux (2. 154), and is thus carried back to about 160 A.D.; it is also in A and a majority of our other MSS.; while L's á¼€Ï‡Îµá½·ÏÎ·Ï„Î¿Î½ is clearly a corruption. The question is whether á¼€Ï‡Îµá½·ÏÏ‰Ï„Î¿Î½ means (1) "unvanquished," the only sense in which it occurs elsewhere, as Thuc. 6.10 Î¿á¼± Î§Î±Î»ÎºÎ¹Î´á¿†Ï‚...á¼€Ï‡Îµá½·ÏÏ‰Ï„Î¿á½· Îµá¼°ÏƒÎ¹: or (2) á¼€Ï‡ÎµÎ¹ÏÎ¿á½»ÏÎ³Î·Ï„Î¿Î½, as Pollux takes it, "not cultivated by human hands." Ï‡Îµá½·ÏÏ‰Î¼Î± usu. meant "a conquest," or "a violent deed"; yet Aesch. could say Ï„Ï…Î¼Î²Î¿Ï‡á½¹Î± Ï‡ÎµÎ¹Ïá½½Î¼Î±Ï„Î± (work of the hand in mound-making) Theb. 1022. A bold artist in language might similarly, perhaps, have ventured on á¼€Ï‡Îµá½·ÏÏ‰Ï„Î¿Ï‚ as ="not hand-wrought." My reason for preferring "unvanquished" is the context. While Î²Î»Î±ÏƒÏ„á½¹Î½ (697) refers to the miraculous creation of the olive by Athena, Î±á½Ï„Î¿Ï€Î¿Î¹á½¹Î½ refers (I think) to its miraculous self-renewal after the Persians had burnt it. Her. 8.55 Î´ÎµÏ…Ï„á½³Ïá¿ƒ Ï„Îµ á¼¡Î¼á½³Ïá¿ƒ á¼€Ï€á½¸ Ï„á¿†Ï‚ á¼Î¼Ï€Ïá½µÏƒÎ¹Î¿Ï‚ á¼ˆÎ¸Î·Î½Î±á½·Ï‰Î½ Î¿á¼± Î¸á½»ÎµÎ¹Î½ á½‘Ï€á½¸ Î²Î±ÏƒÎ¹Î»á½³Î¿Ï‚ ÎºÎµÎ»ÎµÏ…á½¹Î¼ÎµÎ½Î¿Î¹ á½¡Ï‚ á¼€Î½á½³Î²Î·ÏƒÎ±Î½ á¼Ï‚ Ï„á½¸ á¼±Ïá½¹Î½, á½¥ÏÏ‰Î½ Î²Î»Î±ÏƒÏ„á½¸Î½ á¼Îº Ï„Î¿á¿¦ ÏƒÏ„ÎµÎ»á½³Ï‡ÎµÎ¿Ï‚ á½…ÏƒÎ¿Î½ Ï„Îµ Ï€Î·Ï‡Ï…Î±á¿–Î¿Î½ á¼€Î½Î±Î´ÎµÎ´ÏÎ±Î¼Î·Îºá½¹Ï„Î±. This connection of ideas is further indicated by the next phrase, á¼Î³Ï‡á½³Ï‰Î½ etc. For Î±á½Ï„Î¿Ï€Î¿Î¹á½¹Ï‚ as "self-produced" (i.e. producing itself from itself) cp. Î±á½Ï„Î¿Ï„á½¹ÎºÎ¿Ï‚, Î±á½Ï„Î¿Ï†á½±Î³Î¿Ï‚, Î±á½Ï„Î¿Ï†á½¹Î½Î¿Ï‚. Chandler (Accent. Â§ 457 2nd ed.) remarks that all compounds of â€Ï€Î¿Î¹Î¿Ï‚ are oxytone (quoting Arcadius 88. 2): Î±á½Ï„á½¹Ï€Î¿Î¹Î¿Ï‚ (as our MSS. give it) in this passage "is the one solitary exception, and therefore probably a false accent."

700 á½ƒ Ï„á¾·Î´Îµ Î¸á½±Î»Î»ÎµÎ¹ Î¼á½³Î³Î¹ÏƒÏ„Î± Ï‡á½½Ïá¾³, ğŸ—©
Line 700

Ï„á¾·Î´Îµ â€¦ Ï‡á½½Ïá¾³, locative dat.: in Attica.

Î¼á½³Î³Î¹ÏƒÏ„Î±: cp. 219 Î¼Î±ÎºÏá½±, 319 Ï†Î±Î¹Î´Ïá½±, O. T. 883 á½‘Ï€á½³ÏÎ¿Ï€Ï„Î± n. The light soil of Attica (Ï„á½¸ Î»ÎµÏ€Ï„á½¹Î³ÎµÏ‰Î½), and the climate, esp. favoured the olive: cp. Theophr. Causs. Plantt. 2. 4. 4 á¼¡ ÏƒÏ€Î¹Î»á½°Ï‚ (stony ground) ÎºÎ±á½¶ á¼”Ï„Î¹ Î¼á¾¶Î»Î»Î¿Î½ á¼¡ Î»ÎµÏ…Îºá½¹Î³ÎµÎ¹Î¿Ï‚ (670 n.) á¼Î»Î±Î¹Î¿Ï†á½¹ÏÎ¿Ï‚. For Greece, the olive-zone begins s. of the plains of Thessaly, as for Italy it begins s. of the plains of Lombardy. The olive is found in Phthiotis and Magnesia: in Epeirus, only on the sea-coast.

Î³Î»Î±Ï…Îºá¾¶Ï‚ Ï€Î±Î¹Î´Î¿Ï„Ïá½¹Ï†Î¿Ï… Ï†á½»Î»Î»Î¿Î½ á¼Î»Î±á½·Î±Ï‚Â· ğŸ—©
Line 701

Ï€Î±Î¹Î´Î¿Ï„Ïá½¹Ï†Î¿Ï…, nourishing the young lives in the land. The epithet is especially fitting here, after the recent allusion to Demeter and Cora, because at the Thesmophoria the prayer to those goddesses associated Earth with them as á¼¡ ÎºÎ¿Ï…ÏÎ¿Ï„Ïá½¹Ï†Î¿Ï‚: see Ar. Thesm. 295. Cp. Juv. Sat. 3. 84 quod nostra infantia caelum Hausit Aventini, baca nutrita Sabina (the olive). Hesych. (s.v. ÏƒÏ„á½³Ï†Î±Î½Î¿Î½ á¼ÎºÏ†á½³ÏÎµÎ¹Î½) says that it was the Attic custom ÏƒÏ„á½³Ï†Î±Î½Î¿Î½ á¼Î»Î±á½·Î±Ï‚ Ï„Î¹Î¸á½³Î½Î±Î¹ Ï€Ïá½¸ Ï„á¿¶Î½ Î¸Ï…Ïá¿¶Î½, when a male child was born; as wool, when a female (cp. foribus suspende coronas: Iam pater es). But there is no such allusion here. Nor could Ï€Î±Î¹Î´Î¿Ï„Ï. mean "propagated from the parent olive" on the acropolis, as Schneidewin thought.

Ï„á½¸ Î¼á½³Î½ Ï„Î¹Ï‚ Î¿á½ Î½ÎµÎ±Ïá½¸Ï‚ Î¿á½Î´á½² Î³á½µÏá¾³ ğŸ—©
Line 702

Ï„á½¸ Î¼á½³Î½ Ï„Î¹Ï‚ Îº.Ï„.Î». Two points first claim notice. (1) Î¿á½”Ï„Îµ and Î½ÎµÎ±Ïá½¹Ï‚ are both in the MSS., but both cannot be right. Cp. v. 715. If with Porson the first Î¿á½”Ï„Îµ is changed to Î¿á½, the second Î¿á½”Ï„Îµ must certainly be changed to Î¿á½Î´á½³. A single Î¿á½”Ï„Îµ cannot follow Î¿á½, though a repeated Î¿á½”Ï„Îµ can (Tr. 1058). Elmsley's Î¿á½”Ï„Îµ Î½á½³Î¿Ï‚ is hardly probable. (2) Î³á½µÏá¾³ ÏƒÎ·Î¼Î±á½·Î½Ï‰Î½ seems to me impossible. It surely could not mean either (a) "commanding in old age"â€”the elderly Archidamus in contrast with the young Xerxesâ€” or (b) "commanding the elderly men." The difficulty is not in the sense of

ÏƒÎ·Î¼Î±á½·Î½Ï‰Î½ itself, for which cp. Il. 1.288 Ï€á½±Î½Ï„Ï‰Î½ Î¼á½²Î½ ÎºÏÎ±Ï„á½³ÎµÎ¹Î½ á¼Î¸á½³Î»ÎµÎ¹, Ï€á½±Î½Ï„ÎµÏƒÏƒÎ¹ Î´â€™ á¼€Î½á½±ÏƒÏƒÎµÎ¹Î½, Ï€á¾¶ÏƒÎ¹ Î´á½² ÏƒÎ·Î¼Î±á½·Î½ÎµÎ¹Î½,â€”he would be master, king, captain (ÏƒÎ·Î¼á½±Î½Ï„Ï‰Ï): it is in the combination with Î³á½µÏá¾³.

Now comes this question:â€”Was the antithesis here between youth and age, or between some other notions? Hartung writes Î¿á½”Ï„â€™ á¼¦ÏÎ¿Ï‚ Î¿á½”Ï„Îµ Î³á½µÏá¾³, understanding, "neither in spring nor in winter," ÏƒÎ·Î¼Î±á½·Î½Ï‰Î½, "by his word of command": but such a fig. sense of Î³á½µÏá¾³ is inconceivable. Nauck's Î¿á½”Ï„â€™ á¼¦ÏÎ¿Ï‚ Î¿á½”Ï„â€™ á¼Î½ á½¥Ïá¾³ | Ï‡ÎµÎ¹Î¼á½½Î½Ï‰Î½ is too far from the MSS., and the plur. is strange. I incline to believe that the poet indeed meant "neither young nor old," but without any personal reference, and merely in this general sense:â€”"from generation to generation of men these sacred trees are safe." The words á½ Î³á½°Ï Î±á¼°á½²Î½ á½Ïá¿¶Î½ suit this. The conjecture ÏƒÏ…Î½Î½Î±á½·Ï‰Î½ has palaeographic probability (for a cursive text): for the phrase cp. Eur. fr. 370 Î¼ÎµÏ„á½° Î´â€™ á¼¡ÏƒÏ…Ï‡á½·Î±Ï‚ Ï€Î¿Î»Î¹á¿· Î³á½µÏÎ±ÏŠ ÏƒÏ…Î½Î¿Î¹ÎºÎ¿á½·Î·Î½.

Line 705

ÎœÎ¿Ïá½·Î¿Ï… Î”Î¹á½¹Ï‚. Attic Orators, vol. I. p. 289: "Throughout Attica, besides the olives which were private property (á¼´Î´Î¹Î±Î¹ á¼Î»Î±á¿–Î±Î¹", Lys. or. 7 Â§ 10) there were others which, whether on public or on private lands, were considered as the property of the state. They were called moriae (Î¼Î¿Ïá½·Î±Î¹ï¼‰â€”the legend being that they had been propagated (Î¼ÎµÎ¼Î¿ÏÎ·Î¼á½³Î½Î±Î¹) from the original olive which Athena herself had caused to spring up on the Acropolis. This theory was convenient for their conservation as State property, since, by giving them a sacred character, it placed them directly under the care of the Areiopagus, which caused them to be visited once a month by Inspectors (á¼Ï€Î¹Î¼ÎµÎ»Î·Ï„Î±á½·, Lys. or. 7 Â§ 29), and once a year by special Commissioners (Î³Î½á½½Î¼Î¿Î½ÎµÏ‚, ib. Â§ 25). To uproot a moria was an offence punishable by banishment and confiscation of goods (ib. Â§ 41).

This antistrophe is devoted to Poseidon, as the strophe to Athena.

Î¼Î±Ï„Ïá½¹Ï€Î¿Î»ÎµÎ¹, "mother-city" (Athens), since the men of Colonus, like all other dwellers in Attica, may deem themselves her children. So Pind. Îµá½”Î¹Ï€Ï€Î¿Î½, Îµá½”Ï€Ï‰Î»Î¿Î½ harmonizes with a strain of feeling which pervades the ode,â€”that the bounty of the gods to Attica is continued from day to day and from age to age. The supply of good á¼µÏ€Ï€Î¿Î¹ is perpetually replenished by good Ï€á¿¶Î»Î¿Î¹: "est in equis patrum Virtus."

Ï€Ïá½½Ï„Î±Î¹ÏƒÎ¹ Ï„Î±á¿–ÏƒÎ´Îµ â€¦ á¼€Î³Ï…Î¹Î±á¿–Ï‚, first in these roads (about Colonus); locative dat.:

ÎºÏ„á½·ÏƒÎ±Ï‚, "having instituted," brought into use among men, as one could say ÎºÏ„á½·Î¶ÎµÎ¹Î½ Î½á½Î¼Î¹Î¼Î± on the analogy of ÎºÏ„á½·Î¶ÎµÎ¹Î½ á¼‘Î¿ÏÏ„á½µÎ½ etc. Greek mythology places Poseidon in two distinct relations to the horse. (a) As creator. Servius ad Verg. Geo. 1. 12 ideo dicitur ecum invenisse quia velox est eius numen et mobile sicut mare. (So waves on a rough sea are "white horses," Ital. cavalloni.) The Thessalians connected this myth with the cult of Poseidon Î ÎµÏ„ÏÎ±á¿–Î¿Ï‚, who had caused the first horse (Î£Îºá½»Ï†Î¹Î¿Ï‚) to spring from a rock in Thessaly,â€”the name being taken from ÏƒÎºá½»Ï†Î¿Ï‚, a rocky cup, where perh. marks in the rock were shown. From Tzetzes on Lycophron 767 it seems that this legend was in later times localised at Colonus also. Arcadia and Boeotia, too, had their legends, in which the first horse was called á¼ˆÏá½·Ï‰Î½ (the wondrous steed of Adrastus in Il. 23.346). (b) As tamer. This was the prominent trait of the Corinthian and Attic legends. At Corinth Poseidon was worshipped as Î´Î±Î¼Î±á¿–Î¿Ï‚, and Athena as Ï‡Î±Î»Î¹Î½á¿–Ï„Î¹Ï‚ (cp. Pind. Ol. 13.65 ff.). In Thessaly the horse-yoking Poseidon was called á¼´Î¼ÏˆÎ¹Î¿Ï‚: Hesych. á¼´Î¼ÏˆÎ±Ï‚Â· Î¶Îµá½»Î¾Î±Ï‚ Î˜ÎµÏ„Ï„Î±Î»Î¿á½·, á¼´Î¼ÏˆÎ¹Î¿Ï‚ Î Î¿ÏƒÎµÎ¹Î´á¿¶Î½ á½ Î¶á½»Î³Î¹Î¿Ï‚. In Aesch. PV 462 ff. Prometheus is the first who taught men to drive animals,â€” á½‘Ï†â€™ á¼…ÏÎ¼Î± Ï„â€™ á¼¤Î³Î±Î³Î¿Î½ Ï†Î¹Î»Î·Î½á½·Î¿Ï…Ï‚ | á¼µÏ€Ï€Î¿Ï…Ï‚.

Ï€Ïá½½Ï„Î±Î¹ÏƒÎ¹ Ï„Î±á¿–ÏƒÎ´Îµ ÎºÏ„á½·ÏƒÎ±Ï‚ á¼€Î³Ï…Î¹Î±á¿–Ï‚. ğŸ—©
Line 716

Poseidon has taught men to row as well as to ride. He fits the oars to their hands. But, instead of Ï„á½°Î½ Î´á½² Ï€Î»á½±Ï„Î±Î½ Ï‡ÎµÏÏƒá½¶ Ï€Î±Ïá½±ÏˆÎ±Ï‚, the form is varied to a passive constr. If Ï€Î±ÏÎ±Ï€Ï„Î¿Î¼á½³Î½Î± is sound, this seems the best account of it,â€”Ï€Î±Ïá½±, "at the side," suggesting the notion, "as an aid." Ï„á¿¶Î½ á¼‘ÎºÎ±Ï„Î¿Î¼Ï€á½¹Î´Ï‰Î½ ÎÎ·Ïá¿„Î´Ï‰Î½, the Nereids with their hundred feet, the fifty Nereids whose dance and song lead the ship on her way. (But in Pind. fr. 122 ÎºÎ¿Ïá¾¶Î½ á¼€Î³á½³Î»Î±Î½ á¼‘ÎºÎ±Ï„á½¹Î³Î³Ï…Î¹Î¿Î½ prob. denotes 100, not 50, persons, as though Î³Ï…á¿–Î¿Î½ were Ïƒá¿¶Î¼Î±.) The choice of the number (though here meant merely to suggest a numerous sisterhood) is not accidental: fifty was the number regularly assigned to the Nereids by the earlier Greek poets, as Hesiod Th. 264, Pindar Isthm. 5. 6, Aesch. Fr. 168, Eur. Ion 1081. Later it becomes a hundred; so Plat. Critias 116E (describing Poseidon's temple in the island of Atlantis) ÎÎ·Ïá¿‡Î´Î±Ï‚ Î´á½² á¼Ï€á½¶ Î´ÎµÎ»Ï†á½·Î½Ï‰Î½ á¼‘ÎºÎ±Ï„á½¸Î½ Îºá½»ÎºÎ»á¿³Â· Ï„Î¿ÏƒÎ±á½»Ï„Î±Ï‚ Î³á½°Ï á¼Î½á½¹Î¼Î¹Î¶Î¿Î½ Î±á½Ï„á½°Ï‚ Î¿á¼± Ï„á½¹Ï„Îµ Îµá¼¶Î½Î±Î¹; and so Ovid Fasti 6. 499. Second á¼Ï€ÎµÎ¹Ïƒá½¹Î´Î¹Î¿Î½. Creon comes, in the hope of persuading Oed. to return with him. Failing, he causes his attendants to carry off Antigone,â€”Ismene having already been captured elsewhere. á¼Î³á½½. It is unsafe to argue that ÎºÏ…Ïá¿¶ could not be a gloss, because it is a poetical word. It was just such a conjecture as correctors of the later age readily made, to smooth a supposed difficulty, or in mere wantonness. With Î³á½³ÏÏ‰Î½ opposed to Î¿á½ Î³ÎµÎ³á½µÏÎ±ÎºÎµ we requlre á¼Î³á½½ opposed to Ï‡á½½ÏÎ±Ï‚. Ï„Î·Î»Î¹Îºá½¹ÏƒÎ´) is clearly right. It confirms the previous assurance that his errand is peaceful, and it harmonises with Ï€Îµá½·ÏƒÏ‰Î½. "I have not come to use force. Line 742

Î´Î¹ÎºÎ±á½·Ï‰Ï‚, with right, since Thebes, which had been his Ï„Ïá½¹Ï†Î¿Ï‚ so long (760), has a better claim to him than Athens, however hospitable. And Creon has an especial right to urge the claim as being now the guardian of the family honour (755). Not: "as they owed it to thee to do": nor, "in due form," as opp. to private overtures.

Ï€Ï„Ï‰Ï‡á¿·. The poet. tendency was often to treat adjectives with three terminations as if they had only two. Line 754

"I have uttered a cruel reproach against my kindred and myself. But indeed the reproach is one that cannot be hid, so long as thou and thy daughter are seen wandering thus. Hide it, then, thou (no one else can)â€”by coming home." Unless we correct Î½Ï…Î½ to Î½Î¹Î½ (=Ï„á½° á¼Î¼Ï†Î±Î½á¿†), it is better to place a point, and not merely a comma, at ÎºÏá½»Ï€Ï„ÎµÎ¹Î½: "But (I have some excuse) for," etc.,â€”the elliptical use of á¼€Î»Î»â€™ Î¿á½ Î³á½±Ï, as at 988, El. 595, Tr. 552. Î¼ÎµÏ„Î±ÏƒÏ€á¾¶Î½, to snatch to the other side (cp. Î¼ÎµÏ„Î±ÎºÎ¹Î½Îµá¿–Î½, Î¼ÎµÏ„Î±Ï€Îµá½·Î¸ÎµÎ¹Î½ etc.), found only here, but not open to just suspicion, though Blaydes changes it to Î¼â€™ á¼€Ï€Î¿ÏƒÏ€á¾¶Î½. So Î¼ÎµÎ¸á½³Î»ÎºÎµÎ¹Î½ in Anth. Plan. 5. 384.

ÏƒÎºÎ»Î·Ïá½° Î¼Î±Î»Î¸Î±Îºá¿¶Ï‚ Î»á½³Î³Ï‰Î½, putting hard purposes into soft words: disguising the ungenerous treatment which was really contemplated (399) under the name of a recall to home and friends (757). Ï„Î¿ÏƒÎ±á½»Ï„Î· was a mere blunder.

ÎºÎ±á½¶ Ï„Î¿á¿–ÏƒÎ´). The Chorus had been present when Ismene told Oed. of the Theban designs, and when he uttered an imprecation on his sons (399â€”460): and Theseus left the stage at 667. á¼€Ï€Î±Î»Î»Î±Ï‡Î¸á¿‡ is absol., "get off," as El. 1002 á¼„Î»Ï…Ï€Î¿Ï‚ á¼„Ï„Î·Ï‚ á¼Î¾Î±Ï€Î±Î»Î»Î±Ï‡Î¸á½µÏƒÎ¿Î¼Î±Î¹: Ar. Plut. 271 á¼€Ï€Î±Î»Î»Î±Î³á¿†Î½Î±Î¹ | á¼€Î¶á½µÎ¼Î¹Î¿Ï‚. Besides, the words would naturally mean, "get safely out of this land."

á¼Î½Î¸Î±Î½Îµá¿–Î½: cp. [Eur.] Rhes. 869 á½¦ Î³Î±á¿–Î± Ï€Î±Ï„Ïá½·Ï‚, Ï€á¿¶Ï‚ á¼‚Î½ á¼Î½Î¸á½±Î½Î¿Î¹Î¼á½· ÏƒÎ¿Î¹; a poet. word: in Lys. or. 16 Â§ 15 the prose á¼Î½Î±Ï€Î¿Î¸Î±Î½á½¹Î½Ï„Ï‰Î½ should prob. be restored. Remark that á¼Î½Î¸Î±Î½Îµá¿–Î½ can mean only "to die in," not "to lie dead in": but the sense is, "just enough ground, with a view to dying (instead of reigning) on Theban soil"; i.e., as much as a dead man will need. The phrase is half-proverbial: Aristoph. Eccl. 592 Î¼Î·Î´á½² Î³ÎµÏ‰ÏÎ³Îµá¿–Î½ Ï„á½¸Î½ Î¼á½²Î½ Ï€Î¿Î»Î»á½µÎ½, Ï„á¿· Î´â€™ Îµá¼¶Î½Î±Î¹ Î¼Î·Î´á½² Ï„Î±Ï†á¿†Î½Î±Î¹. Freeman, Old English History p. 313,/bibl> "...What will my brother King Harold of England give to King Harold of Norway?" â€¦ "Seven foot of the ground of England, or more perchance, seeing he is taller than other men." Shaksp. H. IV. Pt. i. 5. 4. 89 When that this body did contain a spirit, A kingdom for it was too small a bound; But now two paces of the vilest earth Is room enough.

Line 795

Ï€Î¿Î»Î»á½´Î½ á¼”Ï‡Î¿Î½ ÏƒÏ„á½¹Î¼Ï‰ÏƒÎ¹Î½, with a hard and keen edge,â€”thoroughly attempered to a shameless and cruel task. Hence, fig., Plut. Mor. 988 D Ï„á¿†Ï‚ á¼€Î½Î´ÏÎµá½·Î±Ï‚ Î¿á¼·Î¿Î½ Î²Î±Ï†á½µ Ï„Î¹Ï‚ á½ Î¸Ï…Î¼á½¹Ï‚ á¼ÏƒÏ„Î¹ ÎºÎ±á½¶ ÏƒÏ„á½¹Î¼Ï‰Î¼Î±: Lycurg. 16 Ï„á½° Î´) á½‘Î³Î¹ÎµÎ¹Î½á½° (Î²Ïá½³Ï†Î·) Î¼á¾¶Î»Î»Î¿Î½ ÏƒÏ„Î¿Î¼Î¿á¿¦ÏƒÎ¸Î±Î¹ ÎºÎ±á½¶ ÎºÏÎ±Ï„á½»Î½ÎµÏƒÎ¸Î±Î¹ Ï„á½´Î½ á¼•Î¾Î¹Î½, have their constitutions tempered and strengthened.
