á¼€Î»Î»â€™ Î¿á¼¶Î´Î± Î³á½±Ï ÏƒÎµ Ï„Î±á¿¦Ï„Î± Î¼á½´ Ï„Îµá½·Î¸Ï‰Î½, á¼´Î¸Î¹Â· ğŸ—©
Line 797

If Î¿á¼¶Î´Î± is right (as it seems to be), Î¼á½µ can hardly be explained otherwise than by emphasis, i.e. by the strong assurance which the speaker expresses. But what form should the partic. have? (1) With the MS. Ï€Îµá½·Î¸Ï‰Î½, the sense is: "However, I am assured that I am not persuading you of this,â€”go!" In 656 Î¿á¼¶Î´â€™ á¼Î³á½½ ÏƒÎµ Î¼á½µÏ„Î¹Î½Î± á¼Î½Î¸á½³Î½Î´â€™ á¼€Ï€á½±Î¾Î¿Î½Ï„â€™ á¼„Î½Î´ÏÎ± appears to be a like case of strong assurance. Cp. O. T. 1455. In 1121 there is another: á¼Ï€á½·ÏƒÏ„Î±Î¼Î±Î¹ Î³á½°Ï Ï„á½µÎ½Î´Îµ... Ï„á½³ÏÏˆÎ¹Î½ Ï€Î±Ïâ€™ á¼„Î»Î»Î¿Ï… Î¼Î·Î´ÎµÎ½á½¸Ï‚ Ï€ÎµÏ†Î±ÏƒÎ¼á½³Î½Î·Î½. Here, however, Î¿á¼·Î´Î± Î¼á½´ Ï€Îµá½·Î¸Ï‰Î½ is so far stranger, that the emphasis appears less appropriate in stating the speaker's consciousness of what he himself is doing. (2) The v.l. Ï€Îµá½·Î¸Î¿Î½Ï„), extant in at least one MS. (F), removes this objection. "However, I am assured that you are not persuading (either the Athenians or me, cp. 803)â€”go!" (3) Ï€Îµá½·ÏƒÏ‰Î½ would be liable to the same remark as Ï€Îµá½·Î¸Ï‰Î½. (4) Ï€Îµá½·ÏƒÎ¿Î½Ï„) would complete the parallelism with 656, but is not required by the "strong assurance" view, which applies to past (1121) or present as well as to future.â€”Another view is that Î¼á½µ gives a quasi-imperative force: "I know that you shan't persuade." This might apply to 656. Here it is much more difficult, esp. if we do not adopt Ï€Îµá½·ÏƒÎ¿Î½Ï„): in 1121 it fails.

With á¼´ÏƒÎ¸Î¹ â€¦ Î¼Îµ for Î¿á¼¶Î´Î±...Î´Îµ the imper. would explain Î¼á½µ (cp. on 78): and we may note that in O. T. 376 the MSS. changed ÏƒÎµ...á¼‘Î¼Î¿á¿¦ into Î¼Îµ...ÏƒÎ¿á¿¦. But the context confirms Î¿á¼¶Î´Î±.

In later Greek Î¼á½µ with partic., in regard to fact, was common, as Luc. Dial. Mort. 16 Ï€á¿¶Ï‚ Î¿á½–Î½ á¼€ÎºÏÎ¹Î²á½´Ï‚ á½ Î‘á¼°Î±Îºá½¸Ï‚ á½¢Î½ Î¿á½ Î´Î¹á½³Î³Î½Ï‰ Î´Îµ Î¼á½´ á½„Î½Ï„Î± á¼ÎºÎµá¿–Î½Î¿Î½; "failed to discern that you were not he," where Î¼á½´ á½„Î½Ï„Î±, though it might be paraphrased by Îµá¼° Î¼á½´ á¼¦ÏƒÎ¸Î±, virtually=á½…Ï„Î¹ Î¿á½Îº á¼¦ÏƒÎ¸Î±. Line 800

Which of us do you consider the greater sufferer by your present attitude? Me, because I am not to bring you back? Or yourself, when you reject your friends and country?

Î´Ï…ÏƒÏ„Ï…Ï‡Îµá¿–Î½ has been explained as "to be in error," referring to Creon's ignorance of the lot in store for Thebes (787); but it is simpler to take it of Creon's failure to win Oedipus. However great that loss may be, Creon means, the loss to Oed. himself will be greater still.

Line 802

Creon had said, in effect, "Your happiness is as much my object as our own." "My happiness," Oed. rejoins, "will be best secured if your application is rejected by the people of Colonus, as by myself."

For Î¼Îµ followed by á¼Î¼á½³, cp. El. 1359 á¼€Î»Î»á½± Î¼Îµ | Î»á½¹Î³Î¿Î¹Ï‚ á¼€Ï€á½½Î»Î»Ï…Ï‚, á¼”ÏÎ³â€™ á¼”Ï‡Ï‰Î½ á¼¥Î´Î¹ÏƒÏ„â€™ á¼Î¼Î¿á½·, where á¼Î¼Î¿á½· is not more emphatic than Î¼Îµ. So in Tr. 1171 Îºá¼€Î´á½¹ÎºÎ¿Ï…Î½ Ï€Ïá½±Î¾ÎµÎ¹Î½ ÎºÎ±Î»á¿¶Ï‚Â· | Ï„á½¸ Î´â€™ á¼¦Î½ á¼„Ïâ€™ Î¿á½Î´á½²Î½ á¼„Î»Î»Î¿ Ï€Î»á½´Î½ Î¸Î±Î½Îµá¿–Î½ á¼Î¼á½³, where there is no contrast between á¼Î¼á½³ and some one else: Ant. 292 á½¡Ï‚ ÏƒÏ„á½³ÏÎ³ÎµÎ¹Î½ á¼Î¼á½³: Ph. 299 Ï„á½¸ Î¼á½´ Î½Î¿ÏƒÎµá¿–Î½ á¼Î¼á½³, where the stress is on the verb, not on the pronoun. The stress is rather on Ï‡Ïá½´ Î½Î±á½·ÎµÎ¹Î½: Apollo has brought him to this rest (89).

ÎšÏ. Î¼Î±ÏÏ„á½»ÏÎ¿Î¼Î±Î¹ Ï„Î¿á½»ÏƒÎ´â€™, Î¿á½ Ïƒá½³Â· Ï€Ïá½¸Ï‚ Î´á½² Ï„Î¿á½ºÏ‚ Ï†á½·Î»Î¿Ï…Ï‚ ğŸ—©
Line 813

This passage, which has been variously altered, appears to me to be sound as it stands in the MSS. Oedipus has undertaken to speak for the men of Attica (á¼Ïá¿¶ Î³á½°Ï ÎºÎ±á½¶ Ï€Ïá½¸ Ï„á¿¶Î½Î´Îµ). Creon refuses to identify him with them, bitterly reminding the Theban that his real ties are elsewhere. "I call themâ€”not theeâ€” to witness my protest": i.e. "I have a just claim on thee, which thou repellest:â€” I appeal to a judgment more impartial than thine own." The words mark the point at which he drops persuasion. He now turns to menace. "But, for the tone of thy reply to kinsmen" (meaning, to himself, cp. on 148 ÏƒÎ¼Î¹ÎºÏÎ¿á¿–Ï‚), "if I catch thee"â€”an aposiopesis. (Cp. Il. 1.580 Îµá¼´Ï€ÎµÏ Î³á½±Ï Îºâ€™ á¼Î¸á½³Î»á¿ƒÏƒÎ¹Î½ á½ˆÎ»á½»Î¼Ï€Î¹Î¿Ï‚ á¼€ÏƒÏ„ÎµÏÎ¿Ï€Î·Ï„á½´Ï‚ á¼Î¾ á¼‘Î´á½³Ï‰Î½ ÏƒÏ„Ï…Ï†ÎµÎ»á½·Î¾Î±Î¹Â· á½ Î³á½°Ï Ï€Î¿Î»á½º Ï†á½³ÏÏ„ÎµÏá½¹Ï‚ á¼ÏƒÏ„Î¹Î½: Verg. Aen. 1. 135 Quos ego â€¦ ï¼‰

Î¼Î±ÏÏ„á½»ÏÎ¿Î¼Î±Î¹, antestor: cp. Aristoph. Pax 1119 Î¤Î . á½¦ Ï€Î±á¿–Îµ Ï€Î±á¿–Îµ Ï„á½¸Î½ Î’á½±ÎºÎ¹Î½. Î™Î•. Î¼Î±ÏÏ„á½»ÏÎ¿Î¼Î±Î¹.

Line 833

â€”886 The phrase Ï„Î¿á½ºÏ‚ á¼Î¼Î¿á½ºÏ‚ á¼„Î³Ï‰ indicates the moment at which Creon lays his hand on Antigone. It is followed by 11 verses, 833â€”843, in which the dochmiacs of the Chorus, blended with iambic trimeters, mark excitement. Antistrophic to these are the 11 verses, 876â€”886, which in like manner follow the moment at which Creon lays his hand on Oedipus. As a lyric interposition in dialogue, the passage has a kommatic character, though it does not constitute a ÎºÎ¿Î¼Î¼á½¹Ï‚ proper in the same sense as 510â€”548, 1447â€”1499, or 1670â€” 1750.

Line 839

Î¼á½´ )Ï€á½·Ï„Î±ÏƒÏƒâ€™ á¼ƒ Î¼á½´ ÎºÏÎ±Ï„Îµá¿–Ï‚, do not give orders in matters where you are not master. á¼ƒ is not for á½§Î½, but is cogn. accus. (or acc. of respect), as O. Ant. 664 Ï„Î¿á½Ï€Î¹Ï„á½±ÏƒÏƒÎµÎ¹Î½ Ï„Î¿á¿–Ï‚ ÎºÏÎ±Ï„á½»Î½Î¿Ï…ÏƒÎ¹Î½, to dictate to one's masters. Î§Î¿. Î¼á½³Î¸ÎµÏ‚ Ï‡ÎµÏÎ¿á¿–Î½ ğŸ—©
Line 840

At Creon's words, when he laid his hand on Antigone (832), one of his guards stepped up, and placed himself at her side.

Ï‡Î±Î»á¾¶Î½ Î»á½³Î³Ï‰ ÏƒÎ¿Î¹, like Î¿á½Îº á¼€Ï†á½µÏƒÎµÎ¹Ï‚ and Î¼á½³Î¸ÎµÏ‚, is said to Creon. Creon's ÏƒÎ¿á½·, a mocking echo of theirs, is said to the guard: "and I tell thee to start on thy journey." If it were said to the Chorus, the sense would be either, (1) "and I tell thee to begone," or (2) "and I tell thee that [she] is to go": but (1) is not idiomatic, and (2) is impossible.

Ï„á½´Î½ Ï€Î±á¿–Î´Î± Î¸á¾¶ÏƒÏƒÎ¿Î½. ğŸ—©

Ï€á½¹Î»Î¹Ï‚ â€¦ ÏƒÎ¸á½³Î½ÎµÎ¹: our cityâ€”yea, our cityâ€”is being brought low by sheer strength: á¼Î½Î±á½·ÏÎµÏ„Î±Î¹, because the majesty of the State is destroyed when its asylum is violated. In Ï€á½¹Î»Î¹Ï‚ á¼Î¼á½±, the stress is on the first word, not on the second.

Î¿Î´Î¿Î¹Ï€Î¿Ïá½µÏƒá¿ƒÏ‚. As between â€ÎµÎ¹Ï‚ and â€Î·Î¹Ï‚ in verbal endings, neither L nor any of our MSS. has authority. The reason for preferring the aor. subj. here is one of usage. Î¿á½ Î¼á½´ á½Î´Î¿Î¹Ï€Î¿Ïá½µÏƒá¿ƒÏ‚ is a denial: Î¿á½ Î¼á½´ á½Î´Î¿Î¹Ï€Î¿Ïá½µÏƒÎµÎ¹Ï‚, a prohibition. The latter is grammatically as right as the other, but does not suit this context. For Î´Ïá¾·Ï‚ followed by Îµá¼°ÏÎ³á½±ÏƒÏ‰, instead of á¼”Î´ÏÎ±ÏƒÎ±Ï‚, cp. O. T. 54 á½¡Ï‚ Îµá¼´Ï€ÎµÏ á¼„ÏÎ¾ÎµÎ¹Ï‚ â€¦ á½¥ÏƒÏ€ÎµÏ ÎºÏÎ±Ï„Îµá¿–Ï‚ (n.).

Î²á½·á¾³ Ï†á½·Î»Ï‰Î½ applies to his former conduct, since, in searching out his origin, he acted against the passionate entreaties of Iocasta (O. T. 1060ff. ). Greek idiom uses a parataxis, Î¿á½”Ï„Îµ Î½á¿¦Î½ ... Î¿á½”Ï„Îµ Ï€Ïá½¹ÏƒÎ¸ÎµÎ½, where ours would subordinate the second clause to the first, "now, as before": cp. 308.

Line 856

The guards, carrying off Antigone, have already left the scene (847); cp. 875 Î¼Î¿á¿¦Î½Î¿Ï‚. Creon is now about to follow them, when the Chorus again approach him, and protest that he shall not leave Colonus unless the two maidens are restored.

ÎšÏ. Î¼á½´ ÏˆÎ±á½»ÎµÎ¹Î½ Î»á½³Î³Ï‰. ğŸ—©
Line 857

Ï„á¿¶Î½Î´Îµ. So the plur. Î±á¼µÎ´Îµ of the two sisters below, 1107, 1367, 1379 (immediately after the masc. dual Ï„Î¿Î¹á½½Î´â€™, referring to the brothers), 1668; Ï„á½±ÏƒÎ´â€™ 1121, 1146, 1634, O. T. 1507, Ant. 579. On the other hand the dual of á½…Î´Îµ occurs only thrice in Soph.; above, 445 Ï„Î¿á¿–Î½Î´Îµ: Ï„á½½Î´Îµ El. 981f. bis. (Below, 1121, Ï„á½±Î´Îµ is a corrupt v.l. for Ï„á½±ÏƒÎ´Îµ.) It is surely needless, then, to write Ï„Î¿á¿–Î½Î´Îµ here. But Reisig's plea for the plur. is over-subtle,â€” that it contrasts with the extenuating tone of Ï„Î¿á½»Ï„Î¿Î¹Î½ in 859 (merely two). Rather Creon uses the dual because he is thinking of the two sisters together as the "two supports" of Oed. (848, 445). The plur. differs from the dual simply by the absence of any stress on the notion of "a pair." The Chorus are thinking how he had first seized Ismene (818) and then Antigone.

Î§Î¿. Î¿á½”Ï„Î¿Î¹ Ïƒâ€™ á¼€Ï†á½µÏƒÏ‰, Ï„á¿¶Î½Î´á½³ Î³â€™ á¼ÏƒÏ„ÎµÏÎ·Î¼á½³Î½Î¿Ï‚. ğŸ—©
Line 858

á¿¥á½»ÏƒÎ¹Î¿Î½: Then thou shalt soon deposit even a greater security for my city.

Ï€á½¹Î»ÎµÎ¹=Thebes, as in Creon's former words, 837 Ï€á½¹Î»ÎµÎ¹ Î¼Î±Ï‡Îµá¿–. á¿¥á½»ÏƒÎ¹Î¿Ï‚ denotes what one draws to oneself, carries off, (1) as booty, (2) as a security, (3) in reprisal. Here Î¸á½µÏƒÎµÎ¹Ï‚ points to (2), since á¼Î½á½³Ï‡Ï…ÏÎ¿Î½ Ï„Î¹Î¸á½³Î½Î±Î¹, to deposit a pledge, was a regular phrase: Aristoph. Eccl. 754 Ï€á½¹Ï„ÎµÏÎ¿Î½ Î¼ÎµÏ„Î¿Î¹ÎºÎ¹Î¶á½¹Î¼ÎµÎ½Î¿Ï‚ á¼Î¾ÎµÎ½á½µÎ½Î¿Ï‡Î±Ï‚ Î±á½”Ï„â€™, á¼¢ Ï†á½³ÏÎµÎ¹Ï‚ á¼Î½á½³Ï‡Ï…ÏÎ± Î¸á½µÏƒÏ‰Î½; "or are you taking them to be deposited as securities?" Plat. Legg. 820 E á¼Î½á½³Ï‡Ï…ÏÎ±...Ï„Î¿á½ºÏ‚ Î¸á½³Î½Ï„Î±Ï‚ (Ï„Î·Î¿ÏƒÎµ Ï‰Î·Î¿ Î·Î±vÎµ Î³Î¹vÎµÎ½ Ï„Î·Îµ Ï€Î»ÎµÎ´Î³ÎµÏ‚)... Ï„Î¿á½ºÏ‚ Î¸ÎµÎ¼á½³Î½Î¿Ï…Ï‚ (Ï„Î·Î¿ÏƒÎµ Ï„Î¿ Ï‰Î·Î¿Î¼ Ï„Î·ÎµÏˆ Î·Î±vÎµ Î²ÎµÎµÎ½ Î³Î¹vÎµÎ½).

Ï€á½¹Î»ÎµÎ¹ dat. of interest, as á½‘Ï€Î¿Ï„Î¹Î¸á½³Î½Î±Î¹ "to mortgage" takes a dat. of the mortgagee: Dem. or. 27 Â§ 25 á½ á½‘Ï€Î¿Î¸Îµá½¶Ï‚ Ï„á¿· Ï€Î±Ï„Ïá½¶ Ï„á¼€Î½Î´Ïá½±Ï€Î¿Î´Î±.â€”The version, "you will cause a greater prize to be taken from Athens," is inadmissible.

Î¸á½µÏƒÎµÎ¹Ï‚ Ï€á½¹Î»ÎµÎ¹ could not mean, "cause for Athens," in the sense, "cause to be taken from Athens." If Î¸á½µÏƒÎµÎ¹Ï‚ meant "cause" (instead of "pay"), Ï€á½¹Î»ÎµÎ¹ would still be the city which received the á¿¥á½»ÏƒÎ¹Î¿Î½.

á¼Ï†á½±ÏˆÎ¿Î¼Î±Î¹: Aesch. Suppl. 412 ÎºÎ±á½¶ Î¼á½µÏ„Îµ Î´á¿†ÏÎ¹Ï‚ á¿¥Ï…Ïƒá½·Ï‰Î½ á¼Ï†á½±ÏˆÎµÏ„Î±Î¹, (and so) "that the foeman shall not lay hands on you as prizes" (where the king of Argos is speaking to the DanaÃ¯des whom he protects).

ÎšÏ. ÎºÎ±á½¶ Î¼Îµá¿–Î¶Î¿Î½ á¼†ÏÎ± á¿¥á½»ÏƒÎ¹Î¿Î½ Ï€á½¹Î»ÎµÎ¹ Ï„á½±Ï‡Î±
Î¸á½µÏƒÎµÎ¹Ï‚Â· á¼Ï†á½±ÏˆÎ¿Î¼Î±Î¹ Î³á½°Ï Î¿á½ Ï„Î±á½»Ï„Î±Î¹Î½ Î¼á½¹Î½Î±Î¹Î½.
Î§Î¿. 860 á¼€Î»Î»â€™ á¼Ï‚ Ï„á½· Ï„Ïá½³ÏˆÎµÎ¹;
ÎšÏ. Ï„á½¹Î½Î´â€™ á¼€Ï€á½±Î¾Î¿Î¼Î±Î¹ Î»Î±Î²á½½Î½. ğŸ—©
Line 861

After Î´ÎµÎ¹Î½á½¸Î½ Î»á½³Î³Î¿Î¹Ï‚ (L), or Î»á½³Î³ÎµÎ¹Ï‚, a syllable has to be supplied conjecturally. Triclinius added á½¡Ï‚ ("be sure that," 45) before Ï„Î¿á¿¦Ï„Î¿: but this mars the rhythm: and the simple fut. (as in 860) is more forcible. The optat. Î»á½³Î³Î¿Î¹Ï‚ of L, which is not likely to be a mere error for Î»á½³Î³ÎµÎ¹Ï‚, strongly favours Hermann's simple remedy, Î´ÎµÎ¹Î½á½¸Î½ Î»á½³Î³Î¿Î¹Ï‚ á¼„Î½, "'twere a dread deed that thou threatenest" (if only thou couldst do it): cp. on 647 Î¼á½³Î³â€™ á¼‚Î½ Î»á½³Î³Î¿Î¹Ï‚ Î´á½½ÏÎ·Î¼Î±. Next to this, I should prefer Wecklein's Î´ÎµÎ¹Î½á½¸Ï‚ Î»á½¹Î³Î¿Î¹Ï‚ Îµá¼¶.

Ï€ÎµÏ€Ïá½±Î¾ÎµÏ„Î±Î¹, "will have been done": i.e. will be done forthwith: Dem. or. 19 Â§ 74 á¼”Ï†Î·...Ï„Î±á¿¦Ï„Î± Ï€ÎµÏ€Ïá½±Î¾ÎµÏƒÎ¸Î±Î¹ Î´Ï…Î¿á¿–Î½ á¼¢ Ï„ÏÎ¹á¿¶Î½ á¼¡Î¼ÎµÏá¿¶Î½. Cp. O. T. 1146 n.

Î§Î¿. Î´ÎµÎ¹Î½á½¸Î½ Î»á½³Î³Î¿Î¹Ï‚ á¼„Î½. ğŸ—©
Line 862

á¼¢Î½ Î¼á½µ Î³). Piderit is clearly right (I think) in giving this verse to the Chorus, not to Creon. Creon, who has long since dropped the semblance of courtesy with which he began (759), cannot, of course, mean to express serious deference for the wishes of Theseus; while, as an ironical defiance, the words would be extremely tame. In the mouth of the Chorus, however, the threat has point, since they know their king's public resolve (656); it has also dramatic force, since he is soon to appear (887). The words of Oed. (863) refer to 861.

á¼€Ï€ÎµÎ¹ÏÎ³á½±Î¸á¿ƒ: cp. El. 1271 Îµá¼°ÏÎ³Î±Î¸Îµá¿–Î½ (and so Eur.): Aesch. Eum. 566 ÎºÎ±Ï„ÎµÎ¹ÏÎ³Î±Î¸Î¿á¿¦ (aor. imper. midd.). The forms á¼á½³ÏÎ³Î±Î¸ÎµÎ½, á¼€Ï€Î¿á½³ÏÎ³Î±Î¸Îµ (aor., or, as some would call them, impf.) are Homeric. See n. on O. T. 651 Îµá¼°Îºá½±Î¸Ï‰.

Line 863

Ï†Î¸á½³Î³Î¼), "voice," rather than "word": the conj. Î¸Ïá½³Î¼Î¼) (Blaydes) would efface an expressive touch. ÏˆÎ±á½»ÎµÎ¹Ï‚ might be defended as present of intention or attempt (cp. on 993 ÎºÏ„Îµá½·Î½Î¿Î¹): but ÏˆÎ±á½»ÏƒÎµÎ¹Ï‚ is more natural, and expresses indignation with greater force.

Line 864

Î±á½Î´á¿¶ ÏƒÎ¹Ï‰Ï€á¾¶Î½. Creon forbids the utterance of the curse which he forebodes; and the injunction reminds Oedipus that he is near the Awful Goddesses who impose abstinence from all ill-omened words. "Nay" (Î³á½±Ï), he cries, "may they suffer me to utter one imprecation more (á¼”Ï„Î¹"). Î³á½±Ï implies, "I will not yet be mute"; cp. also its use in wishes, Îµá¼° Î³á½±Ï, Îµá¼´Î¸Îµ Î³á½±Ï, etc. á¼”Ï„Î¹ recalls the former imprecation on his sons (421 ff.).

ÏˆÎ¹Î»á½¸Î½ á½„Î¼Î¼) can mean only "a defenceless eye," i.e. a defenceless maiden (Antigone) who was to him as eyesight. Î§Î¿. á¼†Ïâ€™ Î¿á½Ï‡ á½•Î²ÏÎ¹Ï‚ Ï„á½±Î´â€™; ğŸ—©
Line 885

Ï€á½³ÏÎ±Î½ Ï€ÎµÏá¿¶Ïƒâ€™ Î¿á¼µÎ´Îµ Î´á½µ, "yonder men" (with a gesture in the direction taken by Creon's guards) "are already passing towards the other side." Elmsley wrote Ï€á½³ÏÎ±, which as adv. would mean "further." But Ï€á½³ÏÎ±Î½ is right, since the Chorus is thinking of a passage from the Attic to the Boeotian side of the frontier, as of a passage across a river. Ï€á½³ÏÎ± is ultra, "to some point beyond" a line which is either left to be understood, or expressed in the gen.: Ï€á½³ÏÎ±Î½ is trans, "on, or to, the further side" of a river, sea, or intervening space. Ï€ÎµÏá¿¶ÏƒÎ¹ implies only that the fugitives are on their way to the border,â€”not that they are now actually crossing it.

Î´á½µ nearly=á¼¤Î´Î·: O. T. 968 n.

Line 885Line 885

Ï€á½³ÏÎ±Î½ Ï€ÎµÏá¿¶Ïƒâ€™ Î¿á¼µÎ´Îµ Î´á½µ, "yonder men" (with a gesture in the direction taken by Creon's guards) "are already passing towards the other side." Elmsley wrote Ï€á½³ÏÎ±, which as adv. would mean "further." But Ï€á½³ÏÎ±Î½ is right, since the Chorus is thinking of a passage from the Attic to the Boeotian side of the frontier, as of a passage across a river. Ï€á½³ÏÎ± is ultra, "to some point beyond" a line which is either left to be understood, or expressed in the gen.: Ï€á½³ÏÎ±Î½ is trans, "on, or to, the further side" of a river, sea, or intervening space. Ï€ÎµÏá¿¶ÏƒÎ¹ implies only that the fugitives are on their way to the border,â€”not that they are now actually crossing it.

Î´á½µ nearly=á¼¤Î´Î·: O. T. 968 n.

Join ÏƒÏ€Îµá½»Î´ÎµÎ¹Î½ á¼€Ï€á½¸ Î¸Ï…Î¼á½±Ï„Ï‰Î½, á¼„Î½Î¹Ï€Ï€Î¿Î½, á¼±Ï€Ï€á½¹Ï„Î·Î½ Ï„Îµ á¼€Ï€á½¸ á¿¥Ï…Ï„á¿†ÏÎ¿Ï‚: to hasten from the sacrifice, some on foot, others on horseback, with slack rein. The worshippers of the á¼½Ï€Ï€Î¹Î¿Ï‚ and á¼¹Ï€Ï€á½·Î± are in part á¼±Ï€Ï€Îµá¿–Ï‚ (cp. 1070), and have their horses with them. The place of á¼€Ï€á½¸ Ïâ€™. is due to the fact that these horsemen are the important pursuers, á¼„Î½Î¹Ï€Ï€Î¿Î½ being added merely to give the notion of a pursuit en masse. Thus there is some formal resemblance to Ant. 1108 á¼´Ï„â€™, á¼´Ï„â€™, á½€Ï€á½±Î¿Î½ÎµÏ‚ Î¿á¼µ Ï„â€™ á½„Î½Ï„ÎµÏ‚ Î¿á¼µ Ï„â€™ á¼€Ï€á½¹Î½Ï„ÎµÏ‚, though there "present and absent" is merely a colloquial phrase for "every one."

á¼€Ï€á½¸ á¿¥Ï…Ï„á¿†ÏÎ¿Ï‚, "away from the rein," i.e. "unchecked by the rein," immissis habenis: Phrynichus ap. Bekker Anecd. p. 24 á¼€Ï€á½¸ á½Ï…Ï„á¿†ÏÎ¿Ï‚ Ï„Ïá½³Ï‡ÎµÎ¹Î½ á¼µÏ€Ï€Î¿Î½Â· Î¿á¼·Î¿Î½ á¼€Ï€á½¸ Ï‡Î±Î»Î¹Î½Î¿á¿¦ á¼£ á¼„Î½ÎµÏ… Ï‡Î±Î»Î¹Î½Î¿á¿¦. Cp. El. 1127 á¼€Ï€â€™ á¼Î»Ï€á½·Î´Ï‰Î½, contrary to my hopes: Tr. 389 Î¿á½Îº á¼€Ï€á½¸ Î³Î½á½½Î¼Î·Ï‚, not against my judgment: and so Î¿á½Îº á¼€Ï€á½¸ Ï„Ïá½¹Ï€Î¿Ï… (not unreasonably), Î¿á½Îº á¼€Ï€á½¸ ÎºÎ±Î¹ÏÎ¿á¿¦, etc. Plut. Dion 42 Î¿á½—Ï„Î¿Î¹ Î´Î¹ÎµÎ»á½±ÏƒÎ±Î½Ï„ÎµÏ‚ Ï„á½´Î½ á½Î´á½¸Î½ á¼µÏ€Ï€Î¿Î¹Ï‚ á¼€Ï€á½¸ á¿¥Ï…Ï„á¿†ÏÎ¿Ï‚ á¼§ÎºÎ¿Î½ Îµá¼°Ï‚ Î›ÎµÎ¿Î½Ï„á½·Î½Î¿Ï…Ï‚ Ï„á¿†Ï‚ á¼¡Î¼á½³ÏÎ±Ï‚ á¼¤Î´Î· ÎºÎ±Ï„Î±Ï†ÎµÏÎ¿Î¼á½³Î½Î·Ï‚, "having ridden the whole distance at full speed." For the Î¿â€” in á¼€Ï€á½¸ before á¿¥, cp. Ant. 712 n.

Î´á½·ÏƒÏ„Î¿Î¼Î¿Î¹ â€¦ á½Î´Î¿á½·. See map in Appendix on 1059. The two roads meant are probably:â€”(1) A road leading from Colonus, north of the Sacred Way, to the pass now called DaphnÃ¨, a depression in the range of Mount Aegaleos through which the Sacred Way issued from the plain of Athens, after which it skirted the shores of the bay of Eleusis. The beginning of this road is shown by the map in the Introduction. (2) A road diverging from the former in a N.W. direction, and going round the N. end of the same range of Aegaleos, at a point some miles N. of the DaphnÃ¨ pass, into the Thriasian plain. By either route the captors could gain the pass of Dryoscephalae, over Mount Cithaeron, leading from Attica into Boeotia. The hope of Theseus is that the pursuers may reach the point of bifurcation before the captors, since it is conceivable that the latter should wait to be joined by their master, Creon. see on 1054 ff.

Î¼á½±Î»Î¹ÏƒÏ„Î± with á¼”Î½Î¸Î±, lit., "to about the place where": cp. Her. 1.191 á¼€Î½Î´Ïá½¶ á½¡Ï‚ á¼Ï‚ Î¼á½³ÏƒÎ¿Î½ Î¼Î·Ïá½¸Î½ Î¼á½±Î»Î¹ÏƒÏ„á½± Îºá¿ƒ, "just about to the height of a man's thigh."

á½…ÏƒÏ„Î¹Ï‚ Î´á½·ÎºÎ±á¿‘ á¼€ÏƒÎºÎ¿á¿¦ÏƒÎ±Î½ Îµá¼°ÏƒÎµÎ»Î¸á½¼Î½ Ï€á½¹Î»Î¹Î½ ğŸ—©
Line 913

Athens "practises justice," i.e. respects the rights of other states; and "determines (ÎºÏÎ±á½·Î½Î¿Ï…ÏƒÎ±Î½") nothing without law, i.e. admits no claim which the laws do not sanction. Oedipus had placed himself and his daughters under the protection of Attic law. Creon should have sought legal warrant for their removal. Instead of doing so, he has used violence.

ÎºÎ±á½·Ï„Î¿Î¹ ÏƒÎµ Î˜á¿†Î²Î±á½· Î³â€™ Î¿á½Îº á¼Ï€Î±á½·Î´ÎµÏ…ÏƒÎ±Î½ ÎºÎ±Îºá½¹Î½Â· ğŸ—©
Line 919

Î˜á¿†Î²Î±Î¹. A courteous exoneration of Thebes accords with the hereditary Î¾ÎµÎ½á½·Î± which this play supposes: see on 632, and cp. the compliments to Thebes in 929, 937. It has been seriously suggested that all these touches must have been inserted by Sophocles the grandson, because in the poet's time Athens and Thebes were not usually on the best terms.

á¼Ï€Î±á½·Î´ÎµÏ…ÏƒÎ±Î½, more than á¼”Î¸ÏÎµÏˆÎ±Î½, implying a moral and mental training: cp. 920 Î¿á½ Î³á½°Ï Ï†Î¹Î»Î¿á¿¦ÏƒÎ¹Î½ á¼„Î½Î´ÏÎ±Ï‚ á¼ÎºÎ´á½·ÎºÎ¿Ï…Ï‚ Ï„Ïá½³Ï†ÎµÎ¹Î½,

ÏƒÏ…Î»á¿¶Î½Ï„Î± Ï„á¼€Î¼á½° ÎºÎ±á½¶ Ï„á½° Ï„á¿¶Î½ Î¸Îµá¿¶Î½, Î²á½·á¾³ ğŸ—©
Line 922

ÏƒÏ…Î»á¿¶Î½Ï„Î± Îº.Ï„.Î»., forcibly carrying off what belongs to me,â€”yes, and what belongs to the gods, when you seek to lead captive unhappy men who are suppliants. It is best to put a comma after Ï„á½° Ï„á¿¶Î½ Î¸Îµá¿¶Î½, which is explained by Î²á½·á¾³ á¼„Î³Î¿Î½Ï„Î±, etc. He robs the gods when he seeks to seize the sacred suppliant of the Eumenides (44, 287). He robs Theseus (Ï„á¼€Î¼á½°) when he seizes persons who are under the protection of Attic law (915). If Ï„á½° Ï„á¿¶Î½ Î¸Îµá¿¶Î½ Ï†Ï‰Ï„á¿¶Î½ á¼€Î¸Î». á¼±ÎºÏ„á½µÏÎ¹Î± were joined (as Blaydes prefers), the double gen. would be very awkward.

Ï†Ï‰Ï„á¿¶Î½ á¼€Î¸Î»á½·Ï‰Î½ á¼±ÎºÏ„á½µÏÎ¹Î±=literally "suppliant objects consisting in hapless per sons,"=Ï†á¿¶Ï„Î±Ï‚ á¼€Î¸Î»á½·Î¿Ï…Ï‚ á¼±ÎºÏ„Î·Ïá½·Î¿Ï…Ï‚. The gen. defines the "material," or nature, of the á¼±ÎºÏ„á½µÏÎ¹Î±, as in El. 758 Ïƒá¿¶Î¼Î± Î´ÎµÎ¹Î»Î±á½·Î±Ï‚ ÏƒÏ€Î¿Î´Î¿á¿¦ is a body consisting in (reduced to) ashes. We could not render, "the emblems of supplication brought by hapless persons." Nor, again, "the suppliants belonging to a wretched man" (the two maidens). In the following periphrases we see an analogous poet. use of the neut. plur., though the relation to the gen. is not precisely the same: Ant. 1209 á¼€Î¸Î»á½·Î±Ï‚ á¼„ÏƒÎ·Î¼Î±...Î²Î¿á¿†Ï‚, "confused accents of a mournful cry," where the gen. might be either of material, as here, or possessive: ib. 1265 á½¤Î¼Î¿Î¹ á¼Î¼á¿¶Î½ á¼„Î½Î¿Î»Î²Î± Î²Î¿Ï…Î»ÎµÏ…Î¼á½±Ï„Ï‰Î½ (partitive gen.): Eur. Phoen. 1485 Î¿á½ Ï€ÏÎ¿ÎºÎ±Î»Ï…Ï€Ï„Î¿Î¼á½³Î½Î± Î²Î¿Ï„ÏÏ…Ï‡á½½Î´ÎµÎ¿Ï‚ | á¼Î²Ïá½° Ï€Î±Ïá½µÎ¹Î´Î¿Ï‚, "not veiling the delicate cheek,"â€”for this is clearly the sense, rather than "spreading a delicate veil" (sc. ÎºÎ±Î»á½»Î¼Î¼Î±Ï„Î±) over it.

á¼„Î³Î¿Î½Ï„Î± Ï†Ï‰Ï„á¿¶Î½ á¼€Î¸Î»á½·Ï‰Î½ á¼±ÎºÏ„á½µÏÎ¹Î±.
Î¿á½”ÎºÎ¿Ï…Î½ á¼”Î³Ï‰Î³â€™ á¼‚Î½ Ïƒá¿†Ï‚ á¼Ï€ÎµÎ¼Î²Î±á½·Î½Ï‰Î½ Ï‡Î¸Î¿Î½á½¹Ï‚, ğŸ—©
Line 924

á¼Ï€ÎµÎ¼Î²Î±á½·Î½Ï‰Î½: cp. on 400. Theseus points his reproof, as Oed. did in 776 ff., by asking Creon to imagine their respective situations reversed.

á¼„Î½ÎµÏ… Î³Îµ Ï„Î¿á¿¦ ÎºÏÎ±á½·Î½Î¿Î½Ï„Î¿Ï‚, iniussu dominatoris, cp. Il. 15.213 á¼„Î½ÎµÏ… á¼Î¼á½³Î¸ÎµÎ½ ÎºÎ±á½¶ á¼ˆÎ¸Î·Î½Î±á½·Î·Ï‚ á¼€Î³ÎµÎ»Îµá½·Î·Ï‚, without my consent and hers.

Ï‡Î¸Î¿Î½á½¸Ï‚, gen. with ÎºÏ., as Ai. 1050 á½ƒÏ‚ ÎºÏÎ±á½·Î½ÎµÎ¹ ÏƒÏ„ÏÎ±Ï„Î¿á¿¦.

Line 927

Î¿á½”Î¸â€™ Îµá¼·Î»ÎºÎ¿Î½ Î¿á½”Ï„â€™ á¼‚Î½ á¼¦Î³Î¿Î½. The chief protasis is contained in the partic. á¼Ï€ÎµÎ¼Î²Î±á½·Î½Ï‰Î½ (924),=Îµá¼° á¼Ï€ÎµÎ½á½³Î²Î±Î¹Î½Î¿Î½, while Îµá¼° â€¦ Îµá¼¶Ï‡Î¿Î½ merely subjoins a special case in which the apodosis would still hold good:â€”Îµá¼° á¼Ï€ÎµÎ½á½³Î²Î±Î¹Î½Î¿Î½, Î¿á½Îº á¼‚Î½ Îµá¼·Î»ÎºÎ¿Î½, Î¿á½Î´á½² (Îµá¼·Î»ÎºÎ¿Î½ á¼‚Î½) Îµá¼° Îµá¼¶Ï‡Î¿Î½. Remark that the form of the apodosis, Î¿á½”Î¸â€™ Îµá¼·Î»ÎºÎ¿Î½...á¼‚Î½ etc., does not logically imply, "I am now dragging," but merely, "I am not now forbearing to drag": there is no opportunity for such abstention, since the fact supposed by á¼Ï€ÎµÎ¼Î²Î±á½·Î½Ï‰Î½ ("If I were on Theban soil") is non-existent. The conditional form with the imperf. indic. has been preferred to that with the optative (used in the similar illustration at 776), because Theseus is thinking of what Creon is actually doing.

PV 921 á¼Ï€â€™ Î±á½Ï„á½¸Ï‚ Î±á½‘Ï„á¿·: ib. 762 Ï€Ïá½¸Ï‚ Î±á½Ï„á½¸Ï‚ Î±á½‘Ï„Î¿á¿¦ ÎºÎµÎ½Î¿Ï†Ïá½¹Î½Ï‰Î½ Î²Î¿Ï…Î»ÎµÏ…Î¼á½±Ï„Ï‰Î½. In this hyperbaton Î±á½Ï„á½¹Ï‚ merely adds emphasis to the reflexive. Line 933

Ï„Î¹Î½Î±, simply "some one": not here a threatening substitute for Ïƒá½³ (as in Ai. 1138, Ant. 751). Indifference as to the agent strengthens insistence on the act.

Îµá¼° Î¼á½´ Î¼á½³Ï„Î¿Î¹ÎºÎ¿Ï‚ Ï„á¿†ÏƒÎ´Îµ Ï„á¿†Ï‚ Ï‡á½½ÏÎ±Ï‚ Î¸á½³Î»ÎµÎ¹Ï‚ ğŸ—©
Line 934

The essence of the notion conveyed by Î¼á½³Ï„Î¿Î¹ÎºÎ¿Ï‚, in ordinary Attic usage, was a voluntary sojourn, terminable at the will of the sojourner. Hence the irony here. With a similar force the Attic poets apply it to one who has found his "last, long home" in foreign earth. Aesch. Cho. 683 Îµá¼´Ï„â€™ Î¿á½–Î½ ÎºÎ¿Î¼á½·Î¶ÎµÎ¹Î½ Î´á½¹Î¾Î± Î½Î¹Îºá½µÏƒÎµÎ¹ Ï†á½·Î»Ï‰Î½, Îµá¼´Ï„â€™ Î¿á½–Î½ Î¼á½³Ï„Î¿Î¹ÎºÎ¿Î½, Îµá¼°Ï‚ Ï„á½¸ Ï€á¾¶Î½ á¼€Îµá½¶ Î¾á½³Î½Î¿Î½, Î¸á½±Ï€Ï„ÎµÎ¹Î½: "whether his friends decide to bring his ashes home, or to bury him among strangers, an alien utterly for ever": so a Persian whose corpse was left at Salamis is ÏƒÎºÎ»Î·Ïá¾¶Ï‚ Î¼á½³Ï„Î¿Î¹ÎºÎ¿Ï‚ Î³á¿†Ï‚ á¼ÎºÎµá¿– (Pers. 319): Eur. Line 936

The words Ï„á¿· Î½á¿· have been suspected by recent criticism. They seem to me sound. The sense is, "these things, which I say to you, are purposed by my mind as really as they are uttered by my tongue." With Ï„á¿· Î½á¿· a verb meaning "I intend" (e.g. Î´Î¹Î±Î½Î¿Î¿á¿¦Î¼Î±Î¹) should strictly have been used; but the verb appropriate to á¼€Ï€á½¸ Î³Î»á½½ÏƒÏƒÎ·Ï‚ is made to serve for both. For a similar zeugma cp. O. Line 937

á½Ïá¾·Ï‚ á¼µÎ½â€™ á¼¥ÎºÎµÎ¹Ï‚; an indignant reproach, as O. T. 687.

á¼€Ï†â€™ á½§Î½=á¼€Ï€á½¸ Ï„Î¿á½»Ï„Ï‰Î½, á¼€Ï†â€™ á½§Î½ (cp. on 274): "Judging by the folk from whom thou art sprung (the Thebans, cp. 919), thou seemest just"â€” i.e., a member of a just race. For á¼€Ï€á½¹ of judging by a thing, cp. on 15. The Greek sense of the prep. with the relative here is really the same as with the supplied antecedent. It is our idiom which makes them seem different.

á¼Î³á½¼ Î¿á½”Ï„): so 998: O.T. 332 á¼Î³á½¼ Î¿á½”Ï„â€™ á¼Î¼Î±Ï…Ï„á½¹Î½: Ant. 458 á¼Î³á½¼ Î¿á½Îº á¼”Î¼ÎµÎ»Î»Î¿Î½: Ph. 585 á¼Î³á½½ Îµá¼°Î¼â€™ á¼ˆÏ„ÏÎµá½·ÏƒÎ±Î¹Ï‚.

L's Î»á½³Î³Ï‰, of which Î»á½³Î³Ï‰Î½ was a correction, came in by mistake from 936. Schneidewin's Î½á½³Î¼Ï‰Î½ has been generally received, and is clearly right: cp. on 879. While á¼„Î½Î±Î½Î´ÏÎ¿Î½ answers to Îºá½³Î½Î±Î½Î´ÏÎ¿Î½ á¼¢ Î´Î¿á½»Î»Î·Î½ in 917, á¼„Î²Î¿Ï…Î»Î¿Î½ (940), which implies the lack of a guiding mind, answers to Îºá¼„Î¼â€™ á¼´ÏƒÎ¿Î½ Ï„á¿· Î¼Î·Î´ÎµÎ½á½· in 918.â€”Creon's speech is as clever as it is impudent. He has only anticipated what the Athenians themselves would have wished. Indeed, he has acted in reliance on the Areiopagus (950). If his method has been rough, he was provoked by the violence of Oedipus.

Î¾Ï…Î½á½¹Î½Ï„ÎµÏ‚ Î·á½‘Ïá½³Î¸Î·ÏƒÎ±Î½ á¼€Î½á½¹ÏƒÎ¹Î¿Î¹ Ï„á½³ÎºÎ½Ï‰Î½. ğŸ—©
Line 946

Î·á½‘Ïá½³Î¸Î·ÏƒÎ±Î½. Attic inscriptions nearly as old as the poet's time confirm Î·á½‘â€ against Îµá½‘â€: cp. O. T. 546 n.

Ï„á½³ÎºÎ½Ï‰Î½ has been suspected. The literal meaning of á¼€Î½á½¹ÏƒÎ¹Î¿Î¹ Î³á½±Î¼Î¿Î¹ Ï„á½³ÎºÎ½Ï‰Î½ can be nothing but "unholy nuptials with children" (such as Iocasta's with Oed.). But here the sense should be, "unholy nuptials with parents": cp. 978 Î¼Î·Ï„Ïá½¸Ï‚...Î³á½±Î¼Î¿Ï…Ï‚. Can Ï„á½³ÎºÎ½Ï‰Î½, then, be defended? Thus, I think.

Î¾Ï…Î½á½¹Î½Ï„ÎµÏ‚ suggests the consort. Hence á¼€Î½á½¹ÏƒÎ¹Î¿Î¹ Î³á½±Î¼Î¿Î¹ Ï„á½³ÎºÎ½Ï‰Î½ is said, with poetical boldness and also with a certain designed obscurity, in this sense:â€”"a woman who has made an unholy marriage with her son."

Wecklein takes Ï„á½³ÎºÎ½Ï‰Î½ as "relative" gen. with á¼€Î½á½¹ÏƒÎ¹Î¿Î¹, in the sense of Ï€Î±Î¹Î´Î¿Ï…ÏÎ³á½·Î±Ï‚, ÏƒÏ€Î¿Ïá¾¶Ï‚: "a marriage unholy in respect of its offspring." This seems forced. Musgrave's Ï„Î¿Îºá½³Ï‰Î½ would be more specious if the gen. of a noun in â€Îµá½»Ï‚ anywhere else suffered synizesis in this place of the verse. (In 1361 Ï†Î¿Î½á½³Ï‰Ï‚ is in the 4th place.) Soph. has Î³Î¿Î½á½³Ï‰Î½ El. 146, 241, and Ï„Î¿Îºá½³Ï‰Î½ ib. 187, Eur. the latter H. F. 915, Or. 815, and in these 5 places (all lyric) the words are scanned as trisyllables: a fact which, so far as it goes, is against Ï„Î¿Îºá½³Ï‰Î½ here. Neither Ï„á½³ÎºÎ½Î¿Î¹Ï‚ nor Ï„á½³ÎºÎ½á¿³ is a probable remedy; nor is Ï†á½·Î»Ï‰Î½. In my belief Ï„á½³ÎºÎ½Ï‰Î½ is sound.

Ï„Î¿Î¹Î¿á¿¦Ï„Î¿Î½ Î±á½Ï„Î¿á¿–Ï‚ á¼ŒÏÎµÎ¿Ï‚ Îµá½”Î²Î¿Ï…Î»Î¿Î½ Ï€á½±Î³Î¿Î½ ğŸ—©
Line 947

Ï„Î¿Î¹Î¿á¿¦Ï„Î¿Î½, introducing a reason for a preceding statement, as Ai. 164 (Ï„Î¿Î¹Î¿á½»Ï„Ï‰Î½), 218 (Ï„Î¿Î¹Î±á¿¦Ï„)), 251 (Ï„Î¿á½·Î±Ï‚), 562 (Ï„Î¿á¿–Î¿Î½).â€”

Îµá½”Î²Î¿Ï…Î»Î¿Î½ suggests the title of the Court, á¼¡ á¼Î¾ á¼ˆÏÎµá½·Î¿Ï… Ï€á½±Î³Î¿Ï… Î²Î¿Ï…Î»á½µ. If the Council of the Areiopagus (Creon assumes) became aware that a polluted person, such as Oedipus, was in Attica, it would take steps for his expulsion. Such a proceeding would doubtless have come within the limits of the general moral censorship actually possessed by the Areiopagus, at least in the earlier days of the Athenian democracy. Indeed that court is found exercising authority of a like kind (though only by special warrant) even after the reforms of Pericles and Ephialtes. Cp. Deinarchus or. 1 Â§ 58, where the Ecclesia commissions the Areiopagus to inquire into the conduct of a merely suspected person, and the Areiopagus, having done so, reports to the Ecclesia (Ï„Î¿á¿¦ Î´á½µÎ¼Î¿Ï… Ï€ÏÎ¿ÏƒÏ„á½±Î¾Î±Î½Ï„Î¿Ï‚ Î¶Î·Ï„á¿†ÏƒÎ±Î¹ Ï„á½´Î½ Î²Î¿Ï…Î»á½µÎ½,...ÎºÎ±á½¶ Î¶Î·Ï„á½µÏƒÎ±ÏƒÎ±Î½ á¼€Ï€Î¿Ï†á¿†Î½Î±Î¹ Ï€Ïá½¸Ï‚ á½‘Î¼á¾¶Ï‚, á¼€Ï€á½³Ï†Î·Î½ÎµÎ½ á¼¡ Î²Î¿Ï…Î»á½µ, etc.). See also Plut. Sol. 22, Isocr. or. 7 Â§Â§ 36-55, and my Attic Orators vol. II. p. 211.

á¼Î³á½¼ Î¾Ï…Î½á¿„Î´Î· Ï‡Î¸á½¹Î½Î¹Î¿Î½ á½„Î½Î¸â€™, á½ƒÏ‚ Î¿á½Îº á¼á¾· ğŸ—©
Line 948

Ï„Î¿Î¹Î¿á½»ÏƒÎ´â€™ á¼€Î»á½µÏ„Î±Ï‚ Ï„á¿‡Î´â€™ á½Î¼Î¿á¿¦ Î½Î±á½·ÎµÎ¹Î½ Ï€á½¹Î»ÎµÎ¹Â·

Line 954

Î¸Ï…Î¼Î¿á¿¦, the anger which moved Creon to make the seizure: cp. 874 Î¿á½”Ï„Î¿Î¹ ÎºÎ±Î¸á½³Î¾Ï‰ Î¸Ï…Î¼á½¹Î½. Theseus had said that Creon's violence disgraced his years (931). Creon replies, "There is no old age for anger, except death"; i.e., "anger, under gross insult, ceases to be felt only when a man is dead, and can feel nothing." Schol.: Ï„Î¿á¿¦Ï„Î¿ Î´á½² ÎºÎ±á½¶ Ï€Î±ÏÎ¿Î¹Î¼Î¹Î±Îºá¿¶Ï‚ Î»á½³Î³ÎµÏ„Î±Î¹, á½…Ï„Î¹ á½ Î¸Ï…Î¼á½¸Ï‚ á¼”ÏƒÏ‡Î±Ï„Î¿Î½ Î³Î·Ïá½±ÏƒÎºÎµÎ¹. Cp. Aesch. Line 965

á¼„Î½ cannot go with Î¼Î·Î½á½·Î¿Ï…ÏƒÎ¹Î½. since the partic. does not represent an apodosis, as á¼‚Î½ Ï†á½³ÏÏ‰Î½ does in 761 (n.). On the other hand, á¼„Î½ does not here give any conditional force to á¼¦Î½, which is a simple statement of fact. Rather Ï„á½±Ï‡â€™ á¼„Î½ is here felt as one word,="perhaps." "It was dear to the gods,â€”perhaps because they were wroth." The origin of this usage was an ellipse: Î¸ÎµÎ¿á¿–Ï‚ á¼¦Î½ Ï†á½·Î»Î¿Î½, Ï„á½±Ï‡Î± (Î´)) á¼‚Î½ (Ï†á½·Î»Î¿Î½ Îµá¼´Î·) Î¼Î·Î½á½·Î¿Ï…ÏƒÎ¹Î½, "and perhaps (it would be dear) because they were wroth": where the supplied Îµá¼´Î· expresses a conjecture about a past fact, as in Her. 1.2 Îµá¼´Î·ÏƒÎ±Î½ Î´â€™ á¼‚Î½ Î¿á½—Ï„Î¿Î¹ ÎšÏá¿†Ï„ÎµÏ‚. Cp. O. T. 523 á¼€Î»Î»â€™ á¼¦Î»Î¸Îµ Î¼á½²Î½ Î´á½´ Ï„Î¿á¿¦Ï„Î¿ Ï„Î¿á½”Î½ÎµÎ¹Î´Î¿Ï‚ Ï„á½±Ï‡â€™ á¼‚Î½ | á½€ÏÎ³á¿‡ Î²Î¹Î±ÏƒÎ¸á½³Î½, "this reproach came under stress, perchance, of anger." See Appendix.

á¼Ï€Îµá½¶ ÎºÎ±Î¸â€™ Î±á½‘Ï„á½¹Î½ Î³â€™ Î¿á½Îº á¼‚Î½ á¼Î¾Îµá½»ÏÎ¿Î¹Ï‚ á¼Î¼Î¿á½¶ ğŸ—©
Line 966

á¼Ï€Îµá½¶ ÎºÎ±Î¸â€™ Î±á½‘Ï„á½¹Î½ Î³). "My fate must have been a divine judgment upon me for the sins of ancestors. For you could not discover against me (á¼Î¼Î¿á½·, dat. of interest, cp. 962),â€”taken by myself (ÎºÎ±Î¸â€™ Î±á½‘Ï„á½¹Î½, apart from those ancestors),â€”any charge of sin, in retribution for which (á¼€Î½Î¸â€™ á½…Ï„Î¿Ï…) I proceeded to sin (impf. á¼¡Î¼á½±ÏÏ„Î±Î½Î¿Î½) against myself and my kindred." If any voluntary crime on his part had preceded his involuntary crimes, the latter might have been ascribed to an á¼„Ï„Î· sent on him by angry gods. But he had committed no such voluntary crime. For Î±á½‘Ï„á½¹Î½=á¼Î¼Î±Ï…Ï„á½¹Î½ see on 852 f.

Others take á¼€Î½Î¸â€™ á½…Ï„Î¿Ï… as="in that," "because," and understand:â€”"For you cannot charge any guilt on me personally (ÎºÎ±Î¸â€™ Î±á½‘Ï„á½¹Î½"), in that I sinned against myself and my kindred. But (1) ÎºÎ±Î¸â€™ Î±á½‘Ï„á½¹Î½ could not naturally express this contrast between the badness of the acts and the innocence of the agent. It contrasts the man with the Î³á½³Î½Î¿Ï‚. (2) á¼€Î½Î¸â€™ á½…Ï„Î¿Ï… regularly (if not always)="in return for which," "wherefore": e.g. El. 585 Î´á½·Î´Î±Î¾Î¿Î½ á¼€Î½Î¸â€™ á½…Ï„Î¿Ï… Ï„Î±Î½á¿¦Î½ Î±á¼´ÏƒÏ‡Î¹ÏƒÏ„Î± Ï€á½±Î½Ï„Ï‰Î½ á¼”ÏÎ³Î± Î´Ïá¿¶ÏƒÎ± Ï„Ï…Î³Ï‡á½±Î½ÎµÎ¹Ï‚: Eur. Ï†Î±Î½Îµá½¶Ï‚ Î´á½»ÏƒÏ„Î·Î½Î¿Ï‚, having been born to misery (as being fated to slay his sire): so 1225 á¼Ï€Îµá½¶ Ï†Î±Î½á¿‡, when one has come into the world. This is better here than, "having proved unfortunate."

The MSS. have Ï€á¿¶Ï‚ Î³â€™ á¼„Î½, but Î³â€™ should probably be omitted. L's Ï„Î»á½µÎ¼Ï‰Î½ might be either (a) predicate with the verb, or (b) nom. for voc., as 185 á½¦ Ï„Î»á½±Î¼Ï‰Î½, where see n. But (a) would be rather weak; and a direct address, rather than a half-comment (as in 185), is fitting here. Ï„Î»á¿†Î¼Î¿Î½, then, seems most probable.

â€”984 He has just said, "why force me to speak of Iocasta's marriage, when it was such as I will tell?" (980). In these three vv. he tells of what sort it was,â€”viz., incestuous, but unconsciously so;â€”a double reason why Creon should have spared the taunt.

á¼”Ï„Î¹ÎºÏ„ÎµÎ½="she was my mother"â€”she, who was becoming my brideâ€”though neither of us knew it at the time of the marriage. Cp. Eur. Ion 1560 á¼¥Î´Îµ Ï„á½·ÎºÏ„ÎµÎ¹ Ï‚), "she is thy mother"; and O. T. 437, 870.

Î±á½‘Ï„á¿†Ï‚ á½„Î½ÎµÎ¹Î´Î¿Ï‚, because, although she was morally guiltless in the marriage, yet such a union was, in fact, shameful: cp. O. T. 1494, 1500. Ï„á½¸ Î˜. á½„Î½Î¿Î¼Î± Î¸Ï‰Ï€., "to pay court to the great name of Th. (to the renowned Th.)." Î¸Ï‰Ï€Îµá¿¦ÏƒÎ±Î¹: cp. 1336.

Line 1004

á½¡Ï‚ ÎºÎ±Ï„á¿´ÎºÎ·Î½Ï„Î±Î¹ ÎºÎ±Î»á¿¶Ï‚, lit., "that it has been administered well," the perf. here denoting that a good administration is thoroughly established in it (cp. on Ï„á½³Ï„ÏÎ¿Ï†ÎµÎ½, 186). The political senses of ÎºÎ±Ï„Î¿Î¹Îºá½³Ï‰ and ÎºÎ±Ï„Î¿Î¹Îºá½·Î¶Ï‰ should be carefully distinguished. (1) á¼¡ Ï€á½¹Î»Î¹Ï‚ ÎºÎ±Î»á¿¶Ï‚ ÎºÎ±Ï„Î¿Î¹ÎºÎµá¿–Ï„Î±Î¹=the city is dwelt-in on good principles, "is well administered": see Plat. Legg. 683A. (2) á¼¡ Ï€á½¹Î»Î¹Ï‚ ÎºÎ±Î»á¿¶Ï‚ ÎºÎ±Ï„á¿´ÎºÎ¹ÏƒÏ„Î±Î¹=the city has been established on good principles, "has a good constitution": see Legg. 752 B. In this verse the poetical peculiarity is the use of the perf. where a prose-writer would have said either ÎºÎ±Ï„Î¿Î¹ÎºÎ¿á¿¦Î½Ï„Î±Î¹ or else ÎºÎ±Ï„á¿³ÎºÎ¹ÏƒÎ¼á½³Î½Î±Î¹ Îµá¼°Ïƒá½·. Oed. refers to Creon's implied praise of Athenian loyalty (941 ff.), and esp. to his mention of the Areiopagus (947 ff.).

The contrast with Ï€Î±Î¸á½¹Î½Ï„ÎµÏ‚, and the impossibility (as I think) of justifying á¼Î¾Î·ÏÏ€Î±ÏƒÎ¼á½³Î½Î¿Î¹, confirm F. W. Schmidt's á¼Î¾ÎµÎ¹ÏÎ³Î±ÏƒÎ¼á½³Î½Î¿Î¹. Since E also represented H in the older Ionic alphabet, the origin of the vulgate is at once explained if it is supposed that in Î•ÎÎ•Î¡Î“Î‘Î£ÎœÎ•ÎÎŸÎ™ the Î“ became Î ,â€”one of the slightest and easiest of all errors in uncial writing.

á¼Î¾Î·ÏÏ€Î±ÏƒÎ¼á½³Î½Î¿Î¹ must be explained in one of two ways. 1. "The captured ones are speeding." Here (a) ÏƒÏ€Îµá½»Î´Î¿Ï…ÏƒÎ¹Î½ is most strange as="are being carried off": it should imply eagerness. (b) The masc. plur. is strangely used when two girls are definitely meant. It is different when a woman, speaking of herself in the plur., uses the masc. (El. 399),â€” when the masc. sing. is used by the leader of a female Chorus (Eur. Hipp. 1105),â€”or when the masc. sing. is used in an abstract statement, though with allusion to a woman (El. 145). 2. "The captors are hurrying away." There is no other instance of á¼¥ÏÏ€Î±ÏƒÎ¼Î±Î¹, simple or in comp., as a perf. middle, while the pass. use is common. This may be an accident, for there are several instances of perfect forms which can be either passive or middle,â€”e.g. Îµá¼´ÏÎ³Î±ÏƒÎ¼Î±Î¹, Ï„ÎµÏ„Î¹Î¼á½½ÏÎ·Î¼Î±Î¹ (pass. in Thuc. 7.77, midd. in Antiph. Tetr. 3. Î². Â§ 8), Î¼ÎµÎ¼á½·Î¼Î·Î¼Î±Î¹ (pass. in Her. 2.78, midd. ib. 169 etc.). But it is a fact which increases the difficulty of assuming a middle sense here.

Ï€Î¿Î¼Ï€á½¸Î½ Î´) Îº.Ï„.Î». Three views of this clause require notice. I place first the view which seems to me right. 1. Legg. 631C Îµá¼´Ï‚ Ï„Îµ Î´Ïá½¹Î¼Î¿Î½ ÎºÎ±á½¶ Îµá¼°Ï‚ Ï„á½°Ï‚ á¼„Î»Î»Î±Ï‚ Ï€á½±ÏƒÎ±Ï‚ ÎºÎ¹Î½á½µÏƒÎµÎ¹Ï‚ Ï„á¿· Ïƒá½½Î¼Î±Ï„Î¹: Soph. 261 E Ï„á¿¶Î½ Ï„á¿‡ Ï†Ï‰Î½á¿‡ Ï€ÎµÏá½¶ Ï„á½´Î½ Î¿á½Ïƒá½·Î±Î½ Î´Î·Î»Ï‰Î¼á½±Ï„Ï‰Î½.

Ï„á¿· Î¼á½´ Î´Î¹ÎºÎ±á½·á¿³: cp. 73.

Ï„á¿· Î¼á½´ Î´Î¹ÎºÎ±á½·á¿³ ÎºÏ„á½µÎ¼Î±Ï„â€™ Î¿á½Ï‡á½¶ Ïƒá¿´Î¶ÎµÏ„Î±Î¹.
ÎºÎ¿á½Îº á¼„Î»Î»Î¿Î½ á¼•Î¾ÎµÎ¹Ï‚ Îµá¼°Ï‚ Ï„á½±Î´â€™Â· á½¡Ï‚ á¼”Î¾Î¿Î¹Î´á½± ÏƒÎµ ğŸ—©
Line 1028

ÎºÎ¿á½Îº á¼„Î»Î»Î¿Î½ á¼•Î¾ÎµÎ¹Ï‚ Îµá¼°Ï‚ Ï„á½¹Î´), and you will not have another (to aid you) with a view to this (i.e. to the removal of the captives). For this use of á¼”Ï‡ÎµÎ¹Î½ cp. Andoc. or. 1 Â§ 63 á¼•Î¾ÎµÎ¹Ï‚ á¼¡Î¼á¾¶Ï‚ á¼Ï€Î¹Ï„Î·Î´Îµá½·Î¿Ï…Ï‚: for Îµá¼°Ï‚ Ï„á½¹Î´) cp. 507.

á½¡Ï‚ á¼”Î¾Î¿Î¹Î´Î±, "(I speak of another,") for I know, etc.: á½¡Ï‚ causal; cp. 45.

Î¿á½ ÏˆÎ¹Î»á½¸Î½: see on 866.

á¼„ÏƒÎºÎµÏ…Î¿Î½: El. 36 á¼„ÏƒÎºÎµÏ…Î¿Î½ Î±á½Ï„á½¸Î½ á¼€ÏƒÏ€á½·Î´Ï‰Î½ Ï„Îµ ÎºÎ±á½¶ ÏƒÏ„ÏÎ±Ï„Î¿á¿¦. The allusion is not, of course, to Creon's guards, but to some Attic accomplices, whose secret aid had emboldened him to make the attempt (1031). The ancient Greek was quick to explain disaster by treason; thus it instantly occurs to Oedipus that some Theban must have been concerned in the murder of LaÃ¯us (O. T. 124). After Aegospotami, "the general belief...held that the Athenian fleet had been sold to perdition by some of its own commanders" (Grote VIII. 300). Theseus had no definite ground for his suspicion, but its utterance serves to place him (for a Greek audience) on the proper level of wary sagacity.

Î¿á½ ÏˆÎ¹Î»á½¸Î½ Î¿á½Î´â€™ á¼„ÏƒÎºÎµÏ…Î¿Î½ á¼Ï‚ Ï„Î¿Ïƒá½µÎ½Î´â€™ á½•Î²ÏÎ¹Î½ ğŸ—©
Line 1029

á¼Ï‚ Ï„Î¿Ïƒá½µÎ½Î´â€™ á½•Î²ÏÎ¹Î½ â€¦ Ï„á½¹Î»Î¼Î·Ï‚. The Ï„á½¹Î»Î¼Î± is the audacious spirit manifested in the á½•Î²ÏÎ¹Ï‚, or outrageous action. The gen. Ï„á½¹Î»Î¼Î·Ï‚ seems best taken as partitive, á¼Ï‚ Ï„Î¿Ïƒá½µÎ½Î´â€™ á½•Î²ÏÎ¹Î½ á¼¥ÎºÎ¿Î½Ï„Î± being equiv. to á¼Ï‚ Ï„Î¿ÏƒÎ¿á¿¦Ï„Î¿Î½ á¼¥ÎºÎ¿Î½Ï„Î±: cp. Isocr. 8 Â§ 31 Îµá¼°Ï‚ Ï„Î¿á¿¦Ï„Î¿ Î³á½±Ï Ï„Î¹Î½ÎµÏ‚ á¼€Î½Î¿á½·Î±Ï‚ á¼Î»Î·Î»á½»Î¸Î±ÏƒÎ¹Î½ (and n. on O. T. 771): "you have come to such a point of violence in the daring which now possesses you." If the gen. is taken as possessive, á½•Î²ÏÎ¹Ï‚ Ï„á½¹Î»Î¼Î·Ï‚ nearly =á½•Î²ÏÎ¹Ï‚ Ï„Î¿Î»Î¼Î·Ïá½±: but the addition of Ï„á¿†Ï‚ Ï€Î±ÏÎµÏƒÏ„á½½ÏƒÎ·Ï‚ Ï„Î±Î½á¿¦Î½ makes this awkward.

Ï€Î¹ÏƒÏ„á½¸Ï‚, active: Aesch. PV 916 Î¸Î±ÏÏƒá¿¶Î½ ÎºÎ±Î¸á½µÏƒÎ¸Ï‰ Ï„Î¿á¿–Ï‚ Ï€ÎµÎ´Î±ÏÏƒá½·Î¿Î¹Ï‚ ÎºÏ„á½»Ï€Î¿Î¹Ï‚ | Ï€Î¹ÏƒÏ„á½¹Ï‚. á¼ƒ Î´Îµá¿– Î¼â€™ á¼€Î¸Ïá¿†ÏƒÎ±Î¹, Î¼Î·Î´á½² Ï„á½µÎ½Î´Îµ Ï„á½´Î½ Ï€á½¹Î»Î¹Î½

Ï„Î¹ Ï„Î¿á½»Ï„Ï‰Î½, ironical for Ï„Î±á¿¦Ï„Î±: O. T. 1140 Î»á½³Î³Ï‰ Ï„Î¹ Ï„Î¿á½»Ï„Ï‰Î½, á¼¢ Î¿á½ Î»á½³Î³Ï‰ Ï€ÎµÏ€ÏÎ±Î³Î¼á½³Î½Î¿Î½;

Ï„á½° Î½á¿¦Î½ is slightly better than Ï„Î±Î½á¿¦Î½. (1) With Ï„á½° Î½á¿¦Î½ the sense is:â€”"Or do the things said just now seem to you no less vain than (the things said) at the time when you were plotting these deeds?" alluding to the remonstrances and menaces of the Chorus, 829 ff. Ï„á½° Î½á¿¦Î½ Ï„Îµ Ï‡á½¥Ï„Îµ is then like Ï„á¼€Î¼á½° Îºá¼€ÎºÎµá½·Î½Ï‰Î½ (606), one article doing double duty. (2) With Ï„Î±Î½á¿¦Î½: "Or do these things (Ï„Î±á¿¦Ï„Î±", supplied from Ï„Î¿á½»Ï„Ï‰Î½) seem to you to have been said in vain, both now, and when you were plotting these deeds? But it is natural that Theseus should refer to his own wordsâ€”by Ï„á½° Î½á¿¦Î½â€”rather than to thoughts which the Chorus had suggested before him.

ÎšÏ. Î¿á½Î´á½²Î½ Ïƒá½º Î¼ÎµÎ¼Ï€Ï„á½¸Î½ á¼Î½Î¸á½±Î´â€™ á½¢Î½ á¼ÏÎµá¿–Ï‚ á¼Î¼Î¿á½·Â· ğŸ—©

á¼Î½Î¸á½±Î´â€™ á½¢Î½ has been generally suspected, because the qualification, "while here," seems to suit Creon better than Theseus. But, though á¼Î½Î¸á½±Î´â€™ á½„Î½Ï„) á¼ÏÎµá¿–Ï‚ á¼Î¼á½³ lies near, the vulgate is right. "While here," said of Theseus, means, "since this is your own realm, in which you have force at command."

Î¼ÎµÎ¼Ï€Ï„á½¸Î½ á¼Î¼Î¿á½·, predicate; "you will say nothing to my dissatisfaction": i.e. "you can say what you please,â€”I shall not dispute it." It is vain to argue with a master of legions.

á¼Ï€Î¹ÏƒÏ„ÏÎ¿Ï†Î±á½¶, the wheeling-about of Creon's guards, carrying off their captives, when overtaken by the Attic pursuers. Line 1046

Ï‡Î±Î»ÎºÎ¿Î²á½¹Î±Î½ cannot be resolved into two separate epithets,â€”"brassclad," and "clamorous": rather it seems to mean, "with noise of brass,"â€”the clatter of shields and swords in battle. Cp. O. T. 190, where the Death-god (the plague) is an Ares who is á¼„Ï‡Î±Î»ÎºÎ¿Ï‚ á¼€ÏƒÏ€á½·Î´Ï‰Î½, yet Ï€ÎµÏÎ¹Î²á½¹Î±Ï„Î¿Ï‚. Ï‡Î±Î»ÎºÎµá½¹Ï†Ï‰Î½Î¿Ï‚, "with voice as of brass," is not really similar: it is the epithet of Stentor (Il. 5.785) and of Cerberus (Hes. Theog. 311).

Î¼Îµá½·Î¾Î¿Ï…ÏƒÎ¹Î½: cp. Il. 15.510 á¼¢ Î±á½Ï„Î¿ÏƒÏ‡ÎµÎ´á½·á¿ƒ Î¼á¿–Î¾Î±Î¹ Ï‡Îµá¿–Ïá½±Ï‚ Ï„Îµ Î¼á½³Î½Î¿Ï‚ Ï„Îµ. The Attic spelling in the age of Sophocles was Î¼Îµá½·Î¾Ï‰ (not Î¼á½·Î¾Ï‰), á¼”Î¼ÎµÎ¹Î¾Î±, verb. adj. Î¼ÎµÎ¹ÎºÏ„á½¹Ï‚: and so in the proper names ÎœÎµÎ¹Î¾á½·Î±Ï‚, ÎœÎµá½·Î¾Î¹Ï€Ï€Î¿Ï‚, etc.: see Meisterhans pp. 25, 87. There is no epigraphic evidence for the pres.; but, as Curtius remarks (Gr. Verb p. 111 Eng. tr.), Î¼Îµá½·Î³Î½Ï…Î¼Î¹: Î¼Î¹Î³ :: Î´Îµá½·ÎºÎ½Ï…Î¼Î¹: Î´Î¹Îº.

á¼¢ Ï€Ïá½¸Ï‚ Î Ï…Î¸á½·Î±Î¹Ï‚ á¼¢ Î»Î±Î¼Ï€á½±ÏƒÎ¹Î½ á¼€ÎºÏ„Î±á¿–Ï‚. The Chorus here imagine the Athenians as pursuing the Thebans through the pass of Daphne, over Mount Aegaleos, towards Eleusis. Two points are mentioned as possible scenes for a fight.

(1) Î á½»Î¸Î¹Î±Î¹ á¼€ÎºÏ„Î±á½·, the Pythian shores; the shore of the bay of Eleusis just beyond the pass of DaphnÃ¨ on the N.W., near the salt-springs called á¿¬Îµá½·Ï„Î¿Î¹ (Thuc. 2.19). The distance from Colonus is about six miles. Î á½»Î¸Î¹Î±Î¹ alludes to the Î á½»Î¸Î¹Î¿Î½, an Ionic temple of Apollo (some fragments from which are among the Elgin marbles in the British Museum), situated on the site of the present monastery of DaphnÃ¨, in the narrowest and highest part of the pass. (Cp. Leake, Demes pp. 144 f.: Paus. 1.37.6.) Others take the Î á½»Î¸Î¹Î±Î¹ á¼€ÎºÏ„Î±á½· to mean Oenoe, where also there was a temple of Apollo. But (a) Oenoe was about 12 miles N.W. of Eleusis, near the pass of Dryoscephalae over Cithaeron. á¼€ÎºÏ„Î±á½· could not be said of such an inland place, and the distance imagined is too great. (b) The order of mention indicates the Î á½»Î¸Î¹Î±Î¹ á¼€ÎºÏ„Î±á½· as nearer than Eleusis to Colonus.

(2) Î»Î±Î¼Ï€á½±Î´ÎµÏ‚ á¼€ÎºÏ„Î±á½·, "the torch-lit shores" (cp. Harpocr. 184, quoted on 56, á¼‘Î¿ÏÏ„á½°Ï‚ Î»Î±Î¼Ï€á½±Î´Î±Ï‚): the coast of the same bay of Eleusis at a point about 5 miles W.N.W. of the former point,â€”viz. at Eleusis itself. The yearly celebration of the great Eleusinia began on or about the 16th of Boedromion (September). On the 20th of that month an image of Iacchus was borne in a torch-light procession along the á¼±ÎµÏá½° á½Î´á½¹Ï‚ from Athens to Eleusis. This procession is indicated by the Ï‡Î¿Ïá½¸Ï‚ Î¼Ï…ÏƒÏ„á¿¶Î½ in Aristoph. Ran. 316 ff.: see ib. 340 á¼”Î³ÎµÎ¹ÏÎµ Ï†Î»Î¿Î³á½³Î±Ï‚ Î»Î±Î¼Ï€á½±Î´Î±Ï‚, á¼Î½ Ï‡ÎµÏÏƒá½¶ Î³á½°Ï á¼¥ÎºÎµÎ¹Ï‚ Ï„Î¹Î½á½±ÏƒÏƒÏ‰Î½, á¼¼Î±ÎºÏ‡), á½¦ á¼¼Î±ÎºÏ‡Îµ, Î½Ï…ÎºÏ„á½³ÏÎ¿Ï… Ï„ÎµÎ»ÎµÏ„á¿†Ï‚ Ï†Ï‰ÏƒÏ†á½¹ÏÎ¿Ï‚ á¼€ÏƒÏ„á½µÏ. The search of Demeter for Persephone was also represented at Eleusis in a Ï€Î±Î½Î½Ï…Ï‡á½·Ï‚ of torch-bearing mystae. Cp. Aesch. fr. 376 (speaking of Eleusis) Î»Î±Î¼Ï€ÏÎ±á¿–ÏƒÎ¹Î½ á¼€ÏƒÏ„ÏÎ±Ï€Î±á¿–ÏƒÎ¹ Î»Î±Î¼Ï€á½±Î´Ï‰Î½ ÏƒÎ¸á½³Î½ÎµÎ¹. Ar. Th. 1151 á½„ÏÎ³Î¹Î± ÏƒÎµÎ¼Î½á½° Î¸ÎµÎ±á¿–Î½, á¼µÎ½Î± Î»Î±Î¼Ï€á½±ÏƒÎ¹ Ï†Î±á½·Î½ÎµÏ„Î¿Î½ á¼„Î¼Î²ÏÎ¿Ï„Î¿Î½ á½„ÏˆÎ¹Î½.

Î¼Îµá½·Î¾Î¿Ï…ÏƒÎ¹Î½, á¼¢ Ï€Ïá½¸Ï‚ Î Ï…Î¸á½·Î±Î¹Ï‚
á¼¢ Î»Î±Î¼Ï€á½±ÏƒÎ¹Î½ á¼€ÎºÏ„Î±á¿–Ï‚,
1050 Î¿á½— Ï€á½¹Ï„Î½Î¹Î±Î¹ ÏƒÎµÎ¼Î½á½° Ï„Î¹Î¸Î·Î½Î¿á¿¦Î½Ï„Î±Î¹ Ï„á½³Î»Î· ğŸ—©
Line 1050

Ï€á½¹Ï„Î½Î¹Î±Î¹, Demeter and Persephone (Cora), who in Ar. Th. 1156 are called Î˜ÎµÏƒÎ¼Î¿Ï†á½¹ÏÏ‰ Ï€Î¿Î»Ï…Ï€Î¿Ï„Î½á½·Î±. Cp. 683.

Ï„Î¹Î¸Î·Î½Î¿á¿¦Î½Ï„Î±Î¹, as the spiritual nurturers of their faithful votaries. Simonides, too, has this word in a fig. sense, fr. 150. 7 Îµá½– Î´â€™ á¼Ï„Î¹Î¸Î·Î½Îµá¿–Ï„Î¿ Î³Î»Ï…ÎºÎµÏá½°Î½ á½„Ï€Î± Î”Ï‰Ïá½·Î¿Î¹Ï‚ á¼ˆÏá½·ÏƒÏ„Ï‰Î½ | á¼ˆÏÎ³Îµá¿–Î¿Ï‚ ("cultivated").

Ï„á½³Î»Î·: Plat. Rep. 560E Ï„ÎµÎ»Î¿Ï…Î¼á½³Î½Î¿Ï… ÏˆÏ…Ï‡á½´Î½ Î¼ÎµÎ³á½±Î»Î¿Î¹ÏƒÎ¹ Ï„á½³Î»ÎµÏƒÎ¹: Eur. Hipp. 25 ÏƒÎµÎ¼Î½á¿¶Î½ á¼Ï‚ á½„ÏˆÎ¹Î½ ÎºÎ±á½¶ Ï„á½³Î»Î· Î¼Ï…ÏƒÏ„Î·Ïá½·Ï‰Î½: Aesch. fr. 377 Î¼Ï…ÏƒÏ„Î¹ÎºÎ¿á¿¦ Ï„á½³Î»Î¿Ï…Ï‚: in prose usu. Ï„ÎµÎ»ÎµÏ„Î±á½·.

Î¸Î½Î±Ï„Î¿á¿–ÏƒÎ¹Î½, á½§Î½ ÎºÎ±á½¶ Ï‡ÏÏ…Ïƒá½³Î± ğŸ—©
Line 1051

Î¸Î½Î±Ï„Î¿á¿–ÏƒÎ¹Î½, esp. fitting here, since the highest value of the Eleusinia consisted in opening a prospect of bliss after death. Soph. fr. 753 á½¡Ï‚ Ï„Ïá½¶Ï‚ á½„Î»Î²Î¹Î¿Î¹ ÎºÎµá¿–Î½Î¿Î¹ Î²ÏÎ¿Ï„á¿¶Î½, Î¿á¼³ Ï„Î±á¿¦Ï„Î± Î´ÎµÏÏ‡Î¸á½³Î½Ï„ÎµÏ‚ Ï„á½³Î»Î· Î¼á½¹Î»Ï‰Ïƒâ€™ á¼Ï‚ á¼Î¹Î´Î¿Ï…Â· Ï„Î¿á¿–ÏƒÎ´Îµ Î³á½°Ï Î¼á½¹Î½Î¿Î¹Ï‚ á¼ÎºÎµá¿– Î¶á¿†Î½ á¼”ÏƒÏ„Î¹, Ï„Î¿á¿–Ï‚ Î´â€™ á¼„Î»Î»Î¿Î¹ÏƒÎ¹ Ï€á½±Î½Ï„â€™ á¼ÎºÎµá¿– ÎºÎ±Îºá½±. Isocr. or. 4 Â§ 28 á¼§Ï‚ ï¼ˆ Ï„ÎµÎ»ÎµÏ„á¿†Ï‚ ï¼‰ Î¿á¼± Î¼ÎµÏ„Î±ÏƒÏ‡á½¹Î½Ï„ÎµÏ‚ Ï€ÎµÏá½· Ï„Îµ Ï„á¿†Ï‚ Ï„Î¿á¿¦ Î²á½·Î¿Ï… Ï„ÎµÎ»ÎµÏ…Ï„á¿†Ï‚ ÎºÎ±á½¶ Ï„Î¿á¿¦ Ïƒá½»Î¼Ï€Î±Î½Ï„Î¿Ï‚ Î±á¼°á¿¶Î½Î¿Ï‚ á¼¡Î´á½·Î¿Ï…Ï‚ Ï„á½°Ï‚ á¼Î»Ï€á½·Î´Î±Ï‚ á¼”Ï‡Î¿Ï…ÏƒÎ¹Î½.

á½§Î½ ÎºÎ±á½¶ Ï‡ÏÏ…Ïƒá½³Î± Îº.Ï„.Î».: á½§Î½ refers to Î¸Î½Î±Ï„Î¿á¿–ÏƒÎ¹Î½: ÎºÎ±á½¶ ("also") has the effect of limiting the reference to those persons on whom the pledge of secrecy has been imposed; â€” "those mortals on whose lips has been set the divine seal of the ministrant Eumolpidae": i.e. those who have been duly initiated by the Eumolpid Hierophant at Eleusis, and have been bound by him to secrecy.

ÎºÎ»á½´|Ï‚ Î•á½Î¼Î¿Î»Ï€Î¹Î´á¾¶Î½ (possessive gen.), the silence which they impose. Perhaps we should read Î²á½³Î²Î±Îºâ€™ á¼Îº. The Eumolpidae figure here as interpreters between the Two Goddesses and mortals, not as guardians of a secret which they may not communicate. Hence the above version is better than either of the following:â€”(1) á½¦Î½ referring to Ï€á½¹Ï„Î½Î¹Î±Î¹: "whose seal has been set on the lips of the Eumolpidae": (2) á½§Î½ referring to Ï„á½³Î»Î·: "the seal whereof has been set on the lips of the E."

ÎºÎ»á½´|Ï‚ á¼Ï€á½¶ Î³Î»á½½ÏƒÏƒá¾³ Î²á½³Î²Î±ÎºÎµ ğŸ—©
Line 1052

ÎºÎ»á½´|Ï‚, "that which closes," cannot well be rendered "key" here, any more than in Aesch. fr. 309 á¼€Î»Î»â€™ á¼”ÏƒÏ„Î¹ Îºá¼€Î¼Î¿á½¶ ÎºÎ»á½´|Ï‚ á¼Ï€á½¶ Î³Î»á½½ÏƒÏƒá¿ƒ Ï†á½»Î»Î±Î¾. The apparent boldness of a Greek metaphor is sometimes thus mitigated by the poet's consciousness of the literal sense; as when Pindar calls an inspiring thought an á¼€Îºá½¹Î½Î·,â€”literally, "sharpener," conventionally "whetstone"); or when he calls the master, who tempers a chorus into harmony, a ÎºÏÎ±Ï„á½µÏ (Ol. 6. 82, 91: cp. my paper in Journ. Hellen. Stud. III. 171). â€” Cp. the Î²Î¿á¿¦Ï‚ á¼Ï€á½¶ Î³Î»á½½ÏƒÏƒá¿ƒ (Aesch. Ag. 36), perh. a mere metaphor from a heavy weight,â€”parodied by Menander *(aliei=s fr. 1 Ï€Î±Ï‡á½ºÏ‚ Î³á½°Ï á½—Ï‚ á¼”ÎºÎµÎ¹Ï„â€™ á¼Ï€á½¶ ÏƒÏ„á½¹Î¼Î±. Anthol. Pal. 10. 42 á¼€ÏÏá½µÏ„Ï‰Î½ á¼Ï€á½³Ï‰Î½ Î³Î»á½½ÏƒÏƒá¿ƒ ÏƒÏ†ÏÎ±Î³á½¶Ï‚ á¼Ï€Î¹ÎºÎµá½·ÏƒÎ¸Ï‰. Eur. Med. 660 ÎºÎ±Î¸Î±Ïá½°Î½ á¼€Î½Î¿á½·Î¾ | Î±Î½Ï„Î± ÎºÎ»á¿‡Î´Î± Ï†ÏÎµÎ½á¿¶Î½, "having unlocked his heart in sincerity." ÎºÎ»á¿ƒÎ´Î¿á¿¦Ï‡Î¿Ï‚ was said either of a tutelar deity or of a priestess, and on the vases the symbolic key, adorned with woollen threads, is sometimes borne by the priestess (Passeri III. 294, Welcker Alte Denkm. III. 450 ff. etc.): but there is no evidence for the Eleusinian Hierophant actually putting a key to the lips of the initiated.

Ï‡ÏÏ…Ïƒá½³Î±, divine, precious,â€”because of the truths revealed: O. T. 157 Ï‡ÏÏ…Ïƒá½³Î±Ï‚ Ï„á½³ÎºÎ½Î¿Î½ á¼˜Î»Ï€á½·Î´Î¿Ï‚.

Ï€ÏÎ¿ÏƒÏ€á½¹Î»Ï‰Î½ Î•á½Î¼Î¿Î»Ï€Î¹Î´á¾¶Î½. The Eleusinia had four chief ministrants. 1. The á¼±ÎµÏÎ¿Ï†á½±Î½Ï„Î·Ï‚. This office was hereditary in the Eumolpid gens; Plut. De Exil. 17 Î•á½”Î¼Î¿Î»Ï€Î¿Ï‚ á¼Î¼á½»Î·ÏƒÎµ ÎºÎ±á½¶ Î¼Ï…Îµá¿– Ï„Î¿á½ºÏ‚ á¼Î»Î»Î·Î½Î±Ï‚ (as the earliest hierophant, and the ancestor of his successors). 2. The Î´á¾³Î´Î¿á¿¦Ï‡Î¿Ï‚: hereditary in the gens of Callias and Hipponicus, which traced itself from Triptolemus. 3. The á¼±ÎµÏÎ¿Îºá½µÏÏ…Î¾: hereditary in the gens of the ÎšÎ·ÏÏ…Îºá½·Î´Î±Î¹ (or Îšá½µÏÏ…ÎºÎµÏ‚). 4. The altar-priest, á¼±ÎµÏÎµá½ºÏ‚ á½ á¼Ï€á½¶ Î²Ï‰Î¼á¿·, or á¼Ï€Î¹Î²á½½Î¼Î¹Î¿Ï‚, who offered the sacrifice. It is not known whether this office was hereditary. As some relationship seems to have existed between the Eumolpidae and the two other gentes, Ï€ÏÎ¿ÏƒÏ€á½¹Î»Ï‰Î½ here possibly includes (2) and (3), but is more naturally taken of the á¼±ÎµÏÎ¿Ï†á½±Î½Ï„Î·Ï‚ only. A hydria found at Cumae, and belonging to a Campanian collection now at St Petersburg, exhibits an Eleusinian group of deities and priests, among whom the á¼±ÎµÏÎ¿Ï†á½±Î½Ï„Î·Ï‚ is distinguished by a long white stole, partly embroidered with gold, a myrtle wreath, and the thyrsus. (It is reproduced by Baumeister, DenkmÃ¤ler des kl. Alt.., p. 474, pl. 520.)

á¼”Î½Î¸â€™ Î¿á¼¶Î¼Î±Î¹ Ï„á½¸Î½ á¼Î³ÏÎµÎ¼á½±Ï‡Î±Î½ ğŸ—©
Line 1054

I incline to believe that the MS. words á¼”Î½Î¸â€™ Î¿á¼¶Î¼Î±Î¹ Ï„á½¸Î½ á¼Î³ÏÎµÎ¼á½±Ï‡Î±Î½ are sound, and that the variant á½€ÏÎµÎ¹Î²á½±Ï„Î±Î½ may have arisen by corruption from á¼Î³ÏÎµÎ¼á½±Ï‡Î±Î½. See Appendix on this passage. The fact that the antistrophic passage is certainly unsound in the MSS. has increased the doubt: see on 1069.

á¼Î³ÏÎµÎ¼á½±Ï‡Î±Î½, "rousing the fight," is a fit epithet for the champion who overtakes the captors, and forces them to a contest. Elsewhere we find only the fem. á¼Î³ÏÎµÎ¼á½±Ï‡Î·, as epithet of Pallas, Hom. Hymn. 5.424. Cp. Bacchyl. 12. 100[=13.67 of Kenyon's ed.] á¼€ÎµÏÏƒÎ¹Î¼á½±Ï‡Î¿Ï…Ï‚.

1055 Î˜Î·Ïƒá½³Î± ÎºÎ±á½¶ Ï„á½°Ï‚ Î´Î¹ÏƒÏ„á½¹Î»Î¿Ï…Ï‚ ğŸ—©
Line 1055

Î˜Î·Ïƒá½³Î± has the final Î± long in 1458, but short here: cp. Eur. Hec. 882 Î¾á½ºÎ½ Ï„Î±á¿–ÏƒÎ´Îµ Ï„á½¸Î½ á¼Î¼á½¸Î½ Ï†Î¿Î½á½³Î± Ï„Î¹Î¼Ï‰Ïá½µÏƒÎ¿Î¼Î±Î¹, =870 ed. Porson, who adds Philemon ap. Athen. 7. 307 E ÎºÎµÏƒÏ„Ïá¼” á½€Ï€Ï„á½¹Î½. Is the MS. ÎºÎ±á½¶ after Î˜Î·Ïƒá½³Î± genuine? If so, á¼Î¼Î¼Îµá½·Î¾ÎµÎ¹Î½ is here intrans., like á¼Ï€Î¹â€, Ï€ÏÎ¿Ï‚â€, ÏƒÏ…Î¼Î¼Î¹Î³Î½á½»Î½Î±Î¹: and the sense is, "Theseus and the two maidens will soon meet amid a battle-cry of confident prowess." Thus with á¼Î¼Î¼Îµá½·Î¾ÎµÎ¹Î½ we are to understand á¼€Î»Î»á½µÎ»Î¿Î¹Ï‚. The verb is fitting, because the maidens, though their sympathies are with Theseus, are in the midst of the hostile force.

Î±á½Ï„á½±ÏÎºÎµÎ¹ Î²Î¿á¾· is dat. of circumstance. This I believe to be the right view. Not, "Th. and the maidens will join battle with the foe," sc. Ï„Î¿á¿–Ï‚ Ï€Î¿Î»ÎµÎ¼á½·Î¿Î¹Ï‚: for the maidens are in the hands of the foe. Such a phrase is not defensible merely because in spirit they are with Theseus.

Many critics, however, now regard ÎºÎ±á½¶ as spurious: for Î˜Î·Ïƒá½³Î± ÎºÎ±á½¶ Dindorf proposes Î‘á¼°Î³Îµá¿“Î´Î±Î½: for Î˜Î·Ïƒá½³Î± ÎºÎ±á½¶ Ï„á½°Ï‚ Wecklein Î˜Î·Ïƒá½³Î± Ï€Î±á¿–Î´Î±Ï‚. The sense would then be:â€”"Theseus will soon bring the sisters into (i.e., will soon raise around them) a battle-cry of confident prowess,"â€”by attacking their captors. This is possibly right: but a change of ÎºÎ±á½¶ Ï„á½°Ï‚ into Ï€Î±á¿–Î´Î±Ï‚ is hardly likely. In Ph. 79 Ï€Î±á¿–, which Erfurdt changed to ÎºÎ±á½·, is clearly sound.

Î´Î¹ÏƒÏ„á½¹Î»Î¿Ï…Ï‚="two journeying" sisters, â€”as borne off by their captors: see on 17 Ï€Ï…ÎºÎ½á½¹Ï€Ï„ÎµÏÎ¿Î¹. Not, "separately carried off," with ref. to two bands of Thebans (cp. 818).

Î±á½Ï„á½±ÏÎºÎµÎ¹, "self-sufficing," and so "self-reliant," giving confident promise of victorious rescue.

Ï„Î¿á½»ÏƒÎ´â€™ á¼€Î½á½° Ï‡.: i.e. in Attica, before the border can be passed.

The poet has left the details of the rescue indistinct. Creon's guards first carried off the girls (844), and Theseus sent mounted Athenians in pursuit (897). Afterwards, Theseus commands Creon to lead him to where the girls are; if they are "in these regions" (1020 á¼Î½ Ï„á½¹Ï€Î¿Î¹ÏƒÎ¹ Ï„Î¿á¿–ÏƒÎ´)), Theseus himself will recover them: if, however, the guards are already flying with them, then Theseus has nothing to do; the mounted Athenians, who have already started, will pursue (1020 ff.). But from the words of Theseus in 1148 it is plain that they have been rescued by his personal prowess, of which he forbears to boast (ÎºÎ¿Î¼Ï€Îµá¿–Î½, 1149): and the same inference must be drawn from Antigone's words (1117). How are these facts to be reconciled? We can only suppose that the mounted Athenians, who started first, halted to watch the Î´á½·ÏƒÏ„Î¿Î¼Î¿Î¹ á½Î´Î¿á½· (900), while Creon's guards also halted somewhere in concealment, to await their master. Theseus, with Creon, was thus enabled to overtake his Athenians before the struggle. The fact is that Sophocles did not care to think out these points, about which an Athenian audience in the theatre would not trouble themselves. Cp. on O. T. 758.

á¼€Î´Î¼á¿†Ï„Î±Ï‚ á¼€Î´ÎµÎ»Ï†á½°Ï‚
Î±á½Ï„á½±ÏÎºÎµÎ¹ Ï„á½±Ï‡â€™ á¼Î¼Î¼á½·Î¾ÎµÎ¹Î½ Î²Î¿á¾·
Ï„Î¿á½»ÏƒÎ´â€™ á¼€Î½á½° Ï‡á½½ÏÎ¿Ï…Ï‚Â·
Î§Î¿. á¼¤ Ï€Î¿Ï… Ï„á½¸Î½ á¼Ï†ÎµÏƒÏ€á½³ÏÎ¿Ï… ğŸ—©
Line 1059

Hartung's Îµá¼°Ï‚ Î½Î¿Î¼á½¹Î½ for the MS. á¼Îº Î½Î¿Î¼Î¿á¿¦ is certain. With the latter, we could only render: "they will approach (the region) to the west of the snowy rock, out of (leaving) the pastures of the Oeatid territory." The rare acc. with Ï€ÎµÎ»á½±Î¶Ï‰ could be supported by Eur. Andr. 1167 Î´á¿¶Î¼Î± Ï€ÎµÎ»á½±Î¶ÎµÎ¹: but the ellipse of Ï‡á¿¶ÏÎ¿Î½ with Ï„á½¸Î½ á¼Ï†á½³ÏƒÏ€ÎµÏÎ¿Î½ is surely impossible.

Î½Î¿Î¼Î¿á¿¦, being always masc., could not agree with ÎŸá¼°á½±Ï„Î¹Î´Î¿Ï‚, and the latter, without art., could not stand for ÎŸá¼°á½±Ï„Î¹Î´Î¿Ï‚ Î³á¿†Ï‚: while ÎŸá¼°Î±Ï„á½³Î¿Ï‚ is most improbable.

Ï€ÎµÎ»á¿¶Ï‚), if sound, must be fut. of Ï€ÎµÎ»á½±Î¶Ï‰, as Ï€ÎµÎ»á¾¶Î½ clearly is in El. 497. The evidence for a pres. Ï€ÎµÎ»á½±Ï‰ is scanty (Hom. Hymn. 7.44 Ï€ÎµÎ»á½±Î±Î½: poet. ap. Plut. Mor. 457 C imperat. Ï€á½³Î»Î±: Oppian Cyn. 1. 514 Ï€ÎµÎ»á½±ÎµÎ¹: cp. Veitch Irreg. Verbs). The fut. seems defensible here, as="they will (presently) approach": though Hartung's Ï€ÎµÏá¿¶Ï‚) may be right. Construe, then: â€” á¼¤ Ï€Î¿Ï… Ï€ÎµÎ»á¿¶Ïƒâ€™ Îµá¼°Ï‚ á¼Ï†á½³ÏƒÏ€ÎµÏÎ¿Î½ Ï€á½³Ï„Ï. Î½Î¹Ï†. ÎŸá¼°á½±Ï„Î¹Î´Î¿Ï‚ Î½Î¿Î¼á½¹Î½: "or perchance they will presently approach the pastures to the west of the snowy rock of Oea."

The place meant is not certain. See note and map in Appendix. But the scholium here deserves at least thus much weight: it is our one ancient warrant for a definite view. Like the other old scholia in L, it probably dates (in substance) from the later Alexandrian age, which possessed many Attic writings, now lost, on the topography of Attica. The scholiast takes the Î½Î¹Ï†á½°Ï‚ Ï€á½³Ï„ÏÎ± to be a rock or crag of Mount Aegaleos;â€” the same which was called Î»Îµá½·Î± Ï€á½³Ï„ÏÎ±, "the smooth rock," by Istros, a writer on Attica, c. 240 B.C., whom he quotes. The schol. then explains ÎŸá¼°á½±Ï„Î¹Î´Î¿Ï‚ by the fact that Aegaleos á¼Ï€â€™ á¼ÏƒÏ‡á½±Ï„Ï‰Î½ á¼ÏƒÏ„á½¶ Ï„Î¿á¿¦ Î´á½µÎ¼Î¿Ï… Ï„Î¿á½»Ï„Î¿Ï…, "skirts that deme," â€”namely, of ÎŸá¼´Î·. It cannot reasonably be doubted that this statement about ÎŸá¼´Î·, if it did not rest on the scholiast's own knowledge, was derived from Istros, or from some other old writer on Attic topography.

The meaning will then be:â€”"Or perhaps the captors did not take the road through the pass of DaphnÃ¨, which goes by the sea-coast to Eleusis. Perhaps they went round the N. end of Aegaleos, and will soon be emerging on the Thriasian plain, to the west of Aegaleos, near the deme of Oea." This is also Leake's view (Demi of Attica p. 154). The route supposed would be in the general line of that taken by Archidamus and the Peloponnesians in 431 B.C., when they moved from Oenoe E.S.E. to Acharnae, á¼Î½ Î´ÎµÎ¾Î¹á¾· á¼”Ï‡Î¿Î½Ï„ÎµÏ‚ Ï„á½¸ Î‘á¼°Î³á½±Î»ÎµÏ‰Î½ á½„ÏÎ¿Ï‚,â€” i.e. keeping it to the S.,â€”Î´Î¹á½° ÎšÏÏ‰Ï€Î¹á¾¶Ï‚, a deme in the valley between the N. end of Aegaleos and the S.W. end of Parnes. Hartung, referring to the Î»Îµá½·Î± Ï€á½³Ï„ÏÎ± of Istros, conjectures Î»Î¹^Ï„á½±Î´Î¿Ï‚, as="smooth," for Î½Î¹Ï†á½±Î´Î¿Ï‚: but though late poets could use Î»Î¹^Ï„á½¹Ï‚ for Î»Î¹â€”Ï„á½¹Ï‚, the Î¹^ is most improbable for Soph.

á¼Î»á½½ÏƒÎµÏ„Î±Î¹, sc. á½ ÎšÏá½³Ï‰Î½, "he will be worsted" (not, "captured," since he was already in the hands of Theseus): cp. ÎºÎ±á½¶ á¼¢Î½ Î¼á½²Î½ á¼€Î½Î¸Î¹ÏƒÏ„á¿†Ï„Î±Î¹, "and if the enemy (the king) resist," etc.â€”This is better than (1) "the fugitive will be captured," supplying á½ Ï†Îµá½»Î³Ï‰Î½ from Ï†Îµá½»Î³Î¿Î½Ï„ÎµÏ‚: (2) "a capture will be made,"â€” taking the verb as impers.: or (3) "the battle will be won," á¼Î»á½½ÏƒÎµÏ„Î±Î¹ á½ á¼€Î³á½½Î½, as Elms. takes it, comparing 1148 á¼Î³á½¼Î½ á¾‘Ïá½³Î¸Î·.

Ï€ÏÎ¿ÏƒÏ‡á½½ÏÏ‰Î½, the neighbours of the grove, the Coloniates (cp. 493); not, "our neighbours the Thebans," for the Chorus are predicting an easy victory, not a tough fight. Colonus and its neighbourhood had furnished a contingent to the party of rescue (897).

Î˜Î·ÏƒÎµÎ¹Î´á¾¶Î½, schol. á¼ˆÎ¸Î·Î½Î±á½·Ï‰Î½: cp. ÎšÎµÎºÏÎ¿Ï€á½·Î´Î±Î¹, á¼˜ÏÎµÏ‡Î¸Îµá¿–Î´Î±Î¹, Aeneadae, etc.: here, followers of Theseus from Athens, as distinct from the Coloniates. We could not well understand, with Ellendt, "the Coloniates, and the followers of Theseus generally," as if Î˜Î·ÏƒÎµÎ¹Î´á¾¶Î½ included Ï€ÏÎ¿ÏƒÏ‡á½½ÏÏ‰Î½.

á¼€ÎºÎ¼á½±, vigour, might: Pind. Isthm. 3. 68 á¼€Î»Î»â€™ á½€Î½Î¿Ï„á½¸Ï‚ Î¼á½²Î½ á¼°Î´á½³ÏƒÎ¸Î±Î¹, ÏƒÏ…Î¼Ï€ÎµÏƒÎµá¿–Î½ Î´â€™ á¼€ÎºÎ¼á¾· Î²Î±Ïá½»Ï‚, "dread to grapple with in his strength."

á¼€Î¼Ï€Ï…ÎºÏ„á½µÏÎ¹Î± ÏƒÏ„Î¿Î¼á½·Ï‰Î½ ğŸ—©
Line 1069

á¼€Î¼Ï€Ï…ÎºÏ„á½µÏÎ¹Î± Ï†á½±Î»Î±ÏÎ± Ï€á½½Î»Ï‰Î½ is the MS. reading. Hesychius s.v. has: á¼€Î¼Ï€Ï…ÎºÏ„á½µÏÎ¹Î±Â· Ï„á½° Ï†á½±Î»Î±ÏÎ±. Î£Î¿Ï†Î¿ÎºÎ»á¿†Ï‚ ÎŸá¼°Î´á½·Ï€Î¿Î´Î¹ á¼Î½ ÎšÎ¿Î»Ï‰Î½á¿·. This proves what the metre (on any view of 1054) already hinted,â€” that Ï†á½±Î»Î±ÏÎ± is a gloss. á¼€Î¼Ï€Ï…ÎºÏ„á½µÏÎ¹Î¿Î½ here="bridle," as á¼€Î¼Ï€Ï…ÎºÏ„á½µÏ in Aesch. Theb. 461 á¼µÏ€Ï€Î¿Ï…Ï‚ Î´â€™ á¼Î½ á¼€Î¼Ï€Ï…ÎºÏ„á¿†ÏÏƒÎ¹Î½ á¼Î¼Î²ÏÎ¹Î¼Ï‰Î¼á½³Î½Î±Ï‚: where the schol. (minor) expressly says that á¼„Î¼Ï€Ï…Î¾ (properly the head-band) was similarly used: ÎºÏ…Ïá½·Ï‰Ï‚ Î¿á¼± Ï€ÎµÏá½¶ Ï„á½´Î½ ÎºÎµÏ†Î±Î»á½´Î½ á¼±Î¼á½±Î½Ï„ÎµÏ‚ Ï„Î¿á¿¦ Ï‡Î±Î»Î¹Î½Î¿á¿¦ á¼„Î¼Ï€Ï…Î¾ ÎºÎ±Î»Î¿á¿¦Î½Ï„Î±Î¹: and so Quintus Smyrnaeus uses á¼„Î¼Ï€Ï…Î¾, 4. 511. It is but a slight poetical extension of meaning to use á¼€Î¼Ï€Ï…ÎºÏ„á½µÏÎ¹Î± as including the bridle-reins. The MS. Ï€á½½Î»Ï‰Î½ is against the metre, unless 1054 f. are very boldly altered (see Metrical Analysis). When the gloss Ï†á½±Î»Î±ÏÎ± had crept into the text, Ï€á½½Î»Ï‰Î½ (suggested by 1062) may have been tacked on to it. Wecklein's conjecture, á¼€Î¼Ï€Ï…ÎºÏ„á½µÏÎ¹Î± ÏƒÏ„Î¿Î¼á½·Ï‰Î½ ("the reins of the bits") gives an exact correspondence with 1054 á¼”Î½Î¸â€™ Î¿á¼¶Î¼Î±Î¹ Ï„á½¸Î½ á¼Î³ÏÎµÎ¼á½±Ï‡Î±Î½. Nothing better has been suggested.

á¼„Î¼Î²Î±ÏƒÎ¹Ï‚, in such a context, needs not to be defined by Ï€á½½Î»Ï‰Î½. For the apocopÃ¨, cp. Ant. 1275 á¼€Î½Ï„Ïá½³Ï€Ï‰Î½, n.

Line 1072

Î³Î±Î¹á½±Î¿Ï‡Î¿Î½, in the Homeric use, is most simply explained as "earth-embracer," with ref. to the Homeric idea of á½¨ÎºÎµÎ±Î½á½¹Ï‚ flowing round the earth: though some understand "reigning on earth" (as Zeus in heaven, and Hades in the nether world Il. 15.190). Some take it here as = "guarding our land," like Î³. á¼ŒÏÏ„ÎµÎ¼Î¹Î½ in O. T. 160: and this certainly has more special point here. But would the constant Homeric epithet of Poseidon be applied to him in a sense different from the Homeric? All Greek hearers would think of the Î³Î±Î¹á½µÎ¿Ï‡Î¿Ï‚ á¼˜Î½Î½Î¿Ïƒá½·Î³Î±Î¹Î¿Ï‚.

á¿¬á½³Î±Ï‚, here a monosyllable, as in Il. 15.187,â€”the only instance of this form in Il. or Od., but a dissyllable in Hom. Hymn. 5.459, Ï„á½´Î½ Î´â€™ á½§Î´Îµ Ï€ÏÎ¿Ïƒá½³ÎµÎ¹Ï€Îµ á¿¬á½³Î· Î»Î¹Ï€Î±ÏÎ¿ÎºÏá½µÎ´ÎµÎ¼Î½Î¿Ï‚. Elsewhere in the Hymns the form is always á¿¬Îµá½·Î·, as in Il. 14.203. In Hes. Th. 634 á¿¬Îµá¿–Î± is read.

Rhea, in the Greek theogony, is daughter of Uranos and Gaia, wife of Cronus, and "mother of the gods." The cult was that of the "Phrygian Mother" Cybele in a special phase, and came very early to Greece from Lydia: in Attica it was intimately connected with the Eleusinian cult of Demeter (cp. Hom. Hymn. 5.442, Eur. Helen 1301 ff. ). The ÎœÎ·Ï„Ïá¿·Î¿Î½ at Athens, the temple of Rhea Cybele, contained a celebrated statue of the goddess, by Pheidias or his pupil Agoracritus.

á¼”ÏÎ´Î¿Ï…Ï‚): "are they (the pursuers) in action, or on the point of being so? for (á½¡Ï‚) I have a foreboding, etc."

Î¼á½³Î»Î»Î¿Ï…ÏƒÎ¹Î½, sc. á¼”ÏÎ¾ÎµÎ¹Î½: cp. Line 1075

Î³Î½á½½Î¼Î± Î¼Î¿Î¹ my mind Ï€ÏÎ¿Î¼Î½á¾¶Ï„Î±á½· Ï„Î¹ (adv.) somehow pleads for the belief, presages. Ï€ÏÎ¿Î¼Î½á¾¶ÏƒÎ¸Î±Î¹ means (1) to woo for another, Îºá½¹ÏÎ·Î½ Ï„Î¹Î½á½·: (2) fig., to seek to obtain anything for another, e.g. Î´á¿¶Ïá½± Ï„Î¹Î½Î¹. The bold use here comes through the notion of pleading, or speaking persuasively, as the Ï€ÏÎ¿Î¼Î½á½µÏƒÏ„ÏÎ¹Î± to the maiden on behalf of the lover. This use is bolder than the fig. use in Plat. Menex. 239 C, where the question is of themes which have already been "married to immortal verse," as distinguished from others in respect of which Poetry á¼”Ï„Î¹ á¼ÏƒÏ„Î¹Î½ á¼Î½ Î¼Î½Î·ÏƒÏ„Îµá½·á¾³, is still in the stage of courtship. Of these latter, says the orator, I will speakâ€”á¼Ï€Î±Î¹Î½Î¿á¿¦Î½Ï„á½± Ï„Îµ ÎºÎ±á½¶ Ï€ÏÎ¿Î¼Î½á½½Î¼ÎµÎ½Î¿Î½ á¼„Î»Î»Î¿Î¹Ï‚ á¼Ï‚ á¾ Î´á½°Ï‚...Î±á½Ï„á½° Î¸Îµá¿–Î½Î±Î¹, commending them, and wooing them for others (i.e. for the poets), with a view to their putting them into verse. (A passage which has often been misunderstood as if Ï€ÏÎ¿Î¼Î½. á¼„Î»Î»Î¿Î¹Ï‚ meant "pleading with others":â€”so Lidd. and Scott, with Ast.)

Î³Î½á½½Î¼Î± Ï„á½±Ï‡â€™ á¼€Î½Ï„á½±ÏƒÎµÎ¹Î½ ğŸ—©
Line 1076

á¼€Î½Ï„á½±ÏƒÎµÎ¹Î½ (Buecheler),â€”a conjecture which had occurred independently to myself,â€”seems the most probable correction of á¼‚Î½ Î´á½½ÏƒÎµÎ¹Î½. The Chorus express a presentiment that they will soon again be brought face to face with the maidens who were dragged away before their eyes; and this prepares for the approaching entrance of Antigone and Ismene, 1097 Ï„á½°Ï‚ Îºá½¹ÏÎ±Ï‚ Î³á½°Ï Îµá¼°ÏƒÎ¿Ïá¿¶.

á¼€Î½Ï„á½±Ï‰ usu. takes a dat. of meeting a person, but sometimes a gen., as Il. 16.423 á¼€Î½Ï„á½µÏƒÏ‰ Î³á½°Ï á¼Î³á½¼ Ï„Î¿á¿¦Î´â€™ á¼€Î½á½³ÏÎ¿Ï‚ (in battle). With the gen., á¼€Î½Ï„á½±Ï‰ also=ÎºÏ…ÏÎµá¿–Î½, Ï„Ï…Î³Ï‡á½±Î½ÎµÎ¹Î½: Od. 3.97 á¼¤Î½Ï„Î·ÏƒÎ±Ï‚ á½€Ï€Ï‰Ï€á¿†Ï‚: Her. 2.119 Î¾ÎµÎ¹Î½á½·Ï‰Î½ á¼¤Î½Ï„Î·ÏƒÎµ Î¼ÎµÎ³á½±Î»Ï‰Î½. Cp. Soph. Ant. 982 á¼„Î½Ï„Î±Ïƒâ€™ á¼˜ÏÎµÏ‡Î¸ÎµÎ¹Î´á¾¶Î½, she attained unto them (traced her lineage back to them). Here the idea of obtaining back is blended with that of being brought face to face. It is not, then, a valid objection that the Chorus do not move to meet the maidens.

To á¼€Î½Î´á½½ÏƒÎµÎ¹Î½ the objections are: (1) it could not possibly mean á¼€Ï€Î¿Ïƒá½½ÏƒÎµÎ¹Î½, "give back." In Pind. fr. 133. 3, the sole passage quoted for this sense, á¼€Î½Î´Î¹Î´Î¿Î¹ ÏˆÏ…Ï‡á½°Î½ Ï€á½±Î»Î¹Î½ is not "gives back," but "sends up," to the sunlight,â€”like Î³á¿† á¼€Î½Î±Î´á½·Î´Ï‰ÏƒÎ¹ ÎºÎ±ÏÏ€á½¹Î½. We must not be confused by our "give up." (2) To supply "Creon" or "the enemy" as subject is extremely awkward. (3) The sing. Ï„á½°Î½...Ï„Î»á¾¶ÏƒÎ±Î½, etc., which this requires, cannot well be defended on the ground that Antigone is chiefly thought of.

With á¼Î½Î´á½½ÏƒÎµÎ¹Î½ we have to render:â€” "that the sufferings of those who have endured dread things, and found dread sufferings at the hands of kinsmen, will remit,"â€”become milder. Hippocrates (Progn. 43) uses the intrans. á¼Î½Î´Î¹Î´á½¹Î½Î±Î¹ of a malady which remits its force. But is Ï€á½±Î¸Î· â€¦ á¼Î½Î´á½½ÏƒÎµÎ¹Î½ tolerable here, where the question is not of the sisters' sufferings being mitigated, but of their triumphant deliverance from the hands of the enemy? If, again, á¼Î½Î´á½½ÏƒÎµÎ¹Î½="give up," it incurs the 2nd and 3rd objections to á¼€Î½Î´á½½ÏƒÎµÎ¹Î½.

In the MS. order of the words, á¼°á½¼ Î–Îµá¿¦, Ï€á½±Î½Ï„Î±ÏÏ‡Îµ Î¸Îµá¿¶Î½ (monosyll.)=1074 á¼”ÏÎ´Î¿Ï…Ïƒâ€™ á¼¢ Î¼á½³Î»Î»Î¿Ï…ÏƒÎ¹Î½; á½¡Ï‚, and Ï€Î±Î½Ï„á½¹Ï€Ï„Î±, Ï€á½¹ÏÎ¿Î¹Ï‚=1075 Ï€ÏÎ¿Î¼Î½á¾¶Ï„Î±á½· Ï„á½· Î¼Î¿Î¹. Ï„á½¸Î½ Îµá½”Î±Î³ÏÎ¿Î½, proleptic: cp. Tr. 477 Ï„á¿†ÏƒÎ´â€™ Î¿á½•Î½ÎµÏ‡â€™ á¼¡ Ï€Î¿Î»á½»Ï†Î¸Î¿ÏÎ¿Ï‚ ÎºÎ±Î¸á¿ƒÏá½³Î¸Î· Ï€Î±Ï„Ïá¿·Î¿Ï‚ ÎŸá¼°Ï‡Î±Î»á½·Î± Î´á½¹ÏÎµÎ¹.

Î»á½¹Ï‡Î¿Î½, "ambuscade," seems here to have the more general sense, "scheme of capture" (cp. Line 1094

ÏƒÏ„á½³ÏÎ³Ï‰, "I desire." Schol. ÏƒÎ·Î¼Î±á½·Î½ÎµÎ¹ Î¼á½²Î½ Î¿á¼¶Î¿Î½ Ï€ÏÎ¿Ïƒá½·ÎµÎ¼Î±Î¹Â· Ï„ÎµÎ»ÎµÏ…Ï„á¾· Î´á½² Îµá¼°Ï‚ á¼´ÏƒÎ¿Î½ Ï„á¿· Ï€ÏÎ¿ÎºÎ±Î»Î¿á¿¦Î¼Î±Î¹, â€œthe (literal) sense is nearly, "I approve" (or "consent"); but the ultimate (or virtual) sense is, "I invoke".â€ The scholiast saw the impropriety of rendering, "I am content that the gods should come to help us," and so imagined this transition of meaning. His only fault lay in starting from the special and derivative sense of ÏƒÏ„á½³ÏÎ³ÎµÎ¹Î½, "to be content," and not from its primary sense, "to love," whence poetry could easily draw the neighbouring sense, "to desire." So in O. T. 11 ÏƒÏ„á½³ÏÎ¾Î±Î½Ï„ÎµÏ‚= "having formed a desire." Hermann and others take ÏƒÏ„á½³ÏÎ³Ï‰ here as="I entreat," â€”getting the idea of "praying" through that of "revering" (as implied in the ÏƒÏ„Î¿ÏÎ³á½µ of children for parents, etc.). Hermann so takes the word in the Orphic Argonautica 772 Î¼ÎµÎ¹Î»Î¹Ï‡á½·Î¿Î¹Ï‚ ÏƒÏ„á½³ÏÎ¾Î¿Î¹ Ï„Îµ Ï€Î±ÏÎ±Î¹Ï†á½±Î¼ÎµÎ½Î¿Ï‚ á¼Ï€á½³ÎµÏƒÏƒÎ¹Î½ ("entreat him"), where Ruhnken conjectured Î¸á½³Î»Î¾Î¿Î¹.

Î´Î¹Ï€Î»á¾¶Ï‚ á¼€ÏÏ‰Î³á½°Ï‚, two aids (abstract for concrete), Apollo and Artemis. Cp. O. T. 164 Ï„ÏÎ¹ÏƒÏƒÎ¿á½¶ á¼€Î»ÎµÎ¾á½·Î¼Î¿ÏÎ¿Î¹ Ï€ÏÎ¿Ï†á½±Î½Î·Ï„á½³ Î¼Î¿Î¹ (Zeus, Apollo, Artemis).

Î¼á½³Î½ implies, "if my mere presage (1075) did not persuade, my eyes, at least, may be trusted."

Ï€ÏÎ¿ÏƒÏ€Î¿Î»Î¿Ï…Î¼á½³Î½Î±Ï‚ has been much suspected (see cr. n.). The verb Ï€ÏÎ¿ÏƒÏ€Î¿Î»Îµá¿–Î½ elsewhere occurs only in the act. as=to be a Ï€Ïá½¹ÏƒÏ€Î¿Î»Î¿Ï‚ (with dat., Eur.). Î¼Î·Î´Î±Î¼á½±, Î¿á½Î´Î±Î¼á½± are used by the poets when the final must be short; Î¼Î·Î´Î±Î¼á¿‡, Î¿á½Î´Î±Î¼á¿‡, when it must be long. Where, as here, either form is possible, L is not a safe guide in choosing between them. The Î¼Î·-adverb occurs 5 times in Soph.: here L has Î¼Î·Î´Î±Î¼á¾¶: in Ph. 789 (a like case) Î¼Î·Î´Î±Î¼á¿†Î¹. Above, 517, where Î¼Î·Î´Î±Î¼á½± is necessary, L has Î¼Î·Î´Î±Î¼á¾¶: in 1698 (a like case), Î¼Î·Î´Î±Î¼á¿†Î¹. The Î¿á½-adv. occurs 4 times in Soph., and L has always Î¿á½Î´Î±Î¼á¾¶Î¹, which is necessary only in Ant. 874, while Î¿á½Î´Î±Î¼á½± is necessary ib. 830: either could stand ib. 763, Tr. 323. Thus L's perispomenon form has displaced a necessary â€á½± in 3 places, while only one place of all 9 requires the long form.

Î¸Î±Î½á½¼Î½ can mean only, "having died,"â€”"after my death": but the reading, which has been suspected, seems sound. The sense is:â€”"were I to die now, I could not after my death be said to have been altogether unhappy, when my last hours had been thus cheered."

á¼Î¼Ï†á½»Î½Ï„Îµ, clinging close, like the Homeric á¼Î½ Î´â€™ á¼„ÏÎ± Î¿á¼± Ï†á¿¦ Ï‡ÎµÎ¹Ïá½· ï¼ˆIl. 6.253), á¼”Ï†Ï…Î½ á¼Î½ Ï‡ÎµÏÏƒá½¶Î½ á¼•ÎºÎ±ÏƒÏ„Î¿Ï‚ Od. 10.397, clasped my hands, each and all. For the paronomasia with Ï†á½»ÏƒÎ±Î½Ï„Î¹ cp. O. T. 878 Ï‡ÏÎ·Ïƒá½·Î¼á¿³ Ï‡Ïá¿†Ï„Î±Î¹ n.: for the masc. ending, see on 1676 á¼°Î´á½¹Î½Ï„Îµ.

With Îºá¼€Î½Î±Ï€Î±á½»ÏƒÎ±Ï„Î¿Î½ (note that L has Îºá¼€Î½Î±Ï€Î±á½»ÏƒÎµÏ„Î¿Î½) the words are usu. taken to mean, "and give me relief from this hapless wandering, desolate before," â€”i.e. since Antigone was carried off (844).

Ï€Î»á½±Î½Î¿Ï…, then, must mean, "wanderer's doom," for we cannot explain it merely of restless movements on the scene since his daughter's departure. But this seems forced. Wecklein explains it figuratively, of the insecurity felt by a blind man who has no guide ("Haltlosigkeit und Unsicherheit, wie sie der Blinde ohne FÃ¼hrer fÃ¼hlt"). But how could Ï€Î»á½±Î½Î¿Ï… alone denote this mental state? Neither Ï„á½¸Î½ Ï€Ïá½¹ÏƒÎ¸â€™ á¼”ÏÎ·Î¼Î¿Î½ tou=de dusth/nou pla/nou nor Ï„Î¿á¿¦ Ï€Ï. á¼Ïá½µÎ¼Î¿Ï… Ï„á½¹Î½Î´Îµ Î´á½»ÏƒÏ„Î·Î½Î¿Î½ pla/nou mends matters. Schneidewin (rightly, I think) referred Ï€Î»á½±Î½Î¿Ï… to the carrying away of the maidens by Creon's guards, rendering, "repose from your late forlorn and hapless wandering." But á¼€Î½Î±Ï€Î±á½»ÏƒÎ±Ï„Î¿Î½ could not thus stand for the midd.: when the act. seems to do so, there is an acc. to be mentally supplied, as Thuc. 4.11 á¼€Î½Î±Ï€Î±á½»Î¿Î½Ï„ÎµÏ‚ á¼Î½ Ï„á¿· Î¼á½³ÏÎµÎ¹, (not "resting," but) "relieving (their comrades) in turn": Xen. Hellen. 5.1.21 á¼Ï€ÎµÎ¹Î´á½´ Î´á½² á¼€Ï€Îµá¿–Ï‡Îµ Ï€á½³Î½Ï„Îµ á¼¢ á¼“Î¾ ÏƒÏ„á½±Î´Î¹Î± Ï„Î¿á¿¦ Î»Î¹Î¼á½³Î½Î¿Ï‚ á¼¡ÏƒÏ…Ï‡á½·Î±Î½ Îµá¼¶Ï‡Îµ ÎºÎ±á½¶ á¼€Î½á½³Ï€Î±Ï…Îµ (sc. Ï„á½°Ï‚ Î½Î±á¿¦Ï‚). I would read Îºá¼€Î½Î±Ï€Î½Îµá½»ÏƒÎ±Ï„Î¿Î½: for the gen. cp. Ai. 274 á¼”Î»Î·Î¾Îµ Îºá¼€Î½á½³Ï€Î½ÎµÏ…ÏƒÎµ Ï„á¿†Ï‚ Î½á½¹ÏƒÎ¿Ï…: Il. 11.382 á¼€Î½á½³Ï€Î½ÎµÏ…ÏƒÎ±Î½ ÎºÎ±Îºá½¹Ï„Î·Ï„Î¿Ï‚: 15. 235 á¼€Î½Î±Ï€Î½Îµá½»ÏƒÏ‰ÏƒÎ¹ Ï€á½¹Î½Î¿Î¹Î¿. At such a moment it is surely natural that the father should have a word of sympathy for the late terror and distress of his helpless daughters, instead of dwelling solely on the pain to himself of being left without their support. The Îµ in L is a trace of the truth.

Line 1116

Ï„Î±á¿–Ï‚ Ï„Î·Î»Î¹ÎºÎ±á¿–ÏƒÎ´Îµ: i.e. it is not fitting for young maidens to make long speeches in such a presence. The epithet need not be pressed as implying extreme youthfulness (cp. 751). Î¿á½— Îºá¼„ÏƒÏ„Î¹ Ï„Î¿á½”ÏÎ³Î¿Î½Â· Ï„Î¿á½Î¼á½¸Î½ á½§Î´â€™ á¼”ÏƒÏ„Î±Î¹ Î²ÏÎ±Ï‡á½». ğŸ—©
Line 1118

Hermann's change of the MS. Ï„Î¿á½Î¼á½¸Î½ into Ï„Î¿á¿¦Ï„â€™ á¼Î¼Î¿á½· Ï„) has been accepted by many edd. But the sense is most unsatisfactory. If Ï„Î¿á½”ÏÎ³Î¿Î½ means the deed of rescue, as is most natural, the meaning will be: "this deed will be a short story both for thee and for me": i.e. "I shall not have to relate it, and you will be so much interested in listening to Theseus that you will not find it tedious." But is this tolerable,â€”to say nothing of the somewhat ungracious suggestion that the account of their deliverer's exploit would otherwise be fatiguing? The alternative version would be worse still: "this task (viz. that of reciting, or of hearing) will be short both for thee and me." I cannot but think, then, that this popular correction, though palaeographically easy, is untenable.

I have little doubt that Wex is right, or nearly so, in his Î¿á½— Îºá¼„ÏƒÏ„Î¹ Ï„Î¿á½”ÏÎ³Î¿Î½. The Î»á½¹Î³Î¿Ï‚ should be his to whom belongs the á¼”ÏÎ³Î¿Î½. This supposes an accidental loss of Î¿á½—, after which Îºá¼„ÏƒÏ„Î¹ grew into ÎºÎ±á½¶ ÏƒÎ¿á½· Ï„Îµ. The words Ï„Î¿á½Î¼á½¸Î½ á½¦Î´â€™ á¼”ÏƒÏ„Î±Î¹ Î²ÏÎ±Ï‡á½º then mean, "my part will thus be brief" (as you desire it to be, 1115) â€” consisting simply in referring Oed. to Theseus.

ÎŸá¼°. á½¦ Î¾Îµá¿–Î½Îµ, Î¼á½´ Î¸Î±á½»Î¼Î±Î¶Îµ, Ï€Ïá½¸Ï‚ Ï„á½¸ Î»Î¹Ï€Î±Ïá½²Ï‚ ğŸ—©
Line 1119

Take Ï€Ïá½¸Ï‚ Ï„á½¸ Î»Î¹Ï€Î±Ïá½²Ï‚ with Î¼Î·Îºá½»Î½á¿³ Î»á½¹Î³Î¿Î½: "do not wonder if with eager insistence I prolong my words to my children, now that they have appeared unexpectedly":

Ï€Ïá½¸Ï‚ Ï„á½¸ Î».=Î»Î¹Ï€Î±Ïá¿¶Ï‚, as Ï€Ïá½¸Ï‚ Î²á½·Î±Î½=Î²Î¹Î±á½·Ï‰Ï‚, Ï€Ïá½¸Ï‚ á¼¡Î´Î¿Î½á½µÎ½ =á¼¡Î´á½³Ï‰Ï‚: Ai. 38 Ï€Ïá½¸Ï‚ ÎºÎ±Î¹Ïá½¹Î½=ÎºÎ±Î¹Ïá½·Ï‰Ï‚: El. 464 Ï€Ïá½¸Ï‚ Îµá½Ïƒá½³Î²ÎµÎ¹Î±Î½ (Î»á½³Î³ÎµÎ¹)=Îµá½ÏƒÎµÎ²á¿¶Ï‚. Line 1156

á¼¡Î¼á¿–Î½, ethic dat. (81).

á¼”Î¼Ï€Î¿Î»Î¹Î½: cp. 637. As Theseus was returning from the rescue, word had been brought him that a stranger had seated himself as a suppliant on the steps of the altar of Poseidon at Colonus (see on 55). This man said merely that he was a kinsman of Oedipus; and that he wished to speak a few words to him (1162). The fact that he was not from Thebes, but from Argos (1167), seems to have been inferred from something in his dress, for Theseus says that he does not know whence the man had come (cp. 1161). Polyneices took this precaution of becoming a á¼±Îºá½³Ï„Î·Ï‚ because he did not know what power might now be at the command of the paternal anger which he foresaw (cp. 1165).

Ï€ÏÎ¿ÏƒÏ€ÎµÏƒá½¹Î½Ï„Î± Ï€Ï‰Ï‚: lit., "having somehow rushed to" the altar: i.e. he had come in the absence of those Coloniates who had hurried from the sacrifice to the rescue (899), and no one had witnessed his arrival. (Cp. 156 Ï€ÏÎ¿Ï€á½³Ïƒá¿ƒÏ‚, 915 á¼Ï€ÎµÎ¹ÏƒÏ€ÎµÏƒÏ‰Î½.)

Ï€Ï‰Ï‚ could not mean, "for an unknown reason."

á¼„Î»Î³Î¹ÏƒÏ„Î± á¼€Î½Î´Ïá¿¶Î½,=á¼„Î»Î³Î¹Î¿Î½ á¼¢ Ï€Î±Î½Ï„á½¸Ï‚ á¼„Î»Î»Î¿Ï… á¼€Î½Î´Ïá½¸Ï‚ (Î»á½¹Î³Ï‰Î½), more reluctantly than the words of any one else. Line 1176

The emphasis is on ÎºÎ»á½»ÎµÎ¹Î½, not on Ï„Î¿á¿¦Î´): "why is it painful to thee to give this man a hearing?" Theseus has no need to ask, "why is it painful to thee to hear this man?"â€”for he knows already how Oed. has been treated by his sons (599). The sense is thus the same as if we kept the MS. Ï„Î¿á¿¦Ï„â€™: "why is this thing painful to thee,â€”namely, to hear?" (Cp. Ph. 1121 ÎºÎ±á½¶ Î³á½°Ï á¼Î¼Î¿á½¶ Ï„Î¿á¿¦Ï„Î¿ Î¼á½³Î»ÎµÎ¹, Î¼á½´ Ï†Î¹Î»á½¹Ï„Î·Ï„â€™ á¼€Ï€á½½Ïƒá¿ƒ: and O. T. 1058.) By Ï„Î¿á¿¦Î´Îµ it is adapted to the particular case. Cp. 1117 Ï„Î¿á¿¦Î´Îµ Ï‡Ïá½´ ÎºÎ»á½»ÎµÎ¹Î½.

Ï„á½¸Î½ á¼„Î½Î´ÏÎ± Ï„á½¹Î½Î´Îµ, Theseus (cp. 1100). "Allow him at once to gratify his own mind (his hinted desire that Polyneices should be heard, 1175), and to gratify Poseidon as he wishes to do," i.e. by granting the prayer made in Poseidon's name. The whole phrase Ï‡á½±ÏÎ¹Î½ Ï€Î±ÏÎ±ÏƒÏ‡Îµá¿–Î½ belongs to both clauses; á¼ƒ is acc. of respect. ÎºÎ±Îºá¿¶Ï‚ is Hermann's easy and certain correction of the MS. ÎºÎ±Î»á¿¶Ï‚. "Evilly devised deeds are disclosed by speech": i.e. even supposing that Polyneices is harbouring ill designs, the best way to discover them is to converse with him. Cp. Ant. 493 Ï†Î¹Î»Îµá¿– Î´â€™ á½ Î¸Ï…Î¼á½¸Ï‚ Ï€Ïá½¹ÏƒÎ¸ÎµÎ½ á¾‘Ïá¿†ÏƒÎ¸Î±Î¹ ÎºÎ»Î¿Ï€Îµá½»Ï‚, Ï„á¿¶Î½ Î¼Î·Î´á½²Î½ á½€ÏÎ¸á¿¶Ï‚ á¼Î½ ÏƒÎºá½¹Ï„á¿³ Ï„ÎµÏ‡Î½Ï‰Î¼á½³Î½Ï‰Î½,â€”where the bad consoience is supposed to bewray itself even before (Ï€Ïá½¹ÏƒÎ¸ÎµÎ½) investigation. With ÎºÎ±Î»á¿¶Ï‚, the words are merely "a rhetorical generality," as Campbell (who retains it) says: i.e. speech is a good thing, "for it is by speech that all man's best discoveries are revealed." But surely we need something more relevant to the matter in hand.

Î»á½¹Î³Ï‰Î½ Î´â€™ á¼€ÎºÎ¿á¿¦ÏƒÎ±Î¹ Ï„á½·Ï‚ Î²Î»á½±Î²Î·; Ï„á½± Ï„Î¿Î¹ ÎºÎ±Îºá¿¶Ï‚
Î·á½‘ÏÎ·Î¼á½³Î½â€™ á¼”ÏÎ³Î± Ï„á¿· Î»á½¹Î³á¿³ Î¼Î·Î½á½»ÎµÏ„Î±Î¹. ğŸ—©
Line 1189

Meineke rejects the three verses, 1189â€”1191, because (1) á¼”Ï†Ï…ÏƒÎ±Ï‚ Î±á½Ï„á½¹Î½ is too abrupt: (2) it is too much to tell Oed. that he must bear anything from his son: (3) the phrase Ï„á½° Ï„á¿¶Î½ ÎºÎ±Îºá½·ÏƒÏ„Ï‰Î½ etc. is indefensible. As to (1), few readers can fail to perceive that the "abruptness" is both forcible and pathetic at the moment when she turns from colder and more external arguments to the plea of natural affection. As to (2), it is enough to observe that Antigone means, "The relationship between parent and child is indelibly sacred. No wickedness on your son's part can alter the fact that he is your son." As to (3), see next n.

1190 á¼”Ï†Ï…ÏƒÎ±Ï‚ Î±á½Ï„á½¹Î½Â· á½¥ÏƒÏ„Îµ Î¼Î·Î´á½² Î´Ïá¿¶Î½Ï„á½± ÏƒÎµ ğŸ—©
Line 1190

Î´Ï…ÏƒÏƒÎµÎ²á½³ÏƒÏ„Î±Ï„), á½¦ (Dawes) seems right: it amends the MS. Ï„á½° Ï„á¿¶Î½ ÎºÎ±Îºá½·ÏƒÏ„Ï‰Î½ Î´Ï…ÏƒÏƒÎµÎ²ÎµÏƒÏ„á½±Ï„Ï‰Î½ by simply striking off the final Î½. "The most impious among the worst of deeds" is a vehement phrase suited to the passion of the appeal. Among evil deeds, Ï„á½° ÎºÎ±Îºá½±, those which outrage gods or kinsfolk form a class, Ï„á½° Î´Ï…ÏƒÏƒÎµÎ²á¿†. If ÎºÎ±Îºá½·ÏƒÏ„Ï‰Î½ were changed to Îºá½±ÎºÎ¹ÏƒÏ„Î±, the latter must be an adv., and Ï„á¿¶Î½ Î´Ï…ÏƒÏƒÎµÎ²ÎµÏƒÏ„á½±Ï„Ï‰Î½ must be masc.: "the deeds of men who in the worst way are most impious." Îºá¼€ÏƒÎµÎ²ÎµÏƒÏ„á½±Ï„Ï‰Î½ ("the deeds of the worst and most impious men") is less probable.

Ï„á½° Ï„á¿¶Î½ ÎºÎ±Îºá½·ÏƒÏ„Ï‰Î½ Î´Ï…ÏƒÏƒÎµÎ²á½³ÏƒÏ„Î±Ï„â€™, á½¦ Ï€á½±Ï„ÎµÏ, ğŸ—©
Line 1191

Î¸á½³Î¼Î¹Ï‚ Ïƒá½³ Î³â€™ Îµá¼¶Î½Î±Î¹. The MSS. here agree in the nominative. Vauvilliers suggested that á¼ÏƒÏ„á½· might be supplied, taking Ïƒá½³ Î³â€™ Îµá¼¶Î½Î±Î¹ in the sense of Ïƒá½³ Î³â€™ á½„Î½Ï„Î±, and comparing á¼‘Îºá½¼Î½ Îµá¼¶Î½Î±Î¹, etc. This may be rejected, as may also Reisig's Î´Ï…ÏƒÏƒÎµÎ²á½³ÏƒÏ„Î±Ï„â€™ á¼„Î½, with Îµá¼´Î· for Îµá¼¶Î½Î±Î¹: for then we should require Î¿á½Î´á½² in 1189. Is Î¸á½³Î¼Î¹Ï‚, then, indeclinable in this phrase? That is now the received view. It rests, however, solely on the fact that our MSS. have Î¸á½³Î¼Î¹Ï‚, and not Î¸á½³Î¼Î¹Î½, here, and in four other places, Plat. Gorg. 505D, Xen. Oec. 11 Â§ 11, Aelian Nat. An. 1. 60, Aesch. Suppl. 335. Porson believed that, with Dawes, we ought to read Î¸á½³Î¼Î¹Î½. That is my own opinion; but, as the question must be considered doubtful, I have preferred to leave Î¸á½³Î¼Î¹Ï‚ in the text, and to submit the evidence in the Appendix.

Î¸á½³Î¼Î¹Ï‚ Ïƒá½³ Î³â€™ Îµá¼¶Î½Î±Î¹ ÎºÎµá¿–Î½Î¿Î½ á¼€Î½Ï„Î¹Î´Ïá¾¶Î½ ÎºÎ±Îºá¿¶Ï‚. ğŸ—©

á¼€Î»Î»â€™ Î±á½Ï„á½¹Î½Â· Îµá¼°Ïƒá½¶, etc., is the traditional reading, on which á¼€Î»Î»â€™ Î±á½‘Ï„á½¹Î½ was a variant, adapted, seemingly, to the fatuous interpretation, "Nay, you will hurt yourself" (see cr. n.). Aesch. PV 172 Î¼ÎµÎ»Î¹Î³Î»á½½ÏƒÏƒÎ¿Î¹Ï‚ Ï€ÎµÎ¹Î¸Î¿á¿¦Ï‚ | á¼Ï€Î±Î¿Î¹Î´Î±á¿–ÏƒÎ¹Î½. The frequency of the metaphor is due to the regular use of á¼Ï€á¿³Î´Î±á½· in the medical practice of the age: thus Pindar describes Cheiron as using (1) incantations, (2) draughts, (3) amulets, (4) surgery (Pyth. 3. 51), and Plato's list of remedies is the same, with ÎºÎ±á½»ÏƒÎµÎ¹Ï‚ added (Rep. 426 B). In Od. 19.457 an á¼Ï€á¿³Î´á½µ stops hemorrhage, and in [Dem.] or. 25 Â§ 80 is applied to epilepsy. Sophocles Tr. 1001 has Ï„á½·Ï‚ Î³á½°Ï á¼€Î¿Î¹Î´á½¹Ï‚ (=á¼Ï€á¿³Î´á½¹Ï‚), Ï„á½·Ï‚ á½ Ï‡ÎµÎ¹ÏÎ¿Ï„á½³Ï‡Î½Î·Ï‚ á¼°Î±Ï„Î¿Ïá½·Î±Ï‚, á½ƒÏ‚ Ï„á½µÎ½Î´â€™ á¼„Ï„Î·Î½ ...ÎºÎ±Ï„Î±ÎºÎ·Î»á½µÏƒÎµÎ¹; Ai. 582 Î¸ÏÎ·Î½Îµá¿–Î½ á¼Ï€á¿³Î´á½°Ï‚ Ï€Ïá½¸Ï‚ Ï„Î¿Î¼á¿¶Î½Ï„Î¹ Ï€á½µÎ¼Î±Ï„Î¹. Cymbeline 1. 6. 115 'tis your graces That from my mutest conscience to my tongue Charms this report out.

Line 1202

Notice the dat. Ï€ÏÎ¿ÏƒÏ‡Ïá¿„Î¶Î¿Ï…ÏƒÎ¹Î½ (with ÎºÎ±Î»á½¹Î½), followed by the acc. Î±á½Ï„á½¹Î½ with Ï€á½±ÏƒÏ‡ÎµÎ¹Î½, and Ï€Î±Î¸á½¹Î½Ï„Î± with á¼Ï€á½·ÏƒÏ„Î±ÏƒÎ¸Î±Î¹. A literal version shows the reason:â€”"It is not fitting for the askers of just things to sue long, nor that a man should himself be well-treated, and then not know how to requite it." Importunity is here viewed as touching the dignity of the suppliants; ingratitude, in its moral aspect.â€”

If Î´) is omitted (with Wecklein) after ÎºÎ¿Î¼Ï€Îµá¿–Î½, we must either make ÎºÎ¿Î¼Ï€Îµá¿–Î½ Î¿á½Ï‡á½¶ Î²Î¿á½»Î»Î¿Î¼Î±Î¹ a parenthesis (as he does), or else point thus: ÎºÎ»á½»ÎµÎ¹Î½Â· á½¦ Ï€Ïá½³ÏƒÎ²Ï…, etc. The abruptness would add a certain spirit to the words. Ïƒá½º Î´á½² Ïƒá¿¶Ï‚ á¼´ÏƒÎ¸Î¹ could not mean, "know that you are safe": á½¤Î½ is indispensable: and the choice lies between (1) Ïƒá½º Î´â€™ á½¢Î½ Ïƒá¿¶Ï‚ á¼´ÏƒÎ¸â€™, and (2) Ïƒá½º Ïƒá¿¶Ï‚ á½¢Î½ á¼´ÏƒÎ¸â€™. á½…ÏƒÏ„Î¹Ï‚ Ï„Î¿á¿¦ Ï€Î»á½³Î¿Î½Î¿Ï‚ Î¼. Ï‡Ïá¿„Î¶ÎµÎ¹, whoever desires the ampler portion, Î¶á½½ÎµÎ¹Î½ (epexeg. inf.) that he should live (through it), Ï€Î±ÏÎµá½¶Ï‚, having neglected, i.e. not being content, Ï„Î¿á¿¦ Î¼ÎµÏ„Ïá½·Î¿Ï… (Ï‡Ïá¿„Î¶ÎµÎ¹Î½), to desire a moderate portion: i.e., "whoever desires the larger part (of the extreme period allotted to human life), and is not satisfied with moderate length of days."

Ï‡Ïá¿„Î¶. with gen., as Ai. 473 Ï„Î¿á¿¦ Î¼Î±ÎºÏÎ¿á¿¦ Ï‡Ïá¿„Î¶ÎµÎ¹Î½ Î²á½·Î¿Ï…, which also illustrates the art. with Ï€Î»á½³Î¿Î½Î¿Ï‚: cp. O. Î¶á½½ÎµÎ¹Î½ Ï„á½¸ Ï€Î»á½³Î¿Î½ Î¼á½³ÏÎ¿Ï‚, cp. 1755: Plat. Crito 52B Î¿á½Î´â€™ á¼Ï€Î¹Î¸Ï…Î¼á½·Î± ÏƒÎµ á¼„Î»Î»Î·Ï‚ Ï€á½¹Î»ÎµÏ‰Ï‚ Î¿á½Î´â€™ á¼„Î»Î»Ï‰Î½ Î½á½¹Î¼Ï‰Î½ á¼”Î»Î±Î²ÎµÎ½ Îµá¼°Î´á½³Î½Î±Î¹.

Ï€Î±ÏÎµá½·Ï‚, if sound, must be construed in one of two ways: (1) as above, which is best: or (2) in Hermann's way, Ï€Î±ÏÎµá½¶Ï‚ Ï„Î¿á¿¦ Î¼ÎµÏ„Ïá½·Î¿Ï… (Ï‡Ïá¿„Î¶Ï‰Î½) Î¶á½½ÎµÎ¹Î½, "negligens vivere modicam partem expetens," scorning to live with desire of a modest span only. Others make it govern

Î¼ÎµÏ„Ïá½·Î¿Ï…, "neglecting the moderate portion," and for the gen. Campbell quotes Plat. Phaedr. 235 E Ï€Î±Ïá½³Î½Ï„Î± Ï„Î¿á¿¦ ... á¼Î³ÎºÏ‰Î¼Î¹á½±Î¶ÎµÎ¹Î½. Liddell and Scott give the same citation along with this passage, which they render, "letting go one's hold of moderation," i.e. giving it up. But the active Ï€Î±ÏÎ¹á½³Î½Î±Î¹ never governs a gen. (in the nautical Ï€Î±ÏÎ¹á½³Î½Î±Î¹ Ï„Î¿á¿¦ Ï€Î¿Î´á½¹Ï‚, "to slack away the sheet," the gen. is partitive): and a reference to Plat. Phaedr. 235 E will show that Ï„Î¿á¿¦ has nothing to do with the inf., but is masc. The passage runs:â€” Ï„á½·Î½Î± Î¿á¼´ÎµÎ¹ Î»á½³Î³Î¿Î½Ï„Î± á½¡Ï‚ Ï‡Ïá½´ Î¼á½´ á¼Ïá¿¶Î½Ï„Î¹ Î¼á¾¶Î»Î»Î¿Î½ á¼¢ á¼Ïá¿¶Î½Ï„Î¹ Ï‡Î±Ïá½·Î¶ÎµÏƒÎ¸Î±Î¹, Ï€Î±Ïá½³Î½Ï„Î± Ï„Î¿á¿¦ Î¼á½²Î½ Ï„á½¸ Ï†Ïá½¹Î½Î¹Î¼Î¿Î½ á¼Î³ÎºÏ‰Î¼Î¹á½±Î¶ÎµÎ¹Î½, Ï„Î¿á¿¦ Î´á½² Ï„á½¸ á¼„Ï†ÏÎ¿Î½ Ïˆá½³Î³ÎµÎ¹Î½, á¼€Î½Î±Î³ÎºÎ±á¿–Î± Î³Î¿á¿¦Î½ á½„Î½Ï„Î±, Îµá¼´Ï„â€™ á¼„Î»Î»â€™ á¼„Ï„Ï„Î± á¼•Î¾ÎµÎ¹Î½ Î»á½³Î³ÎµÎ¹Î½; i.e., "if he omitted to praise the sense of the one (Ï„Î¿á¿¦ Î¼á½³Î½", the non-lover), and to blame the folly of the other (Ï„Î¿á¿¦ Î´á½³, the lover).

Hartung explains his Ï„á½°Î½ Î¼ÎµÏ„Ïá½·Î¿Ï… Ï€Î±ÏÎµá½¶Ï‚ | Î¶Ï‰á½±Î½ as "neglecting the life of moderate span" (sc. Î¼á½³ÏÎ¿Ï…Ï‚). Though the phrase Ï„á½¸ Î¼á½³Ï„ÏÎ¹Î¿Î½ Ï€Î±ÏÎµá½·Ï‚ ("in neglect of due limit") occurs in Plat. Legg. 691C (quoted by Wunder), it seems very doubtful whether Ï€Î±ÏÎµá½¶Ï‚ is sound here. The conjecture Ï€á½³ÏÎ± (Schneidewin) is possible, but derives no real support from the fact that Ï€Î±Ïá½° Ï„á½¸ ÎºÎ±á½·ÏÎ¹Î¿Î½ ÎºÎ±á½¶ Ï„á½¸ Î¼á½³Ï„ÏÎ¹Î¿Î½ occurs in the schol.'s loose paraphrase. Verrall ingeniously proposes Ï€Î±Ïá½²Îº, which, however, does not occur in Tragedy. Possibly Ï„Î¿á¿¦ Î¼ÎµÏ„Ïá½·Î¿Ï… Ï€ÏÎ¿Î¸Îµá½¶Ï‚, "in preference to the moderate portion."

ÏƒÎºÎ±Î¹Î¿Ïƒá½»Î½Î±Î½, perversity, folly: cp. Ant. 1028 Î±á½Î¸Î±Î´á½·Î± Ï„Î¿Î¹ ÏƒÎºÎ±Î¹á½¹Ï„Î·Ï„â€™ á½€Ï†Î»Î¹ÏƒÎºá½±Î½ÎµÎ¹.

Ï†Ï…Î»á½±ÏƒÏƒÏ‰Î½, cleaving to: Eur. Ion 735 á¼„Î¾á¿‘ á¼€Î¾á½·Ï‰Î½ Î³ÎµÎ½Î½Î·Ï„á½¹ÏÏ‰Î½ | á¼¤Î¸Î· Ï†Ï…Î»á½±ÏƒÏƒÎµÎ¹Ï‚. Cp. 626, 1180.

á¼Î½ á¼Î¼Î¿á½¶, me iudice, á¼Î½ denoting the tribunal, as O. T. 677 (n.) á¼Î½...Ï„Î¿á¿–ÏƒÎ´â€™ á¼´ÏƒÎ¿Ï‚, "just in their sight": Plat. Legg. 916B Î´Î¹Î±Î´Î¹ÎºÎ±Î¶á½³ÏƒÎ¸Ï‰ Î´á½² á¼”Î½ Ï„Î¹ÏƒÎ¹ Ï„á¿¶Î½ á¼°Î±Ï„Ïá¿¶Î½.

Î¶á½½ÎµÎ¹Î½, ÏƒÎºÎ±Î¹Î¿Ïƒá½»Î½Î±Î½ Ï†Ï…Î»á½±ÏƒÏƒÏ‰Î½

1215 á¼Ï€Îµá½¶ Ï€Î¿Î»Î»á½° Î¼á½²Î½ Î±á¼± Î¼Î±ÎºÏÎ±á½¶ á¼Î¼á½³ÏÎ±Î¹ ÎºÎ±Ï„á½³Î¸ÎµÎ½Ï„Î¿ Î´á½´
