Î ÎµÏá½·Î¸Î¿Ï…. Elsewhere in extant classical literature the form is Î ÎµÎ¹Ïá½·Î¸Î¿Î¿Ï‚ or (Attic) Î ÎµÎ¹Ïá½·Î¸Î¿Ï…Ï‚. But a form Î ÎµÏá½·Î¸Î¿Ï…Ï‚ is sufficiently attested by the name of the Attic deme of which this hero was eponymus. Harpocr. Î ÎµÏÎ¹Î¸Î¿á¿–Î´Î±Î¹Â· Î´á¿†Î¼á½¹Ï‚ á¼ÏƒÏ„Î¹ Ï„á¿†Ï‚ ÎŸá¼°Î½Î·á¿“Î´Î¿Ï‚. Aeschin. or. 1 Â§ 156 Î ÎµÏÎ¹ÎºÎ»Îµá½·Î´Î·Î½ Ï„á½¸Î½ Î ÎµÏÎ¹Î¸Î¿á½·Î´Î·Î½: and so [Dem.] or. 50 Â§ 41. Eustathius (101. 3) notices both forms, and Dindorf ascribes Î ÎµÏá½·Î¸Î¿Ï…Î½ to the Paris MSS. of Georgius Syncellus (the Byzantine chronographer, 800 A.D.), p. 299. 11: vases and inscriptions also give it. There is no need, then, to write Î ÎµÎ¹Ïá½·Î¸Î¿Ï… Î˜Î·Ïƒá½³Ï‰Ï‚ Ï„Îµ, as Blaydes does.

ÎºÎµá¿–Ï„Î±Î¹ â€¦ Î¾Ï…Î½Î¸á½µÎ¼Î±Ï„Î±: schol. Î¿á¼·Î¿Î½ á½‘Ï€Î¿Î¼Î½á½µÎ¼Î±Ï„Î± Ï„á¿†Ï‚ Ï€á½·ÏƒÏ„ÎµÏ‰Ï‚ á¼§Ï‚ á¼”Î¸ÎµÎ½Ï„Î¿ Ï€Ïá½¸Ï‚ á¼€Î»Î»á½µÎ»Î¿Ï…Ï‚: i.e. he understood by ÎºÎµá¿–Ï„Î±Î¹ some visible memorial. This seems clearly right. The local belief probably pointed to characters or marks on the rock. See the schol. on Aristoph. Eq. 785 á¼”ÏƒÏ„Î¹ Î´á½² ÎºÎ±á½¶ á¼€Î³á½³Î»Î±ÏƒÏ„Î¿Ï‚ Ï€á½³Ï„ÏÎ± ÎºÎ±Î»Î¿Ï…Î¼á½³Î½Î· Ï€Î±Ïá½° Ï„Î¿á¿–Ï‚ á¼ˆÎ¸Î·Î½Î±á½·Î¿Î¹Ï‚, á½…Ï€Î¿Ï… ÎºÎ±Î¸á½·ÏƒÎ±Î¹ Ï†Î±Ïƒá½¶ Î˜Î·Ïƒá½³Î± Î¼á½³Î»Î»Î¿Î½Ï„Î± ÎºÎ±Ï„Î±Î²Î±á½·Î½ÎµÎ¹Î½ Îµá¼°Ï‚ á¾Î´Î¿Ï…. Leake (Demi I. 635) conjectured that this Ï€á½³Ï„ÏÎ± may have marked the place (Ï‡Ï‰Ïá½·Î¿Î½) mentioned by Paus. 1.18.4 as near the temple of Sarapis, S.E. of the acropolis, á¼”Î½Î¸Î± Î ÎµÎ¹Ïá½·Î¸Î¿Ï…Î½ ÎºÎ±á½¶ Î˜Î·Ïƒá½³Î± ÏƒÏ…Î½Î¸ÎµÎ¼á½³Î½Î¿Ï…Ï‚ á¼Ï‚ Î›Î±ÎºÎµÎ´Î±á½·Î¼Î¿Î½Î± ÎºÎ±á½¶ á½•ÏƒÏ„ÎµÏÎ¿Î½ á¼Ï‚ Î˜ÎµÏƒÏ€ÏÏ‰Ï„Î¿á½ºÏ‚ ÏƒÏ„Î±Î»á¿†Î½Î±Î¹ Î»á½³Î³Î¿Ï…ÏƒÎ¹Î½. But the expeditions named there are distinct from the descent to Hades with which the schol. connects the Ï€á½³Ï„ÏÎ±. And, wherever this á¼€Î³á½³Î»Î±ÏƒÏ„Î¿Ï‚ Ï€á½³Ï„ÏÎ± was, there must have been a cavern suggestive of the descent to Hades. The schol.'s phrase, Ï€Î±Ïá½° Ï„Î¿á¿–Ï‚ á¼ˆÎ¸Î·Î½Î±á½·Î¿Î¹Ï‚, would cover Colonus.

Others understand: "where the compact has been made" (ÎºÎµá¿–Ï„Î±Î¹=pf. pass. of Ï„á½·Î¸Î·Î¼Î¹),â€”a lively way of saying, "was made," á¼Ï„á½³Î¸Î·: but this is improbable.â€” Wecklein conjectures Î ÎµÏá½·Î¸á¿³ ÎºÎ±Î»Îµá¿–Ï„Î±Î¹: "where men say that the compact of Th. with P. was made": the dat. as Tr. 668 Ï„á¿¶Î½ Ïƒá¿¶Î½ á¼©ÏÎ±ÎºÎ»Îµá¿– Î´Ï‰ÏÎ·Î¼á½±Ï„Ï‰Î½: the verb as Simonides fr. 107 á¼”Î½Î¸Î± ÎºÎ±Î»Îµá¿–Ï„Î±Î¹...á¼ˆÏÏ„á½³Î¼Î¹Î´Î¿Ï‚...Ï„á½³Î¼ÎµÎ½Î¿Ï‚. (Cp. on O. T. 1451.) This idiom, however, elsewhere always refers to places, not to acts.

Line 1595

(1) With L's á¼Ï†) Î¿á½—: "At which (the ÎºÏÎ±Ï„á½µÏ") he halted, midway between the other objects. Cp. Il. 22.153 á¼”Î½Î¸Î± Î´â€™ á¼Ï€â€™ Î±á½Ï„á½±Ï‰Î½ Ï€Î»Ï…Î½Î¿á½¶ Îµá½Ïá½³ÎµÏ‚ á¼Î³Î³á½ºÏ‚ á¼”Î±ÏƒÎ¹Î½, at the springs. With á¼Ï†), L's Î¼á½³ÏƒÎ¿Ï… is possible; "at which, midway as it is." (2) With Brunck's á¼€Ï†) Î¿á½—, it becomes necessary to read Î¼á½³ÏƒÎ¿Ï‚. The ÎºÏÎ±Ï„á½µÏ is then one of four points from which the point denoted by Î¼á½³ÏƒÎ¿Ï‚ is measured. Î¼á½³ÏƒÎ¿Ï‚ usu. takes a simple gen. of the extremes, and is not elsewhere found with á¼€Ï€á½¹, but the latter is natural (Plat. Parm. 145 B Ï„á½¹ Î³Îµ Î¼á½³ÏƒÎ¿Î½ á¼´ÏƒÎ¿Î½ Ï„á¿¶Î½ á¼ÏƒÏ‡á½±Ï„Ï‰Î½ á¼€Ï€á½³Ï‡ÎµÎ¹).

Ï„Î¿á¿¦ Ï„Îµ Î˜Î¿ÏÎ¹Îºá½·Î¿Ï… Ï€á½³Ï„ÏÎ¿Ï…. It was from Thoricus (Apollod. 2. 4. 7) that "radiant Eos caught up Cephalus to the gods" (Eur. Hipp. 455). Hence the name of that place may have been associated in the Athenian mind with the idea of removal to another world. Î˜Î¿ÏÎ¹Îºá½¹Ï‚ (so Her., Xen., etc.: Î˜á½¹ÏÎ¹ÎºÎ¿Ï‚ schol.) was a town and deme of Attica, belonging to the tribe á¼ˆÎºÎ±Î¼Î±Î½Ï„á½·Ï‚, on the S.E. coast, about 6 miles N. of Sunium, and 42 S.E. of Colonus. It was reckoned among the twelve towns of the old Attic dodecapolis, and, to judge by the ruins, was a considerable place down to late times (Leake, Demi II. 17â€”22). If Î˜Î¿ÏÎ¹Îºá½·Î¿Ï… is unsound, the familiarity of Î˜Î¿Ïá½·ÎºÎ¹Î¿Î¹ as a deme-name may have suggested it. Schneidewin's Ï„ÏÎ¹ÎºÎ¿Ïá½»Ï†Î¿Ï… rests on the schol. to 57: ÎºÎ±á½· Ï„Î¹Ï‚ Ï„á¿¶Î½ Ï‡ÏÎ·ÏƒÎ¼Î¿Ï€Î¿Î¹á¿¶Î½ Ï†Î·Ïƒá½·Â· Î’Î¿Î¹Ï‰Ï„Î¿á½¶ Î´â€™ á¼µÏ€Ï€Î¿Î¹Î¿ Ï€Î¿Ï„Î¹ÏƒÏ„Îµá½·Ï‡Î¿Ï…ÏƒÎ¹ ÎšÎ¿Î»Ï‰Î½á½¹Î½, á¼”Î½Î¸Î± Î»á½·Î¸Î¿Ï‚ Ï„ÏÎ¹Îºá½±ÏÎ±Î½Î¿Ï‚ á¼”Ï‡ÎµÎ¹ ÎºÎ±á½¶ Ï‡á½±Î»ÎºÎµÎ¿Ï‚ Î¿á½Î´á½¹Ï‚. Line 1596

ÎºÎ¿á½·Î»Î·Ï‚ Ï„â€™ á¼€Ï‡á½³ÏÎ´Î¿Ï…: schol. Ï„á¿†Ï‚ Ï„á½¸Î½ Ï€Ï…Î¸Î¼á½³Î½Î± á¼Ï‡Î¿á½»ÏƒÎ·Ï‚ á½‘Ï€á½¹ÎºÎµÎ½Î¿Î½, ÏƒÎ±Ï€á½³Î½Ï„Î±. The wild pear gave its name to the Attic deme á¼ˆÏ‡ÎµÏÎ´Î¿á¿¦Ï‚ (á¼ˆÏ‡ÎµÏÎ´Î¿á½»ÏƒÎ¹Î¿Î¹); as in its other form, á¼€Ï‡Ïá½±Ï‚, to á¼ˆÏ‡ÏÎ±Î´á½·Î½Î·, the E. quarter of Syracuse. If, as the schol. states (n. 1593), the local myth placed the rape of Persephone here, this old tree may have been pointed out as the spot whence she was snatched. An á¼ÏÎ¹Î½Îµá½¹Ï‚ (wild figtree) by the Cephisus was connected with a like legend (Paus. 1.38.5). A wild olive-tree (Îºá½¹Ï„Î¹Î½Î¿Ï‚) at Troezen was associated with the disaster of Hippolytus (2. 32. 10), as the ÏƒÏ„ÏÎµÏ€Ï„á½´ á¼Î»Î±á½·Î± at Epidaurus (see on 694) with Heracles.

Îºá¼€Ï€á½¸ Î»Î±á¿“Î½Î¿Ï… Ï„á½±Ï†Î¿Ï…. Dobree's ÎºÎ±á½Ï„Î¿Î»Î±á¿“Î½Î¿Ï… ("of natural rock," cp. on 192) is more ingenious than probable. Cp. Eur. Helen 962 Ï„á½¹Î½Î´Îµ Î»á½±ÏŠÎ½Î¿Î½ Ï„á½±Ï†Î¿Î½: El. 328 Î¼Î½á¿†Î¼Î± Î»á½±ÏŠÎ½Î¿Î½ Ï€Î±Ï„Ïá½¹Ï‚. The Î»á½±ÏŠÎ½Î¿Ï‚ Ï„á½±Ï†Î¿Ï‚ is opposed to a Ï„á½»Î¼Î²Î¿Ï‚ of earth or a Î»á½±ÏÎ½Î±Î¾ of wood (Thuc. 2.34): it would commonly denote an oblong monument with a flat slab (Ï„Ïá½±Ï€ÎµÎ¶Î±) on top, the sides being sometimes sculptured.

The power and beauty of this passage are in no way lessened for us because we know nothing of the basin or the stone, the tree or the tomb. Rather it might be said that the very fact of our ignorance illustrates the spirit in which these details are introduced. Their significance is essentially local: Ï„Î±á¿¦Ï„Î± Î³Î½á½½ÏÎ¹Î¼Î± Ï„Î¿á¿–Ï‚ á¼Î³Ï‡Ï‰Ïá½·Î¿Î¹Ï‚ (schol.). They show us how the blind man, who had never been at Colonus before, placed himself at precisely the due point in the midst of its complex sanctities. The god made him as one who had the most intimate and minute knowledge of the ground.

Ï€Î±Î½Ï„á½¸Ï‚ â€¦ Î´Ïá¿¶Î½Ï„Î¿Ï‚. (1) Usu. explained:â€”"when he had content of all service," i.e. when his daughters had done for him all that he wished. Î»á½»Î³Î´Î·Î½ á¼”ÎºÎ»Î±Î¹Î¿Î½ Ï€á½±Î½Ï„ÎµÏ‚. á½¡Ï‚ Î´á½² Ï€Ïá½¸Ï‚ Ï„á½³Î»Î¿Ï‚

Line 1623

ÏƒÎ¹Ï‰Ï€á½µ, a moment of absolute stillness, after the wails had subsided. Job iv. 15 "Then a spirit passed before my face; the hair of my flesh stood up. It stood still, but I could not discern the appearance thereof; a form was before mine eyes: there was silence, and I heard a voice."

Ï„Î¹Î½á½¸Ï‚: Eur. Andr. 1147 Ï€Ïá½¶Î½ Î´á½µ Ï„Î¹Ï‚ á¼€Î´á½»Ï„Ï‰Î½ á¼Îº Î¼á½³ÏƒÏ‰Î½ á¼Ï†Î¸á½³Î³Î¾Î±Ï„Î¿ Î´ÎµÎ¹Î½á½¹Î½ Ï„Î¹ ÎºÎ±á½¶ Ï†ÏÎ¹Îºá¿¶Î´ÎµÏ‚.

Ï€á½±Î½Ï„Î±Ï‚, subject to ÏƒÏ„á¿†ÏƒÎ±Î¹. For this phrase, instead of Ï€á¾¶ÏƒÎ¹ ÏƒÏ„á¿†Î½Î±Î¹ Ï„Ïá½·Ï‡Î±Ï‚, see on 150 Ï†Ï…Ï„á½±Î»Î¼Î¹Î¿Ï‚. Cp. 1464.

1625 ÏƒÏ„á¿†ÏƒÎ±Î¹ Ï†á½¹Î²á¿³ Î´Îµá½·ÏƒÎ±Î½Ï„Î±Ï‚ á¼Î¾Î±á½·Ï†Î½Î·Ï‚ Ï„Ïá½·Ï‡Î±Ï‚,
ÎºÎ±Î»Îµá¿– Î³á½°Ï Î±á½Ï„á½¸Î½ Ï€Î¿Î»Î»á½° Ï€Î¿Î»Î»Î±Ï‡á¿‡ Î¸Îµá½¹Ï‚Â· ğŸ—©
Line 1626

Ï€Î¿Î»Î»á½° Ï€Î¿Î»Î»Î±Ï‡á¿‡, "with repeated and manifold calling." There seems to be no genuine instance of Ï€Î¿Î»Î»Î±Ï‡á¿‡ meaning simply Ï€Î¿Î»Î»á½±ÎºÎ¹Ï‚. It is always "by many routes" (as Xen. Anab. 7.3.12), "in many ways" (Her. 6.21), or "on many grounds" (id. 1. 42). The phrase here, then, cannot mean "loudly (Ï€Î¿Î»Î»á½±) and often": nor can it be merely, "again and again." But Ï€Î¿Î»Î»Î±Ï‡á¿‡ need not refer to different forms of words. It is enough to understand it of varying tones in which the name was sounded, or of the voice seeming to come from different points at successive moments.

It is strange that a modern critic should have thought this "alienissimum a divina maiestate" (Schaefer). He must have forgotten that a divine summons had already been thrice repeated when "the LORD came, and stood, and called as at other times, Samuel, Samuel."

á½¦ Î¿á½—Ï„Î¿Ï‚ Î¿á½—Ï„Î¿Ï‚, ÎŸá¼°Î´á½·Ï€Î¿Ï…Ï‚, Ï„á½· Î¼á½³Î»Î»Î¿Î¼ÎµÎ½ ğŸ—©
Line 1627

á½¦ Î¿á½—Ï„Î¿Ï‚. So the goddess Athena, calling Ajax to come forth from his tent; Ai. 71 Î¿á½—Ï„Î¿Ï‚, Ïƒá½² Ï„á½¸Î½ Ï„á½°Ï‚ etc.: 89 á½¦ Î¿á½—Ï„Î¿Ï‚, Î‘á¼´Î±Ï‚, Î´Îµá½»Ï„ÎµÏá½¹Î½ ÏƒÎµ Ï€ÏÎ¿ÏƒÎºÎ±Î»á¿¶, where Î‘á¼´Î±Ï‚ is voc. (ib. 482), as ÎŸá¼°Î´á½·Ï€Î¿Ï…Ï‚ here (cp. 461).

Î¿á½—Ï„Î¿Ï‚ ("Ho there!"), thus used, implies that the person addressed is not duly heeding the speaker; here it helps to express impatience. So, when Medea turns her face away from Jason's smooth words, he cries to her, Î±á½•Ï„Î·, Ï„á½· Ï‡Î»Ï‰ÏÎ¿á¿–Ï‚ Î´Î±ÎºÏá½»Î¿Î¹Ï‚ Ï„á½³Î³Î³ÎµÎ¹Ï‚ Îºá½¹ÏÎ±Ï‚; etc. (Med. 922). There is nothing of roughness in the phrase, except in the particular combination Î¿á½—Ï„Î¿Ï‚ Ïƒá½» (O. T. 532, 1121: Eur. Hec. 1280).

Î¿á¼±, ethic dat., "for him," as a grace to him: cp. 81. Îºá¼€Ï€Îµá½¶ Ï€ÏÎ¿Ïƒá¿†Î»Î¸ÎµÎ½, Îµá¼¶Ï€ÎµÎ½Â· á½¦ Ï†á½·Î»Î¿Î½ Îºá½±ÏÎ±,

Line 1632

á½ÏÎºá½·Î±Î½, the conjecture of P. N. Papageorgius, is the best emendation of the certainly corrupt á¼€ÏÏ‡Î±á½·Î±Î½. It gives exactly what we need, viz. such an epithet for Ï€á½·ÏƒÏ„Î¹Î½ as marks the special solemnity of the pledge. Cp. Plat. Legg. 843A Ï†Î¹Î»á½·Î±Î½ Ï„Îµ ÎºÎ±á½¶ á¼”Ï‡Î¸ÏÎ±Î½ á¼”Î½Î¿ÏÎºÎ¿Î½. The occurrence of á½…ÏÎºÎ¹Î¿Ï‚ in 1637 cannot be made an objection (cp. 544 n.); on the contrary, it rather confirms á½ÏÎºá½·Î±Î½ here. Theseus did just what Oedipus asked.

á¼€ÏÏ‡Î±á½·Î±Î½ has been explained as follows: â€”(1) "Thy right hand, that time-honoured pledge." I agree with Campbell and Bellermann that this is the best version: indeed, I should be disposed to say, the only sound one. But in such a context we surely want something more than so general an epithet. (2) Thy pledge, "which some day will be old," i.e. which you are sure to observe permanently. Herm. supports this extraordinary "prolepsis" by Aesch. Ag. 579, where, however, á¼€ÏÏ‡Î±á¿–Î¿Î½ Î³á½±Î½Î¿Ï‚ is rather, "the traditional ornament" of temples (spoils): unless we should read (Î´á½¹Î¼Î¿Î¹Ï‚) á¼€ÏÏ‡Î±á½·Î¿Î¹Ï‚. (3) "A pledge of such good faith as you have always observed" (fides perpetuo apud te usu sacrata, Ellendt). (4) A modification of the last view refers á¼€ÏÏ‡Î±á½·Î±Î½ to v. 631, as="the pledge given at the beginning (of our intercourse)." It is impossible to accept any one of these interpretations.

(1) Two other conjectures claim notice. á¼€ÏÎ¸Î¼á½·Î±Î½ (Wecklein)="in a friendly compact." Cp. Od. 16.427 Î¿á¼± Î´â€™ á¼¡Î¼á¿–Î½ á¼„ÏÎ¸Î¼Î¹Î¿Î¹ á¼¦ÏƒÎ±Î½, "they were in amity with us." In Ph. 1132 Erfurdt has restored á¼„ÏÎ¸Î¼Î¹Î¿Î½ (as ="trusty comrade") for á¼„Î¸Î»Î¹Î¿Î½. But this epithet does not strengthen Ï€á½·ÏƒÏ„Î¹Î½. (2) á¼€ÏÎºá½·Î±Î½ (L. Schmidt)="sure." The only support for this is the epic phrase Î¼Î¹ÏƒÎ¸á½¸Ï‚ á¼„ÏÎºÎ¹Î¿Ï‚ (Il. 10.304, Od. 18.358, Hes. Op. 368).

Ï†ÏÎµÎ½á½¶, in or with it. L's Ï†á½³ÏÎµÎ¹Î½ is conceivably genuine, but in that case Ï„á½¸ Î³ÎµÎ½Î½Î±á¿–Î¿Î½ can hardly be so. Bellermann combines them by rendering, "that which it is noble to bear." á¼Î¾Î±Ï€Îµá½·Î´Î¿Î¼ÎµÎ½. This compound occurs only here, but is not intrinsically more questionable than the Homeric á¼Î¾Î±Ï€Î¿Î²Î±á½·Î½Ï‰, á¼Î¾Î±Ï€Î¿Î´á½»Î½Ï‰, etc. While á¼Î¾Î¿Ïá¾¶Î½="to see at a distance" (used in pass. by Eur. Ï„á½¸Î½ á¼„Î½Î´ÏÎ± Ï„á½¸Î½ Î¼á½²Î½: "we saw Oedipus,â€”him, I say,â€” no longer present anywhere, but Theseus, etc." The Ï„á½¸Î½ Î¼á½²Î½ comes in, by an afterthought, to prepare the distinction: cp. á¼€Î½Ï„á½³Ï‡Î¿Î½Ï„Î±, holding over against, from the primary sense of á¼€Î½Ï„á½·: so with dat. (á½„Î¼Î¼Î±ÏƒÎ¹) Ph. 830. â€”Perhaps nothing else in Greek literature leaves on the mind an impression so nearly akin to that of the awful vision in Job (iv. 15, 16).

Î³á¿†Î½ Ï„Îµ â€¦ ÎºÎ±á½¶ â€¦ á½ŒÎ»Ï…Î¼Ï€Î¿Î½. Theseus bows down and kisses the earth, then suddenly rises, and with upturned face stretches forth his hands towards the sky. Ï€Î¿Î¼Ï€á½¹Ï‚: cp. 1548.

á¼¢ Ï„á½¸ Î½ÎµÏÏ„á½³ÏÏ‰Î½ Î³á¿†Ï‚ Î²á½±Î¸ÏÎ¿Î½, the nether world on which the upper world rests. Î³á¿†Ï‚ Î²á½±Î¸ÏÎ¿Î½, earth's firm floor, rocky base: cp. Milton, "Hymn on the Nativity," And cast the dark foundations deep. So Ai. 860 á¼‘ÏƒÏ„á½·Î±Ï‚ Î²á½±Î¸ÏÎ¿Î½ is the ground on which the home stands.

á¼€Î»á½»Ï€Î·Ï„Î¿Î½, the MS. reading, is incomparably better than the variant á¼€Î»á½±Î¼Ï€ÎµÏ„Î¿Î½, which I believe to have been merely one of those conjectures in which the old transcribers and commentators sometimes indulged. By á¼€Î»á½»Ï€Î·Ï„Î¿Î½ the poet meant, "without pain" (to Oed.); though it does not follow that he used the word with definite consciousness of an active sense. Cp. Legg. 958E Ï„á½° Ï„á¿¶Î½ Ï„ÎµÏ„ÎµÎ»ÎµÏ…Ï„Î·Îºá½¹Ï„Ï‰Î½ Ïƒá½½Î¼Î±Ï„Î± Î¼á½±Î»Î¹ÏƒÏ„Î± á¼€Î»Ï…Ï€á½µÏ„Ï‰Ï‚ Ï„Î¿á¿–Ï‚ Î¶á¿¶ÏƒÎ¹... ÎºÏá½»Ï€Ï„ÎµÎ¹Î½, to bury the dead with least annoyance to the living. The passive sense, "not pained,"â€”i.e., where all earthly pain is over,â€”seems less suitable. Pollux 3. 98 says, Î Î»á½±Ï„Ï‰Î½ Î´á½² ÎºÎ±á½¶ á¼€Î»á½»Ï€Î·Ï„Î¿Ï‚ á¼”Ï‡ÎµÎ¹, á½¥ÏƒÏ€ÎµÏ ÎºÎ±á½¶ Î£Î¿Ï†Î¿ÎºÎ»á¿†Ï‚ á¼€Î»á½»Ï€Î·Ï„Î¿Î½: where, since Plat. has the word only in the place just cited, á¼€Î»á½»Ï€Î·Ï„Î¿Ï‚ should perh. be á¼€Î»Ï…Ï€á½µÏ„Ï‰Ï‚. á¼€Î»á½±Î¼Ï€ÎµÏ„Î¿Î½ (instead of á¼€Î»Î±Î¼Ï€á½³Ï‚) is not attested for the classical age, though it occurs in later poetry (Anthol. P. 9. 540, etc.), as does also a subst. Î»Î±Î¼Ï€á½³Ï„Î·Ï‚.

Î¿á½ ÏƒÏ„ÎµÎ½Î±ÎºÏ„á½¸Ï‚, "not with wailing." Some assume a definitely active sense, "not wailing"; see last n., and add Î¼ÎµÎ¼Ï€Ï„á½¹Ï‚ "blaming" (Tr. 446). Others make it definitely passive, "not bewailed." The thought is that his end was "not accompanied by ÏƒÏ„ÎµÎ½Î±Î³Î¼Î¿á½·", and the poet probably meant to suggest both ideas. Cp. on ÏƒÏ‰Ï„á½µÏÎ¹Î¿Î½ 487.

Ïƒá½ºÎ½ Î½á½¹ÏƒÎ¿Î¹Ï‚: cp. O. T. 17 Ïƒá½ºÎ½ Î³á½µÏá¾³ Î²Î±ÏÎµá¿–Ï‚.

Line 1665

Îµá¼° Î´á½² Î¼á½´ Î´Î¿Îºá¿¶, "But if I seem not to speak with understanding" (i.e. if my narrative is thought incredible and foolish), "I would not crave belief from those to whom I seem not sane."â€”Î¿á½Îº á¼‚Î½ Ï€Î±ÏÎµá½·Î¼Î·Î½. Ant. 469 ÏƒÎ¿á½¶ Î´â€™ Îµá¼° Î´Î¿Îºá¿¶ Î½á¿¦Î½ Î¼á¿¶ÏÎ± Î´Ïá¿¶ÏƒÎ± Ï„Ï…Î³Ï‡á½±Î½ÎµÎ¹Î½, ÏƒÏ‡ÎµÎ´á½¹Î½ Ï„Î¹ Î¼á½½Ïá¿³ Î¼Ï‰Ïá½·Î±Î½ á½€Ï†Î»Î¹ÏƒÎºá½±Î½Ï‰. To the ancient Greek, who enjoyed discussion, there was something peculiarly impressive in declining it.

Ï‡Î¿á¼± Ï€ÏÎ¿Ï€á½³Î¼Ïˆ.: meaning Theseus (295 n.), though the plur. might also be explained of Theseus with his attendants (1646).

á¼€Ïƒá½µÎ¼Î¿Î½ÎµÏ‚=á¼„ÏƒÎ·Î¼Î¿Î¹, only here.

á¼ŒÎ³. Î±á¼µÎ´â€™ Î¿á½Ï‡ á¼‘Îºá½±Ï‚Â· Î³á½¹Ï‰Î½ Î³á½°Ï Î¿á½Îº á¼€Ïƒá½µÎ¼Î¿Î½ÎµÏ‚

á¼ˆÎ½. 1670 Î±á¼°Î±á¿–, Ï†Îµá¿¦, á¼”ÏƒÏ„Î¹Î½ á¼”ÏƒÏ„Î¹ Î½á¿·Î½ Î´á½´ ğŸ—©
Line 1670

Î±á¼°Î±á¿–, Ï†Îµá¿¦. To delete Ï†Îµá¿¦ here seems a less probable remedy than to supply Ï„Î¿Î¹ in 1697, where the neighbourhood of ÎºÎ±á½¶ may have caused its loss.

á¼”ÏƒÏ„Î¹Î½ á¼”ÏƒÏ„Î¹ Î½á¿·Î½ Î´á½µ. The passage is simple if it is only remembered that Î¿á½ Ï„á½¸ Î¼á½³Î½, á¼„Î»Î»Î¿ Î´á½² Î¼á½µ is an adverbial phrase, equivalent to Ï€Î±Î½Ï„ÎµÎ»á¿¶Ï‚. "It is indeed for us twain in no incomplete sense to bewail the accurst blood of our father which was born in us, hapless that we are." While he lived, they suffered with him. Now, his fate has snatched him from them in strange and terrible sort, leaving them destitute.

Î¿á½ Ï„á½¸ Î¼á½³Î½, á¼„Î»Î»Î¿ Î´á½² Î¼á½µ (Î¼á½µ, instead of Î¿á½, because it goes with the inf. ÏƒÏ„ÎµÎ½á½±Î¶ÎµÎ¹Î½), "not in one respect merely, with the exception of some other"; not merely partially. This phrase is frequent where the notion of completeness or universality is to be brought out with greater emphasis than would be given by the mere use of Ï€á¾¶Ï‚ or like words. Aesch. Pers. 802 ÏƒÏ…Î¼Î²Î±á½·Î½ÎµÎ¹ Î³á½°Ï Î¿á½ Ï„á½° Î¼á½²Î½ Ï„á½° Î´â€™ Î¿á½”, i.e. "for our disasters are complete." Her. 1.139 Î¿á½ Ï„á½° Î¼á½³Î½, Ï„á½° Î´â€™ Î¿á½”, á¼€Î»Î»á½° Ï€á½±Î½Ï„Î± á½Î¼Î¿á½·Ï‰Ï‚: so id. 2. 37: Phocylides fr. 1 Î›á½³ÏÎ¹Î¿Î¹ ÎºÎ±ÎºÎ¿á½·, Î¿á½Ï‡ á½ Î¼á½³Î½, á½ƒÏ‚ Î´â€™ Î¿á½”, | Ï€á½±Î½Ï„ÎµÏ‚: Eur. Phoen. 1641 Î¿á½ Î³á½°Ï Ï„á½¸ Î¼á½³Î½ ÏƒÎ¿Î¹ Î²Î±Ïá½º ÎºÎ±Îºá¿¶Î½, Ï„á½¸ Î´â€™ Î¿á½ Î²Î±Ïá½», á¼€Î»Î»â€™ Îµá¼°Ï‚ á¼…Ï€Î±Î½Ï„Î± Î´Ï…ÏƒÏ„Ï…Ï‡á½´Ï‚ á¼”Ï†Ï…Ï‚, Ï€á½±Ï„ÎµÏ: Plat. Rep. 475B, etc. The idiom strikingly illustrates three tendencies of Greek; (1) love of antithesis, (2) love of parataxis, (3) the tendency to treat whole clauses as virtually adverbs (cp. Î¿á½Îº á¼”ÏƒÎ¸â€™ á½…Ï€Ï‰Ï‚ Î¿á½, Î¿á¼¶Î´â€™ á½…Ï„Î¹, etc.).

Î¿á½ Ï„á½¸ Î¼á½³Î½, á¼„Î»Î»Î¿ Î´á½² Î¼á½µ, Ï€Î±Ï„Ïá½¸Ï‚ á¼”Î¼Ï†Ï…Ï„Î¿Î½ ğŸ—©
Line 1671

á¼”Î¼Ï†Ï…Ï„Î¿Î½, "planted in us at our birth": whereby they are sharers in the hereditary á¼€Ïá½± on the Labdacid race.

á¼„Î»Î±ÏƒÏ„Î¿Î½: cp. on 1482.

Î±á¼·Î¼Î±, as kinsfolk are of the same "blood": cp. Eur. Phoen. 246 ÎºÎ¿Î¹Î½á½¸Î½ Î±á¼·Î¼Î±, ÎºÎ¿Î¹Î½á½° Ï„á½³ÎºÎµÎ±: O. T. 1406 Î±á¼·Î¼â€™ á¼Î¼Ï†á½»Î»Î¹Î¿Î½, an incestuous kinship.

á¼„Î»Î±ÏƒÏ„Î¿Î½ Î±á¼·Î¼Î± Î´Ï…ÏƒÎ¼á½¹ÏÎ¿Î¹Î½ ÏƒÏ„ÎµÎ½á½±Î¶ÎµÎ¹Î½,

Line 1673

á¾§Ï„Î¹Î½Î¹, dat. of interest, for whom: cp. 508 Ï„Î¿á¿–Ï‚ Ï„ÎµÎºÎ¿á¿¦ÏƒÎ¹ Î³á½°Ï | Î¿á½Î´â€™ Îµá¼° Ï€Î¿Î½Îµá¿– Ï„Î¹Ï‚. As making the sense of Ï€á½¹Î½Î¿Î½ clearer, the dat. is preferable to the nom. dual, á½¥Ï„Î¹Î½Îµ (Badham).

Ï„á½¸Î½ Ï€Î¿Î»á½ºÎ½: for the art. cp. on 87.

á¼„Î»Î»Î¿Ï„Îµ Î¼á½²Î½ Ï€á½¹Î½Î¿Î½ á¼”Î¼Ï€ÎµÎ´Î¿Î½ Îµá¼´Ï‡Î¿Î¼ÎµÎ½,
1675 á¼Î½ Ï€Ï…Î¼á½±Ï„á¿³ Î´â€™ á¼€Î»á½¹Î³Î¹ÏƒÏ„Î± Ï€Î±ÏÎ¿á½·ÏƒÎ¿Î¼ÎµÎ½ ğŸ—©
Line 1675

á¼Î½ Ï€Ï…Î¼á½±Ï„á¿³, "at the last," i.e. "at his death," as opp. to á¼„Î»Î»Î¿Ï„Îµ Î¼á½³Î½, i.e. "during his life."

á¼€Î»á½¹Î³Î¹ÏƒÏ„Î±, things which baffle Î»Î¿Î³Î¹ÏƒÎ¼á½¹Ï‚, things which transcend human reason. As á¼°Î´á½¹Î½Ï„Îµ shows, the reference is to the mysterious manner of their father's death, while Ï€Î±Î¸Î¿á½»ÏƒÎ± marks their loss by that death.

Ï€Î±ÏÎ¿á½·ÏƒÎ¿Î¼ÎµÎ½ can only be explained with Hermann, as="we shall bring forward," "allege." "And we shall have to tell of things baffling reason, as seen and suffered by us at the end." This will seem less strained, I think, if we observe that Antigone need not be supposed to know of the Messenger's narrative. She may believe that she is bringing the Chorus the first intelligence of the event; and, if so, á¼€Î»á½¹Î³Î¹ÏƒÏ„Î± Ï€Î±ÏÎ¿á½·ÏƒÎ¿Î¼ÎµÎ½ would be no unsuitable preface. This view agrees with the next words of the Chorus, who ask Ï„á½· Î´â€™ á¼”ÏƒÏ„Î¹Î½; as if uncertain what she means; and Î²á½³Î²Î·ÎºÎµÎ½; as if they did not know that Oedipus was gone. They do not wish to check the flow of her sorrow, to which utterance will be a relief. Cp. Eur. I. A. 981 Î±á¼°ÏƒÏ‡á½»Î½Î¿Î¼Î±Î¹ Î´á½² Ï€Î±ÏÎ±Ï†á½³ÏÎ¿Ï…Ïƒâ€™ Î¿á¼°ÎºÏ„ÏÎ¿á½ºÏ‚ Î»á½¹Î³Î¿Ï…Ï‚, "advancing a plea to pity" (unless "bringing in" be preferable). Her. 9.26 ÎºÎ±á½¶ ÎºÎ±Î¹Î½á½° ÎºÎ±á½¶ Ï€Î±Î»Î±Î¹á½° Ï€Î±ÏÎ±Ï†á½³ÏÎ¿Î½Ï„ÎµÏ‚ á¼”ÏÎ³Î±, "citing" (as claims).â€”We cannot render Ï€Î±ÏÎ¿á½·ÏƒÎ¿Î¼ÎµÎ½ "we shall suffer beside" (over and above our former sufferings), since the reference is to the fact of their bereavement, not to its prospective consequences.â€”Though the phrase is certainly strange, yet the defence indicated above may at least avail in arrest of judgment. If Ï€Î±ÏÎ¿á½·ÏƒÎ¿Î¼ÎµÎ½ were to be altered, I should be disposed to suggest á¼Ï€ÎµÏá½±ÏƒÎ±Î¼ÎµÎ½ ("we have gone through," cp. Ï€ÎµÏá¾¶Î½ Îºá½·Î½Î´Ï…Î½Î¿Î½ etc.). The more obvious á¼„Ï€Î¿Ïâ€™ Î¿á¼´ÏƒÎ¿Î¼ÎµÎ½ and á¼€Ï€Î¿Ïá½µÏƒÎ¿Î¼ÎµÎ½ are barred by the context.

á¼°Î´á½¹Î½Ï„Îµ ÎºÎ±á½¶ Ï€Î±Î¸á½¹Î½Ï„Îµ. ğŸ—©
Line 1676

á¼°Î´á½¹Î½Ï„Îµ ÎºÎ±á½¶ Ï€Î±Î¸Î¿á½»ÏƒÎ±. The difficulty is to explain how, if Ï€Î±Î¸á½¹Î½Ï„Îµ originally stood here, it was changed in the MSS. to Ï€Î±Î¸Î¿á½»ÏƒÎ±, when á¼°Î´á½¹Î½Ï„Îµ (which metre requires) was more likely to cause an opposite change. I therefore leave Ï€Î±Î¸Î¿á½»ÏƒÎ± in the text. And it is important to notice that a similar combination of forms (both attested by metre) occurs in an Attic inscription of about the second cent. B.C., edited by Kaibel, Epigr. 1110: Î»ÎµÏ…ÎºÎ¿á¿–ÏƒÎ¹Î½ Ï†á½±ÏÎµÏƒÏƒÎ¹ ÎºÎ±Î»Ï…ÏˆÎ±Î¼á½³Î½Î± Ï‡Ïá½¹Î± ÎºÎ±Î»á½¸Î½ á¼€Î¸Î±Î½á½±Ï„Ï‰Î½ Î¼ÎµÏ„á½° Ï†á¿¦Î»Î¿Î½ á¼´Ï„Î¿Î½ Ï€ÏÎ¿Î»Î¹Ï€á½¹Î½Ï„â€™ á¼€Î½Î¸Ïá½½Ï€Î¿Ï…Ï‚ Î‘á¼°Î´á½¼Ï‚ Î•á½Î½Î¿Î¼á½·Î· Ï„Îµ.â€” Cp. Eur. Andr. 1214 á½¦ ÎºÎ±Îºá½° Ï€Î±Î¸á½¼Î½ á¼°Î´á½½Î½ Ï„Îµ.â€”See Appendix.

Î§Î¿. Ï„á½· Î´â€™ á¼”ÏƒÏ„Î¹Î½; ğŸ—©
Line 1677

The Chorus ask, "And what is it?" She replies, á¼”ÏƒÏ„Î¹Î½ Î¼á½²Î½ Îµá¼°Îºá½±ÏƒÎ±Î¹, "we may conjecture" (Ï„á½¸ Î´á½² ÏƒÎ±Ï†á½²Ï‚ Î¿á½Î´Îµá½¶Ï‚ Î¿á¼¶Î´Îµ). Cp. á½¡Ï‚ Î¼á½±Î»Î¹ÏƒÏ„â€™ á¼‚Î½ á¼Î½ Ï€á½¹Î¸á¿³ Î»á½±Î²Î¿Î¹Ï‚, as thou mightest most desire (that he should pass away). Line 1679

Ï„á½· Î³á½±Ï, á½…Ï„á¿³: "How else, when he," etc. For the causal use of the relat. see on 263.

Î¼á½µÏ„â€™ á¼ŒÏÎ·Ï‚ Î¼á½µÏ„Îµ Ï€á½¹Î½Ï„Î¿Ï‚. His death was sudden, yet not violent. Death in battle and death by drowning are taken as types of the death which is both sudden and violent. Schol.: á¾§Ï„Î¹Î½Î¹ Î¼á½µÏ„Îµ Ï€á½¹Î»ÎµÎ¼Î¿Ï‚ Î¼á½µÏ„Îµ Î½á½¹ÏƒÎ¿Ï‚ á¼Ï€á¿†Î»Î¸ÎµÎ½. This certainly looks as if he read something else than Ï€á½¹Î½Ï„Î¿Ï‚. Cp. Ant. 819 Î¿á½”Ï„Îµ Ï†Î¸Î¹Î½á½±ÏƒÎ¹Î½ Ï€Î»Î·Î³Îµá¿–ÏƒÎ± Î½á½¹ÏƒÎ¿Î¹Ï‚ Î¿á½”Ï„Îµ Î¾Î¹Ï†á½³Ï‰Î½ á¼Ï€á½·Ï‡ÎµÎ¹ÏÎ± Î»Î±Ï‡Î¿á¿¦Ïƒâ€™. Hence the conjecture Î½Î¿á¿¦ÏƒÎ¿Ï‚, a form which the Attic poets nowhere use. Wecklein's Ï€Ï…ÏÎµÏ„á½¸Ï‚ is too specific (as if one said, "neither the War-God, nor typhoid").

I think that I can suggest the true solution. The schol.'s Î½á½¹ÏƒÎ¿Ï‚ was a paraphrase of Ï€á½¹Î½Î¿Ï‚, a corruption of Ï€á½¹Î½Ï„Î¿Ï‚ which actually appears in the Vatican MS. here.

The words Ï€Î±Ï„Ïá½¶ Î¾Ï…Î½Î¸Î±Î½Îµá¿–Î½ Î³ÎµÏÎ±Î¹á¿· are not suspicious in themselves (though Nauck demurs to calling a dead man Î³ÎµÏÎ±á½·Î¿Ï‚); but they are in metrical excess of 1715 f. Î¿á½”Ï„Î¿Î¹ ÎºÎ±Ï„á½±Î¼ÎµÎ¼Ï€Ï„â€™ á¼”Î²Î·Ï„Î¿Î½, "ye have fared not blameably": ye cannot justly complain of the destiny which has removed your father, in old age, by a painless death (cp. 1678).

ÎºÎ±Ï„á½±Î¼ÎµÎ¼Ï€Ï„Î±, neut. pl. as adv.: cp. on 319.

Î²Î±á½·Î½ÎµÎ¹Î½ does not occur elsewhere in a strictly similar use, for we cannot compare the perf. Îµá½– Î²ÎµÎ²Î·Îºá½½Ï‚ ï¼ˆEl. 979) as="placed well," "prosperous." Indeed, the metaphor is so easy and natural as hardly to demand special warrant in the case of Î²Î±á½·Î½Ï‰: e.g. O. But the scholium in L is:â€”Î¿á½”Ï„Î¿Î¹ ÎºÎ±Ï„á½±Î¼ÎµÎ¼Ï€Ï„Î¿Ï‚ á¼”Î²Î·: Î¿á½Îº á¼Î½ Ï„Î¿á¿–Ï‚ Ï„Î¿Î¹Î¿á½»Ï„Î¿Î¹Ï‚ á¼”ÏƒÏ„Î±Î¹ [Elmsley á¼ÏƒÏ„á½²] á½¥ÏƒÏ„Îµ ÎºÎ±Ï„Î±Î¼á½³Î¼Ï†ÎµÏƒÎ¸Î±Î¹Â· á¼¤Ï„Î¿Î¹ á½¡Ï‚ á¼‚Î½ á¼Ï€Î¹ÎºÎ¿Ï…Ï†á½·Î¶Î¿Î½Ï„Î¿Ï‚ Î±á½Ï„Î±á¿–Ï‚ Ï„á½´Î½ ÏƒÏ…Î¼Ï†Î¿Ïá½°Î½ Ï„Î¿á¿¦ Î²Î±ÏƒÎ¹Î»á½³Ï‰Ï‚ (Theseus). á¼¢ Î¿á¼·Î¿Î½, Î¿á½Îº á¼Î½ Ï‡Îµá½·ÏÎ¿Î½Î¹ Î½á¿¦Î½ á½‘Î¼á¿–Î½ á¼”ÏƒÏ„Î±Î¹ Ï„á½° Ï€Ïá½±Î³Î¼Î±Ï„Î±. Does the lemma point to another reading? I do not think so. Papageorgius points out (Krit. und palaeogr. BeitrÃ¤ge z. d. alt. Line 1702

Î¿á½Î´á½³ Î³â€™ á¼”Î½ÎµÏÎ¸â€™ is Wecklein's correction of the corrupt Î¿á½Î´á½² Î³á½³ÏÏ‰Î½. In Linwood's Î¿á½Î´á½² Î³á½°Ï á½£Ï‚ (which Hartung and Blaydes adopt), Î³á½±Ï will refer to her addressing him as á½¦ Ï†á½·Î»Î¿Ï‚ (1700). We might also conjecture Î¿á½Î´â€™ á¼ÎºÎµá¿– á½¢Î½, "not even in that other world" (Ai. 1372 Îºá¼€ÎºÎµá¿– Îºá¼€Î½Î¸á½±Î´â€™ á½¤Î½): for the hiatus cp. 1720 á¼€Î»Î»â€™ á¼Ï€Îµá½¶ á½€Î»Î²á½·Ï‰Ï‚.

Î¿á½Î´á½² Î³á½³ÏÏ‰Î½ yields no intelligible sense. (1) "Even though thou wast old at the time of thy death." (2) "Even though thou art old in Hades,"â€”the dead being supposed to remain such as they were at the time of death. (3) "Even when they memory is old"â€”i.e. after the lapse of years. This last is untenable: while neither (1) nor (2),â€”which Campbell blends by rendering "Even old as thou wast (or art),"â€”seems appropriate. She could hardly say that they would still love him though he had been so long with them, and had died at a ripe age.

Line 1713

á½¤Î¼Î¿Î¹ is Wecklein's correction of á¼°á½¼ Î¼á½µ. That Î¼á½µ was an error for Î¼Î¿Î¹ had already been surmised by some old corrector (see cr. n.). Hermann defended Î¼á½µ by taking it with á¼”Ï‡Ïá¿ƒÎ¶ÎµÏ‚ as="would that thou hadst not wished"â€”an unheardof construction (cp. on 540). He took á¼”ÏÎ·Î¼Î¿Ï‚ á½§Î´á½³ â€¦ Î¼Î¿Î¹ as="lonely, just as thou wast, for me,"â€”i.e. in his wanderings before he had found Attic friends; since, if he had died while still alone with her, she could have given him burial herself.â€”With á½¤Î¼Î¿Î¹ render:â€”"Ah me, it was thy wish to die in a strange land (and so far thy death is well): but thus (by this manner of death) thou hast died forlorn in regard to me" (Î¼Î¿Î¹ ethic dat.). She means, "I have had no opportunity of rendering thee the due rites, and now I do not know the place of thy grave, so as to make the á¼Î½Î±Î³á½·ÏƒÎ¼Î±Ï„Î±" at it. Hence her passionate desire to find his grave (1724 ff.), which Theseus with difficulty allays by reminding her of his solemn promise (1760). The preparatory offices rendered at 1602 f. could not be viewed as taking the place of a daughter's tribute to the dead. Like 1410, this trait serves to recall the special manifestation of her piety in the earlier play.â€”Not merely:â€”"It was your wish; but it was sad for me to see you die forlorn,"â€”i.e. in exile. Though á¼Ï€á½¶ Î¾á½³Î½Î·Ï‚, he was not in this sense á¼”ÏÎ·Î¼Î¿Ï‚,â€”he who, in his own words, had "Athens and all her people" for his friends (772).â€”Cp. 1705 á¼†Ï‚ á¼”Ï‡Ïá¿ƒÎ¶Îµ...á¼”Î¸Î±Î½Îµ. The repetition of one phrase in no way justifies Dindorf's rash hypothesis of interpolation here (see cr. n.). Here, the wish is connected with a painful thought; there, with a soothing one. Mention of the wish itself might most naturally recur in a lament.

The MS. Ï€Î¿á¿– Î´á¿†Ï„)...á¼•Î¾Ï‰ has been defended in two ways, neither of which is satisfactory: (1) by an ellipse of Î¼Î¿Î»Î¿á¿¦ÏƒÎ±: (2) as="until when?" 1735 Î±á½–Î¸Î¹Ï‚ á½§Î´â€™ á¼”ÏÎ·Î¼Î¿Ï‚ á¼„Ï€Î¿ÏÎ¿Ï‚
Î±á¼°á¿¶Î½Î± Ï„Î»á½±Î¼Î¿Î½â€™ á¼•Î¾Ï‰;
Î§Î¿. Ï†á½·Î»Î±Î¹, Ï„Ïá½³ÏƒÎ·Ï„Îµ Î¼Î·Î´á½³Î½. ğŸ—©
Line 17371737 - 1750

In these verses the utterances usually assigned to Antigone all turn on her anxiety as to a refuge, and her desire to return to Thebes. Such feelings, at this moment, are more in harmony with the character of Ismene (cp. 1735). Antigone is at present absorbed in the yearning to visit her father's tomb, or at least the spot where she last saw him alive (1724). When Theseus appears, it is this wish which she instantly presses on him. Only when it has been put aside does she think of a return to Thebes (1769).

Ought we, then, to read Î™Î£. for Î‘Î. throughout vv. 1737â€”1750? This has been suggested by Bergk. I may observe that the Laur. MS. leaves the question open. At 1730 it has Î‘Î. before Ï„á½· Ï„á½¹Î´â€™ á¼Ï€á½³Ï€Î»Î·Î¾Î±Ï‚. After that, there is no indication of any person, but only short lines (-), until at 1741 Î‘Î. again stands before Ï†ÏÎ¿Î½á¿¶. The next words, Ï„á½· Î´á¿†Î¸â€™ etc., have Î§ÎŸ. before them: but after that no person is indicated till 1751, where Î§ÎŸ. (instead of Î˜Î—.) is erroneously placed before Ï€Î±á½»ÎµÏ„Îµ.

I am disposed to think that Sophocles wrote the words for Ismene, but that the fourth-actor difficulty had led to a fluctuation of stage-practice, which helps to account for the ambiguity of the MS. tradition. See the note on the Dramatis Personae. If the part of Ismene, after v. 509, was ever taken by a ÎºÏ‰Ï†á½¸Î½ Ï€Ïá½¹ÏƒÏ‰Ï€Î¿Î½, there may then have been a wish to keep her part in this scene as small as possible. Similarly at 1689 ff. there is a doubt as to which sister ought to have the words Î¿á½ Îºá½±Ï„Î¿Î¹Î´Î±...Î²Î¹Ï‰Ï„á½¹Ï‚.

á¼ˆÎ½. á¼€Î»Î»á½° Ï€Î¿á¿– Ï†á½»Î³Ï‰; ğŸ—©
Line 1738

Ï†á½»Î³Ï‰: cp. on 170.

Î§Î¿. ÎºÎ±á½¶ Ï€á½±ÏÎ¿Ï‚ á¼€Ï€á½³Ï†Ï…Î³Îµ ğŸ—©
Line 1739

The MS. á¼€Ï€ÎµÏ†Îµá½»Î³ÎµÏ„Î¿Î½ is most simply corrected to á¼€Ï€ÎµÏ†á½»Î³ÎµÏ„Î¿Î½. But then we must either (1) add Ï„á½· Î´á½µ, and expand v. 1726, as Bergk and Gleditsch do (cr. n. ad l.): or (2), leaving v. 1726 intact, suppose that vv. 1739, 1740 are spoken by the Chorus without any interpellation by Antigone. This, however, is improbable, and also injurious to the point of v. 1740. Further, with á¼€Ï€ÎµÏ†á½»Î³ÎµÏ„Î¿Î½, v. 1740 has a construction which makes the order of the words harsh, viz.: â€”"Ye escaped,"

Ï„á½¸ Î¼á½´ Ï„á½° ÏƒÏ†á¿·Î½ Ï€á½·Ï„Î½ÎµÎ¹Î½ ÎºÎ±Îºá¿¶Ï‚, "so that your affairs should not fall out ill" (Xen. Anab. 1.3.2 ÎšÎ»á½³Î±ÏÏ‡Î¿Ï‚ Î¼Î¹ÎºÏá½¸Î½ á¼€Ï€á½³Ï†Ï…Î³Îµ Î¼á½´ ÎºÎ±Ï„Î±Ï€ÎµÏ„ÏÏ‰Î¸á¿†Î½Î±Î¹). I therefore incline to Hermann's á¼€Ï€á½³Ï†Ï…Î³Îµ Î‘Î. Ï„á½·; "Long ago there was an escape"â€” Î‘Î. "For what?" [lit. "what escaped?"]â€” ÎÎ—. "For your fortunes, from falling out ill." The merits of this reading are:â€”(1) it leaves v. 1725, which seems quite sound, unaltered: (2) by making Ï„á½° ÏƒÏ†á¿·Î½ nom. to á¼€Ï€á½³Ï†Ï…Î³Îµ, it smooths v. 1740. It may be added that, with á¼€Ï€ÎµÏ†á½»Î³ÎµÏ„Î¿Î½, v. 1740 is somewhat pointless, since the mere allusion in Ï„á½° ÏƒÏ†á¿·Î½ to Creon's attempt is too vague to answer Antigone's Ï„á½·; ("what did we escape?"). Most "escapes" are escapes from "one's affairs falling out ill."

á¼ˆÎ½. Ï„á½·;
Î§Î¿. 1740 Ï„á½° ÏƒÏ†á¿·Î½ Ï„á½¸ Î¼á½´ Ï€á½·Ï„Î½ÎµÎ¹Î½ ÎºÎ±Îºá¿¶Ï‚.
á¼ˆÎ½. Ï†ÏÎ¿Î½á¿¶. ğŸ—©
Line 1741

Ï†ÏÎ¿Î½á¿¶, I am conscious of that, â€”"I know it well,"â€”in quick and grateful response to their allusion. Theseus and the men of Attica had indeed rescued her and her sister in their extremity. Not, "I am thinking...," for (a) the question Ï„á½· Î´á¿†Î¸â€™ refers back to her Ï€Î¿á¿– Ï†á½»Î³Ï‰; and (b) some acknowledgement was due to their reminder.â€”The MS. á½‘Ï€ÎµÏÎ½Î¿Îµá¿–Ï‚, as Hermann saw, is corrupt. The compound, which occurs only here, could not mean (1) "why art thou too anxious?" (Wunder): nor (2) "what further hast thou in thy thoughts?"â€”Hermann's á½‘Ï€ÎµÎ½Î½Î¿Îµá¿–Ï‚ is a compound used by Aelian Var. Hist. 4. 8 as="to have a secret thought or purpose." But the word seems scarcely appropriate in regard to thoughts which, far from hiding, she is in the act of uttering. Graser's á½…Ï€ÎµÏ Î½Î¿Îµá¿–Ï‚ is so far closer to the MSS. that Ï… for Î¿ would be an easier mistake than Ï for Î½.

Î§Î¿. Ï„á½· Î´á¿†Î¸â€™ á½…Ï€ÎµÏ Î½Î¿Îµá¿–Ï‚; ğŸ—©
Line 1742

á½…Ï€Ï‰Ï‚ Î¼Î¿Î»Î¿á½»Î¼ÎµÎ¸â€™: "how we are to return to Thebes, I know not":â€”for Oedipus had predicted that both her brothers would soon fall in the war (1373), and Creon, the next heir to the throne, was no friend. Î¼á½¹Î³Î¿Ï‚ á¼”Ï‡ÎµÎ¹, sc. á¼¡Î¼á¾¶Ï‚.

á¼Ï€Îµá¿–Ï‡Îµ, "bore hardly on you," sc. á½‘Î¼á¿–Î½ or á¼Ï†â€™ á½‘Î¼á¾¶Ï‚: for Î¼á½¹Î³Î¿Ï‚ á¼Ï€Îµá¿–Ï‡ÎµÎ½ á½‘Î¼á¾¶Ï‚ would mean, "restrained you." Line 1745

Ï„Î¿Ï„á½² Î¼á½²Î½ â€¦ á½•Ï€ÎµÏÎ¸ÎµÎ½. Whitelaw: "Oh then past cure, but worst is now grown worse." The neut. plur. is most simply taken as adverb (319), referring to Î¼á½¹Î³Î¿Ï‚ á¼Ï€Îµá¿–Ï‡Îµ: though we might also construe, á¼„Ï€Î¿ÏÎ± (á¼¦Î½ Ï„á½° á¼¡Î¼á½³Ï„ÎµÏÎ±).

Line 17511751-1779: Closing episode

Î¸Ïá¿†Î½Î¿Î½, not Î¸Ïá½µÎ½Ï‰Î½, is clearly right. The 2nd per. sing. imper., Ï€Î±á¿¦Îµ, is the only part of Ï€Î±á½»Ï‰ which is used intransitively by the classical Attic writers,â€”being, in fact, an exclamation (like our "stop!"), though sometimes joined with a gen. (Ï€Î±á¿¦Îµ Ï„Î¿á¿¦ Î»á½¹Î³Î¿Ï…, Aristoph. Ran. 580). No weight can be given to the fact that L has Î¸Ïá½µÎ½Ï‰Î½ here, since it has it also in 1778 (see cr. n.).

Î¾á½»Î½â€™ á¼€Ï€á½¹ÎºÎµÎ¹Ï„Î±Î¹ for the MS. Î¾Ï…^Î½Î±Ï€á½¹ÎºÎµÎ¹Ï„Î±Î¹ is (I think) right. The literal sense is:â€” á¼Î½ Î¿á¼·Ï‚ Î³á½°Ï "for in a case where" (neut. pl.), Ï‡á½±ÏÎ¹Ï‚ á¼¡ Ï‡Î¸Î¿Î½á½·Î± "the kindness shown by the Ï‡Î¸á½¹Î½Î¹Î¿Î¹," Î¾á½»Î½â€™ á¼€Ï€á½¹ÎºÎµÎ¹Ï„Î±Î¹ "is stored up as a common benefit" (Î¾Ï…Î½á½±, neut. pl. as adv.),â€”common, namely, to Oedipus and the Athenians. That is:â€”"By the death of Oedipus, the Powers below have given him the everlasting rest which he desired, and us the abiding safeguard which he promised" (i.e. his grave). To mourn here would be to provoke the deities who have ordered all things well for him and for us.â€”

á¼€Ï€á½¹ÎºÎµÎ¹Ï„Î±Î¹, is laid up in store: cp. Line 1758

The MS. words ÎºÎµá¿–ÏƒÎµ Î¼Î¿Î»Îµá¿–Î½, which I omit, were almost certainly a gloss upon á¼€Î»Î»â€™ Î¿á½ Î¸ÎµÎ¼Î¹Ï„á½¹Î½. Ï„Î±á¿¦Ï„â€™ Î¿á½–Î½: "These things, then, (Î¿á½–Î½, according to the injunctions of Oedipus,) I was heard to promise by the god," etc. Ï„Î±á¿¦Ï„) is short for "the promise to do these things," as if á½‘Ï€Î¹ÏƒÏ‡Î½Î¿Ï…Î¼á½³Î½Ï‰Î½ stood with á¼¡Î¼á¿¶Î½. Line 1767

Ï€á½±Î½Ï„â€™ á¼€á¿“Ï‰Î½: cp. 42. The Î± of á¼€á¿“Ï‰ short, as in 240 and Ph. 1410: whereas it is long in 181, 304, Ai. 1263.

Î”Î¹á½¸Ï‚ á½ÏÎºÎ¿Ï‚, as the servant of Zeus. Hes. Op. 803 á¼Î½ Ï€á½³Î¼Ï€Ï„á¿ƒ Î³á½±Ï Ï†Î±ÏƒÎ¹Î½ á¼˜ÏÎ¹Î½á½»Î±Ï‚ á¼€Î¼Ï†Î¹Ï€Î¿Î»Îµá½»ÎµÎ¹Î½ á½ÏÎºÎ¿Î½ Î³ÎµÎ¹Î½á½¹Î¼ÎµÎ½Î¿Î½, Ï„á½¸Î½ á¼œÏÎ¹Ï‚ Ï„á½³ÎºÎµ Ï€á¿†Î¼â€™ á¼Ï€Î¹á½¹ÏÎºÎ¿Î¹Ï‚. This personified Horkis is a deity who witnesses an oath, and punishes perjury (Hes. Theog. 231). He is the son of Eris, because strife gives birth to treaties; he is attended at his birth by the Erinyes, because they avenge broken faith. And he is the servant of Zeus, because Î–Îµá½ºÏ‚ á½ÏÎºÎ¹Î¿Ï‚ is the supreme guardian of good-faith â€” represented in the Î²Î¿Ï…Î»ÎµÏ…Ï„á½µÏÎ¹Î¿Î½ at Olympia by a Zeus with lightnings in both hands, â€”the most terrible, Pausanias says, that he knew: Ï€á½±Î½Ï„Ï‰Î½ á½Ï€á½¹ÏƒÎ± á¼€Î³á½±Î»Î¼Î±Ï„Î± Î”Î¹á½¸Ï‚ Î¼á½±Î»Î¹ÏƒÏ„Î± á¼Ï‚ á¼”ÎºÏ€Î»Î·Î¾Î¹Î½ á¼€Î´á½·ÎºÏ‰Î½ á¼€Î½Î´Ïá¿¶Î½ (5. 24. 9)

Î¸á½µÎºÎ·Î½ á¼±ÎµÏá½±Î½, á¼£Î½ ÎºÎµá¿–Î½Î¿Ï‚ á¼”Ï‡ÎµÎ¹. ğŸ—©
Line 1768

ÎºÎ±Ï„á½° Î½Î¿á¿¦Î½. Ar. Eq. 549 ÎºÎ±Ï„á½° Î½Î¿á¿¦Î½ Ï€Ïá½±Î¾Î±Ï‚: so oft. ÎºÎ±Ï„á½° Î³Î½á½½Î¼Î·Î½.

Ï„á½±Î´â€™ â€¦ Ï„Î±á¿¦Ï„â€™: cp. on 787.

ÎºÎ±á½¶ Ï„Î±á¿¦Ï„á½± Î¼â€™ á¼”Ï†Î· Ï€Ïá½±ÏƒÏƒÎ¿Î½Ï„Î± ÎºÎ±Î»á¿¶Ï‚
Ï‡á½½ÏÎ±Î½ á¼•Î¾ÎµÎ¹Î½ Î±á¼°á½²Î½ á¼„Î»Ï…Ï€Î¿Î½. ğŸ—©
Line 1770

Ï„á¾¶Ï‚ á½ Î³Ï…Î³á½·Î¿Ï…Ï‚: a specially fit epithet, since the mythical á½¨Î³á½»Î³Î·Ï‚ was represented (in one legend at least) as son of Boeotus, and first ruler of Thebes (Paus. 9.5.1). Another legend connected him with Attica (Paus. 1.38.7). The trait common to the two legends is a great inundation which happened in his reign. The adj. is applied by Aesch. to Thebes (Th. 321 Ï€á½¹Î»Î¹Î½ á½ Î³Ï…Î³á½·Î±Î½, Pers. 37 Ï„á½±Ï‚ Ï„â€™ á½ Î³Ï…Î³á½·Î¿Ï…Ï‚ Î˜á½µÎ²Î±Ï‚), and also to Athens (Pers. 974). The Attic poets used it in the general sense of "very ancient," as Phil. 142 ÎºÏá½±Ï„Î¿Ï‚ á½ Î³á½»Î³Î¹Î¿Î½, "royalty inherited from of old."

Ï„Î±á¿¦Ï„â€™ Î¿á½–Î½ á¼”ÎºÎ»Ï…ÎµÎ½ Î´Î±á½·Î¼Ï‰Î½ á¼¡Î¼á¿¶Î½ ğŸ—©
Line 1771

á¼°á½¹Î½Ï„Î±, a pres., not fut., partic. (O. T. 773 n.), "coming on them": El. 374 ÎºÎ±Îºá½¸Î½...Îµá¼°Ï‚ Î±á½Ï„á½´Î½ á¼°á½¹Î½: Plat. Legg. 873E Ï€Î±Ïá½° Î¸ÎµÎ¿á¿¦...Î²á½³Î»Î¿Ï‚ á¼°á½¹Î½. So Ant. 185 Ï„á½´Î½ á¼„Ï„Î·Î½ á½Ïá¿¶Î½ | ÏƒÏ„Îµá½·Ï‡Î¿Ï…ÏƒÎ±Î½ á¼€ÏƒÏ„Î¿á¿–Ï‚.

á½Î¼Î±á½·Î¼Î¿Î¹Ï‚: see on 330.

Antigone suggests that she and Ismene may yet be in time to plead with their two brothers, and so to avert the doom of mutual destruction pronounced on them by their father (1373). Thus the close of this drama is linked by the poet with the beginning of his earlier Antigone, which opens at a moment just after the deaths of the brothers. The sisters are then living at Thebes, where Creon has succeeded to the throne. An additional pathos is lent to Antigone's part there by the suggestion here of a previous intercession. In Aesch. Theb. it is the Chorus (of Theban maidens) that endeavours to dissuade Eteocles from going to meet his brother (677 ff.): in Eur. Phoen. it is their mother Iocasta who seeks to reconcile them (452 ff.).

Ï‡á½  Ï€á½±Î½Ï„â€™ á¼€á¿“Ï‰Î½ Î”Î¹á½¸Ï‚ á½ÏÎºÎ¿Ï‚.
á¼ˆÎ½. á¼€Î»Î»â€™ Îµá¼° Ï„á½±Î´â€™ á¼”Ï‡ÎµÎ¹ ÎºÎ±Ï„á½° Î½Î¿á¿¦Î½ ÎºÎµá½·Î½á¿³, ğŸ—©
Line 17731773-1776

After Î¿á½ in 1776 the MS. Î³á½±Ï must be struck out, as Hermann saw, so that the anapaests spoken by Theseus may end with a paroemiac. When anapaests spoken by the Chorus close a tragedy, these always form a system separate from the anapaests (if any) which precede them. This was plainly necessary, in order to avoid an unduly abrupt ending. But if we point thus:â€” Ï€Ïá½¸Ï‚ Ï‡á½±ÏÎ¹Î½Â· Î¿á½ Î´Îµá¿– Î¼â€™ á¼€Ï€Î¿Îºá½±Î¼Î½ÎµÎ¹Î½, the asyndeton has a crude effect. Hence, placing only a comma after Ï€Ïá½¸Ï‚ Ï‡á½±ÏÎ¹Î½, we should render:â€” "Not only will I do these things, but in all things which I am likely to do for your advantage (etc.) I must not wax weary." The sentence begins as if the constr. was to be Î´Ïá½±ÏƒÏ‰ ÎºÎ±á½¶ Ï„á½±Î´Îµ ÎºÎ±á½¶ Ï€á½±Î½Ï„Î±. But the new verb added at the end requires Ï€á½±Î½Ï„Î± to be acc. with á¼€Ï€Î¿Îºá½±Î¼Î½ÎµÎ¹Î½. (Cp. on 351.)

á½Ï€á½¹Ïƒâ€™ á¼‚Î½ seems slightly preferable to á½…ÏƒÎ± Î³â€™ á¼‚Î½ as a correction of the MS. á½…Ïƒâ€™ á¼‚Î½ (or á½…ÏƒÎ± á¼‚Î½), because the qualification which Î³) would imply is sufficiently provided for by Ï€Ïá½¹ÏƒÏ†Î¿ÏÎ± etc.: cp. 1634 Ï„ÎµÎ»Îµá¿–Î½ Î´â€™ á½…Ïƒâ€™ á¼‚Î½ Î¼á½³Î»Î»á¿ƒÏ‚ Ï†ÏÎ¿Î½á¿¶Î½ Îµá½– Î¾Ï…Î¼Ï†á½³ÏÎ¿Î½Ï„â€™ Î±á½Ï„Î±á¿–Ï‚ á¼€Îµá½·.

1770 Ï„á½°Ï‚ á½ Î³Ï…Î³á½·Î¿Ï…Ï‚ Ï€á½³Î¼ÏˆÎ¿Î½, á¼á½±Î½ Ï€Ï‰Ï‚ ğŸ—©
Line 1770Line 1770

Ï„á¾¶Ï‚ á½ Î³Ï…Î³á½·Î¿Ï…Ï‚: a specially fit epithet, since the mythical á½¨Î³á½»Î³Î·Ï‚ was represented (in one legend at least) as son of Boeotus, and first ruler of Thebes (Paus. 9.5.1). Another legend connected him with Attica (Paus. 1.38.7). The trait common to the two legends is a great inundation which happened in his reign. The adj. is applied by Aesch. to Thebes (Th. 321 Ï€á½¹Î»Î¹Î½ á½ Î³Ï…Î³á½·Î±Î½, Pers. 37 Ï„á½±Ï‚ Ï„â€™ á½ Î³Ï…Î³á½·Î¿Ï…Ï‚ Î˜á½µÎ²Î±Ï‚), and also to Athens (Pers. 974). The Attic poets used it in the general sense of "very ancient," as Phil. 142 ÎºÏá½±Ï„Î¿Ï‚ á½ Î³á½»Î³Î¹Î¿Î½, "royalty inherited from of old."

Î´Î¹Î±ÎºÏ‰Î»á½»ÏƒÏ‰Î¼ÎµÎ½ á¼°á½¹Î½Ï„Î± Ï†á½¹Î½Î¿Î½ ğŸ—©
Line 1771Line 1771

á¼°á½¹Î½Ï„Î±, a pres., not fut., partic. (O. T. 773 n.), "coming on them": El. 374 ÎºÎ±Îºá½¸Î½...Îµá¼°Ï‚ Î±á½Ï„á½´Î½ á¼°á½¹Î½: Plat. Legg. 873E Ï€Î±Ïá½° Î¸ÎµÎ¿á¿¦...Î²á½³Î»Î¿Ï‚ á¼°á½¹Î½. So Ant. 185 Ï„á½´Î½ á¼„Ï„Î·Î½ á½Ïá¿¶Î½ | ÏƒÏ„Îµá½·Ï‡Î¿Ï…ÏƒÎ±Î½ á¼€ÏƒÏ„Î¿á¿–Ï‚.

á½Î¼Î±á½·Î¼Î¿Î¹Ï‚: see on 330.

Antigone suggests that she and Ismene may yet be in time to plead with their two brothers, and so to avert the doom of mutual destruction pronounced on them by their father (1373). Thus the close of this drama is linked by the poet with the beginning of his earlier Antigone, which opens at a moment just after the deaths of the brothers. The sisters are then living at Thebes, where Creon has succeeded to the throne. An additional pathos is lent to Antigone's part there by the suggestion here of a previous intercession. In Aesch. Theb. it is the Chorus (of Theban maidens) that endeavours to dissuade Eteocles from going to meet his brother (677 ff.): in Eur. Phoen. it is their mother Iocasta who seeks to reconcile them (452 ff.).

Ï„Î¿á¿–ÏƒÎ¹Î½ á½Î¼Î±á½·Î¼Î¿Î¹Ï‚.
Î˜Î·. Î´Ïá½±ÏƒÏ‰ ÎºÎ±á½¶ Ï„á½±Î´Îµ ÎºÎ±á½¶ Ï€á½±Î½Î¸â€™ á½Ï€á½¹Ïƒâ€™ á¼‚Î½ ğŸ—©
Line 1773Line 17731773-1776

After Î¿á½ in 1776 the MS. Î³á½±Ï must be struck out, as Hermann saw, so that the anapaests spoken by Theseus may end with a paroemiac. When anapaests spoken by the Chorus close a tragedy, these always form a system separate from the anapaests (if any) which precede them. This was plainly necessary, in order to avoid an unduly abrupt ending. But if we point thus:â€” Ï€Ïá½¸Ï‚ Ï‡á½±ÏÎ¹Î½Â· Î¿á½ Î´Îµá¿– Î¼â€™ á¼€Ï€Î¿Îºá½±Î¼Î½ÎµÎ¹Î½, the asyndeton has a crude effect. Line 1776

á¼€Ï€Î¿Îºá½±Î¼Î½ÎµÎ¹Î½, "to cease from labouring," can take an acc. of the labour avoided: hence Ï€á½±Î½Î¸â€™ in 1773 need not be merely acc. of respect. Xen. Hellen. 7.5.19 Ï€á½¹Î½Î¿Î½...Î¼Î·Î´á½³Î½Î± á¼€Ï€Î¿Îºá½±Î¼Î½ÎµÎ¹Î½, "to flinch from no toil." Also with inf., Plat. Crito 45B Î¼á½´ á¼€Ï€Î¿Îºá½±Î¼á¿ƒÏ‚ ÏƒÎ±Ï…Ï„á½¸Î½ Ïƒá¿¶ÏƒÎ±Î¹, "do not abandon the effort to save yourself." So á¼ÎºÎºá½±Î¼Î½Ï‰, Thuc. 2.51 Ï„á½°Ï‚ á½€Î»Î¿Ï†á½»ÏÏƒÎµÎ¹Ï‚ Ï„á¿¶Î½ á¼€Ï€Î¿Î³Î¹Î³Î½Î¿Î¼á½³Î½Ï‰Î½...á¼Î¾á½³ÎºÎ±Î¼Î¿Î½, "were worn out by the lamentations of the dying." Rep. 445B á¼Ï€ÎµÎ¹Î´á½´ á¼Î½Ï„Î±á¿¦Î¸Î± á¼Î»Î·Î»á½»Î¸Î±Î¼ÎµÎ½, á½…ÏƒÎ¿Î½ Î¿á¼·á½¹Î½ Ï„Îµ ÏƒÎ±Ï†á½³ÏƒÏ„Î±Ï„Î± ÎºÎ±Ï„Î¹Î´Îµá¿–Î½ á½…Ï„Î¹ Ï„Î±á¿¦Ï„Î± Î¿á½•Ï„Ï‰Ï‚ á¼”Ï‡ÎµÎ¹, Î¿á½ Ï‡Ïá½´ á¼€Ï€Î¿Îºá½±Î¼Î½ÎµÎ¹Î½. Î§Î¿. á¼€Î»Î»â€™ á¼€Ï€Î¿Ï€Î±á½»ÎµÏ„Îµ Î¼Î·Î´â€™ á¼Ï€á½¶ Ï€Î»Îµá½·Ï‰ ğŸ—©
Line 1777

á¼€Î»Î») introduces the final words of comfort which the elders of Colonus address to the Theban maidens; cp. 101.

á¼€Ï€Î¿Ï€Î±á½»ÎµÏ„Îµ, no less than the following verb, governs Î¸Ïá¿†Î½Î¿Î½: cp. on 1751.

Though the neut. pl. Ï€Î»Îµá½·Ï‰ alone is sometimes adverbial, there seems to be no instance of á¼Ï€á½¶ Ï€Î»Îµá½·Ï‰ as=á¼Ï€á½¶ Ï€Î»á½³Î¿Î½: indeed, such a phrase is hardly conceivable. á¼Ï€á½¶ must therefore belong to á¼Î³Îµá½·ÏÎµÏ„Îµ: for the tmesis cp. on 1689.

Î¸Ïá¿†Î½Î¿Î½ á¼Î³Îµá½·ÏÎµÏ„ÎµÂ·
Ï€á½±Î½Ï„Ï‰Ï‚ Î³á½°Ï á¼”Ï‡ÎµÎ¹ Ï„á½±Î´Îµ Îºá¿¦ÏÎ¿Ï‚. ğŸ—©
Line 1779

á¼”Ï‡ÎµÎ¹ â€¦ Îºá¿¦ÏÎ¿Ï‚, lit., "have validity," = ÎºÎµÎºá½»ÏÏ‰Ï„Î±Î¹, sancta sunt. Cp. El. 919 Ï€Î¿Î»Î»á¿¶Î½...Îºá¿¦ÏÎ¿Ï‚...ÎºÎ±Î»á¿¶Î½ ("sanction of"), Aesch. Suppl. 391 Î¿á½Îº á¼”Ï‡Î¿Ï…ÏƒÎ¹ Îºá¿¦ÏÎ¿Ï‚...á¼€Î¼Ï†á½¶ ÏƒÎ¿á¿¦, "authority over thee." â€” Two meanings are possible: (1) "These promises of Theseus are certain to hold good": or, more generally, (2) "These events have assuredly been ordained past recall" (by the gods). Most commentators prefer (1). But (2) seems more fitting at the conclusion. The last soothing words of the Chorus convey a precept of resignation to the divine will.

Fr. Ritter rejects the last three verses, as he rejects the choral clausulae of all the other six plays (Philol. XVII. 422-436): cp. O. T. 1524 cr. n. Here, at least, there is not a shadow of ground for the suspicion. It did not require a Sophocles to write vv. 1777-1779, but the burden of proof rests with those who deny that he wrote them.
